column1: 1~1~Bassline~4313~4321~"A bassline (also known as a bass line or bass part) is the term used in many styles of music
column2: such as jazz
column3: blues
column4: funk
column5: dub and electronic
column6: traditional music
column7: or classical music for the low-pitched instrumental part or line played (in jazz and some forms of popular music) by a rhythm section instrument such as the electric bass
column8: double bass
column9: cello
column10: tuba or keyboard (piano
column11: Hammond organ
column12: electric organ
column13: or synthesizer). In unaccompanied solo performance
column14: basslines may simply be played in the lower register of any instrument such as guitar or piano while melody and/or further accompaniment is provided in the middle or upper register. In solo music for piano and pipe organ
column15: these instruments have an excellent lower register that can be used to play a deep bassline. On organs
column16: the bass line is typically played using the pedal keyboard and massive 16' and 32' bass pipes.

column1: Basslines in popular music often use ""riffs"" or ""grooves""
column2: which are usually simple
column3: appealing musical motifs or phrases that are repeated
column4: with variation
column5: throughout the song. ""The bass differs from other voices because of the particular role it plays in supporting and defining harmonic motion. It does so at levels ranging from immediate
column6: chord-by-chord events to the larger harmonic organization of a [sic] entire work."" Bassline riffs usually emphasize the chord tones of each chord (usually the root note
column7: the third note
column8: or the fifth note)
column9: which helps to define a song's key. At the same time
column10: basslines work along with the drum part and the other rhythm instruments to create a clear rhythmic pulse.

column1: The type of rhythmic pulse used in basslines varies widely in different types of music. In swing jazz and jump blues
column2: basslines are often created from a continuous sequence of quarter notes in a mostly scalar
column3: stepwise or arpeggio-based part called a ""walking bass line"". In Latin
column4: salsa music
column5: jazz fusion
column6: reggae
column7: electronica
column8: and some types of rock and metal
column9: basslines may be very rhythmically complex and syncopated. In bluegrass and traditional country music
column10: basslines often emphasize the root and fifth of each chord.

column1: Though basslines may be played by many different types of instruments and in a broad musical range
column2: they are generally played on bass instruments and in the range roughly at least an octave and a half below middle C (roughly the range of the bass clef). In classical music such as string quartets and symphonies
column3: basslines play the same harmonic and rhythmic role; however
column4: they are usually referred to as the ""bass voice"" or the ""bass part""."~0.41530200802142736

column1: 2~1~Bizet~6047~6052~"Georges Bizet (French: [ʒɔʁʒ bizɛ]; 25 October 1838 – 3 June 1875)
column2: registered at birth as Alexandre César Léopold Bizet
column3: was a French composer of the romantic era. Best known for his operas in a career cut short by his early death
column4: Bizet achieved few successes before his final work
column5: Carmen
column6: which has become one of the most popular and frequently performed works in the entire opera repertoire.

column1: During a brilliant student career at the Conservatoire de Paris
column2: Bizet won many prizes
column3: including the prestigious Prix de Rome in 1857. He was recognised as an outstanding pianist
column4: though he chose not to capitalise on this skill and rarely performed in public. Returning to Paris after almost three years in Italy
column5: he found that the main Parisian opera theatres preferred the established classical repertoire to the works of newcomers. His keyboard and orchestral compositions were likewise largely ignored; as a result
column6: his career stalled
column7: and he earned his living mainly by arranging and transcribing the music of others. Restless for success
column8: he began many theatrical projects during the 1860s
column9: most of which were abandoned. Neither of his two operas that reached the stage in this time—Les pêcheurs de perles and La jolie fille de Perth—were immediately successful.

column1: After the Franco-Prussian War of 1870–1871
column2: during which Bizet served in the National Guard
column3: he had little success with his one-act opera Djamileh
column4: though an orchestral suite derived from his incidental music to Alphonse Daudet's play L'Arlésienne was instantly popular. The production of Bizet's final opera
column5: Carmen
column6: was delayed because of fears that its themes of betrayal and murder would offend audiences. After its premiere on 3 March 1875
column7: Bizet was convinced that the work was a failure; he died of a heart attack three months later
column8: unaware that it would prove a spectacular and enduring success.

column1: Bizet's marriage to Geneviève Halévy was intermittently happy and produced one son. After his death
column2: his work
column3: apart from Carmen
column4: was generally neglected. Manuscripts were given away or lost
column5: and published versions of his works were frequently revised and adapted by other hands. He founded no school and had no obvious disciples or successors. After years of neglect
column6: his works began to be performed more frequently in the 20th century. Later commentators have acclaimed him as a composer of brilliance and originality whose premature death was a significant loss to French musical theatre."~0.36996728920737026

column1: 3~1~Boulez~4472~4478~"A boiler is a closed vessel in which water or other fluid is heated. The fluid does not necessarily boil. (In North America
column2: the term ""furnace"" is normally used if the purpose is not to boil the fluid.) The heated or vaporized fluid exits the boiler for use in various processes or heating applications
column3: including water heating
column4: central heating
column5: boiler-based power generation
column6: cooking

column1: 4~1~Carlo Gesualdo~5845~5859~Carlo Gesualdo da Venosa (8 March 1566 – 8 September 1613) was Prince of Venosa and Count of Conza. As a composer he is best known for writing intensely expressive madrigals and pieces of sacred music that use a chromatic language not heard again until the late 19th century. The best known fact of his life is his brutal and violent killing of his first wife and her aristocratic lover upon finding them in flagrante delicto. The fascination for his extraordinary music and for his shocking acts have gone hand in hand.~0.3617482346512343
5~1~Chromatic~0~9~"Diatonic (Greek: διατονική) and chromatic (Greek: χρωματική) are terms in music theory that are most often used to characterize scales
column2: and are also applied to musical instruments
column3: intervals
column4: chords
column5: notes
column6: musical styles
column7: and kinds of harmony. They are very often used as a pair
column8: especially when applied to contrasting features of the common practice music of the period 1600–1900.

column1: These terms may mean different things in different contexts. Very often
column2: diatonic refers to musical elements derived from the modes and transpositions of the ""white note scale"" C–D–E–F–G–A–B. In some usages it includes all forms of heptatonic scale that are in common use in Western music (the major
column3: and all forms of the minor). Chromatic most often refers to structures derived from the twelve-note chromatic scale
column4: which consists of all semitones. Historically
column5: however
column6: it had other senses
column7: referring in Ancient Greek music theory to a particular tuning of the tetrachord
column8: and to a rhythmic notational convention in mensural music of the 14th through 16th centuries."~0.2677492619838683

column1: 6~1~Cliché~7269~7275~"A cliché or cliche ( or ) is an expression
column2: idea
column3: or element of an artistic work which has become overused to the point of losing its original meaning or effect
column4: even to the point of being trite or irritating
column5: especially when at some earlier time it was considered meaningful or novel.

column1: In phraseology
column2: the term has taken on a more technical meaning
column3: referring to an expression imposed by conventionalized linguistic usage. The term is frequently used in modern culture for an action or idea that is expected or predictable
column4: based on a prior event. Typically pejorative
column5: ""clichés"" may or may not be true. Some are stereotypes
column6: but some are simply truisms and facts. Clichés often are employed for comic effect
column7: typically in fiction.

column1: Most phrases now considered clichéd originally were regarded as striking
column2: but have lost their force through overuse. The French poet Gérard de Nerval once said
column3: ""The first man who compared woman to a rose was a poet
column4: the second
column5: an imbecile.""

column1: A cliché is often a vivid depiction of an abstraction that relies upon analogy or exaggeration for effect
column2: often drawn from everyday experience. Used sparingly
column3: it may succeed
column4: but the use of a cliché in writing
column5: speech
column6: or argument is generally considered a mark of inexperience or a lack of originality."~0.2689703187829327

column1: 7~1~Igor Stravinsky~4929~4944~"Igor Fyodorovich Stravinsky (Russian: И́горь Фёдорович Страви́нский
column2: IPA: [ˈiɡərʲ ˈfʲɵdərəvʲɪtɕ strɐˈvʲinskʲɪj]; 17 June [O.S. 5 June] 1882 – 6 April 1971) was a Russian-born composer
column3: pianist
column4: and conductor. He is widely considered one of the most important and influential composers of the 20th century.

column1: Stravinsky's compositional career was notable for its stylistic diversity. He first achieved international fame with three ballets commissioned by the impresario Serge Diaghilev and first performed in Paris by Diaghilev's Ballets Russes: The Firebird (1910)
column2: Petrushka (1911)
column3: and The Rite of Spring (1913). The last of these transformed the way in which subsequent composers thought about rhythmic structure and was largely responsible for Stravinsky's enduring reputation as a musical revolutionary who pushed the boundaries of musical design. His ""Russian phase"" which continued with works such as Renard
column4: the Soldier's Tale and Les Noces
column5: was followed in the 1920s by a period in which he turned to neoclassical music. The works from this period tended to make use of traditional musical forms (concerto grosso
column6: fugue and symphony)
column7: drawing on earlier styles
column8: especially from the 18th century. In the 1950s
column9: Stravinsky adopted serial procedures. His compositions of this period shared traits with examples of his earlier output: rhythmic energy
column10: the construction of extended melodic ideas out of a few two- or three-note cells and clarity of form
column11: and of instrumentation."~0.31802870535969807

column1: 8~1~Isolde~775~781~"Iseult ()
column2: alternatively Isolde ()
column3: Iseo
column4: Yseult
column5: Isode
column6: Isoude

column15: sister of Sir Kahedin

9~1~Jazz~2731~2735~Jazz is a music genre that originated in the African-American communities of New Orleans
column2: United States
column3: in the late 19th and early 20th centuries
column4: and developed from roots in blues and ragtime. Jazz is seen by many as 'America's classical music'. Since the 1920s Jazz Age
column5: jazz has become recognized as a major form of musical expression. It then emerged in the form of independent traditional and popular musical styles
column6: all linked by the common bonds of African-American and European-American musical parentage with a performance orientation. Jazz is characterized by swing and blue notes
column7: call and response vocals
column8: polyrhythms and improvisation. Jazz has roots in West African cultural and musical expression
column9: and in African-American music traditions including blues and ragtime
column10: as well as European military band music. Although the foundation of jazz is deeply rooted within the black experience of the United States
column11: different cultures have contributed their own experience and styles to the art form as well. Intellectuals around the world have hailed jazz as ""one of America's original art forms"".

column1: As jazz spread around the world
column2: it drew on different national
column3: regional
column4: and local musical cultures
column5: which gave rise to many distinctive styles. New Orleans jazz began in the early 1910s
column6: combining earlier brass-band marches
column7: French quadrilles
column8: biguine
column9: ragtime and blues with collective polyphonic improvisation. In the 1930s
column10: heavily arranged dance-oriented swing big bands
column11: Kansas City jazz
column12: a hard-swinging
column13: bluesy
column14: improvisational style and Gypsy jazz (a style that emphasized musette waltzes) were the prominent styles. Bebop emerged in the 1940s
column15: shifting jazz from danceable popular music toward a more challenging ""musician's music"" which was played at faster tempos and used more chord-based improvisation. Cool jazz developed near the end of the 1940s
column17: smoother sounds and long

column1: The 1950s saw the emergence of free jazz
column2: which explored playing without regular meter
column3: beat and formal structures
column4: and in the mid-1950s
column5: hard bop emerged
column6: which introduced influences from rhythm and blues
column7: gospel
column8: and blues
column9: especially in the saxophone and piano playing. Modal jazz developed in the late 1950s
column10: using the mode
column11: or musical scale
column12: as the basis of musical structure and improvisation. Jazz-rock fusion appeared in the late 1960s and early 1970s
column13: combining jazz improvisation with rock music's rhythms
column14: electric instruments
column15: and highly amplified stage sound. In the early 1980s
column16: a commercial form of jazz fusion called smooth jazz became successful
column17: garnering significant radio airplay. Other styles and genres abound in the 2000s
column18: such as Latin and Afro-Cuban jazz."~0.3914129811643778

column1: 10~1~Monteverdi~4651~4661~"Claudio Giovanni Antonio Monteverdi (Italian: [ˈklaudjo monteˈverdi] ( listen); 15 May 1567 (baptized) – 29 November 1643) was an Italian composer
column2: string player and choirmaster. A composer of both secular and sacred music
column3: and a pioneer in the development of opera
column4: he is considered a crucial transitional figure between the Renaissance and the Baroque periods of music history.

column1: Born in Cremona
column2: where he undertook his first musical studies and compositions
column3: Monteverdi developed his career first at the court of Mantua (c. 1590–1613) and then until his death in the Republic of Venice where he was maestro di capella at the basilica of San Marco. His surviving letters give insight into the life of a professional musician in Italy of the period
column4: including problems of income
column5: patronage and politics.

column1: Much of Monteverdi's output
column2: including many stage works
column3: has been lost. His surviving music includes nine books of madrigals
column4: large-scale sacred works such as his Vespro della Beata Vergine (Vespers) of 1610
column5: and three complete operas. His opera L'Orfeo (1607) is the earliest of the genre still widely performed; towards the end of his life he wrote works for the commercial theatre in Venice
column6: including Il ritorno d'Ulisse in patria and L'incoronazione di Poppea.

column1: While he worked extensively in the tradition of earlier Renaissance polyphony
column2: such as in his madrigals
column3: he undertook great developments in form and melody
column4: and began to employ the basso continuo technique
column5: distinctive of the Baroque. No stranger to controversy
column6: he defended his sometimes novel techniques as elements of a seconda pratica
column7: contrasting with the more orthodox earlier style which he termed the prima pratica. Largely forgotten during the eighteenth and much of the nineteenth centuries
column8: his works enjoyed a rediscovery around the beginning of the twentieth century. He is now established both as a significant influence in European musical history and as a composer whose works are regularly performed and recorded."~0.2935477720429812

column1: 11~1~Octave~2646~2652~"In music
column2: an octave (Latin: octavus: eighth) or perfect octave is the interval between one musical pitch and another with half or double its frequency. It is defined by ANSI as the unit of frequency level when the base of the logarithm is two. The octave relationship is a natural phenomenon that has been referred to as the ""basic miracle of music""
column3: the use of which is ""common in most musical systems"".

column1: The most important musical scales are typically written using eight notes
column2: and the interval between the first and last notes is an octave. For example
column3: the C major scale is typically written C D E F G A B C
column4: the initial and final Cs being an octave apart. Two notes separated by an octave have the same letter name and are of the same pitch class.

column1: The interval between the first and second harmonics of the harmonic series is an octave.
The octave has occasionally been referred to as a diapason.
To emphasize that it is one of the perfect intervals (including unison
column2: perfect fourth
column3: and perfect fifth)
column4: the octave is designated P8. The octave above or below an indicated note is sometimes abbreviated 8a or 8va (Italian: all'ottava)
column5: 8va bassa (Italian: all'ottava bassa
column6: sometimes also 8vb)
column7: or simply 8 for the octave in the direction indicated by placing this mark above or below the staff."~0.2223078374081138

column1: 12~1~Opera~6655~6663~"Opera (Italian: [ˈɔːpera]; English plural: operas; Italian plural: opere [ˈɔːpere]) is an art form in which singers and musicians perform a dramatic work combining text (libretto) and musical score
column2: usually in a theatrical setting. In traditional opera
column3: singers do two types of singing: recitative
column4: a speech-inflected style and arias
column5: a more melodic style
column6: in which notes are sung in a sustained fashion. Opera incorporates many of the elements of spoken theatre
column7: such as acting
column8: scenery
column9: and costumes and sometimes includes dance. The performance is typically given in an opera house
column10: accompanied by an orchestra or smaller musical ensemble
column11: which since the early 19th century has been led by a conductor.

column1: Opera is a key part of the Western classical music tradition. It started in Italy at the end of the 16th century (with Jacopo Peri's mostly lost Dafne
column2: produced in Florence in 1598) and soon spread through the rest of Europe: Heinrich Schütz in Germany
column3: Jean-Baptiste Lully in France
column4: and Henry Purcell in England all helped to establish their national traditions in the 17th century. In the 18th century
column5: Italian opera continued to dominate most of Europe (except France)
column6: attracting foreign composers such as George Frideric Handel. Opera seria was the most prestigious form of Italian opera
column7: until Christoph Willibald Gluck reacted against its artificiality with his ""reform"" operas in the 1760s. The most renowned figure of late 18th-century opera is Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
column8: who began with opera seria but is most famous for his Italian comic operas
column9: especially The Marriage of Figaro (Le nozze di Figaro)
column10: Don Giovanni
column11: and Così fan tutte
column12: as well as Die Entführung aus dem Serail (The Abduction from the Seraglio)
column13: and The Magic Flute (Die Zauberflöte)
column14: landmarks in the German tradition.

column1: The first third of the 19th century saw the high point of the bel canto style
column2: with Gioachino Rossini
column3: Gaetano Donizetti and Vincenzo Bellini all creating works that are still performed. It also saw the advent of Grand Opera typified by the works of Auber and Meyerbeer. The mid-to-late 19th century was a ""golden age"" of opera
column4: led and dominated by Giuseppe Verdi in Italy and Richard Wagner in Germany. The popularity of opera continued through the verismo era in Italy and contemporary French opera through to Giacomo Puccini and Richard Strauss in the early 20th century. During the 19th century
column5: parallel operatic traditions emerged in central and eastern Europe
column6: particularly in Russia and Bohemia. The 20th century saw many experiments with modern styles
column7: such as atonality and serialism (Arnold Schoenberg and Alban Berg)
column8: Neoclassicism (Igor Stravinsky)
column9: and Minimalism (Philip Glass and John Adams). With the rise of recording technology
column10: singers such as Enrico Caruso and Maria Callas became known to much wider audiences that went beyond the circle of opera fans. Since the invention of radio and television
column11: operas were also performed on (and written for) these mediums. Beginning in 2006
column12: a number of major opera houses began to present live high-definition video transmissions of their performances in cinemas all over the world. Since 2009
column13: complete performances can be downloaded and are live streamed."~0.2891870280518801

column1: 13~1~Pianto~6598~6604~"In music
column2: the pianto (en:crying) is the motif of a descending minor second
column3: has represented laments and been associated textually with weeping

column5: grief

column1: 14~1~Purcell~5936~5943~Henry Purcell ( or ; c. 10 September 1659 – 21 November 1695) was an English composer. Although incorporating Italian and French stylistic elements into his compositions
column2: Purcell's legacy was a uniquely English form of Baroque music. He is generally considered to be one of the greatest English composers; no later native-born English composer approached his fame until Edward Elgar
column3: Ralph Vaughan Williams
column4: William Walton and Benjamin Britten in the 20th century.~0.14864925161279635

column1: 15~1~Tristan und Isolde~763~781~"Tristan und Isolde (Tristan and Isolde
column2: or Tristan and Isolda
column3: or Tristran and Ysolt) is an opera
column4: or music drama
column5: in three acts by Richard Wagner to a German libretto by the composer
column6: based largely on the 12th-century romance Tristan by Gottfried von Strassburg. It was composed between 1857 and 1859 and premiered at the Königliches Hof- und Nationaltheater in Munich on 10 June 1865 with Hans von Bülow conducting. Wagner referred to the work not as an opera
column7: but called it ""eine Handlung"" (literally a drama
column8: a plot or an action)
column9: which was the equivalent of the term used by the Spanish playwright Calderón for his dramas.

column1: Wagner's composition of Tristan und Isolde was inspired by the philosophy of Arthur Schopenhauer (particularly The World as Will and Representation)
column2: as well as by Wagner's affair with Mathilde Wesendonck. Widely acknowledged as one of the peaks of the operatic repertoire
column3: Tristan was notable for Wagner's unprecedented use of chromaticism
column4: tonal ambiguity
column5: orchestral colour and harmonic suspension.

column1: The opera was enormously influential among Western classical composers and provided direct inspiration to composers such as Gustav Mahler
column2: Richard Strauss
column3: Karol Szymanowski
column4: Alban Berg
column5: Arnold Schoenberg and Benjamin Britten. Other composers like Claude Debussy
column6: Maurice Ravel and Igor Stravinsky formulated their styles in contrast to Wagner's musical legacy. Many see Tristan as the beginning of the move away from common practice harmony and tonality and consider that it lays the groundwork for the direction of classical music in the 20th century. Both Wagner's libretto style and music were also profoundly influential on the Symbolist poets of the late 19th century and early 20th century."~0.33386567414451296

column1: 16~1~Wagner~736~742~"Wilhelm Richard Wagner (; German: [ˈʁiçaʁt ˈvaːɡnɐ] ( listen); 22 May 1813 – 13 February 1883) was a German composer
column2: theatre director
column3: polemicist
column4: and conductor who is chiefly known for his operas (or
column5: as some of his later works were later known
column6: ""music dramas""). Unlike most opera composers
column7: Wagner wrote both the libretto and the music for each of his stage works. Initially establishing his reputation as a composer of works in the romantic vein of Carl Maria von Weber and Giacomo Meyerbeer
column8: Wagner revolutionised opera through his concept of the Gesamtkunstwerk (""total work of art"")
column9: by which he sought to synthesise the poetic
column10: visual
column11: musical and dramatic arts
column12: with music subsidiary to drama. He described this vision in a series of essays published between 1849 and 1852. Wagner realised these ideas most fully in the first half of the four-opera cycle Der Ring des Nibelungen (The Ring of the Nibelung).

column1: His compositions
column2: particularly those of his later period
column3: are notable for their complex textures
column4: rich harmonies and orchestration
column5: and the elaborate use of leitmotifs—musical phrases associated with individual characters
column6: places
column7: ideas
column8: or plot elements. His advances in musical language
column9: such as extreme chromaticism and quickly shifting tonal centres
column10: greatly influenced the development of classical music. His Tristan und Isolde is sometimes described as marking the start of modern music.

column1: Wagner had his own opera house built
column2: the Bayreuth Festspielhaus
column3: which embodied many novel design features. The Ring and Parsifal were premiered here and his most important stage works continue to be performed at the annual Bayreuth Festival
column4: run by his descendants. His thoughts on the relative contributions of music and drama in opera were to change again
column5: and he reintroduced some traditional forms into his last few stage works
column6: including Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg (The Mastersingers of Nuremberg).

column1: Until his final years
column2: Wagner's life was characterised by political exile
column3: turbulent love affairs
column4: poverty and repeated flight from his creditors. His controversial writings on music
column5: drama and politics have attracted extensive comment
column6: notably
column7: since the late 20th century
column8: where they express antisemitic sentiments. The effect of his ideas can be traced in many of the arts throughout the 20th century; his influence spread beyond composition into conducting
column9: philosophy
column10: literature
column11: the visual arts and theatre."~0.1469238929808546

column1: 17~2~Alban Berg~9951~9961~Alban Maria Johannes Berg (; German: [ˈbɛɐ̯k]; 9 February 1885 – 24 December 1935) was an Austrian composer of the Second Viennese School. His compositional style combined Romantic lyricism with twelve-tone technique.~0.33658839365258064

18~2~Ancient Greek~1448~1453~"The Ancient Greek language includes the forms of Greek used in ancient Greece and the ancient world from around the 9th century BC to the 6th century AD. It is often roughly divided into the Archaic period (9th to 6th centuries BC)
column2: Classical period (5th and 4th centuries BC)
column3: and Hellenistic period (Koine Greek
column4: 3rd century BC to the 4th century AD). It is antedated in the second millennium BC by Mycenaean Greek and succeeded by medieval Greek.

column1: The language of the Hellenistic phase is known as Koine (common). Koine is regarded as a separate historical stage of its own
column2: although in its earliest form it closely resembled Attic Greek and in its latest form it approaches Medieval Greek. Prior to the Koine period
column3: Greek of the classic and earlier periods included several regional dialects.

column1: Ancient Greek was the language of Homer and of fifth-century Athenian historians
column2: playwrights
column3: and philosophers. It has contributed many words to English vocabulary and has been a standard subject of study in educational institutions of the Western world since the Renaissance. This article primarily contains information about the Epic and Classical phases of the language."~0.1458178920622928

column1: 19~2~Arnold Schoenberg~9977~9994~"Arnold Franz Walter Schoenberg or Schönberg (; German: [ˈaːʁnɔlt ˈʃøːnbɛʁk] ( listen); 13 September 1874 – 13 July 1951) was an Austrian composer
column2: music theorist
column3: and painter. He was associated with the expressionist movement in German poetry and art
column4: and leader of the Second Viennese School. With the rise of the Nazi Party
column5: Schoenberg's works were labelled degenerate music
column6: because they were modernist
column7: atonal and what even Paul Hindemith called ""sonic orgies"" and ""decadent intellectual efforts"" (Petropoulos 2014
column8: 94–95). He emigrated to the United States of America in 1934.

column1: Schoenberg's approach
column2: both in terms of harmony and development
column3: has been one of the most influential of 20th-century musical thought. Many European and American composers from at least three generations have consciously extended his thinking
column4: whereas others have passionately reacted against it.

column1: Schoenberg was known early in his career for simultaneously extending the traditionally opposed German Romantic styles of Brahms and Wagner. Later
column2: his name would come to personify innovations in atonality (although Schoenberg himself detested that term) that would become the most polemical feature of 20th-century art music. In the 1920s
column3: Schoenberg developed the twelve-tone technique
column4: an influential compositional method of manipulating an ordered series of all twelve notes in the chromatic scale. He also coined the term developing variation and was the first modern composer to embrace ways of developing motifs without resorting to the dominance of a centralized melodic idea.

column1: Schoenberg was also an influential teacher of composition; his students included Alban Berg
column2: Anton Webern
column3: Hanns Eisler
column4: Egon Wellesz
column5: Nikos Skalkottas
column6: and later John Cage
column7: Lou Harrison
column8: Earl Kim
column9: Roberto Gerhard
column10: Leon Kirchner

20~2~Arpeggio~8742~8751~"A broken chord is a chord broken into a sequence of notes. A broken chord may repeat some of the notes from the chord and span one or more octaves.
An arpeggio (Italian: [arˈpeddʒo]) is a type of broken chord
column2: in which the notes that compose a chord are played or sung in a rising or descending order. An arpeggio may also span more than one octave.

column1: The word arpeggio comes from the Italian word arpeggiare
column2: which means to play on a harp.

column1: Even though the notes of an arpeggio are not played or sung all together at the same time
column2: listeners hear the sequence of notes as forming a chord. When an arpeggio also contains passing tones that are not part of the chord
column3: different music theorists may analyze the same musical excerpt differently.

column1: Arpeggios enable composers writing for monophonic instruments that play one note at a time (e.g.
column2: flute
column3: saxophone
column4: trumpet)
column5: to voice chords and chord progressions in musical pieces. Arpeggios and broken chords are also used to help create rhythmic interest. A notable example of which is the Alberti bass figuration which was widely used in piano music from the Classical music period. With an Alberti bass
column6: rather than play the notes of a chord all at once
column7: the pianist plays simple rhythmic figures in which the notes of the chord are played as a broken chord.

21~2~Art~1655~1658~Art is a diverse range of human activities in creating visual

column1: 23~2~Blues~13030~13035~"Blues is a music genre and musical form originated by African Americans in the Deep South of the United States around the end of the 19th century. The genre developed from roots in African musical traditions
column2: African-American work songs
column3: spirituals
column4: and the folk music of white Americans of European heritage. Blues incorporated spirituals
column5: work songs
column6: field hollers
column7: shouts
column8: chants
column9: and rhymed simple narrative ballads. The blues form
column10: ubiquitous in jazz
column11: rhythm and blues and rock and roll
column12: is characterized by the call-and-response pattern
column13: the blues scale and specific chord progressions
column14: of which the twelve-bar blues is the most common. Blue notes (or ""worried notes"")
column15: usually thirds or fifths flattened in pitch
column16: are also an essential part of the sound. Blues shuffles or walking bass reinforce the trance-like rhythm and form a repetitive effect known as the groove.

column1: Blues as a genre is also characterized by its lyrics
column2: bass lines
column3: and instrumentation. Early traditional blues verses consisted of a single line repeated four times. It was only in the first decades of the 20th century that the most common current structure became standard: the AAB pattern
column4: consisting of a line sung over the four first bars
column5: its repetition over the next four
column6: and then a longer concluding line over the last bars. Early blues frequently took the form of a loose narrative
column7: often relating the racial discrimination and other challenges experienced by African-Americans.

column1: Many elements
column2: such as the call-and-response format and the use of blue notes
column3: can be traced back to the music of Africa. The origins of the blues are also closely related to the religious music of the Afro-American community
column4: the spirituals. The first appearance of the blues is often dated to after the ending of slavery and
column5: later
column6: the development of juke joints. It is associated with the newly acquired freedom of the former slaves. Chroniclers began to report about blues music at the dawn of the 20th century. The first publication of blues sheet music was in 1908. Blues has since evolved from unaccompanied vocal music and oral traditions of slaves into a wide variety of styles and subgenres. Blues subgenres include country blues
column7: such as Delta blues and Piedmont blues
column8: as well as urban blues styles such as Chicago blues and West Coast blues. World War II marked the transition from acoustic to electric blues and the progressive opening of blues music to a wider audience
column9: especially white listeners. In the 1960s and 1970s
column10: a hybrid form called blues rock developed
column11: which blended blues styles with rock music."~0.3015925498513589

column1: 24~2~Béla Bartók~9996~10007~Béla Viktor János Bartók (; Hungarian: [ˈbeːlɒ ˈbɒrtoːk]; 25 March 1881 – 26 September 1945) was a Hungarian composer

column1: 25~2~Classical Music~1066~1075~"Classical music is art music produced or rooted in the traditions of Western culture
column2: including both liturgical (religious) and secular music. While a more precise term is also used to refer to the period from 1750 to 1820 (the Classical period)

column4: which includes the Classical period and various other periods. The central norms of this tradition became codified between 1550 and 1900

column1: the ancient music period
column2: before 500 AD

column1: the early music period
column2: which includes

column1: the Medieval (500–1400) including
the ars antiqua (1170–1310)
the ars nova (1310–1377)
the ars subtilior (1360–1420)
the Renaissance (1400–1600) eras.
the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
the common-practice period
column2: which includes

column1: the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
Classical (1750–1820)
Romantic eras (c.1780–1910)
the 20th century (1901–2000) which includes
the modern (1890–1930) that overlaps from the late-19th century
the high modern (1930–present)
impressionism (1875–1925) that also overlaps from the late-19th century
neoclassicism (1920–1950)
column2: predominantly in the inter-war period

column1: the postmodern (1930–present) eras
the experimental (1950–present)
contemporary (1945 or 1975–present)
European art music is largely distinguished from many other non-European classical and some popular musical forms by its system of staff notation

column3: basslines and chords)
column4: tempo
column5: metre and rhythms for a piece of music. This can leave less room for practices such as improvisation and ad libitum ornamentation
column6: which are frequently heard in non-European art music and in popular-music styles such as jazz and blues. Another difference is that whereas most popular styles adopt the song (strophic) form or a derivation of this form
column7: classical music has been noted for its development of highly sophisticated forms of instrumental music such as the symphony
column8: concerto
column9: fugue
column10: sonata
column11: and mixed vocal and instrumental styles such as opera
column12: cantata
column13: and mass.

column1: The term ""classical music"" did not appear until the early 19th century
column2: in an attempt to distinctly canonize the period from Johann Sebastian Bach to Ludwig van Beethoven as a golden age. The earliest reference to ""classical music"" recorded by the Oxford English Dictionary is from about 1829."~0.4445589816771897

column1: 26~2~Counterpoint~497~509~"In music

column1: 27~2~Edgard Varèse~10013~10026~"Edgard Victor Achille Charles Varèse (French: [ɛdɡaːʁ viktɔːʁ aʃil ʃaʁl vaʁɛːz]; also spelled Edgar Varèse; December 22
column2: 1883 – November 6

column1: Varèse's music emphasizes timbre and rhythm. He coined the term ""organized sound"" in reference to his own musical aesthetic. Varèse's conception of music reflected his vision of ""sound as living matter"" and of ""musical space as open rather than bounded"". He conceived the elements of his music in terms of ""sound-masses""
column2: likening their organization to the natural phenomenon of crystallization. Varèse thought that ""to stubbornly conditioned ears
column3: anything new in music has always been called noise""

column5: ""what is music but organized noises?""

column1: Although his complete surviving works only last about three hours
column2: he has been recognised as an influence by several major composers of the late 20th century. Varèse saw potential in using electronic media for sound production
column3: and his use of new instruments and electronic resources led to his being known as the ""Father of Electronic Music"" while Henry Miller described him as ""The stratospheric Colossus of Sound"".

28~2~Europe~2266~2274~"Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere and mostly in the Eastern Hemisphere. It is bordered by the Arctic Ocean to the north
column2: the Atlantic Ocean to the west
column3: and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. It comprises the westernmost part of Eurasia.

column3: 000 square kilometres (3
column5: 000 sq mi)

column7: art

column4: and economically from the end of the 17th century till the first half of the 19th century. The Industrial Revolution
column5: which began in Great Britain at the end of the 18th century

column7: cultural
column8: and social change in Western Europe
column9: and eventually the wider world. Both world wars took place for the most part in Europe

column2: the Council of Europe was formed in Strasbourg following a speech by Sir Winston Churchill

column1: 29~2~Frequencies~185~196~Frequency is the number of occurrences of a repeating event per unit of time. It is also referred to as temporal frequency
column2: which emphasizes the contrast to spatial frequency and angular frequency. The period is the duration of time of one cycle in a repeating event
column3: so the period is the reciprocal of the frequency. For example
column4: if a newborn baby's heart beats at a frequency of 120 times a minute
column5: its period—the time interval between beats—is half a second (that is
column6: 60 seconds divided by 120 beats). Frequency is an important parameter used in science and engineering to specify the rate of oscillatory and vibratory phenomena
column7: such as mechanical vibrations
column8: audio signals (sound)
column9: radio waves

column1: 30~2~Harmonic~7265~7274~"A harmonic is any member of the harmonic series
column2: a divergent infinite series. Its name derives from the concept of overtones
column3: or harmonics in musical instruments: the wavelengths of the overtones of a vibrating string or a column of air (as with a tuba) are derived from the string's (or air column's) fundamental wavelength. Every term of the series (i.e.
column4: the higher harmonics) after the first is the ""harmonic mean"" of the neighboring terms. The phrase ""harmonic mean"" likewise derives from music.

column1: The term is employed in various disciplines
column2: including music
column3: physics
column4: acoustics
column5: electronic power transmission
column6: radio technology
column7: and other fields. It is typically applied to repeating signals
column8: such as sinusoidal waves. A harmonic of such a wave is a wave with a frequency that is a positive integer multiple of the frequency of the original wave
column9: known as the fundamental frequency. The original wave is also called the 1st harmonic
column10: the following harmonics are known as higher harmonics. As all harmonics are periodic at the fundamental frequency
column11: the sum of harmonics is also periodic at that frequency. For example
column12: if the fundamental frequency is 50 Hz
column13: a common AC power supply frequency
column14: the frequencies of the first three higher harmonics are 100 Hz (2nd harmonic)
column15: 150 Hz (3rd harmonic)
column16: 200 Hz (4th harmonic) and any addition of waves with these frequencies is periodic at 50 Hz.

column1: An nth characteristic mode
column2: for n > 1
column3: will have nodes that are not vibrating. For example
column4: the 3rd characteristic mode will have nodes at

column1: {\displaystyle {\tfrac {1}{3}}}
L and
{\displaystyle {\tfrac {2}{3}}}
L
column2: where L is the length of the string. In fact
column3: each nth characteristic mode
column4: for n a multiple of 3
column5: will not have nodes at these points. These other characteristic modes will be vibrating at the positions

column1: {\displaystyle {\tfrac {1}{3}}}
L and
{\displaystyle {\tfrac {2}{3}}}
L. If the player gently touches one of these positions
column2: then these other characteristic modes will be suppressed. The tonal harmonics from these other characteristic modes will then also be suppressed. Consequently
column3: the tonal harmonics from the nth characteristic modes
column4: where n is a multiple of 3
column5: will be made relatively more prominent.

column1: In music
column2: harmonics are used on string instruments and wind instruments as a way of producing sound on the instrument
column3: particularly to play higher notes and
column4: with strings
column5: obtain notes that have a unique sound quality or ""tone colour"". On strings
column6: harmonics that are bowed have a ""glassy""
column7: pure tone. On stringed instruments
column8: harmonics are played by touching (but not fully pressing down the string) at an exact point on the string while sounding the string (plucking
column9: bowing
column10: etc.); this allows the harmonic to sound
column11: a pitch which is always higher than the fundamental frequency of the string."~0.17729932449731695

column1: 31~2~Harmonization~1171~1184~"In music
column2: harmonization is the chordal accompaniment to a line or melody: ""Using chords and melodies together
column3: making harmony by stacking scale tones as triads"".

column1: A harmonized scale can be created by using each note of a musical scale as a root note for a chord and then by taking other tones within the scale building the rest of a chord.
For example
column2: using an Ionian (major scale)

column1: the root note would become the I major chord
the second note the ii minor chord
the third note the iii minor chord
the fourth note the IV major chord
the fifth note the V major chord (or even a dominant 7th)
the sixth note the vi minor chord
the seventh note the vii diminished chord and
the octave would be a I major chord.
Using the minor (aeolian mode) one would have:
i minor
ii diminished
(♭)III major
iv minor
v minor
(♭)VI major
(♭)VII major and
the i minor an octave higher.

~0.04188700233719353
32~2~Hierarchical~9310~9322~A hierarchy (from the Greek hierarchia
column2: ""rule of a high priest""
column3: from hierarkhes
column4: ""leader of sacred rites"") is an arrangement of items (objects
column5: names
column6: values
column7: categories
column8: etc.) in which the items are represented as being ""above""
column9: ""below""
column10: or ""at the same level as"" one another.

column1: A hierarchy can link entities either directly or indirectly
column2: and either vertically or diagonally. The only direct links in a hierarchy
column3: insofar as they are hierarchical
column4: are to one's immediate superior or to one of one's subordinates
column5: although a system that is largely hierarchical can also incorporate alternative hierarchies. Indirect hierarchical links can extend ""vertically"" upwards or downwards via multiple links in the same direction
column6: following a path. All parts of the hierarchy which are not linked vertically to one another nevertheless can be ""horizontally"" linked through a path by traveling up the hierarchy to find a common direct or indirect superior

column8: but they have the same relative amount of authority. Organizational forms exist that are both alternative and complementary to hierarchy. Heterarchy is one such form."~0.06874019583124807

column1: 35~2~Melody~455~467~"A melody (""singing

column1: 36~2~Music~3~8~"Music is an art form and cultural activity whose medium is sound organized in time. The common elements of music are pitch (which governs melody and harmony)

column1: 37~2~Musical composition~53~64~"Musical composition can refer to an original piece of music

column12: to text compositions such as Karlheinz Stockhausen's Aus den sieben Tagen

column17: and Witold Lutosławski. A more commonly known example of chance-based music is the sound of wind chimes jingling in a breeze. The study of composition has traditionally been dominated by examination of methods and practice of Western classical music

column1: Although in the 2000s

This is what the Ancients called melody. The second is the rendering audible of two or more simultaneous sounds in such a manner that their combination is pleasant. This is what we call harmony

column1: 38~2~Octave~12875~12881~"In music
column2: an octave (Latin: octavus: eighth) or perfect octave is the interval between one musical pitch and another with half or double its frequency. It is defined by ANSI as the unit of frequency level when the base of the logarithm is two. The octave relationship is a natural phenomenon that has been referred to as the ""basic miracle of music""
column3: the use of which is ""common in most musical systems"".

column1: The most important musical scales are typically written using eight notes
column2: and the interval between the first and last notes is an octave. For example
column3: the C major scale is typically written C D E F G A B C
column4: the initial and final Cs being an octave apart. Two notes separated by an octave have the same letter name and are of the same pitch class.

column1: The interval between the first and second harmonics of the harmonic series is an octave.
The octave has occasionally been referred to as a diapason.
To emphasize that it is one of the perfect intervals (including unison
column2: perfect fourth
column3: and perfect fifth)
column4: the octave is designated P8. The octave above or below an indicated note is sometimes abbreviated 8a or 8va (Italian: all'ottava)
column5: 8va bassa (Italian: all'ottava bassa
column6: sometimes also 8vb)
column7: or simply 8 for the octave in the direction indicated by placing this mark above or below the staff."~0.2223078374081138

column1: 39~2~Perception~19334~19344~"Perception (from the Latin perceptio) is the organization
column2: identification
column3: and interpretation of sensory information in order to represent and understand the presented information
column4: or the environment.

column1: All perception involves signals that go through the nervous system
column2: which in turn result from physical or chemical stimulation of the sensory system. For example
column3: vision involves light striking the retina of the eye
column4: smell is mediated by odor molecules
column5: and hearing involves pressure waves.

column1: Perception is not only the passive receipt of these signals
column2: but it's also shaped by the recipient's learning
column3: memory
column4: expectation
column5: and attention.

column1: Perception can be split into two processes
column2: (1) processing the sensory input
column3: which transforms these low-level information to higher-level information (e.g.
column4: extracts shapes for object recognition)
column5: (2) processing which is connected with a person's concepts and expectations (or knowledge)
column6: restorative and selective mechanisms (such as attention) that influence perception.

column1: Perception depends on complex functions of the nervous system
column2: but subjectively seems mostly effortless because this processing happens outside conscious awareness.

column1: Since the rise of experimental psychology in the 19th Century
column2: psychology's understanding of perception has progressed by combining a variety of techniques.  Psychophysics quantitatively describes the relationships between the physical qualities of the sensory input and perception. Sensory neuroscience studies the neural mechanisms underlying perception. Perceptual systems can also be studied computationally
column3: in terms of the information they process. Perceptual issues in philosophy include the extent to which sensory qualities such as sound
column4: smell or color exist in objective reality rather than in the mind of the perceiver.

column1: Although the senses were traditionally viewed as passive receptors
column2: the study of illusions and ambiguous images has demonstrated that the brain's perceptual systems actively and pre-consciously attempt to make sense of their input. There is still active debate about the extent to which perception is an active process of hypothesis testing
column3: analogous to science
column4: or whether realistic sensory information is rich enough to make this process unnecessary.

column1: The perceptual systems of the brain enable individuals to see the world around them as stable
column2: even though the sensory information is typically incomplete and rapidly varying. Human and animal brains are structured in a modular way
column3: with different areas processing different kinds of sensory information. Some of these modules take the form of sensory maps
column4: mapping some aspect of the world across part of the brain's surface. These different modules are interconnected and influence each other. For instance
column5: taste is strongly influenced by smell."~0.12431841602659575

column1: 40~2~Plainsong~7829~7838~"Plainsong (also plainchant; Latin: cantus planus) is a body of chants used in the liturgies of the Western Church. Though the Catholic Church (both its Eastern and Western halves) and the Eastern Orthodox churches did not split until long after the origin of plainsong

column1: Plainsong is monophonic

column3: unaccompanied melodic line. Its rhythm is generally freer than the metered rhythm of later Western music."~0.36700924764496806

column1: 41~2~Polyphony~571~580~"In music
column2: polyphony is one type of musical texture
column3: where a texture is
column4: generally speaking
column5: the way that melodic
column6: rhythmic
column7: and harmonic aspects of a musical composition are combined to shape the overall sound and quality of the work. In particular
column8: polyphony consists of two or more simultaneous lines of independent melody
column9: as opposed to a musical texture with just one voice
column10: monophony
column11: or a texture with one dominant melodic voice accompanied by chords
column12: which is called homophony.

column1: Within the context of the Western musical tradition
column2: the term polyphony is usually used to refer to music of the late Middle Ages and Renaissance. Baroque forms such as fugue
column3: which might be called polyphonic
column4: are usually described instead as contrapuntal. Also
column5: as opposed to the species terminology of counterpoint
column6: polyphony was generally either ""pitch-against-pitch"" / ""point-against-point"" or ""sustained-pitch"" in one part with melismas of varying lengths in another. In all cases the conception was probably what Margaret Bent (1999) calls ""dyadic counterpoint""
column7: with each part being written generally against one other part
column8: with all parts modified if needed in the end. This point-against-point conception is opposed to ""successive composition""
column9: where voices were written in an order with each new voice fitting into the whole so far constructed

column1: 42~2~Prolongation~22932~22944~"In music theory
column2: prolongation is the process in tonal music through which a pitch
column3: interval
column4: or consonant triad is able to govern spans of music when not physically sounding. It is a central principle in the music-analytic methodology of Schenkerian analysis
column5: conceived by Austrian theorist Heinrich Schenker.

column1: Prolongation can be thought of as a way of generating musical content through the linear elaboration of simple and basic tonal structures with progressively increasing detail and sophistication. Important to the operation of prolongation is the hierarchical differentiation of pitches within a passage of tonal music. Typically
column2: the note or harmony of highest hierarchical significance is the tonic
column3: and this is said to be ""prolonged"" across durations of music that may feature many other different harmonies. (However
column4: in principle any other type of consonant chord
column5: pitch
column6: or harmonic function can be prolonged within tonal music.) Conversely
column7: in a chord progression
column8: harmonies are said to prolong a triad when they are subordinated to that governing chord in a systematic manner; the job of such prolonging harmonies is to express and extend the influence of that hierarchically super-ordinate pitch or triad. Because it enables a pitch or pitches to remain in effect over the course of a piece
column9: even as many other harmonic events intervene
column10: prolongation is central to the concept of tonality in music.

He replaced Jean-Baptiste Lully as the dominant composer of French opera and is also considered the leading French composer for the harpsichord of his time

column1: 44~2~Renaissance~2096~2107~"The Renaissance (UK:
column2: US: ) is a period in European history
column3: covering the span between the 14th and 17th centuries. It is an extension of the Middle Ages
column4: and is bridged by the Age of Enlightenment to modern history. It grew in fragments
column5: with the very first traces found seemingly in Italy
column6: coming to cover much of Europe
column7: for some scholars marking the beginning of the modern age.

column1: The intellectual basis of the Renaissance was its own invented version of humanism
column2: derived from the concept of Roman Humanitas and the rediscovery of classical Greek philosophy
column3: such as that of Protagoras
column4: who said that ""Man is the measure of all things."" This new thinking became manifest in art
column5: architecture
column6: politics
column7: science and literature. Early examples were the development of perspective in oil painting and the recycled knowledge of how to make concrete. Although the invention of metal movable type sped the dissemination of ideas from the later 15th century
column8: the changes of the Renaissance were not uniformly experienced across Europe.

column1: As a cultural movement
column2: the Renaissance encompassed innovative flowering of Latin and vernacular literatures
column3: beginning with the 14th-century resurgence of learning based on classical sources
column4: which contemporaries credited to Petrarch; the development of linear perspective and other techniques of rendering a more natural reality in painting; and gradual but widespread educational reform. In politics
column5: the Renaissance contributed to the development of the customs and conventions of diplomacy
column6: and in science to an increased reliance on observation and inductive reasoning. Although the Renaissance saw revolutions in many intellectual pursuits
column7: as well as social and political upheaval
column8: it is perhaps best known for its artistic developments and the contributions of such polymaths as Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo
column9: who inspired the term ""Renaissance man"".

column1: The Renaissance began in Florence
column2: in the 14th century. Various theories have been proposed to account for its origins and characteristics
column3: focusing on a variety of factors including the social and civic peculiarities of Florence at the time: its political structure; the patronage of its dominant family
column4: the Medici; and the migration of Greek scholars and texts to Italy following the Fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Turks. Other major centres were northern Italian city-states such as Venice
column5: Genoa
column6: Milan
column7: Bologna
column8: and finally Rome during the Renaissance Papacy.

column1: The Renaissance has a long and complex historiography
column2: and
column3: in line with general scepticism of discrete periodizations
column4: there has been much debate among historians reacting to the 19th-century glorification of the ""Renaissance"" and individual culture heroes as ""Renaissance men""
column5: questioning the usefulness of Renaissance as a term and as a historical delineation. The art historian Erwin Panofsky observed of this resistance to the concept of ""Renaissance"":

column1: It is perhaps no accident that the factuality of the Italian Renaissance has been most vigorously questioned by those who are not obliged to take a professional interest in the aesthetic aspects of civilization—historians of economic and social developments
column2: political and religious situations
column3: and
column4: most particularly
column5: natural science—but only exceptionally by students of literature and hardly ever by historians of Art.

column1: Some observers have called into question whether the Renaissance was a cultural ""advance"" from the Middle Ages
column2: instead seeing it as a period of pessimism and nostalgia for classical antiquity
column3: while social and economic historians
column4: especially of the longue durée
column5: have instead focused on the continuity between the two eras
column6: which are linked
column7: as Panofsky observed
column8: ""by a thousand ties"".

column1: The word Renaissance
column2: literally meaning ""Rebirth"" in French
column3: first appeared in English in the 1830s. The word also occurs in Jules Michelet's 1855 work
column4: Histoire de France. The word Renaissance has also been extended to other historical and cultural movements
column5: such as the Carolingian Renaissance and the Renaissance of the 12th century."~0.1859419996730194

column1: 45~2~Timbre~207~212~"In music
column2: timbre ( TAM-bər
column3: also known as tone color or tone quality from psychoacoustics) is the perceived sound quality of a musical note
column4: sound or tone. Timbre distinguishes different types of sound production
column5: such as choir voices and musical instruments
column6: such as string instruments
column7: wind instruments
column8: and percussion instruments. It also enables listeners to distinguish different instruments in the same category (e.g. an oboe and a clarinet).

column1: The physical characteristics of sound that determine the perception of timbre include spectrum and envelope. Singers and instrumental musicians can change the timbre of the music they are singing/playing by using different singing or playing techniques. For example
column2: a violinist can use different bowing styles or play on different parts of the string to obtain different timbres (e.g.
column3: playing sul tasto produces a light
column4: airy timbre

column6: even and aggressive tone). On electric guitar and electric piano
column7: performers can change the timbre using effects units and graphic equalizers.

column1: In simple terms
column2: timbre is what makes a particular musical sound have a different sound from another
column3: even when they have the same pitch and loudness. For instance
column4: it is the difference in sound between a guitar and a piano playing the same note at the same volume. Both instruments can sound equally tuned in relation to each other as they play the same note
column5: and while playing at the same amplitude level each instrument will still sound distinctively with its own unique tone color. Experienced musicians are able to distinguish between different instruments of the same type based on their varied timbres

column1: 46~2~Tritone~8322~8329~"In music theory
column2: the tritone is defined as a musical interval composed of three adjacent whole tones. For instance
column3: the interval from F up to the B above it (in short
column4: F–B) is a tritone as it can be decomposed into the three adjacent whole tones F–G
column5: G–A
column6: and A–B. According to this definition
column7: within a diatonic scale there is only one tritone for each octave. For instance
column8: the above-mentioned interval F–B is the only tritone formed from the notes of the C major scale. A tritone is also commonly defined as an interval spanning six semitones. According to this definition
column9: a diatonic scale contains two tritones for each octave. For instance
column10: the above-mentioned C major scale contains the tritones F–B (from F to the B above it
column11: also called augmented fourth) and B–F (from B to the F above it
column12: also called diminished fifth
column13: semidiapente

The tritone can be used to avoid traditional tonality: ""Any tendency for a tonality to emerge may be avoided by introducing a note three whole tones distant from the key note of that tonality."" Contrarily
column3: the tritone found in the dominant seventh chord helps establish the tonality of a composition. These contrasting uses exhibit the flexibility
column4: ubiquity
column5: and distinctness of the tritone in music.

column1: The condition of having tritones is called tritonia; that of having no tritones is atritonia. A musical scale or chord containing tritones is called tritonic; one without tritones is atritonic."~0.35103032478790863

column1: 61~3~Arnold Schoenberg~44722~44739~"Arnold Franz Walter Schoenberg or Schönberg (; German: [ˈaːʁnɔlt ˈʃøːnbɛʁk] ( listen); 13 September 1874 – 13 July 1951) was an Austrian composer
column2: music theorist

column1: 66~3~Bebop~1634~1639~"Bebop or bop is a style of jazz developed in the early to mid-1940s in the United States

93~3~Classical music~230~245~"Classical music is art music produced or rooted in the traditions of Western culture
column2: including both liturgical (religious) and secular music. While a more precise term is also used to refer to the period from 1750 to 1820 (the Classical period)
column3: this article is about the broad span of time from before the 6th century AD to the present day
column4: which includes the Classical period and various other periods. The central norms of this tradition became codified between 1550 and 1900
column5: which is known as the common-practice period. The major time divisions of Western art music are as follows:

column1: the ancient music period
column2: before 500 AD

column1: the early music period
column2: which includes

column1: the Medieval (500–1400) including
the ars antiqua (1170–1310)
the ars nova (1310–1377)
the ars subtilior (1360–1420)
the Renaissance (1400–1600) eras.
the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
the common-practice period
column2: which includes

column1: the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
Classical (1750–1820)
Romantic eras (c.1780–1910)
the 20th century (1901–2000) which includes
the modern (1890–1930) that overlaps from the late-19th century
the high modern (1930–present)
impressionism (1875–1925) that also overlaps from the late-19th century
neoclassicism (1920–1950)
column2: predominantly in the inter-war period

column1: the postmodern (1930–present) eras
the experimental (1950–present)
contemporary (1945 or 1975–present)
European art music is largely distinguished from many other non-European classical and some popular musical forms by its system of staff notation
column2: in use since about the 11th century. Western staff notation is used by composers to indicate to the performer the pitches (which form the melodies
column3: basslines and chords)
column4: tempo
column5: metre and rhythms for a piece of music. This can leave less room for practices such as improvisation and ad libitum ornamentation
column6: which are frequently heard in non-European art music and in popular-music styles such as jazz and blues. Another difference is that whereas most popular styles adopt the song (strophic) form or a derivation of this form
column7: classical music has been noted for its development of highly sophisticated forms of instrumental music such as the symphony
column8: concerto
column9: fugue
column10: sonata
column11: and mixed vocal and instrumental styles such as opera
column12: cantata
column13: and mass.

column1: The term ""classical music"" did not appear until the early 19th century
column2: in an attempt to distinctly canonize the period from Johann Sebastian Bach to Ludwig van Beethoven as a golden age. The earliest reference to ""classical music"" recorded by the Oxford English Dictionary is from about 1829."~0.4445589816771897

column8: Hornbostel-Sachs high-level classification 2) and idiophones - most significantly cymbals
column9: but can also include the woodblock and cowbell (classified as Hornbostel-Sachs high-level classification 1). In the 2000s
column10: some kits also include electronic instruments (Hornbostel-Sachs classification 53). Also
column11: both hybrid (mixing acoustic instruments and electronic drums) and entirely electronic kits are used.

column1: A standard modern kit (for a right-handed player)
column2: as used in popular music and taught in music schools
column3: contains:

column1: A snare drum
column2: mounted on a stand
column3: placed between the player's knees and played with drum sticks (which may include rutes or brushes)

column1: A bass drum
column2: played by a pedal operated by the right foot
column3: which moves a felt-covered beater

column1: One or more toms
column2: played with sticks or brushes (usually three toms: rack tom 1 and 2
column3: and floor tom)

column1: A hi-hat (two cymbals mounted on a stand)
column2: played with the sticks
column3: opened and closed with left foot pedal (it can also produce sound with the foot alone)

column1: One or more cymbals
column2: mounted on stands
column3: played with the sticks

column1: All of these are classed as non-pitched percussion
column2: allowing for the music to be scored using percussion notation
column3: for which a loose semi-standardized form exists for the drum kit. If some or all of them are replaced by electronic drums
column4: the scoring and most often positioning remains the same
column5: allowing a standard teaching approach. The drum kit is usually played while seated on a drum stool or throne. The drum kit differs from instruments that can be used to produce pitched melodies or chords
column6: even though drums are often placed musically alongside others that do
column7: such as the guitar or piano. The drum kit is a part of the standard rhythm section used in many types of popular and traditional music styles
column8: ranging from rock and pop to blues and jazz. Other standard instruments used in the rhythm section include the piano
column9: electric guitar
column10: electric bass
column11: and keyboards.

column1: Many drummers extend their kits from this basic pattern
column2: adding more drums
column3: more cymbals
column4: and many other instruments including pitched percussion. In some styles of music particular extensions are normal
column5: for example double bass drums in heavy metal music and the enlarged kits used by some progressive drummers
column6: which may include unusual instruments such as gongs. Some performers
column7: such as some rockabilly drummers
column8: use small kits that omit elements from the basic setup. Some drum kit players may have other roles in the band
column9: such as providing backup vocals
column10: or less commonly

column1: 129~3~Gospel music~2147~2153~"Gospel music is a genre of Christian music. The creation

column1: 132~3~Guitar~7349~7355~"The guitar is a fretted musical instrument that usually has six strings. The sound is projected either acoustically
column2: using a hollow wooden or plastic and wood box (for an acoustic guitar)
column3: or through electrical amplifier and a speaker (for an electric guitar). It is typically played by strumming or plucking the strings with the fingers
column4: thumb or fingernails of the right hand or with a pick while fretting (or pressing against the frets) the strings with the fingers of the left hand. The guitar is a type of chordophone
column5: traditionally constructed from wood and strung with either gut
column6: nylon or steel strings and distinguished from other chordophones by its construction and tuning. The modern guitar was preceded by the gittern
column7: the vihuela
column8: the four-course Renaissance guitar
column9: and the five-course baroque guitar
column10: all of which contributed to the development of the modern six-string instrument.

column1: There are three main types of modern acoustic guitar: the classical guitar (nylon-string guitar)
column2: the steel-string acoustic guitar
column3: and the archtop guitar
column4: which is sometimes called a ""jazz guitar"". The tone of an acoustic guitar is produced by the strings' vibration
column5: amplified by the hollow body of the guitar
column6: which acts as a resonating chamber. The classical guitar is often played as a solo instrument using a comprehensive finger-picking technique where each string is plucked individually by the player's fingers
column7: as opposed to being strummed. The term ""finger-picking"" can also refer to a specific tradition of folk
column8: blues
column9: bluegrass
column10: and country guitar playing in the United States. The acoustic bass guitar is a low-pitched instrument that is one octave below a regular guitar.

column1: Electric guitars
column2: introduced in the 1930s
column3: use an amplifier and a loudspeaker that both makes the sound of the instrument loud enough for the performers and audience to hear
column4: and
column5: given that it produces an electric signal when played
column6: that can electronically manipulate and shape the tone using an equalizer (e.g.
column7: bass and treble tone controls) and a huge variety of electronic effects units
column8: the most commonly used ones being distortion (or ""overdrive"") and reverb. Early amplified guitars employed a hollow body
column9: but a solid wood body was eventually found more suitable during the 1960s and 1970s
column10: as it was less prone to unwanted acoustic feedback ""howls"". As with acoustic guitars
column11: there are a number of types of electric guitars
column12: including hollowbody guitars
column13: archtop guitars (used in jazz guitar
column14: blues and rockabilly) and solid-body guitars
column15: which are widely used in rock music.

column1: The loud
column2: amplified sound and sonic power of the electric guitar played through a guitar amp has played a key role in the development of blues and rock music
column3: both as an accompaniment instrument (playing riffs and chords) and performing guitar solos
column4: and in many rock subgenres
column5: notably heavy metal music and punk rock. The electric guitar has had a major influence on popular culture. The guitar is used in a wide variety of musical genres worldwide. It is recognized as a primary instrument in genres such as blues
column6: bluegrass
column7: country
column8: flamenco
column9: folk
column10: jazz
column11: jota
column12: mariachi
column13: metal
column14: punk
column15: reggae
column17: soul

column4: conductor
