column1: 134~3~Hammond organ~68256~68269~"The Hammond organ is an electric organ
column2: invented by Laurens Hammond and John M. Hanert and first manufactured in 1935. Various models have been produced
column3: most of which use sliding drawbars to specify a variety of sounds. Until 1975
column4: Hammond organs generated sound by creating an electric current from rotating a metal tonewheel near an electromagnetic pickup
column5: and then strengthening the signal with an amplifier so it can drive a speaker cabinet. Around two million Hammond organs have been manufactured. The organ is commonly used with
column6: and associated with
column7: the Leslie speaker.

column1: The organ was originally marketed and sold by the Hammond Organ Company to churches as a lower-cost alternative to the wind-driven pipe organ
column2: or instead of a piano. It quickly became popular with professional jazz musicians in organ trios
column3: a small group centered on the Hammond organ. Organ trios were hired by jazz club owners
column4: who found that organ trios were a much cheaper alternative to hiring a big band. Jimmy Smith's use of the Hammond B-3
column5: with its additional harmonic percussion feature
column6: inspired a generation of organ players
column7: and its use became more widespread in the 1960s and 1970s in rhythm and blues
column8: rock
column9: and reggae
column10: as well as being an important instrument in progressive rock.

column1: The Hammond Organ Company struggled financially during the 1970s
column2: as they abandoned tonewheel organs and switched to manufacturing instruments using integrated circuits. These instruments were not as popular with musicians as the tonewheels had been
column3: and the company went out of business in 1985. The Hammond name was purchased by the Suzuki Musical Instrument Corporation
column4: which proceeded to manufacture digital simulations of the most popular tonewheel organs. This culminated in the production of the ""New B-3"" in 2002
column5: which provided an accurate recreation of the original B-3 organ using modern digital technology.

column1: Hammond-Suzuki continues to manufacture a variety of organs for both professional players and churches. Other companies
column2: such as Korg
column3: Roland
column4: and Clavia
column5: have also achieved success in providing more lightweight and portable emulations of the original tonewheel organs. The sound of a tonewheel Hammond can also be emulated using modern software such as Native Instruments B4."~0.4133677478309372

column1: 135~3~Han Bennink~60281~60292~"Han Bennink (born 17 April 1942) is a Dutch jazz drummer and percussionist. On occasion his recordings have featured him playing clarinet
column2: violin
column3: banjo and piano.

column1: Though perhaps best known as one of the pivotal figures in early European free jazz and free improvisation
column2: Bennink has worked in essentially every school of jazz
column3: and is described by critic Chris Kelsey as ""one of the unfortunately rare musicians whose abilities and interests span jazz's entire spectrum."" Known for often injecting slapstick and absurdist humor into his performances
column4: Bennink has had especially fruitful long-term partnerships with pianist Misha Mengelberg and saxophonist Peter Brötzmann. Han is a brother of saxophonist Peter Bennink."~0.45883427477907973

column1: 136~3~Hard bop~2078~2086~"Hard bop is a subgenre of jazz that is an extension of bebop (or ""bop"") music. Journalists and record companies began using the term in the mid-1950s to describe a new current within jazz which incorporated influences from rhythm and blues
column2: gospel music
column3: and blues
column4: especially in saxophone and piano playing.

column1: David H. Rosenthal contends in his book Hard Bop that the genre is
column2: to a large degree
column3: the natural creation of a generation of African-American musicians who grew up at a time when bop and rhythm and blues were the dominant forms of black American music. Prominent hard bop musicians included Horace Silver
column4: Clifford Brown
column5: Charles Mingus
column6: Art Blakey
column7: Cannonball Adderley
column8: Miles Davis
column9: John Coltrane
column10: Thelonious Monk and Tadd Dameron.

column1: Hard bop is sometimes referred to as ""funky hard bop."" The ""funky"" label refers to the rollicking
column2: rhythmic feeling associated with the style. The descriptor is also used to describe soul jazz
column3: which is commonly associated with hard bop. According to Mark C. Gridley
column4: soul jazz more specifically refers to music with ""an earthy
column5: bluesy melodic concept and... repetitive
column6: dance-like rhythms.... Note that some listeners make no distinction between 'soul-jazz' and 'funky hard bop
column7: ' and many musicians don't consider 'soul-jazz' to be continuous with 'hard bop.'"" The term ""soul"" suggests the church
column8: and traditional gospel music elements such as ""amen chords"" (the plagal cadence) and triadic harmonies that seemed to suddenly appear in jazz during the era."~0.37453203054646766

column1: 137~3~Hardcore punk~90998~91011~"Hardcore punk (often abbreviated to hardcore) is a punk rock music genre and subculture that originated in the late 1970s. It is generally faster
column2: harder
column3: and more aggressive than other forms of punk rock. Its roots can be traced to earlier punk scenes in San Francisco and Southern California which arose as a reaction against the still predominant hippie cultural climate of the time. It was also inspired by New York punk rock and early proto-punk. New York punk had a harder-edged sound than its San Francisco counterpart
column4: featuring anti-art expressions of masculine anger
column5: energy and subversive humor. Hardcore punk generally disavows commercialism
column6: the established music industry and ""anything similar to the characteristics of mainstream rock"" and often addresses social and political topics with ""confrontational
column7: politically-charged lyrics"".

column1: Hardcore sprouted underground scenes across the United States in the early 1980s
column2: particularly in Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: New York
column5: New Jersey
column6: and Boston—as well as in Australia
column7: Canada and the United Kingdom. Hardcore has spawned the straight edge movement and its associated submovements
column8: hardline and youth crew. Hardcore was heavily involved in the rise of the independent record labels in the 1980s and with the DIY ethics in underground music scenes. It has also influenced various music genres that have experienced widespread commercial success
column9: including alternative rock
column10: thrash metal
column11: emo and metalcore.

column1: While traditional hardcore has never experienced mainstream commercial success
column2: some of its early pioneers have garnered appreciation over time. Black Flag's Damaged
column3: Minutemen's Double Nickels on the Dime and Hüsker Dü's New Day Rising were included in Rolling Stone's list of The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time in 2003 and Dead Kennedys have seen one of their albums reach gold status over a period of 25 years. In 2011
column4: Rolling Stone writer David Fricke placed Greg Ginn of Black Flag 99th place in his 100 Greatest Guitarists list. Although the music genre started in English-speaking western countries
column5: notable hardcore scenes have existed in Italy
column6: Brazil
column7: Japan
column8: Europe and the Middle East."~0.39321347426417264

column1: 138~3~Harp~80013~80017~"The harp is a stringed musical instrument that has a number of individual strings running at an angle to its soundboard; the strings are plucked with the fingers. Harps have been known since antiquity in Asia
column2: Africa and Europe
column3: dating back at least as early as 3500 BCE. The instrument had great popularity in Europe during the Middle Ages and Renaissance
column4: where it evolved into a wide range of variants with new technologies
column5: and was disseminated to Europe's colonies
column6: finding particular popularity in Latin America. Although some ancient members of the harp family died out in the Near East and South Asia
column7: descendants of early harps are still played in Myanmar and parts of Africa
column8: and other defunct variants in Europe and Asia have been utilized by musicians in the modern era.

column1: Harps vary globally in many ways. In terms of size
column2: many smaller harps can be played on the lap
column3: whereas larger harps are quite heavy and rest on the floor. Different harps may use strings of catgut
column4: nylon
column5: metal
column6: or some combination. While all harps have a neck
column7: resonator
column8: and strings
column9: frame harps have a pillar at their long end to support the strings
column10: while open harps
column11: such as arch harps and bow harps
column12: do not. Modern harps also vary in techniques used to extend the range and chromaticism (e.g.
column13: adding sharps and flats) of the strings
column14: such as adjusting a string's note mid-performance with levers or pedals which modify the pitch. The pedal harp is a standard instrument in the orchestra of the Romantic music era (ca. 1800–1910) and the contemporary music era."~0.27496656903939126

column1: 140~3~Havana~14536~14542~"Havana (; Spanish: La Habana
column2: [la aˈβana] ( listen)) is the capital city
column3: largest city
column4: province
column5: major port
column6: and leading commercial center of Cuba. The city has a population of 2.1 million inhabitants
column7: and it spans a total of 728.26 km2 (281.18 sq mi) – making it the largest city by area
column8: the most populous city
column9: and the fourth largest metropolitan area in the Caribbean region. The city extends mostly westward and southward from the bay

column11: Guanabacoa and Atarés. The sluggish Almendares River traverses the city from south to north

column1: The city of Havana was founded by the Spanish in the 16th century and due to its strategic location it served as a springboard for the Spanish conquest of the Americas
column2: becoming a stopping point for treasure-laden Spanish galleons returning to Spain. King Philip II of Spain granted Havana the title of City in 1592. Walls as well as forts were built to protect the old city. The sinking of the U.S. battleship Maine in Havana's harbor in 1898 was the immediate cause of the Spanish–American War.

column1: Contemporary Havana can essentially be described as three cities in one: Old Havana
column2: Vedado and the newer suburban districts. The city is the center of the Cuban government
column3: and home to various ministries
column4: headquarters of businesses and over 90 diplomatic offices. The current mayor is Marta Hernández of the Communist Party of Cuba (PCC). In 2009
column5: the city/province had the third highest income in the country.

column3: 627 international tourists

column5: culture
column6: architecture and monuments. As typical of Cuba

column1: 143~3~Hip hop~88734~88741~"Hip hop or hip-hop is a subculture and art movement developed in the Bronx in New York City during the late 1970s. The origins of the word are often disputed. It is also argued as to whether hip hop started in the South or West Bronx. While the term hip hop is often used to refer exclusively to hip hop music (also called rap)
column2: hip hop is characterized by nine elements
column3: however only four elements are considered most necessary to understand hip-hop musically. The main elements of hip-hop consist of four main pillars. Afrika Bambaataa of the hip hop collective Zulu Nation outlined the pillars of hip hop culture
column4: coining the terms: ""rapping"" (also called MCing or emceeing)
column5: a rhythmic vocal rhyming style (orality); DJing (and turntablism)
column6: which is making music with record players and DJ mixers (aural/sound and music creation); b-boying/b-girling/breakdancing (movement/dance); and graffiti art. Other elements of hip hop subculture and arts movements beyond the main four are: hip hop culture and historical knowledge of the movement (intellectual/philosophical); beatboxing
column7: a percussive vocal style; street entrepreneurship; hip hop language; and hip hop fashion and style
column8: among others. The fifth element is commonly considered either street knowledge
column9: hip hop fashion or beatboxing however it is often debated.

column1: The Bronx hip hop scene emerged in the mid-1970s from neighborhood block parties thrown by the Ghetto Brothers
column2: a Puerto Rican group that has been described as being a gang
column3: a club
column4: and a music group. Hip hop culture has spread to both urban and suburban communities throughout the United States and subsequently the world. These elements were adapted and developed considerably
column5: particularly as the art forms spread to new continents and merged with local styles in the 1990s and subsequent decades. Even as the movement continues to expand globally and explore myriad styles and art forms
column6: including hip hop theater and hip hop film
column7: the four foundational elements provide coherence and a strong foundation for hip hop culture. Hip hop is simultaneously a new and old phenomenon; the importance of sampling tracks
column8: beats and basslines from old records to the art form means that much of the culture has revolved around the idea of updating classic recordings
column9: attitudes
column10: and experiences for modern audiences. Sampling older culture and reusing it in a new context or a new format is called ""flipping"" in hip hop culture. Hip hop music follows in the footsteps of earlier African-American-rooted musical genres such as blues
column11: jazz
column12: rag-time
column13: funk
column14: and disco to become one of the most practiced genres worldwide. It is the language of urban environments and the youth around the world. According to KRS-One
column15: ""Hip hop is the only place where you see Martin Luther King Jr.'s 'I Have A Dream Speech' in real life"". He also notes that hip hop is beyond something as race
column17: it belongs to the world.

column1: In the 2000s
column2: with the rise of new media platforms and Web 2.0
column3: fans discovered and downloaded or streamed hip hop music through social networking sites (SNS) beginning with Myspace
column4: as well as from websites like YouTube
column5: Worldstarhiphop
column6: SoundCloud

column1: 144~3~Horace Silver~53898~53911~"Horace Ward Martin Tavares Silver (September 2
column3: 2014) was an American jazz pianist
column4: composer
column5: and arranger
column6: particularly in the hard bop style that he helped pioneer in the 1950s.

column1: After playing tenor saxophone and piano at school in Connecticut
column2: Silver got his break on piano when his trio was recruited by Stan Getz in 1950. Silver soon moved to New York City
column3: where he developed a reputation as a composer and for his bluesy playing. Frequent sideman recordings in the mid-1950s helped further
column4: but it was his work with the Jazz Messengers
column5: co-led by Art Blakey
column6: that brought both his writing and playing most attention. Their Horace Silver and the Jazz Messengers album contained Silver's first hit
column7: ""The Preacher"". After leaving Blakey in 1956
column8: Silver formed his own quintet
column9: with what became the standard small group line-up of tenor saxophone
column10: trumpet
column11: piano
column12: bass
column13: and drums. Their public performances and frequent recordings for Blue Note Records increased Silver's popularity
column14: even through changes of personnel. His most successful album was Song for My Father
column15: made with two iterations of the quintet in 1963 and 1964.

column1: Several changes occurred in the early 1970s: Silver disbanded his group to spend more time with his wife and to concentrate on composing; he included lyrics in his recordings; and his interest in spiritualism developed. The last two of these were often combined
column2: resulting in commercially unsuccessful releases such as The United States of Mind series. Silver left Blue Note after 28 years
column3: founded his own record label
column4: and scaled back his touring in the 1980s
column5: relying in part on royalties from his compositions for income. In 1993
column6: he returned to major record labels
column7: releasing five albums before gradually withdrawing from public view because of health problems.

column1: As a player
column2: Silver transitioned from bebop to hard bop by stressing melody rather than complex harmony
column3: and combined clean and often humorous right-hand lines with darker notes and chords in a near-perpetual left-hand rumble. His compositions similarly emphasized catchy melodies
column4: but often also contained dissonant harmonies. Many of his varied repertoire of songs
column5: including ""Doodlin'""
column6: ""Peace""
column7: and ""Sister Sadie""
column8: became jazz standards that are still widely played. His considerable legacy encompasses his influence on other pianists and composers
column9: and the development of young jazz talents who appeared in his bands over the course of four decades."~0.43115070907925446

column1: 146~3~Hymn~12693~12698~"A hymn is a type of song
column2: usually religious
column3: specifically written for the purpose of adoration or prayer
column4: and typically addressed to a deity or deities
column5: or to a prominent figure or personification. The word hymn derives from Greek ὕμνος (hymnos)
column6: which means ""a song of praise"". A writer of hymns is known as a hymnodist. The singing or composition of hymns is called hymnody. Collections of hymns are known as hymnals or hymn books. Hymns may or may not include instrumental accompaniment.

column2: hymns are also a fixture of other world religions
column3: especially on the Indian subcontinent. Hymns also survive from antiquity
column4: especially from Egyptian and Greek cultures. Some of the oldest surviving examples of notated music are hymns with Greek texts."~0.47551955514348854

column1: 147~3~Improvisation~27389~27403~"Improvisation is creating or performing something spontaneously or making something from whatever is available. Improvisation
column2: in the performing arts is a very spontaneous performance without specific or scripted preparation. The skills of improvisation can apply to many different faculties

column4: scientific
column5: physical
column6: cognitive
column7: academic
column8: and non-academic disciplines; see Applied improvisation.

column1: Musical improvisation is the composition (and simultaneous playing) of music
column2: without prior preparation. Improvisational comedy is a theatre art performed throughout the world and has had on-again
column3: off-again status throughout history. Dance improvisation is frequently used as a choreographic tool. Choreography is also frequently used as a tool for improvisation.

column1: Improvisation also exists outside the arts. Improvisation in engineering is to solve a problem with the tools and materials immediately at hand. Improvised weapons are often used by guerrillas
column2: insurgents and criminals."~0.32354240334871864

column1: 151~3~Jam session~46480~46491~"A jam session is a relatively informal musical event

column1: 154~3~Jazz band~31527~31536~"A jazz band (jazz ensemble or jazz combo) is a musical ensemble that plays jazz music. Jazz bands vary in the quantity of its members and the style of jazz that they play but it is common to find a jazz band made up of a rhythm section and a horn section.
The size of a jazz band is closely related to the style of jazz they play as well as the type of venues in which they play. Smaller jazz bands
column2: also known as combos
column3: are common in night clubs and other small venues and will be made up of three to seven musicians; whereas big bands are found in dance halls and other larger venues.

column1: Jazz bands can vary in size from a big band
column2: to a smaller trio or quartet. The term jazz trio can refer to a three piece band with a pianist
column3: double bass player and a drummer. Some bands use vocalists
column4: while others are purely instrumental groups. Jazz bands usually have a bandleader. In a big band setting
column5: there is usually more than one player for a type of instrument.

column1: Jazz bands and their composition have changed many times throughout the years just as the music itself changes with each performers personal interpretation and improvisation which is one of the greatest appeals of going to see a jazz band."~0.4613560846164275
155~3~Jazz improvisation~2411~2429~"Jazz improvisation
column2: which is the making up of new melodic solo lines or accompaniment parts
column3: is a key aspect of jazz. Improvisation is composing on the spot
column4: in which a singer or instrumentalist invents solo melodies and lines over top of a chord progression played by rhythm section instruments (piano
column5: electric guitar
column6: double bass
column7: etc.) and also accompanied by drum kit. While blues
column8: rock and other genres also use improvisation
column9: the improvisation in these non-jazz genres typically is done over relatively simple chord progressions which often stay in one key (or closely related keys using the circle of fifths
column10: such as a song in C Major modulating to G Major).

column1: Along with serious or art music
column2: jazz improvisation is distinguished from other genres use of this approach by the high level of chordal complexity in jazz
column3: often with one or more chord changes per bar
column4: altered chords
column5: extended chords
column6: tritone substitution
column7: unusual chords (e.g.
column8: augmented chords)
column9: and extensive use of ii-V-I progressions
column10: all of which typically move through multiple keys within a single song. However
column11: since the release of Kind of Blue by Miles Davis
column12: jazz improvisation has also come to be associated with modal harmony and improvisation over static key centers
column13: while the emergence of 1950s-era free jazz has opened up a much wider variety of styles of jazz improvisation
column14: such as ""free blowing""
column15: in which the soloists improvise freely and ignore the chord changes."~0.33903068583381823

column2: on October 21

column1: 157~3~Jelly Roll Blues~26518~26534~"""Original Jelly Roll Blues""
column2: usually shortened to and known as ""Jelly Roll Blues""
column3: is an early jazz fox-trot composed by Jelly Roll Morton. He recorded it first as a piano solo in Richmond
column4: Indiana
column6: and then with his Red Hot Peppers in Chicago two years later
column7: titled as it was originally copyrighted: ""Original Jelly-Roll Blues"". It is referenced by name in the 1917 Shelton Brooks composition ""Darktown Strutters' Ball"".

column1: The Red Hot Peppers version is a typical New Orleans jazz presentation where the trumpet
column2: clarinet and trombone play lead melody and counterpoint
column3: with the piano
column4: guitar
column5: string bass and drums providing the rhythmic accompaniment. However
column6: Morton varies and enriches this basic structure by providing many instrumental breaks in suspended rhythm
column7: as well as giving the horns and the piano solo passages. The final chorus is in New Orleans ""ride-out"" style
column8: where all the instruments play together and vary the melody and chord progression in counterpoint over a driving
column9: climactic rhythm. The tune is also notable for having an Argentine tango-like rhythm and flavor in several passages
column10: which Morton claimed was essential to real jazz. Although this tango flavoring did not survive into later jazz
column11: it is noteworthy in the mixture of international cultural influences that produced New Orleans jazz
column12: and this recording is a prime example of it. In this record and several other Morton recordings of 1926-7
column13: the New Orleans early jazz style
column14: as a collective blend of instruments varying the basic melody by means of both composed
column15: written notes and improvisation
column16: reached its peak of artistic development."~0.48032264544128

column1: 158~3~Jelly Roll Morton~17838~17855~"Ferdinand Joseph LaMothe (October 20
column4: known professionally as Jelly Roll Morton
column5: was an American ragtime and early jazz pianist
column6: bandleader and composer who started his career in New Orleans
column7: Louisiana.

column1: Widely recognized as a pivotal figure in early jazz
column2: Morton is perhaps most notable as jazz's first arranger
column3: proving that a genre rooted in improvisation could retain its essential spirit and characteristics when notated. His composition ""Jelly Roll Blues""
column4: published in 1915
column5: was the first published jazz composition. Morton also wrote the standards ""King Porter Stomp""
column6: ""Wolverine Blues""
column7: ""Black Bottom Stomp""
column8: and ""I Thought I Heard Buddy Bolden Say""
column9: the last a tribute to New Orleans musicians from the turn of the 20th century.

column1: Morton's claim to have invented jazz in 1902 aroused resentment. The jazz historian
column2: musician
column3: and composer Gunther Schuller says of Morton's ""hyperbolic assertions"" that there is ""no proof to the contrary"" and that Morton's ""considerable accomplishments in themselves provide reasonable substantiation"". Alan Lomax
column4: who recorded extensive biographical interviews of Morton at the Library of Congress in 1938
column5: did not agree that Morton was an egoist:

column1: In being called a supreme egotist
column2: Jelly Roll was often a victim of loose and lurid reporting. If we read the words that he himself wrote
column3: we learn that he almost had an inferiority complex and said that he created his own style of jazz piano because ""All my fellow musicians were much faster in manipulations
column4: I thought than I
column5: and I did not feel as though I was in their class."" So he used a slower tempo to permit flexibility through the use of more notes
column6: a pinch of Spanish to give a number of right seasoning
column7: the avoidance of playing triple forte continuously
column8: and many other points"". --Quoted in John Szwed

column1: 159~3~Jimi Hendrix~73288~73300~"James Marshall ""Jimi"" Hendrix (born Johnny Allen Hendrix; November 27
column2: 1942 – September 18
column3: 1970) was an American rock guitarist
column4: singer
column5: and songwriter. Although his mainstream career spanned only four years
column6: he is widely regarded as one of the most influential electric guitarists in the history of popular music
column7: and one of the most celebrated musicians of the 20th century. The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame describes him as ""arguably the greatest instrumentalist in the history of rock music"".

column1: Born in Seattle
column2: Washington
column3: Hendrix began playing guitar at the age of 15. In 1961
column4: he enlisted in the U.S. Army and trained as a paratrooper in the 101st Airborne Division; he was granted an honorable discharge the following year. Soon afterward
column5: he moved to Clarksville
column6: Tennessee
column7: and began playing gigs on the Chitlin' Circuit
column8: earning a place in the Isley Brothers' backing band and later with Little Richard
column9: with whom he continued to work through mid-1965. He then played with Curtis Knight and the Squires before moving to England in late 1966 after being discovered by Linda Keith
column10: who in turn interested bassist Chas Chandler of the Animals in becoming his first manager. Within months
column11: Hendrix had earned three UK top ten hits with the Jimi Hendrix Experience: ""Hey Joe""
column12: ""Purple Haze""
column13: and ""The Wind Cries Mary"". He achieved fame in the U.S. after his performance at the Monterey Pop Festival in 1967
column14: and in 1968 his third and final studio album
column15: Electric Ladyland
column16: reached number one in the U.S.; it was Hendrix's most commercially successful release and his first and only number one album. The world's highest-paid performer
column17: he headlined the Woodstock Festival in 1969 and the Isle of Wight Festival in 1970
column18: before his accidental death from barbiturate-related asphyxia on September 18

column1: Hendrix was inspired musically by American rock and roll and electric blues. He favored overdriven amplifiers with high volume and gain
column2: and was instrumental in utilizing the previously undesirable sounds caused by guitar amplifier feedback. He helped to popularize the use of a wah-wah pedal in mainstream rock
column3: and was the first artist to use stereophonic phasing effects in music recordings. Holly George-Warren of Rolling Stone commented: ""Hendrix pioneered the use of the instrument as an electronic sound source. Players before him had experimented with feedback and distortion
column4: but Hendrix turned those effects and others into a controlled
column5: fluid vocabulary every bit as personal as the blues with which he began.""

column1: Hendrix was the recipient of several music awards during his lifetime and posthumously. In 1967
column2: readers of Melody Maker voted him the Pop Musician of the Year
column3: and in 1968
column4: Rolling Stone declared him the Performer of the Year. Disc and Music Echo honored him with the World Top Musician of 1969 and in 1970
column5: Guitar Player named him the Rock Guitarist of the Year. The Jimi Hendrix Experience was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1992 and the UK Music Hall of Fame in 2005. Rolling Stone ranked the band's three studio albums
column6: Are You Experienced
column7: Axis: Bold as Love
column8: and Electric Ladyland
column9: among the 100 greatest albums of all time
column10: and they ranked Hendrix as the greatest guitarist and the sixth greatest artist of all time."~0.4346147027043544

column1: 162~3~Joe Venuti~32380~32390~"Giuseppe ""Joe"" Venuti (possibly September 16
column2: 1903 – August 14
column3: 1978) was an Italian-American jazz musician and pioneer jazz violinist.

column1: Considered the father of jazz violin
column2: he pioneered the use of string instruments in jazz along with the guitarist Eddie Lang
column3: a friend since childhood. Through the 1920s and early 1930s
column4: Venuti and Lang made many recordings
column5: as leader and as featured soloists. He and Lang became so well known for their 'hot' violin and guitar solos that on many commercial dance recordings they were hired to do 12- or 24-bar duos towards the end of otherwise stock dance arrangements. In 1926
column6: Venuti and Lang started recording for the OKeh label as a duet (after a solitary duet issued on Columbia)
column7: followed by ""Blue Four"" combinations
column8: which are considered milestone jazz recordings. Venuti also recorded commercial dance records for OKeh under the name ""New Yorkers"".

column1: He worked with Benny Goodman
column2: Adrian Rollini
column3: the Dorsey Brothers
column4: Bing Crosby
column5: Bix Beiderbecke
column6: Jack Teagarden
column7: Frank Signorelli
column8: the Boswell Sisters
column9: and most of the other important white jazz and semi-jazz figures of the late 1920s and early 1930s. However
column10: following Lang's death in 1933
column11: Venuti's career began to wane
column12: though he continued performing through the 1930s
column13: recording a series of commercial dance records (usually containing a Venuti violin solo) for the dime store labels
column14: OKeh and Columbia
column15: as well as the occasional jazz small group sessions. He was also a strong early influence on western swing players like Cecil Brower. (Many of the 1920s OKeh sides continued to sell through 1935

column1: After a period of relative obscurity in the 1940s and 1950s
column2: Venuti played violin and other instruments with Jack Statham at the Desert Inn Hotel in Las Vegas. Statham headed several musical groups that played at the Desert Inn from late 1961 until 1965
column3: including a Dixieland combo. Venuti was with him during that time

column1: 177~3~Latin America~61063~61076~"Latin America is a group of countries and dependencies in the Western Hemisphere where Spanish

column2: including the Caribbean. It has an area of approximately 19
column6: 000 sq mi)

column9: Latin America had a combined nominal GDP of 5

column1: The term ""Latin America"" was first used in an 1856 conference with the title ""Initiative of the America. Idea for a Federal Congress of Republics"" (Iniciativa de la América. Idea de un Congreso Federal de las Repúblicas)

column1: 178~3~Legato~86873~86879~"In music performance and notation
column2: legato [leˈɡaːto] (Italian for ""tied together""; French lié; German gebunden) indicates that musical notes are played or sung smoothly and connected. That is
column3: the player makes a transition from note to note with no intervening silence. Legato technique is required for slurred performance
column4: but unlike slurring (as that term is interpreted for some instruments)
column5: legato does not forbid rearticulation. Standard notation indicates legato either with the word legato
column6: or by a slur (a curved line) under notes that form one legato group. Legato
column7: like staccato
column8: is a kind of articulation. There is an intermediate articulation called either mezzo staccato or non-legato (sometimes referred to as ""portato"")."~0.1434146000687749

column1: 195~3~Minstrel show~18285~18299~"The minstrel show
column2: or minstrelsy
column3: was an American form of entertainment developed in the early 19th century. Each show consisted of comic skits
column4: variety acts
column5: dancing
column6: and music performances that mocked people specifically of African descent. The shows were performed by Caucasians in make-up or blackface for the purpose of playing the role of black people. There were also some African-American performers and all-black minstrel groups that formed and toured under the direction of white people.

column1: Minstrel shows lampooned black people as dim-witted
column2: lazy
column3: buffoonish
column4: superstitious
column5: and happy-go-lucky.

column1: Minstrel shows emerged as brief burlesques and comic entr'actes in the early 1830s in the Northeastern states. They were developed into full-fledged form in the next decade. By 1848
column2: blackface minstrel shows were the national artform
column3: translating formal art such as opera into popular terms for a general audience.

column1: By the turn of the 20th century
column2: the minstrel show enjoyed but a shadow of its former popularity
column3: having been replaced for the most part by vaudeville. The form survived as professional entertainment until about 1910; amateur performances continued until the 1960s in high schools and local theaters. The genre has had a lasting legacy and influence and was featured in a television series as recently as the late 1970s. Generally
column4: as the civil rights movement progressed and gained acceptance
column5: minstrels lost popularity.

column1: The typical minstrel performance followed a three-act structure. The troupe first danced onto stage then exchanged wisecracks and sang songs. The second part featured a variety of entertainments
column2: including the pun-filled stump speech. The final act consisted of a slapstick musical plantation skit or a send-up of a popular play.

column1: Minstrel songs and sketches featured several stock characters
column2: most popularly the slave and the dandy. These were further divided into sub-archetypes such as the mammy
column3: her counterpart the old darky
column4: the provocative mulatto wench
column5: and the black soldier. Minstrels claimed that their songs and dances were authentically black
column6: although the extent of the black influence remains debated. Spirituals (known as jubilees) entered the repertoire in the 1870s
column7: marking the first undeniably black music to be used in minstrelsy.

column1: Blackface minstrelsy was the first theatrical form that was distinctly American. During the 1830s and 1840s at the height of its popularity
column2: it was at the epicenter of the American music industry. For several decades it provided the means through which American whites viewed black people. On the one hand
column3: it had strong racist aspects; on the other
column4: it afforded white Americans a singular and broad awareness of what some whites considered significant aspects of black culture in America.

column1: Although the minstrel shows were extremely popular
column2: being ""consistently packed with families from all walks of life and every ethnic group""
column3: they were also controversial. Integrationists decried them as falsely showing happy slaves while at the same time making fun of them; segregationists thought such shows were ""disrespectful"" of social norms as they portrayed runaway slaves with sympathy and would undermine the southerners' ""peculiar institution""."~0.42824667997184623

column1: 209~3~Ostinato~48583~48592~"In music
column2: an ostinato [ostiˈnaːto] (derived from Italian: stubborn

column1: 214~3~Piano~2198~2203~"The piano is an acoustic
column2: stringed musical instrument invented in Italy by Bartolomeo Cristofori around the year 1700 (the exact year is uncertain)
column3: in which the strings are struck by hammers. It is played using a keyboard
column4: which is a row of keys (small levers) that the performer presses down or strikes with the fingers and thumbs of both hands to cause the hammers to strike the strings. The word piano is a shortened form of pianoforte

column6: which in turn derives from gravicembalo col piano e forte and fortepiano. The Italian musical terms piano and forte indicate ""soft"" and ""loud"" respectively
column7: in this context referring to the variations in volume (i.e.
column8: loudness) produced in response to a pianist's touch or pressure on the keys: the greater the velocity of a key press
column9: the greater the force of the hammer hitting the strings
column10: and the louder the sound of the note produced and the stronger the attack. The first fortepianos in the 1700s had a quieter sound and smaller dynamic range.

column1: An acoustic piano usually has a protective wooden case surrounding the soundboard and metal strings
column2: which are strung under great tension on a heavy metal frame. Pressing one or more keys on the piano's keyboard causes a padded hammer (typically padded with firm felt) to strike the strings. The hammer rebounds from the strings
column3: and the strings continue to vibrate at their resonant frequency. These vibrations are transmitted through a bridge to a soundboard that amplifies by more efficiently coupling the acoustic energy to the air. When the key is released
column4: a damper stops the strings' vibration
column5: ending the sound. Notes can be sustained
column6: even when the keys are released by the fingers and thumbs
column7: by the use of pedals at the base of the instrument. The sustain pedal enables pianists to play musical passages that would otherwise be impossible
column8: such as sounding a 10-note chord in the lower register and then
column9: while this chord is being continued with the sustain pedal
column10: shifting both hands to the treble range to play a melody and arpeggios over the top of this sustained chord. Unlike the pipe organ and harpsichord
column11: two major keyboard instruments widely used before the piano
column12: the piano allows gradations of volume and tone according to how forcefully a performer presses or strikes the keys.

column5: F

column11: G♯/A♭
column12: A♯/B♭

column14: and D♯/E♭)

column21: pianos are considered chordophones. There are two main types of piano: the grand piano and the upright piano. The grand piano is used for Classical solos

column27: as it is a better size for use in private homes for domestic music-making and practice.

column1: 229~3~Saxophone~2184~2193~"The saxophone (also referred to as the sax) is a family of woodwind instruments. Saxophones are usually made of brass and played with a single-reed mouthpiece similar to that of the clarinet. Like the clarinet

column1: The saxophone family was invented by the Belgian instrument maker Adolphe Sax in 1840. Adolphe Sax wanted to create a group or series of instruments that would be the most powerful and vocal of the woodwinds

column5: in two groups of seven instruments each. Each series consisted of instruments of various sizes in alternating transposition. The series pitched in B♭ and E♭

column7: have proved popular and most saxophones encountered today are from this series. Instruments from the so-called ""orchestral"" series
column8: pitched in C and F
column9: never gained a foothold
column10: and the B♭ and E♭ instruments have now replaced the C and F instruments when the saxophone is used in an orchestra.

233~3~Slavery~18012~18019~Slavery is any system in which principles of property law are applied to people

column5: de jure slavery. In a broader sense

column3: capture
column4: or purchase.

column1: While slavery was institutionally recognized by most societies

column1: 241~3~Syncopation~19247~19259~"In music

The correlation of at least two sets of time intervals. Also known as an ""Uneven movement from bar to bar"".

column1: Syncopation can also occur when a strong harmony is placed on a weak beat

column1: A hemiola can also be seen as one straight bar in 3 with one long chord and one short chord and a syncope in the bar thereafter

column4: and as such a strong harmony on a weak beat

column2: timbre ( TAM-bər
column3: also known as tone color or tone quality from psychoacoustics) is the perceived sound quality of a musical note
column4: sound or tone. Timbre distinguishes different types of sound production
column5: such as choir voices and musical instruments
column6: such as string instruments
column7: wind instruments
column8: and percussion instruments. It also enables listeners to distinguish different instruments in the same category (e.g. an oboe and a clarinet).

column1: The physical characteristics of sound that determine the perception of timbre include spectrum and envelope. Singers and instrumental musicians can change the timbre of the music they are singing/playing by using different singing or playing techniques. For example
column2: a violinist can use different bowing styles or play on different parts of the string to obtain different timbres (e.g.
column3: playing sul tasto produces a light
column4: airy timbre
column5: whereas playing sul ponticello produces a harsh
column6: even and aggressive tone). On electric guitar and electric piano
column7: performers can change the timbre using effects units and graphic equalizers.

column1: In simple terms
column2: timbre is what makes a particular musical sound have a different sound from another
column3: even when they have the same pitch and loudness. For instance
column4: it is the difference in sound between a guitar and a piano playing the same note at the same volume. Both instruments can sound equally tuned in relation to each other as they play the same note
column5: and while playing at the same amplitude level each instrument will still sound distinctively with its own unique tone color. Experienced musicians are able to distinguish between different instruments of the same type based on their varied timbres
column6: even if those instruments are playing notes at the same pitch and loudness."~0.3497281011247419

column1: 252~3~Tritone~42096~42103~"In music theory
column2: the tritone is defined as a musical interval composed of three adjacent whole tones. For instance
column3: the interval from F up to the B above it (in short
column4: F–B) is a tritone as it can be decomposed into the three adjacent whole tones F–G
column5: G–A
column6: and A–B. According to this definition
column7: within a diatonic scale there is only one tritone for each octave. For instance
column8: the above-mentioned interval F–B is the only tritone formed from the notes of the C major scale. A tritone is also commonly defined as an interval spanning six semitones. According to this definition
column9: a diatonic scale contains two tritones for each octave. For instance
column10: the above-mentioned C major scale contains the tritones F–B (from F to the B above it
column11: also called augmented fourth) and B–F (from B to the F above it
column12: also called diminished fifth
column13: semidiapente
column14: or semitritonus). In twelve-equal temperament
column15: the tritone divides the octave exactly in half.

column1: In classical music
column2: the tritone is a harmonic and melodic dissonance and is important in the study of musical harmony. The tritone can be used to avoid traditional tonality: ""Any tendency for a tonality to emerge may be avoided by introducing a note three whole tones distant from the key note of that tonality."" Contrarily
column3: the tritone found in the dominant seventh chord helps establish the tonality of a composition. These contrasting uses exhibit the flexibility
column4: ubiquity
column5: and distinctness of the tritone in music.

column1: The condition of having tritones is called tritonia; that of having no tritones is atritonia. A musical scale or chord containing tritones is called tritonic; one without tritones is atritonic."~0.35103032478790863

column1: 254~3~USO~10005~10008~"The United Service Organizations Inc. (USO) is a nonprofit organization that provides live entertainment

column6: goods

column1: During World War II

column6: USOs were sometimes located in combat zones.

column1: 262~3~Whiteness studies~8497~8506~"Whiteness studies is an interdisciplinary arena of inquiry that has developed beginning in the United States
column2: particularly since the late 20th century
column3: and is focused on what proponents describe as the cultural
column4: historical and sociological aspects of people identified as white
column5: and the social construction of ""whiteness"" as an ideology tied to social status. Pioneers in the field include W. E. B. Du Bois (""Jefferson Davis as a Representative of Civilization""
column6: 1890; Darkwater
column8: James Baldwin (The Fire Next Time
column10: Theodore W. Allen (The Invention of the White Race
column12: expanded in 1995)
column13: Ruth Frankenberg (White Women
column14: Race Matters: The Social Construction of Whiteness
column16: author and literary critic Toni Morrison (Playing in the Dark: Whiteness and the Literary Imagination
column17: 1992) and historian David Roediger (The Wages of Whiteness
column19: numerous works across many disciplines analyzed whiteness
column20: and it has since become a topic for academic courses
column21: research and anthologies.

column1: A central tenet of whiteness studies is a reading of history and its effects on the present
column2: inspired by postmodernism and historicism
column3: in which the very concept of racial superiority is said to have been socially constructed in order to justify discrimination against non-whites. Since the 19th century
column4: some writers have argued that the phenotypical significances attributed to specific races are without biological association
column5: and that race is therefore not a valid biological concept. Many scientists have demonstrated that racial theories are based upon an arbitrary clustering of phenotypical categories and customs
column6: and can overlook the problem of gradations between categories. Thomas K. Nakayama and Robert L. Krizek write about whiteness as a ""strategic rhetoric
column7: asserting
column8: in the essay ""Whiteness: A Strategic Rhetoric""
column9: that whiteness is a product of ""discursive formation"" and a ""rhetorical construction"". Nakayama and Krizek write
column10: ""there is no 'true essence' to 'whiteness': there are only historically contingent constructions of that social location."" Nakayama and Krizek also suggest that by naming whiteness
column11: one calls out its centrality and reveals its invisible
column12: central position. Whiteness is considered normal and neutral
column13: therefore
column14: to name whiteness means that one identifies whiteness as a rhetorical construction which can be dissected to unearth its values and beliefs.

column1: Major areas of research in whiteness studies include the nature of white privilege and white identity
column2: the historical process by which a white racial identity was created
column3: the relation of culture to white identity
column4: and possible processes of social change as they affect white identity."~0.17857943054779502

column1: 265~4~Abdominal~2331~2340~The abdomen (less formally called the belly
column2: stomach
column3: tummy or midriff) constitutes the part of the body between the thorax (chest) and pelvis
column4: in humans and in other vertebrates. The region occupied by the abdomen is termed the abdominal cavity. In arthropods it is the posterior tagma of the body; it follows the thorax or cephalothorax. The abdomen stretches from the thorax at the thoracic diaphragm to the pelvis at the pelvic brim. The pelvic brim stretches from the lumbosacral joint (the intervertebral disc between L5 and S1) to the pubic symphysis and is the edge of the pelvic inlet. The space above this inlet and under the thoracic diaphragm is termed the abdominal cavity. The boundary of the abdominal cavity is the abdominal wall in the front and the peritoneal surface at the rear.~0.15677028087752412

column1: 266~4~Accompaniment~47~51~"Accompaniment is the musical parts which provide the rhythmic and/or harmonic support for the melody or main themes of a song or instrumental piece. There are many different styles and types of accompaniment in different genres and styles of music. In homophonic music
column2: the main accompaniment approach used in popular music
column3: a clear vocal melody is supported by subordinate chords. In popular music and traditional music
column4: the accompaniment parts typically provide the ""beat"" for the music and outline the chord progression of the song or instrumental piece. The accompaniment for a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be played by a single musician playing an instrument such as piano
column5: pipe organ
column6: or guitar. While any instrument can in theory be used as an accompaniment instrument
column7: keyboard and guitar-family instruments tend to be used if there is only a single instrument
column8: as these instruments can play chords and basslines simultaneously (chords and a bassline are easier to play simultaneously on keyboard instruments
column9: but a fingerpicking guitarist can play chords and a bassline simultaneously on guitar). A solo singer can accompany herself by playing guitar or piano while she sings
column10: and in some rare cases
column11: a solo singer can even accompany himself or herself just using his or her voice and body (e.g.
column12: Bobby McFerrin).

column1: Alternatively
column2: the accompaniment to a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be provided by a musical ensemble
column3: ranging in size from a duo (e.g.
column4: cello and piano; guitar and double bass; synthesizer and percussion); a trio (e.g.
column5: a rock power trio of electric guitar
column6: electric bass and drum kit; an organ trio); a quartet (e.g.
column7: a string quartet in Classical music can accompany a solo singer; a rock band or rhythm section in rock and pop; a jazz quartet in jazz); all the way to larger ensembles
column8: such as concert bands
column9: Big Bands (in jazz)
column10: pit orchestras in musical theatre; and orchestras
column11: which
column12: in addition to playing symphonies
column13: can also provide accompaniment to a concerto solo instrumentalist or to solo singers in opera. With choral music
column14: the accompaniment to a vocal solo can be provided by other singers in the choir
column15: who sing harmony parts or countermelodies. Accompaniment parts range from so simple that a beginner can play them (e.g.
column16: simple three-note triad chords in a traditional folk song) to so complex that only an advanced player or singer can perform them (e.g.
column17: the piano parts in Schubert's Lieder art songs from the 19th century or vocal parts from a Renaissance music motet)."~0.33330237851433137

column1: 268~4~Amplifier~1844~1853~"An amplifier
column2: electronic amplifier or (informally) amp is an electronic device that can increase the power of a signal (a time-varying voltage or current). An amplifier uses electric power from a power supply to increase the amplitude of a signal. The amount of amplification provided by an amplifier is measured by its gain: the ratio of output voltage
column3: current
column4: or power to input. An amplifier is a circuit that has a power gain greater than one.

column1: An amplifier can either be a separate piece of equipment or an electrical circuit contained within another device. Amplification is fundamental to modern electronics
column2: and amplifiers are widely used in almost all electronic equipment. Amplifiers can be categorized in different ways. One is by the frequency of the electronic signal being amplified. For example
column3: audio amplifiers amplify signals in the audio (sound) range of less than 20 kHz
column4: RF amplifiers amplify frequencies in the radio frequency range between 20 kHz and 300 GHz
column5: and servo amplifiers and instrumentation amplifiers may work with very low frequencies down to direct current. Amplifiers can also be categorized by their physical placement in the signal chain; a preamplifier may precede other signal processing stages
column6: for example.  The first practical electrical device which could amplify was the triode vacuum tube
column7: invented in 1906 by Lee De Forest
column8: which led to the first amplifiers around 1912.

269~4~Anatomy~14246~14253~Anatomy (Greek anatomē
column2: “dissection”) is the branch of biology concerned with the study of the structure of organisms and their parts. Anatomy is a branch of natural science dealing with the structural organization of living things. It is an old science
column3: having its beginnings in prehistoric times. Anatomy is inherently tied to embryology
column4: comparative anatomy
column5: evolutionary biology
column6: and phylogeny
column7: as these are the processes by which anatomy is generated over immediate (embryology) and long (evolution) timescales. Human anatomy is one of the basic essential sciences of medicine. Anatomy and physiology
column8: which study (respectively) the structure and function of organisms and their parts
column9: make a natural pair of related disciplines
column10: and they are often studied together.

column1: The discipline of anatomy is divided into macroscopic and microscopic anatomy. Macroscopic anatomy
column2: or gross anatomy
column3: is the examination of an animal's body parts using unaided eyesight. Gross anatomy also includes the branch of superficial anatomy. Microscopic anatomy involves the use of optical instruments in the study of the tissues of various structures
column4: known as histology
column5: and also in the study of cells.

column1: The history of anatomy is characterized by a progressive understanding of the functions of the organs and structures of the human body. Methods have also improved dramatically
column2: advancing from the examination of animals by dissection of carcasses and cadavers (corpses) to 20th century medical imaging techniques including X-ray
column3: ultrasound
column4: and magnetic resonance imaging."~0.12152466339356488

column2: or arias in common usage

column5: but not always

column1: 271~4~Audition~30485~30494~"An audition is a sample performance by an actor
column2: singer
column3: musician
column4: dancer or other performer. It typically involves the performer displaying their talent through a previously memorized and rehearsed solo piece or by performing a work or piece given to the performer at the audition or shortly before. In some cases
column5: such as with a model or acrobat
column6: the individual may be asked to demonstrate a range of professional skills. Actors may be asked to present a monologue. Singers will perform a song in a popular music context or an aria in a Classical context. A dancer will present a routine in a specific style
column7: such as ballet
column8: tap dance or hip-hop
column9: or show his or her ability to quickly learn a choreographed dance piece.

column1: The audition is a systematic process in which industry professionals select performers
column2: which is in some ways analogous to a job interview in the regular job market. In an audition
column3: the employer is testing the ability of the applicant to meet the needs of the job and assess how well the individual will take directions and deal with changes. After some auditions
column4: after the performer has demonstrated their abilities in a given performance style
column5: the audition panel may ask a few questions that resemble those used in standard job interviews (e.g.
column6: regarding availability).

column1: Auditions are required for many reasons in the performing arts world. Often
column2: employing companies or groups use auditions to select performers for upcoming shows or productions. An audition for a performing opportunity may be for a single performance (e.g.
column3: doing a monologue at a comedy club)
column4: for a series or season of performances (a season of a Broadway play)
column5: or for permanent employment with the performing organization (e.g.
column6: an orchestra or dance troupe). Auditions for performing opportunities may be for amateur
column7: school
column8: or community organizations
column9: in which case the performers will typically not be paid. As well
column10: auditions are used to select or screen candidates for entry to training programs (ballet school or circus school); university programs (B.Mus
column11: M.Mus
column12: MFA in Theater); performance-related scholarships and grants; or to be considered for representation by a talent agency or individual agent."~0.2537809683984706

column1: 272~4~Ballad~14933~14939~"A ballad  is a form of verse
column2: often a narrative set to music. Ballads derive from the medieval French chanson balladée or ballade
column3: which were originally ""danced songs''. Ballads were particularly characteristic of the popular poetry and song of the British Isles from the later medieval period until the 19th century. They were widely used across Europe
column4: and later in Australia
column5: North Africa
column6: North America and South America. Ballads are often 13 lines with an ABABBCBC form
column7: consisting of couplets (two lines) of rhymed verse
column8: each of 14 syllables. Another common form is ABAB or ABCB repeated
column9: in alternating 8 and 6 syllable lines.

column1: Many ballads were written and sold as single sheet broadsides. The form was often used by poets and composers from the 18th century onwards to produce lyrical ballads. In the later 19th century
column2: the term took on the meaning of a slow form of popular love song and is now often used for any love song
column3: particularly the sentimental ballad of pop or rock."~0.4793839274505184

column1: 273~4~Baritone~11918~11926~A baritone is a type of classical male singing voice whose vocal range lies between the bass and the tenor voice types. It is the most common male voice. Originally from the Greek βαρύτονος (barýtonos)
column2: meaning heavy sounding
column3: music for this voice is typically written in the range from the second F below middle C to the F above middle C (i.e. F2–F4) in choral music
column4: and from the second A below middle C to the A above middle C (A2 to A4) in operatic music
column5: but can be extended at either end. The baritone voice type is generally divided into the baryton-Martin baritone (light baritone)
column6: lyric baritone
column7: Kavalierbariton
column8: Verdi baritone
column9: dramatic baritone
column10: baryton-noble baritone
column11: and the bass-baritone.~0.31495226709847957

column1: 275~4~Bel canto~7804~7813~"Bel canto (Italian for ""beautiful singing"" or ""beautiful song""
column2: pronounced [bɛl ˈkanto])
column3: along with a number of similar constructions (""bellezze del canto""/""bell'arte del canto"")
column4: is a term relating to Italian singing. It has several different meanings and is subject to a wide variety of interpretations.

column1: The words were not associated with a ""school"" of singing until the middle of the 19th century
column2: when writers in the early 1860s used it nostalgically to describe a manner of singing that had begun to wane around 1830. Nonetheless

column1: 276~4~Bellows~1724~1731~"A bellows or pair of bellows is a device constructed to furnish a strong blast of air. The simplest type consists of a flexible bag comprising a pair of rigid boards with handles joined by flexible leather sides enclosing an approximately airtight cavity which can be expanded and contracted by operating the handles
column2: and fitted with a valve allowing air to fill the cavity when expanded
column3: and with a tube through which the air is forced out in a stream when the cavity is compressed. It has many applications
column4: in particular blowing on a fire to supply it with air.

column1: The term ""bellows"" is used by extension for a flexible bag whose volume can be changed by compression or expansion
column2: but not used to deliver air. For example
column3: the light-tight (but not airtight) bag allowing the distance between the lens and film of a folding photographic camera to be varied is called a bellows."~0.15249490652431508

column1: 277~4~Bird~40667~40672~"Birds (Aves) are a group of endothermic vertebrates
column2: characterised by feathers
column3: toothless beaked jaws
column4: the laying of hard-shelled eggs
column5: a high metabolic rate
column6: a four-chambered heart
column7: and a strong yet lightweight skeleton. Birds live worldwide and range in size from the 5 cm (2 in) bee hummingbird to the 2.75 m (9 ft) ostrich. They rank as the world’s most numerically-successful class of tetrapods
column8: with approximately ten thousand living species
column9: more than half of these being passerines
column10: sometimes known as perching birds. Birds have wings which are more or less developed depending on the species; the only known groups without wings are the extinct moa and elephant birds. Wings
column11: which evolved from forelimbs
column12: gave birds the ability to fly
column13: although further evolution has led to the loss of flight in flightless birds
column14: including ratites
column15: penguins
column16: and diverse endemic island species of birds. The digestive and respiratory systems of birds are also uniquely adapted for flight. Some bird species of aquatic environments
column17: particularly seabirds and some waterbirds

column1: The fossil record indicates that birds evolved from earlier feathered dinosaurs within the theropod group
column2: which are traditionally placed within the saurischian dinosaurs; their closest living relatives are the crocodilians. Primitive bird-like dinosaurs that lie outside class Aves proper
column3: in the broader group Avialae
column4: have been found dating back to the mid-Jurassic period
column5: around 170 million years ago. Many of these early ""stem-birds""
column6: such as Archaeopteryx
column7: were not yet capable of fully powered flight
column8: and many retained primitive characteristics like toothy jaws in place of beaks
column9: and long bony tails. DNA-based evidence finds that birds diversified dramatically around the time of the Cretaceous–Palaeogene extinction event 66 million years ago
column10: which killed off the pterosaurs and all the non-avian dinosaur lineages. But birds
column11: especially those in the southern continents
column12: survived this event and then migrated to other parts of the world while diversifying during periods of global cooling. This makes them the sole surviving dinosaurs according to cladistics.

column1: Some birds
column2: especially corvids and parrots
column3: are among the most intelligent animals; several bird species make and use tools
column4: and many social species pass on knowledge across generations
column5: which is considered a form of culture. Many species annually migrate great distances. Birds are social
column6: communicating with visual signals
column7: calls
column8: and bird songs
column9: and participating in such social behaviours as cooperative breeding and hunting
column10: flocking
column11: and mobbing of predators. The vast majority of bird species are socially monogamous (referring to social living arrangement
column12: distinct from genetic monogamy)
column13: usually for one breeding season at a time
column14: sometimes for years
column15: but rarely for life. Other species have breeding systems that are polygynous (arrangement of one male with many females) or
column17: polyandrous (arrangement of one female with many males). Birds produce offspring by laying eggs which are fertilised through sexual reproduction. They are usually laid in a nest and incubated by the parents. Most birds have an extended period of parental care after hatching. Some birds
column19: lay eggs even when not fertilised
column20: though unfertilised eggs do not produce offspring.

column1: Many species of birds are economically important as food for human consumption and raw material in manufacturing
column2: with domesticated and undomesticated birds (poultry and game) being important sources of eggs
column3: meat
column4: and feathers. Songbirds
column5: parrots
column6: and other species are popular as pets. Guano (bird excrement) is harvested for use as a fertiliser. Birds prominently figure throughout human culture. About 120–130 species have become extinct due to human activity since the 17th century
column7: and hundreds more before then. Human activity threatens about 1
column8: 200 bird species with extinction
column9: though efforts are underway to protect them. Recreational birdwatching is an important part of the ecotourism industry."~0.19357048016641204

column1: 278~4~Blues~793~798~"Blues is a music genre and musical form originated by African Americans in the Deep South of the United States around the end of the 19th century. The genre developed from roots in African musical traditions
column2: African-American work songs
column3: spirituals
column4: and the folk music of white Americans of European heritage. Blues incorporated spirituals
column5: work songs
column6: field hollers
column7: shouts
column8: chants
column9: and rhymed simple narrative ballads. The blues form
column10: ubiquitous in jazz
column11: rhythm and blues and rock and roll

column1: Blues as a genre is also characterized by its lyrics
column2: bass lines
column3: and instrumentation. Early traditional blues verses consisted of a single line repeated four times. It was only in the first decades of the 20th century that the most common current structure became standard: the AAB pattern
column4: consisting of a line sung over the four first bars
column5: its repetition over the next four
column6: and then a longer concluding line over the last bars. Early blues frequently took the form of a loose narrative

column1: Many elements

column3: can be traced back to the music of Africa. The origins of the blues are also closely related to the religious music of the Afro-American community
column4: the spirituals. The first appearance of the blues is often dated to after the ending of slavery and
column5: later
column6: the development of juke joints. It is associated with the newly acquired freedom of the former slaves. Chroniclers began to report about blues music at the dawn of the 20th century. The first publication of blues sheet music was in 1908. Blues has since evolved from unaccompanied vocal music and oral traditions of slaves into a wide variety of styles and subgenres. Blues subgenres include country blues
column7: such as Delta blues and Piedmont blues

column1: 279~4~Breathing~15361~15372~"Breathing (or respiration
column2: or ventilation) is the process of moving air into and out of the lungs to facilitate gas exchange with the internal environment
column3: mostly by bringing in oxygen and flushing out carbon dioxide.

column1: All aerobic creatures need oxygen for cellular respiration
column2: which uses the oxygen to break down foods for energy and produces carbon dioxide as a waste product. Breathing
column3: or ""external respiration""
column4: brings air into the lungs where gas exchange takes place in the alveoli through diffusion. The body's circulatory system transports these gasses to and from the cells
column5: where ""cellular respiration"" takes place.

column1: The breathing of all vertebrates with lungs consists of repetitive cycles of inhalation and exhalation through a highly branched system of tubes or airways which lead from the nose to the alveoli. The number of respiratory cycles per minute is the breathing or respiratory rate
column2: and is one of the four primary vital signs of life. Under normal conditions the breathing depth and rate is automatically
column3: and unconsciously
column4: controlled by several homeostatic mechanisms which keep the partial pressures of carbon dioxide and oxygen in the arterial blood constant. Keeping the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the arterial blood unchanged under a wide variety of physiological circumstances
column5: contributes significantly to tight control of the pH of the extracellular fluids (ECF). Over-breathing (hyperventilation) and under-breathing (hypoventilation)
column6: which decrease and increase the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide respectively
column7: cause a rise in the pH of ECF in the first case
column8: and a lowering of the pH in the second. Both cause distressing symptoms.

column1: Breathing has other important functions. It provides a mechanism for speech
column2: laughter and similar expressions of the emotions. It is also used for reflexes such as yawning
column3: coughing and sneezing. Animals that cannot thermoregulate by perspiration
column4: because they lack sufficient sweat glands
column5: may lose heat by evaporation through panting."~0.23499938516430716

column1: 281~4~Chest~594~599~"Chess is a two-player strategy board game played on a chessboard
column2: a checkered gameboard with 64 squares arranged in an 8×8 grid. The game is played by millions of people worldwide. Each player begins with 16 pieces: one king
column3: one queen
column4: two rooks
column5: two knights
column6: two bishops
column7: and eight pawns. Each of the six piece types moves differently
column8: with the most powerful being the queen and the least powerful the pawn. The objective is to checkmate the opponent's king by placing it under an inescapable threat of capture. To this end
column9: a player's pieces are used to attack and capture the opponent's pieces
column10: while supporting each other. In addition to checkmate
column11: the game can be won by voluntary resignation of the opponent
column12: which typically occurs when too much material is lost or checkmate appears inevitable. There are also several ways a game can end in a draw.

column1: Chess is believed to have originated in India sometime before the 7th century. The game was derived from the Indian game chaturanga
column2: which is also the likely ancestor of the Eastern strategy games xiangqi
column3: janggi
column4: and shogi. (A minority view holds that chess originated in China.) Chess reached Europe by the 9th century
column5: due to the Moorish conquest of Spain. The pieces assumed their current powers in Spain in the late 15th century; the rules were standardized in the 19th century.

column1: The first generally recognized World Chess Champion
column2: Wilhelm Steinitz
column3: claimed his title in 1886. Since 1948
column4: the World Championship has been regulated by the Fédération Internationale des Échecs (FIDE)
column5: the game's international governing body. FIDE also awards life-time master titles to skilled players
column6: the highest of which is grandmaster. Many national chess organizations have a title system of their own. FIDE also organizes the Women's World Championship
column7: the World Junior Championship
column8: the World Senior Championship
column9: the Blitz and Rapid World Championships
column10: and the Chess Olympiad
column11: a popular competition among international teams. FIDE is a member of the International Olympic Committee
column12: which can be considered as a recognition of chess as a sport;. Several national sporting bodies (for example the Spanish Consejo Superior de Deportes) also recognize chess as a sport. Chess was included in the 2006 and 2010 Asian Games. There is also a Correspondence Chess World Championship and a World Computer Chess Championship. Online chess has opened amateur and professional competition to a wide and varied group of players.

column1: Since the second half of the 20th century
column2: computers have been programmed to play chess with increasing success
column3: to the point where the strongest personal computers play at a higher level than the best human players. Since the 1990s
column4: computer analysis has contributed significantly to chess theory
column5: particularly in the endgame. The IBM computer Deep Blue was the first machine to overcome a reigning World Chess Champion in a match when it defeated Garry Kasparov in 1997. The rise of strong computer programs (called ""engines"") runnable on hand-held devices has led to increasing concerns about cheating during tournaments.

column1: There are many variants of chess that utilize different rules
column2: pieces
column3: or boards. One of these
column4: Chess960 (originally named ""Fischerandom"")
column5: has gained widespread popularity as well as some FIDE recognition."~0.02688020871493513

column1: 282~4~Choir~406~411~"A choir () (also known as a quire

column1: 284~4~Classical music~10639~10654~"Classical music is art music produced or rooted in the traditions of Western culture
column2: including both liturgical (religious) and secular music. While a more precise term is also used to refer to the period from 1750 to 1820 (the Classical period)
column3: this article is about the broad span of time from before the 6th century AD to the present day
column4: which includes the Classical period and various other periods. The central norms of this tradition became codified between 1550 and 1900
column5: which is known as the common-practice period. The major time divisions of Western art music are as follows:

column1: the ancient music period
column2: before 500 AD

column1: the early music period
column2: which includes

column1: the Medieval (500–1400) including
the ars antiqua (1170–1310)
the ars nova (1310–1377)
the ars subtilior (1360–1420)
the Renaissance (1400–1600) eras.
the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
the common-practice period
column2: which includes

column1: the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
Classical (1750–1820)
Romantic eras (c.1780–1910)
the 20th century (1901–2000) which includes
the modern (1890–1930) that overlaps from the late-19th century
the high modern (1930–present)
impressionism (1875–1925) that also overlaps from the late-19th century
neoclassicism (1920–1950)
column2: predominantly in the inter-war period

column1: the postmodern (1930–present) eras
the experimental (1950–present)
contemporary (1945 or 1975–present)
European art music is largely distinguished from many other non-European classical and some popular musical forms by its system of staff notation
column2: in use since about the 11th century. Western staff notation is used by composers to indicate to the performer the pitches (which form the melodies
column3: basslines and chords)
column4: tempo
column5: metre and rhythms for a piece of music. This can leave less room for practices such as improvisation and ad libitum ornamentation
column6: which are frequently heard in non-European art music and in popular-music styles such as jazz and blues. Another difference is that whereas most popular styles adopt the song (strophic) form or a derivation of this form
column7: classical music has been noted for its development of highly sophisticated forms of instrumental music such as the symphony
column8: concerto
column9: fugue
column10: sonata
column11: and mixed vocal and instrumental styles such as opera
column12: cantata
column13: and mass.

column1: The term ""classical music"" did not appear until the early 19th century
column2: in an attempt to distinctly canonize the period from Johann Sebastian Bach to Ludwig van Beethoven as a golden age. The earliest reference to ""classical music"" recorded by the Oxford English Dictionary is from about 1829."~0.4445589816771897

column1: 289~4~Consonant~1978~1988~"In articulatory phonetics

column1: Since the number of possible sounds in all of the world's languages is much greater than the number of letters in any one alphabet

column1: 290~4~Contralto~11844~11853~A contralto (Italian pronunciation: [konˈtralto]) is a type of classical female singing voice whose vocal range is the lowest female voice type. The contralto's vocal range is fairly rare; similar to

column1: 291~4~Countertenor~11897~11909~"A countertenor (also contra tenor) is a type of classical male singing voice whose vocal range is equivalent to that of the female contralto or mezzo-soprano voice types
column2: generally extending from around G3 to D5 or E5
column3: although a sopranist (a specific kind of countertenor) may match the soprano's range of around C4 to C6. Countertenors often are baritones or tenors at core
column4: but rarely use this vocal range in performance.

column1: The nature of the counter-tenor voice has radically changed throughout musical history
column2: from a modal voice
column3: to a modal and falsetto voice
column4: to the primarily falsetto voice which is denoted by the term today. This is partly because of changes in human physiology
column5: and partly because of fluctuations in pitch.

column1: The term first came into use in England during the mid-17th century
column2: and was in wide use by the late 17th century. However
column3: the use of adult male falsettos in polyphony
column4: commonly in the soprano range
column5: was known in European all-male sacred choirs for some decades previous
column6: as early as the mid-16th century.[1] Modern-day ensembles such as The Tallis Scholars and The Sixteen use of counter-tenors on alto parts in works of this period. There is no evidence that falsetto singing was known in Britain before the early 17th century
column7: when it was occasionally heard on soprano parts.

column2: there was great interest in and renewed popularity of the countertenor voice

column1: 292~4~Country music~25190~25203~"Country music ()
