column1: 293~4~Culture~24048~24056~"Culture () is the social behavior and norms found in human societies. Culture is considered a central concept in anthropology
column2: encompassing the range of phenomena that are transmitted through social learning in human societies. Some aspects of human behavior
column3: social practices such as culture
column4: expressive forms such as art
column5: music
column6: dance
column7: ritual
column8: religion
column9: and technologies such as tool usage
column10: cooking
column11: shelter
column12: and clothing are said to be cultural universals
column13: found in all human societies. The concept of material culture covers the physical expressions of culture
column14: such as technology
column15: architecture and art
column16: whereas the immaterial aspects of culture such as principles of social organization (including practices of political organization and social institutions)
column17: mythology
column19: literature (both written and oral)
column20: and science comprise the intangible cultural heritage of a society.

column1: In the humanities
column2: one sense of culture as an attribute of the individual has been the degree to which they have cultivated a particular level of sophistication in the arts
column3: sciences
column4: education
column5: or manners. The level of cultural sophistication has also sometimes been seen to distinguish civilizations from less complex societies. Such hierarchical perspectives on culture are also found in class-based distinctions between a high culture of the social elite and a low culture
column6: popular culture
column7: or folk culture of the lower classes
column8: distinguished by the stratified access to cultural capital. In common parlance
column9: culture is often used to refer specifically to the symbolic markers used by ethnic groups to distinguish themselves visibly from each other such as body modification
column10: clothing or jewelry. Mass culture refers to the mass-produced and mass mediated forms of consumer culture that emerged in the 20th century. Some schools of philosophy
column11: such as Marxism and critical theory
column12: have argued that culture is often used politically as a tool of the elites to manipulate the lower classes and create a false consciousness
column13: and such perspectives are common in the discipline of cultural studies. In the wider social sciences
column14: the theoretical perspective of cultural materialism holds that human symbolic culture arises from the material conditions of human life
column15: as humans create the conditions for physical survival
column16: and that the basis of culture is found in evolved biological dispositions.

column1: When used as a count noun
column2: a ""culture"" is the set of customs
column3: traditions
column4: and values of a society or community
column5: such as an ethnic group or nation. Culture is the set of knowledge acquired over time. In this sense
column6: multiculturalism values the peaceful coexistence and mutual respect between different cultures inhabiting the same planet. Sometimes ""culture"" is also used to describe specific practices within a subgroup of a society
column7: a subculture (e.g. ""bro culture"")
column8: or a counterculture. Within cultural anthropology
column9: the ideology and analytical stance of cultural relativism holds that cultures cannot easily be objectively ranked or evaluated because any evaluation is necessarily situated within the value system of a given culture. Yet within philosophy
column10: this stance of cultural relativism is undermined and made inapplicable since such value judgement is itself a product of a given culture."~0.2375439691798445

column1: 295~4~Ear~3897~3902~"The ear is the organ of hearing and

column1: 296~4~Easy listening~25205~25219~"Easy listening (sometimes known as mood music) is a popular music genre and radio format that was most popular during the 1950s to 1970s. It is related to middle-of-the-road (MOR) music and encompasses instrumental recordings of standards

column1: 297~4~Fach~11574~11578~"The German Fach system (German pronunciation: [fax]; literally ""compartment"" or ""subject of study""

column1: The Fach system is a convenience for singers and opera houses. It prevents singers from being asked to sing roles which they are incapable of performing. Opera companies keep lists of available singers by Fach so that when they are casting roles for an upcoming production
column2: they do not inadvertently contact performers who would be inappropriate for the part.

column1: 298~4~Falsetto~5838~5846~"Falsetto (Italian pronunciation: [falˈsetto]; Italian diminutive of falso
column2: ""false"") is the vocal register occupying the frequency range just above the modal voice register and overlapping with it by approximately one octave.

column1: It is produced by the vibration of the ligamentous edges of the vocal cords
column2: in whole or in part. Commonly cited in the context of singing
column3: falsetto
column4: a characteristic of phonation by all genders
column5: is also one of four main spoken vocal registers recognized by speech pathology.

column1: The term falsetto is most often used in the context of singing to refer to a type of vocal phonation that enables the singer to sing notes beyond the vocal range of the normal or modal voice. The typical tone of falsetto register or M2
column2: has usually a characteristic breathy and flute-like sound relatively free of overtones—which is more limited than its modal counterpart in both dynamic variation and tone quality. However
column3: William Vennard points out that while most untrained people can sound comparatively ""breathy"" or ""hooty"" when using falsetto production
column4: there are in rarer cases individuals who have developed a much stronger falsetto sound production which has more ""ring"" to it."~0.2693180781110453

column1: 299~4~Filmi~877~882~"Filmi (Hindi: फ़िल्मी संगीत
column2: ""of films"") music soundtracks are produced for India's mainstream motion picture industry and written and performed for Indian cinema. In cinema
column3: music directors make up the main body of composers; the songs are performed by playback singers and the genre represents 72% of the music sales market in India.

Filmi playback singers level of success and appeal is tied to their involvement with film soundtracks of cinema releases with the highest box office ratings.

column1: At the ""Filmi Melody: Song and Dance in Indian Cinema"" archive presentation at UCLA

column1: 300~4~Formant~3797~3813~"A formant
column2: as defined by James Jeans
column3: is a harmonic of a note that is augmented by a resonance. Speech researcher Gunnar Fant defined formants as ""the spectral peaks of the sound spectrum |P(f)|"". In acoustics generally
column4: a very similar definition is widely used: the Acoustical Society of America defines a formant as: ""a range of frequencies [of a complex sound] in which there is an absolute or relative maximum in the sound spectrum"".  In speech science and phonetics
column5: however
column6: a formant is also sometimes used to mean acoustic resonance of the human vocal tract. Thus
column7: in phonetics
column8: formant can mean either a resonance or the spectral maximum that the resonance produces. Formants are often measured as amplitude peaks in the frequency spectrum of the sound
column9: using a spectrogram (in the figure) or a spectrum analyzer and
column10: in the case of the voice
column11: this gives an estimate of the vocal tract resonances. In vowels spoken with a high fundamental frequency
column12: as in a female or child voice
column13: however
column14: the frequency of the resonance may lie between the widely spaced harmonics and hence no corresponding peak is visible.

column1: A room can be said to have formants characteristic of that particular room
column2: due to the way sound reflects from its walls and objects. Room formants of this nature reinforce themselves by emphasizing specific frequencies and absorbing others
column3: as exploited
column4: for example
column5: by Alvin Lucier in his piece I Am Sitting in a Room."~0.21559599081263867

column1: 302~4~Gibbon~40674~40680~"Gibbons are apes in the family Hylobatidae. The family historically contained one genus
column2: but now is split into four genera and 18 species. Gibbons occur in tropical and subtropical rainforests from eastern Bangladesh and northeast India to southern China and Indonesia (including the islands of Sumatra
column3: Borneo
column4: and Java).

column1: Also called the smaller apes or lesser apes
column2: gibbons differ from great apes (chimpanzees
column3: bonobos
column4: gorillas
column5: orangutans
column6: and humans) in being smaller
column7: exhibiting low sexual dimorphism
column8: and not making nests. In certain anatomical details
column9: they superficially more closely resemble monkeys than great apes do
column10: but like all apes
column11: gibbons are tailless. Unlike most of the great apes
column12: gibbons frequently form long-term pair bonds. Their primary mode of locomotion
column13: brachiation
column14: involves swinging from branch to branch for distances up to 15 m (50 ft)
column15: at speeds as high as 55 km/h (34 mph). They can also make leaps up to 8 m (26 ft)
column16: and walk bipedally with their arms raised for balance. They are the fastest and most agile of all tree-dwelling
column17: nonflying mammals.

column1: Depending on species and sex
column2: gibbons' fur coloration varies from dark to light brown shades
column3: and any shade between black and white
column4: though a completely ""white"" gibbon is rare.

column1: Gibbon species include the siamang
column2: the white-handed or lar gibbon
column3: and the hoolock gibbons."~0.08196313545283773

column1: 303~4~Gospel music~740~746~"Gospel music is a genre of Christian music. The creation

column3: sometimes referred to as country gospel music
column4: is a subgenre of gospel music with a country flair. It peaked in popularity in the mid-1990s.

column4: with historical distance

column1: 304~4~Hardcore punk~26486~26499~"Hardcore punk (often abbreviated to hardcore) is a punk rock music genre and subculture that originated in the late 1970s. It is generally faster
column2: harder
column3: and more aggressive than other forms of punk rock. Its roots can be traced to earlier punk scenes in San Francisco and Southern California which arose as a reaction against the still predominant hippie cultural climate of the time. It was also inspired by New York punk rock and early proto-punk. New York punk had a harder-edged sound than its San Francisco counterpart
column4: featuring anti-art expressions of masculine anger
column5: energy and subversive humor. Hardcore punk generally disavows commercialism
column6: the established music industry and ""anything similar to the characteristics of mainstream rock"" and often addresses social and political topics with ""confrontational
column7: politically-charged lyrics"".

column5: New Jersey

column7: Canada and the United Kingdom. Hardcore has spawned the straight edge movement and its associated submovements
column8: hardline and youth crew. Hardcore was heavily involved in the rise of the independent record labels in the 1980s and with the DIY ethics in underground music scenes. It has also influenced various music genres that have experienced widespread commercial success

column10: thrash metal
column11: emo and metalcore.

column6: Brazil
column7: Japan
column8: Europe and the Middle East."~0.39321347426417264

column1: 307~4~Hip hop~25221~25228~"Hip hop or hip-hop is a subculture and art movement developed in the Bronx in New York City during the late 1970s. The origins of the word are often disputed. column5: a rhythmic vocal rhyming style (orality); DJing (and turntablism)

Other elements of hip hop subculture and arts movements beyond the main four are: hip hop culture and historical knowledge of the movement (intellectual/philosophical); beatboxing
column7: a percussive vocal style; street entrepreneurship; hip hop language; and hip hop fashion and style
column8: among others. The fifth element is commonly considered either street knowledge
column9: hip hop fashion or beatboxing however it is often debated.

column1: The Bronx hip hop scene emerged in the mid-1970s from neighborhood block parties thrown by the Ghetto Brothers
column2: a Puerto Rican group that has been described as being a gang
column3: a club
column4: and a music group. Hip hop culture has spread to both urban and suburban communities throughout the United States and subsequently the world. These elements were adapted and developed considerably
column5: particularly as the art forms spread to new continents and merged with local styles in the 1990s and subsequent decades. Even as the movement continues to expand globally and explore myriad styles and art forms
column6: including hip hop theater and hip hop film
column7: the four foundational elements provide coherence and a strong foundation for hip hop culture. Hip hop is simultaneously a new and old phenomenon; the importance of sampling tracks
column8: beats and basslines from old records to the art form means that much of the culture has revolved around the idea of updating classic recordings
column9: attitudes
column10: and experiences for modern audiences. Sampling older culture and reusing it in a new context or a new format is called ""flipping"" in hip hop culture. Hip hop music follows in the footsteps of earlier African-American-rooted musical genres such as blues
column11: jazz
column12: rag-time
column13: funk
column14: and disco to become one of the most practiced genres worldwide. It is the language of urban environments and the youth around the world. According to KRS-One
column15: ""Hip hop is the only place where you see Martin Luther King Jr.'s 'I Have A Dream Speech' in real life"". He also notes that hip hop is beyond something as race

column1: In the 2000s

column1: 308~4~Immune system~32927~32940~"The immune system is a host defense system comprising many biological structures and processes within an organism that protects against disease. To function properly
column2: an immune system must detect a wide variety of agents
column3: known as pathogens
column4: from viruses to parasitic worms
column5: and distinguish them from the organism's own healthy tissue. In many species
column6: the immune system can be classified into subsystems
column7: such as the innate immune system versus the adaptive immune system
column8: or humoral immunity versus cell-mediated immunity. In humans
column9: the blood–brain barrier
column10: blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier
column11: and similar fluid–brain barriers separate the peripheral immune system from the neuroimmune system
column12: which protects the brain.

column1: Pathogens can rapidly evolve and adapt
column2: and thereby avoid detection and neutralization by the immune system; however
column3: multiple defense mechanisms have also evolved to recognize and neutralize pathogens. Even simple unicellular organisms such as bacteria possess a rudimentary immune system in the form of enzymes that protect against bacteriophage infections. Other basic immune mechanisms evolved in ancient eukaryotes and remain in their modern descendants
column4: such as plants and invertebrates. These mechanisms include phagocytosis
column5: antimicrobial peptides called defensins
column6: and the complement system. Jawed vertebrates
column7: including humans
column8: have even more sophisticated defense mechanisms
column9: including the ability to adapt over time to recognize specific pathogens more efficiently. Adaptive (or acquired) immunity creates immunological memory after an initial response to a specific pathogen
column10: leading to an enhanced response to subsequent encounters with that same pathogen. This process of acquired immunity is the basis of vaccination.

column1: Disorders of the immune system can result in autoimmune diseases
column2: inflammatory diseases and cancer. Immunodeficiency occurs when the immune system is less active than normal
column3: resulting in recurring and life-threatening infections. In humans
column4: immunodeficiency can either be the result of a genetic disease such as severe combined immunodeficiency
column5: acquired conditions such as HIV/AIDS
column6: or the use of immunosuppressive medication. In contrast
column7: autoimmunity results from a hyperactive immune system attacking normal tissues as if they were foreign organisms. Common autoimmune diseases include Hashimoto's thyroiditis
column8: rheumatoid arthritis
column9: diabetes mellitus type 1
column10: and systemic lupus erythematosus. Immunology covers the study of all aspects of the immune system."~0.10010660746318337

column2: insurgents and criminals."~0.27587296603885136

column1: 313~4~Learn~3337~3342~"Learning is the process of acquiring new or modifying existing knowledge
column2: behaviors
column3: skills
column4: values
column5: or preferences. The ability to learn is possessed by humans
column6: animals
column7: and some machines
column8: and there is also evidence for some kind of learning in some plants. Some learning is immediate

column10: but much skill and knowledge accumulates from repeated experiences. The changes induced by learning often last a lifetime
column11: and it is hard to distinguish learned material that seems to be ""lost"" from that which cannot be retrieved.

column1: Human learning begins before birth and continues until death as a consequence of ongoing interactions between person and environment. The nature and processes involved in learning are studied in many fields
column2: including educational psychology
column3: neuropsychology
column4: experimental psychology
column5: and pedagogy. Research in such fields has led to the identification of various sorts of learning. For example
column6: learning may occur as a result of habituation
column7: or classical conditioning
column8: operant conditioning or as a result of more complex activities such as play
column9: seen only in relatively intelligent animals. Learning may occur consciously or without conscious awareness. Learning that an aversive event can't be avoided nor escaped may result in a condition called learned helplessness. There is evidence for human behavioral learning prenatally
column10: in which habituation has been observed as early as 32 weeks into gestation
column11: indicating that the central nervous system is sufficiently developed and primed for learning and memory to occur very early on in development.

column1: Play has been approached by several theorists as the first form of learning. Children experiment with the world
column2: learn the rules
column3: and learn to interact through play. Lev Vygotsky agrees that play is pivotal for children's development
column4: since they make meaning of their environment through playing educational games."~0.13395112069101114

column1: 316~4~Linguistics~5384~5395~"Linguistics is the scientific study of language

column1: Linguists traditionally analyse human language by observing an interplay between sound and meaning. Phonetics is the study of speech and non-speech sounds
column2: and delves into their acoustic and articulatory properties. The study of language meaning
column3: on the other hand
column4: deals with how languages encode relations between entities
column5: properties
column6: and other aspects of the world to convey
column7: process
column8: and assign meaning
column9: as well as manage and resolve ambiguity. While the study of semantics typically concerns itself with truth conditions
column10: pragmatics deals with how situational context influences the production of meaning.

column1: Grammar is a system of rules which governs the production and use of utterances in a given language. These rules apply to sound as well as meaning
column2: and include componential subsets of rules
column3: such as those pertaining to phonology (the organisation of phonetic sound systems)
column4: morphology (the formation and composition of words)
column5: and syntax (the formation and composition of phrases and sentences). Modern theories that deal with the principles of grammar are largely based within Noam Chomsky's framework of generative linguistics.

column1: In the early 20th century
column2: Ferdinand de Saussure distinguished between the notions of langue and parole in his formulation of structural linguistics. According to him
column3: parole is the specific utterance of speech
column4: whereas langue refers to an abstract phenomenon that theoretically defines the principles and system of rules that govern a language. This distinction resembles the one made by Noam Chomsky between competence and performance in his theory of transformative or generative grammar. According to Chomsky
column5: competence is an individual's innate capacity and potential for language (like in Saussure's langue)
column6: while performance is the specific way in which it is used by individuals
column7: groups
column8: and communities (i.e.
column9: parole
column10: in Saussurean terms).

column1: The study of parole (which manifests through cultural discourses and dialects) is the domain of sociolinguistics
column2: the sub-discipline that comprises the study of a complex system of linguistic facets within a certain speech community (governed by its own set of grammatical rules and laws). Discourse analysis further examines the structure of texts and conversations emerging out of a speech community's usage of language. This is done through the collection of linguistic data
column3: or through the formal discipline of corpus linguistics
column4: which takes naturally occurring texts and studies the variation of grammatical and other features based on such corpora (or corpus data).

column1: Stylistics also involves the study of written
column2: signed
column3: or spoken discourse through varying speech communities
column4: genres
column5: and editorial or narrative formats in the mass media. In the 1960s
column6: Jacques Derrida
column7: for instance
column8: further distinguished between speech and writing
column9: by proposing that written language be studied as a linguistic medium of communication in itself. Palaeography is therefore the discipline that studies the evolution of written scripts (as signs and symbols) in language. The formal study of language also led to the growth of fields like psycholinguistics
column10: which explores the representation and function of language in the mind; neurolinguistics
column11: which studies language processing in the brain; biolinguistics
column12: which studies the biology and evolution of language; and language acquisition
column13: which investigates how children and adults acquire the knowledge of one or more languages.

column1: Linguistics also deals with the social
column2: cultural
column3: historical and political factors that influence language
column4: through which linguistic and language-based context is often determined. Research on language through the sub-branches of historical and evolutionary linguistics also focus on how languages change and grow
column5: particularly over an extended period of time.

column1: Language documentation combines anthropological inquiry (into the history and culture of language) with linguistic inquiry
column2: in order to describe languages and their grammars. Lexicography involves the documentation of words that form a vocabulary. Such a documentation of a linguistic vocabulary from a particular language is usually compiled in a dictionary. Computational linguistics is concerned with the statistical or rule-based modeling of natural language from a computational perspective. Specific knowledge of language is applied by speakers during the act of translation and interpretation
column3: as well as in language education – the teaching of a second or foreign language. Policy makers work with governments to implement new plans in education and teaching which are based on linguistic research.

column1: Related areas of study also includes the disciplines of semiotics (the study of direct and indirect language through signs and symbols)
column2: literary criticism (the historical and ideological analysis of literature
column3: cinema
column4: art
column5: or published material)
column6: translation (the conversion and documentation of meaning in written/spoken text from one language or dialect onto another)
column7: and speech-language pathology (a corrective method to cure phonetic disabilities and dis-functions at the cognitive level)."~0.20066125014857655

column1: 317~4~Lip~1951~1955~"Lips are a visible body part at the mouth of humans and many animals.

column1: 318~4~Loudness~3122~3130~"In acoustics
column2: loudness is the subjective perception of sound pressure. More formally
column3: it is defined as
column4: ""That attribute of auditory sensation in terms of which sounds can be ordered on a scale extending from quiet to loud."" The relation of physical attributes of sound to perceived loudness consists of physical

column3: such as ITU-R BS.1770 refer to relative loudness of different segments of electronically reproduced sounds
column4: such as for broadcasting and cinema. Others
column5: such as ISO 532A (Stevens loudness

column7: ISO 532B (Zwicker loudness)
column8: DIN 45631 and ASA/ANSI S3.4

column1: 319~4~Lyrics~24497~24503~"Lyrics are words that make up a song usually consisting of verses and choruses. The writer of lyrics is a lyricist. The words to an extended musical composition such as an opera are

column1: 320~4~MIT~5358~5361~"The Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) is a private research university in Cambridge
column2: Massachusetts
column3: United States. Founded in 1861 in response to the increasing industrialization of the United States
column4: MIT adopted a European polytechnic university model and stressed laboratory instruction in applied science and engineering. The Institute is traditionally known for its research and education in the physical sciences and engineering
column5: but more recently in biology
column6: economics

column2: 91 Nobel laureates

column4: and 6 Fields Medalists have been affiliated with MIT as alumni

column8: 45 Rhodes Scholars
column9: 38 MacArthur Fellows
column10: 34 astronauts
column11: 16 Chief Scientists of the U.S. Air Force and 6 Fields Medalists have been affiliated with MIT. The school has a strong entrepreneurial culture and the aggregated revenues of companies founded by MIT alumni would rank as the eleventh-largest economy in the world. MIT is a member of the Association of American Universities (AAU)."~0.2255824054681846

column1: 321~4~Melody~25480~25486~"A melody (""singing
column2: chanting"")
column3: also tune
column4: voice
column5: or line
column6: is a linear succession of musical tones that the listener perceives as a single entity. In its most literal sense

column8: while more figuratively
column9: the term can include successions of other musical elements such as tonal color. It may be considered the foreground to the background accompaniment. A line or part need not be a foreground melody.

column1: Melodies often consist of one or more musical phrases or motifs
column2: and are usually repeated throughout a composition in various forms. Melodies may also be described by their melodic motion or the pitches or the intervals between pitches (predominantly conjunct or disjunct or with further restrictions)
column3: pitch range
column4: tension and release
column5: continuity and coherence
column6: cadence
column7: and shape.

column2: the question of which is the more significant
column3: melody or harmony
column4: is futile. Beyond doubt
column5: the means is subordinate to the end."~0.29527158092639144

column1: 322~4~Microphone~13491~13501~"A microphone
column2: colloquially nicknamed mic or mike ()

column1: Microphones are used in many applications such as telephones
column2: hearing aids
column3: public address systems for concert halls and public events
column4: motion picture production
column5: live and recorded audio engineering
column6: sound recording
column7: two-way radios
column8: megaphones
column9: radio and television broadcasting
column10: and in computers for recording voice
column11: speech recognition
column12: VoIP
column13: and for non-acoustic purposes such as ultrasonic sensors or knock sensors.

column1: Several different types of microphone are in use
column2: which employ different methods to convert the air pressure variations of a sound wave to an electrical signal. The most common are the dynamic microphone

column6: which uses a crystal of piezoelectric material. Microphones typically need to be connected to a preamplifier before the signal can be recorded or reproduced."~0.2198669971116609

column1: 323~4~Milli Vanilli~28006~28019~"Milli Vanilli was a German R&B duo from Munich. The group was founded by Frank Farian in 1988 and consisted of Fab Morvan and Rob Pilatus. The group's debut album Girl You Know It's True achieved international success and earned them a Grammy Award for Best New Artist on 21 February 1990.
Milli Vanilli became one of the most popular pop acts in the late 1980s and early 1990s

column1: 324~4~Music~32~37~"Music is an art form and cultural activity whose medium is sound organized in time. The common elements of music are pitch (which governs melody and harmony)
column2: rhythm (and its associated concepts tempo
column3: meter
column4: and articulation)
column5: dynamics (loudness and softness)
column6: and the sonic qualities of timbre and texture (which are sometimes termed the ""color"" of a musical sound). Different styles or types of music may emphasize
column7: de-emphasize or omit some of these elements. Music is performed with a vast range of instruments and vocal techniques ranging from singing to rapping; there are solely instrumental pieces
column8: solely vocal pieces (such as songs without instrumental accompaniment) and pieces that combine singing and instruments. The word derives from Greek μουσική (mousike; ""art of the Muses""). See glossary of musical terminology.

column1: In its most general form
column2: the activities describing music as an art form or cultural activity include the creation of works of music (songs
column3: tunes
column4: symphonies
column5: and so on)
column6: the criticism of music
column7: the study of the history of music
column8: and the aesthetic examination of music. Ancient Greek and Indian philosophers defined music as tones ordered horizontally as melodies and vertically as harmonies. Common sayings such as ""the harmony of the spheres"" and ""it is music to my ears"" point to the notion that music is often ordered and pleasant to listen to. However
column9: 20th-century composer John Cage thought that any sound can be music

column11: for example
column12: ""There is no noise
column13: only sound.""

column1: The creation
column2: performance
column3: significance

column7: including Beethoven's Grosse Fuge string quartet in 1825
column8: early jazz in the beginning of the 1900s and hardcore punk in the 1980s. There are many types of music
column9: including popular music
column10: traditional music
column11: art music
column12: music written for religious ceremonies and work songs such as chanteys. Music ranges from strictly organized compositions–such as Classical music symphonies from the 1700s and 1800s
column13: through to spontaneously played improvisational music such as jazz
column14: and avant-garde styles of chance-based contemporary music from the 20th and 21st centuries.

column1: Music can be divided into genres (e.g.
column2: country music) and genres can be further divided into subgenres (e.g.
column3: country blues and pop country are two of the many country subgenres)
column4: although the dividing lines and relationships between music genres are often subtle
column5: sometimes open to personal interpretation
column6: and occasionally controversial. For example
column7: it can be hard to draw the line between some early 1980s hard rock and heavy metal. Within the arts
column8: music may be classified as a performing art
column9: a fine art or as an auditory art. Music may be played or sung and heard live at a rock concert or orchestra performance
column10: heard live as part of a dramatic work (a music theater show or opera)
column11: or it may be recorded and listened to on a radio
column12: MP3 player
column13: CD player
column14: smartphone or as film score or TV show.

column1: In many cultures
column2: music is an important part of people's way of life
column3: as it plays a key role in religious rituals
column4: rite of passage ceremonies (e.g.
column5: graduation and marriage)
column6: social activities (e.g.
column7: dancing) and cultural activities ranging from amateur karaoke singing to playing in an amateur funk band or singing in a community choir. People may make music as a hobby
column8: like a teen playing cello in a youth orchestra
column9: or work as a professional musician or singer. The music industry includes the individuals who create new songs and musical pieces (such as songwriters and composers)
column10: individuals who perform music (which include orchestra
column11: jazz band and rock band musicians
column12: singers and conductors)
column13: individuals who record music (music producers and sound engineers)
column14: individuals who organize concert tours
column15: and individuals who sell recordings and sheet music and scores to customers."~0.6595721129565328

column1: 325~4~Musical instrument~324~343~"A musical instrument is an instrument created or adapted to make musical sounds. In principle
column2: any object that produces sound can be considered a musical instrument—it is through purpose that the object becomes a musical instrument. The history of musical instruments dates to the beginnings of human culture. Early musical instruments may have been used for ritual
column3: such as a trumpet to signal success on the hunt
column4: or a drum in a religious ceremony. Cultures eventually developed composition and performance of melodies for entertainment. Musical instruments evolved in step with changing applications.

column1: The date and origin of the first device considered a musical instrument is disputed. The oldest object that some scholars refer to as a musical instrument
column2: a simple flute
column3: dates back as far as 67
column4: 000 years. Some consensus dates early flutes to about 37
column5: 000 years ago. However
column6: most historians believe that determining a specific time of musical instrument invention is impossible due to the subjectivity of the definition and the relative instability of materials used to make them. Many early musical instruments were made from animal skins
column7: bone
column8: wood
column9: and other non-durable materials.

column1: Musical instruments developed independently in many populated regions of the world. However
column2: contact among civilizations caused rapid spread and adaptation of most instruments in places far from their origin. By the Middle Ages
column3: instruments from Mesopotamia were in maritime Southeast Asia
column4: and Europeans played instruments from North Africa. Development in the Americas occurred at a slower pace
column5: but cultures of North
column6: Central
column7: and South America shared musical instruments. By 1400
column8: musical instrument development slowed in many areas and was dominated by the Occident.

column1: Musical instrument classification is a discipline in its own right
column2: and many systems of classification have been used over the years. Instruments can be classified by their effective range
column3: their material composition
column4: their size
column5: etc. However
column6: the most common academic method
column7: Hornbostel-Sachs
column8: uses the means by which they produce sound. The academic study of musical instruments is called organology."~0.329967494360614

column1: 327~4~Musical theater~28501~28516~"Musical theatre is a form of theatrical performance that combines songs
column2: spoken dialogue
column3: acting and dance. The story and emotional content of a musical – humor
column4: pathos
column5: love
column6: anger – are communicated through the words
column7: music
column8: movement and technical aspects of the entertainment as an integrated whole. Although musical theatre overlaps with other theatrical forms like opera and dance
column9: it may be distinguished by the equal importance given to the music as compared with the dialogue
column10: movement and other elements. Since the early 20th century
column11: musical theatre stage works have generally been called
column12: simply
column13: musicals.

column1: Although music has been a part of dramatic presentations since ancient times
column2: modern Western musical theatre emerged during the 19th century
column3: with many structural elements established by the works of Gilbert and Sullivan in Britain and those of Harrigan and Hart in America. These were followed by the numerous Edwardian musical comedies and the musical theatre works of American creators like George M. Cohan. The Princess Theatre musicals and other smart shows like Of Thee I Sing (1931) were artistic steps forward beyond revues and other frothy entertainments of the early 20th century and led to such groundbreaking works as Show Boat (1927) and Oklahoma! (1943). Some of the most famous musicals through the decades that followed include West Side Story (1957)
column4: The Fantasticks (1960)
column5: Hair (1967)
column6: A Chorus Line (1975)
column7: Les Misérables (1985)
column8: The Phantom of the Opera (1986)
column9: Rent (1996)
column10: The Producers (2001)
column11: Wicked (2003) and Hamilton (2015).

column1: Musicals are performed around the world. They may be presented in large venues
column2: such as big-budget Broadway or West End productions in New York City or London. Alternatively
column3: musicals may be staged in smaller fringe theatre
column4: Off-Broadway or regional theatre productions
column5: or on tour. Musicals are often presented by amateur and school groups in churches
column6: schools and other performance spaces. In addition to the United States and Britain
column7: there are vibrant musical theatre scenes in continental Europe
column8: Asia
column9: Australasia
column10: Canada and Latin America."~0.2877066097971359

column1: 328~4~Neck~2960~2964~"The neck is the part of the body

column3: that separates the head from the torso. It contains blood vessels and nerves that supply structures in the head to the body. These in humans include part of the esophagus

column2: the neck is also called by its Latin names

column1: 329~4~Neuroplasticity~39833~39842~"Neuroplasticity
column2: also known as brain plasticity and neural plasticity
column3: is the ability of the brain to change throughout an individual's life
column4: e.g.
column5: brain activity associated with a given function can be transferred to a different location
column6: the proportion of grey matter can change
column7: and synapses may strengthen or weaken over time.

column1: Research in the latter half of the 20th century showed that many aspects of the brain can be altered (or are ""plastic"") even through adulthood. This notion is in contrast with the previous scientific consensus that the brain develops during a critical period in early childhood and then remains relatively unchanged (or ""static"").
Neuroplasticity can be observed at multiple scales
column2: from microscopic changes in individual neurons to larger-scale changes such as cortical remapping in response to injury. Behavior
column3: environmental stimuli
column4: thought
column5: and emotions may also cause neuroplastic change through activity-dependent plasticity
column6: which has significant implications for healthy development
column7: learning
column8: memory
column9: and recovery from brain damage.

column1: At the single cell level
column2: synaptic plasticity refers to changes in the connections between neurons
column3: whereas non-synaptic plasticity refers to changes in their intrinsic excitability.

column1:
~0.11198768265721079
330~4~Onomatopoeia~24638~24650~An onomatopoeia ( ( listen); from the Greek ὀνοματοποιία; ὄνομα for ""name"" and ποιέω for ""I make""
column2: adjectival form: ""onomatopoeic"" or ""onomatopoetic"") is a word that phonetically imitates
column3: resembles or suggests the sound that it describes. As an uncountable noun
column4: onomatopoeia refers to the property of such words. Common occurrences of onomatopoeia include animal noises such as ""oink""
column5: ""miaow"" (or ""meow"")
column6: ""roar"" and ""chirp"". Onomatopoeia can differ between languages: it conforms to some extent to the broader linguistic system; hence the sound of a clock may be expressed as tick tock in English
column7: tictac in Spanish
column8: dī dā in Mandarin
column9: or katchin katchin in Japanese
column10: or ""tik-tik"" in Hindi.

column1: Although in the English language the term onomatopoeia means ""the imitation of a sound""
column2: the compound word onomatopoeia (ὀνοματοποιία) in the Greek language means ""making or creating names"". For words that imitate sounds
column3: the term ὴχομιμητικό (echomimetico) or echomimetic) is used. ὴχομιμητικό (echomimetico) derives from ὴχώ
column4: meaning echo or sound
column5: and μιμητικό
column6: meaning mimetic or imitation."~0.3480875785264361

column1: 331~4~Opera~666~671~"Opera (Italian: [ˈɔːpera]; English plural: operas; Italian plural: opere [ˈɔːpere]) is an art form in which singers and musicians perform a dramatic work combining text (libretto) and musical score
column2: usually in a theatrical setting. In traditional opera
column3: singers do two types of singing: recitative
column4: a speech-inflected style and arias
column5: a more melodic style
column6: in which notes are sung in a sustained fashion. Opera incorporates many of the elements of spoken theatre
column7: such as acting
column8: scenery
column9: and costumes and sometimes includes dance. The performance is typically given in an opera house
column10: accompanied by an orchestra or smaller musical ensemble
column11: which since the early 19th century has been led by a conductor.

column1: Opera is a key part of the Western classical music tradition. It started in Italy at the end of the 16th century (with Jacopo Peri's mostly lost Dafne
column2: produced in Florence in 1598) and soon spread through the rest of Europe: Heinrich Schütz in Germany
column3: Jean-Baptiste Lully in France
column4: and Henry Purcell in England all helped to establish their national traditions in the 17th century. In the 18th century
column5: Italian opera continued to dominate most of Europe (except France)
column6: attracting foreign composers such as George Frideric Handel. Opera seria was the most prestigious form of Italian opera
column7: until Christoph Willibald Gluck reacted against its artificiality with his ""reform"" operas in the 1760s. The most renowned figure of late 18th-century opera is Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
column8: who began with opera seria but is most famous for his Italian comic operas
column9: especially The Marriage of Figaro (Le nozze di Figaro)
column10: Don Giovanni
column11: and Così fan tutte
column12: as well as Die Entführung aus dem Serail (The Abduction from the Seraglio)
column13: and The Magic Flute (Die Zauberflöte)
column14: landmarks in the German tradition.

column1: The first third of the 19th century saw the high point of the bel canto style
column2: with Gioachino Rossini
column3: Gaetano Donizetti and Vincenzo Bellini all creating works that are still performed. It also saw the advent of Grand Opera typified by the works of Auber and Meyerbeer. The mid-to-late 19th century was a ""golden age"" of opera
column4: led and dominated by Giuseppe Verdi in Italy and Richard Wagner in Germany. The popularity of opera continued through the verismo era in Italy and contemporary French opera through to Giacomo Puccini and Richard Strauss in the early 20th century. During the 19th century
column5: parallel operatic traditions emerged in central and eastern Europe
column6: particularly in Russia and Bohemia. The 20th century saw many experiments with modern styles
column7: such as atonality and serialism (Arnold Schoenberg and Alban Berg)
column8: Neoclassicism (Igor Stravinsky)
column9: and Minimalism (Philip Glass and John Adams). With the rise of recording technology
column10: singers such as Enrico Caruso and Maria Callas became known to much wider audiences that went beyond the circle of opera fans. Since the invention of radio and television
column11: operas were also performed on (and written for) these mediums. Beginning in 2006
column12: a number of major opera houses began to present live high-definition video transmissions of their performances in cinemas all over the world. Since 2009
column13: complete performances can be downloaded and are live streamed."~0.2891870280518801

column1: 332~4~Palate~1932~1938~The palate  is the roof of the mouth in humans and other mammals. It separates the oral cavity from the nasal cavity. A similar structure is found in crocodilians

column1: 333~4~Phonetics~9782~9791~"Phonetics (pronounced ) is a branch of linguistics that studies the sounds of human speech
column2: or—in the case of sign languages—the equivalent aspects of sign. It is concerned with the physical properties of speech sounds or signs (phones): their physiological production

column1: In the case of oral languages
column2: phonetics has three basic areas of study:

column1: Articulatory phonetics: the study of the organs of speech and their use in producing speech sounds by the speaker.
Acoustic phonetics: the study of the physical transmission of speech sounds from the speaker to the listener.
Auditory phonetics: the study of the reception and perception of speech sounds by the listener."~0.23310724782994602
334~4~Rapping~26030~26037~"Rapping (or rhyming
column2: spitting

column11: and ""delivery"" (cadence

column2: most broadly

column1: 342~4~Speech~83~89~"Speech is the vocalized form of communication used by humans and some animals
column2: which is based upon the syntactic combination of items drawn from the lexicon. Each spoken word is created out of the phonetic combination of a limited set of vowel and consonant speech sound units (phonemes). These vocabularies
column3: the syntax that structures them
column4: and their sets of speech sound units differ
column5: creating many thousands of different
column6: and mutually unintelligible
column7: human languages. The vocal abilities that enable humans to produce speech also enable them to sing.

column1: A gestural form of human communication exists for the deaf in the form of sign language. Speech in some cultures has become the basis of written language
column2: often one that differs in its vocabulary
column3: syntax and phonetics from its associated spoken one
column4: a situation called diglossia. In addition to its use in communication
column5: it is suggested by some psychologists such as Lev Vygotsky that speech is internally used in mental processes to enhance and organize cognition in the form of an interior monologue.

column1: Speech is researched in terms of the speech production and speech perception of the sounds used in vocal language. Other research topics concern speech repetition
column2: the ability to map heard spoken words into the vocalizations needed to recreate them
column3: which plays a key role in vocabulary expansion in children and speech errors. Several academic disciplines study these; including acoustics
column4: psychology
column5: speech pathology
column6: linguistics
column7: cognitive science
column8: communication studies
column9: otolaryngology and computer science. Another area of research is how the human brain in its different areas such as the Broca's area and Wernicke's area underlies speech.

column1: It is controversial how far human speech is unique; in that animals also communicate with vocalizations. While none in the wild have comparably large vocabularies
column2: research upon the nonverbal abilities of language trained apes such as Washoe and Kanzi raises the possibility that they might have these capabilities. The evolutionary origins of speech are unknown and subject to much debate and speculation."~0.15664534227655302

column1: 343~4~Speech pathology~5513~5529~"Speech-language pathology is a field of expertise practiced by a clinician known as a speech-language pathologist (SLP)
column2: also sometimes referred to as a speech and language therapist or a speech therapist. SLP is considered a ""related health profession"" along with audiology
column3: optometry
column4: occupational therapy
column5: clinical psychology
column6: physical therapy
column7: and others. The field of SLP is distinguished from other ""related health professions"" as SLPs are legally permitted to diagnose certain disorders which fall within their scope of practice. SLPs specialize in the evaluation
column8: diagnosis
column9: and treatment of communication disorders (speech disorders and language disorders)
column10: cognitive-communication disorders
column11: voice disorders
column12: and swallowing disorders. SLPs also play an important role in the diagnosis and treatment of autism spectrum disorder (often in a team with pediatricians and psychologists).

column1: A common misconception is that speech-language pathology is restricted to adjusting a speaker's speech sound articulation to meet the expected normal pronunciation
column2: such as helping English speaking individuals enunciate the traditionally difficult ""r"". SLPs can also often help people who stutter to speak more fluently. Articulation and fluency are only two facets of the work of an SLP
column3: however. In fact
column4: speech-language pathology is concerned with a broad scope of speech
column5: language
column6: swallowing
column7: and voice issues involved in communication
column8: some of which include:

column1: Word-finding and other semantic issues
column2: either as a result of a specific language impairment (SLI) such as a language delay or as a secondary characteristic of a more general issue such as dementia.

column1: Social communication difficulties involving how people communicate or interact with others (pragmatics).
Structural language impairments
column2: including difficulties creating sentences that are grammatical (syntax) and modifying word meaning (morphology).

column1: Literacy impairments (reading and writing) related to the letter-to-sound relationship (phonics)
column2: the word-to-meaning relationship (semantics)
column3: and understanding the ideas presented in a text (reading comprehension).

column1: Voice difficulties
column2: such as a raspy voice
column3: a voice that is too soft
column4: or other voice difficulties that negatively impact a person's social or professional performance.

column1: Cognitive impairments (e.g.
column2: attention
column3: memory
column4: executive function) to the extent that they interfere with communication.

column1: The components of speech production include:
phonation (producing sound)
resonance
fluency
Intonation
Pitch variance;
Voice (including aeromechanical components of respiration)
The components of language include:
Phonology (manipulating sound according to the rules of a language);
Morphology (understanding components of words and how they can modify meaning);
Syntax (constructing sentences according to the grammatical rules of a target language);
Semantics (interpreting signs or symbols of communication such as words or signs to construct meaning);
Pragmatics (social aspects of communication).
Primary pediatric speech and language disorders include: receptive and expressive language disorders
column2: speech sound disorders
column3: childhood apraxia of speech (CAS)
column4: stuttering
column5: and language-based learning disabilities.

column1: Swallowing disorders include difficulties in any system of the swallowing process (i.e. oral
column2: pharyngeal
column3: esophageal)
column4: as well as functional dysphagia and feeding disorders. Swallowing disorders can occur at any age and can stem from multiple causes."~0.18777229528499728

column1: 344~4~Streaming media~30386~30395~"Streaming media is multimedia that is constantly received by and presented to an end-user while being delivered by a provider. The verb ""to stream"" refers to the process of delivering or obtaining media in this manner; the term refers to the delivery method of the medium
column2: rather than the medium itself
column3: and is an alternative to file downloading
column4: a process in which the end-user obtains the entire file for the content before watching or listening to it.

column1: A client end-user can use their media player to start playing the data file (such as a digital file of a movie or song) before the entire file has been transmitted. Distinguishing delivery method from the media distributed applies specifically to telecommunications networks
column2: as most of the delivery systems are either inherently streaming (e.g. radio
column3: television
column4: streaming apps) or inherently non-streaming (e.g. books
column5: video cassettes
column6: audio CDs). For example
column7: in the 1930s
column8: elevator music was among the earliest popularly available streaming media; nowadays Internet television is a common form of streamed media. The term ""streaming media"" can apply to media other than video and audio such as live closed captioning
column9: ticker tape
column10: and real-time text
column11: which are all considered ""streaming text"".

column1: The term ""streaming"" was first used for tape drives made by Data Electronics Inc. for drives meant to slowly ramp up and run for the entire track; the slow ramp times resulted in lower drive costs
column2: making a more competitive product. ""Streaming"" was applied in the early 1990s as a better description for video on demand on IP networks; at the time such video was usually referred to as ""store and forward video""
column3: which was misleading nomenclature.

column1: Live streaming is the delivery of Internet content in real-time
column2: as events happen
column3: much as live television broadcasts its contents over the airwaves via a television signal. Live internet streaming requires a form of source media (e.g. a video camera
column4: an audio interface
column5: screen capture software)
column6: an encoder to digitize the content
column7: a media publisher
column8: and a content delivery network to distribute and deliver the content. Live streaming does not need to be recorded at the origination point
column9: although it frequently is.

column1: As of 2017
column2: ""streaming"" generally refers to the situation where a user watches digital video content or listens to digital audio content on a computer screen and speakers (ranging from a smartphone
column3: through a desktop computer to a large-screen home entertainment system) over the Internet. With streaming content
column4: the user does not have to download the entire digital video or digital audio file before they start to play it.

column1: There are challenges with streaming content on the Internet. If the user does not have enough bandwidth in their Internet connection
column2: they may experience stops in the content and some users may not be able to stream certain content due to not having compatible computer or software systems.

column1: Some popular streaming services are the video sharing website YouTube; Twitch and Mixer
column2: which live stream the playing of video games; Netflix
column3: which streams movies and TV shows; and Spotify and Apple Music
column4: which stream music."~0.19104154020232278

column1: 345~4~Symphony orchestra~583~601~"An orchestra ( or US: ; Italian: [orˈkɛstra]) is a large instrumental ensemble typical of classical music

column11: for performances of some modern compositions

column1: The term orchestra derives from the Greek ὀρχήστρα (orchestra)
column2: the name for the area in front of a stage in ancient Greek theatre reserved for the Greek chorus.

column1: A full-size orchestra may sometimes be called a symphony orchestra or philharmonic orchestra. The actual number of musicians employed in a given performance may vary from seventy to over one hundred musicians
column2: depending on the work being played and the size of the venue. The term chamber orchestra (and sometimes concert orchestra) usually refers to smaller-sized ensembles of about fifty musicians or fewer. Orchestras that specialize in the Baroque music of

column10: and later

column1: Orchestras are usually led by a conductor who directs the performance with movements of the hands and arms
column2: often made easier for the musicians to see by use of a conductor's baton. The conductor unifies the orchestra
column3: sets the tempo and shapes the sound of the ensemble. The conductor also prepares the orchestra by leading rehearsals before the public concert
column4: in which the conductor provides instructions to the musicians on their interpretation of the music being performed.

column1: The leader of the first violin section
column2: commonly called the concertmaster
column3: also plays an important role in leading the musicians. In the Baroque music era (1600–1750)
column4: orchestras were often led by the concertmaster or by a chord-playing musician performing the basso continuo parts on a harpsichord or pipe organ

column1: 346~4~Teeth~1940~1945~"A tooth (plural teeth) is a hard
column2: calcified structure found in the jaws (or mouths) of many vertebrates and used to break down food. Some animals
column3: particularly carnivores
column4: also use teeth for hunting or for defensive purposes. The roots of teeth are covered by gums. Teeth are not made of bone
column5: but rather of multiple tissues of varying density and hardness. The cellular tissues that ultimately become teeth originate from the embryonic germ layer
column6: the ectoderm.

column1: The general structure of teeth is similar across the vertebrates
column2: although there is considerable variation in their form and position. The teeth of mammals have deep roots
column3: and this pattern is also found in some fish
column4: and in crocodilians. In most teleost fish
column5: however
column6: the teeth are attached to the outer surface of the bone
column7: while in lizards they are attached to the inner surface of the jaw by one side. In cartilaginous fish
column8: such as sharks
column9: the teeth are attached by tough ligaments to the hoops of cartilage that form the jaw.

column1: Some animals develop only one set of teeth (monophyodont) while others develop many sets (polyphyodont). Sharks
column2: for example
column3: grow a new set of teeth every two weeks to replace worn teeth. Rodent incisors grow and wear away continually through gnawing
column4: which helps maintain relatively constant length. The industry of the beaver is due in part to this qualification. Many rodents such as voles and guinea pigs
column5: but not mice
column6: as well as leporidae like rabbits
column7: have continuously growing molars in addition to incisors.

column1: Teeth are not always attached to the jaw
column2: as they are in mammals. In many reptiles and fish
column3: teeth are attached to the palate or to the floor of the mouth
column4: forming additional rows inside those on the jaws proper. Some teleosts even have teeth in the pharynx. While not true teeth in the usual sense
column5: the dermal denticles of sharks are almost identical in structure and are likely to have the same evolutionary origin. Indeed
column6: teeth appear to have first evolved in sharks
column7: and are not found in the more primitive jawless fish – while lampreys do have tooth-like structures on the tongue
column8: these are in fact
column9: composed of keratin
column10: not of dentine or enamel
column11: and bear no relationship to true teeth. Though ""modern"" teeth-like structures with dentine and enamel have been found in late conodonts
column12: they are now supposed to have evolved independently of later vertebrates' teeth.

column1: Living amphibians typically have small teeth
column2: or none at all
column3: since they commonly feed only on soft foods. In reptiles
column4: teeth are generally simple and conical in shape
column5: although there is some variation between species
column6: most notably the venom-injecting fangs of snakes. The pattern of incisors
column7: canines
column8: premolars and molars is found only in mammals
column9: and to varying extents
column10: in their evolutionary ancestors. The numbers of these types of teeth vary greatly between species; zoologists use a standardised dental formula to describe the precise pattern in any given group."~0.2735269495245698

column1: 347~4~Tenor~11904~11909~"Tenor is a type of classical male singing voice
