column1: 348~4~Timbre~3133~3139~"In music
column2: timbre ( TAM-bər
column3: also known as tone color or tone quality from psychoacoustics) is the perceived sound quality of a musical note
column4: sound or tone. Timbre distinguishes different types of sound production
column5: such as choir voices and musical instruments
column6: such as string instruments
column7: wind instruments
column8: and percussion instruments. It also enables listeners to distinguish different instruments in the same category (e.g. an oboe and a clarinet).

column1: The physical characteristics of sound that determine the perception of timbre include spectrum and envelope. Singers and instrumental musicians can change the timbre of the music they are singing/playing by using different singing or playing techniques. For example
column2: a violinist can use different bowing styles or play on different parts of the string to obtain different timbres (e.g.
column3: playing sul tasto produces a light
column4: airy timbre
column5: whereas playing sul ponticello produces a harsh
column6: even and aggressive tone). On electric guitar and electric piano
column7: performers can change the timbre using effects units and graphic equalizers.

column1: In simple terms
column2: timbre is what makes a particular musical sound have a different sound from another
column3: even when they have the same pitch and loudness. For instance
column4: it is the difference in sound between a guitar and a piano playing the same note at the same volume. Both instruments can sound equally tuned in relation to each other as they play the same note
column5: and while playing at the same amplitude level each instrument will still sound distinctively with its own unique tone color. Experienced musicians are able to distinguish between different instruments of the same type based on their varied timbres
column6: even if those instruments are playing notes at the same pitch and loudness."~0.3497281011247419

column1: 349~4~Tongue~1900~1906~"The tongue is a muscular organ in the mouth of most vertebrates that manipulates food for mastication
column2: and is used in the act of swallowing. It is of importance in the digestive system and is the primary organ of taste in the gustatory system. The tongue's upper surface (dorsum) is covered by taste buds housed in numerous lingual papillae. It is sensitive and kept moist by saliva
column3: and is richly supplied with nerves and blood vessels. The tongue also serves as a natural means of cleaning the teeth. A major function of the tongue is the enabling of speech in humans and vocalization in other animals.

column1: The human tongue is divided into two parts
column2: an oral part at the front and a pharyngeal part at the back. The left and right sides are also separated along most of its length by a vertical section of fibrous tissue (the lingual septum) that results in a groove
column3: the median sulcus on the tongue's surface.

column1: There are two groups of muscles of the tongue. The four intrinsic muscles alter the shape of the tongue and are not attached to bone. The four paired extrinsic muscles change the position of the tongue and are anchored to bone."~0.1616182606109252
350~4~Vibrato~1772~1779~"Vibrato (Italian
column2: from past participle of ""vibrare""
column3: to vibrate) is a musical effect consisting of a regular
column4: pulsating change of pitch. It is used to add expression to vocal and instrumental music. Vibrato is typically characterised in terms of two factors: the amount of pitch variation (""extent of vibrato"") and the speed with which the pitch is varied (""rate of vibrato"").

column1: In singing it can occur spontaneously through variations in the larynx. The vibrato of a string instrument and wind instrument is an imitation of that vocal function."~0.3483105735620141
351~4~Vocal~149~154~"The human voice consists of sound made by a human being using the vocal tract
column2: such as talking
column3: singing
column4: laughing
column5: crying
column6: screaming
column7: etc. The human voice frequency is specifically a part of human sound production in which the vocal folds (vocal cords) are the primary sound source. (Other sound production mechanisms produced from the same general area of the body involve the production of unvoiced consonants
column8: clicks
column9: whistling and whispering.)

column1: Generally speaking
column2: the mechanism for generating the human voice can be subdivided into three parts; the lungs
column3: the vocal folds within the larynx (voice box)
column4: and the articulators. The lung
column5: the ""pump"" must produce adequate airflow and air pressure to vibrate vocal folds. The vocal folds (vocal cords) then vibrate to use airflow from the lungs to create audible pulses that form the laryngeal sound source. The muscles of the larynx adjust the length and tension of the vocal folds to ‘fine-tune’ pitch and tone. The articulators (the parts of the vocal tract above the larynx consisting of tongue
column6: palate
column7: cheek
column8: lips
column9: etc.) articulate and filter the sound emanating from the larynx and to some degree can interact with the laryngeal airflow to strengthen it or weaken it as a sound source.

column1: The vocal folds
column2: in combination with the articulators
column3: are capable of producing highly intricate arrays of sound. The tone of voice may be modulated to suggest emotions such as anger
column4: surprise
column5: or happiness. The human voice is used to express emotion
column6: and can also reveal the gender and age of the speaker.  Singers use the human voice as an instrument for creating music."~0.3316236664410357

column1: 352~4~Vocalese~25323~25331~"Vocalese is a style or musical genre of jazz singing wherein words are sung note for note to melodies that were originally created by a soloist's improvisation. Kurt Elling
column2: perhaps the most well known current practitioner of the style
column3: describes the style as such: ""Although the word 'vocalise' was first applied more strictly to Jon Hendricks' work in big band/multi-voice settings
column4: it quickly broadened through general use to mean any application of a vocally presented lyric based on melodies first recorded by jazz instrumentalists
column5: whether solos -a feat that could only have happened with the advent of recorded sound -the early composers of such lyrics essentially invented a new art form.""

column1: Whereas scat singing uses improvised syllables
column2: such as ""bap ba dee dot bwee dee"" in solos
column3: vocalese uses written lyrics
column4: set to pre-existing instrumental solos. In a 'first wave' of vocalese creation
column5: this sometimes took the form of a tribute to the original instrumentalist
column6: such as Eddie Jefferson's version of ""Body and Soul
column7: which featured lyrics about Coleman Hawkins
column8: whose landmark solo on the tune is globally recognized. The word ""vocalese"" is a play on the musical term ""vocalise"" and the suffix ""-ese""
column9: meant to indicate a sort of language
column10: and the term is attributed to jazz critic Leonard Feather to describe the first Lambert
column11: Hendricks
column12: & Ross album
column13: Sing a Song of Basie.

column1: The inventor and most prolific practitioner of vocalese was Eddie Jefferson
column2: whose rendition of Coleman Hawkins's ""Body and Soul"" became a hit on its own. Pioneers of vocalese include King Pleasure and Babs Gonzales
column3: Jefferson's former dance partner. Pleasure first gained popularity singing Jefferson's vocalese classic ""Moody's Mood for Love""
column4: based on a James Moody saxophone solo to ""I'm in the Mood for Love"". However
column5: Elling makes a point to recognize Bee Palmer
column6: who sang lyrics to a Bix Biederbecke and Frankie Trumbauer solo on ""Singin' the Blues"" as early as 1929.

column1: The best-known practitioners and popularisers are probably Lambert
column2: Hendricks and Ross
column3: which group was made up of Jon Hendricks
column4: Dave Lambert and Annie Ross. Ross's 1952 lyrics for the song ""Twisted""
column5: a blues improvisation by saxophonist Wardell Gray
column6: are considered a classic of the genre. Other performers known for vocalese include Bob Dorough
column7: Giacomo Gates[1]
column8: Kurt Elling
column9: Al Jarreau
column10: Mark Murphy
column11: Roger Miller
column12: New York Voices
column13: and The Manhattan Transfer
column14: whose Grammy-winning version of Weather Report's ""Birdland"" featured lyrics by Jon Hendricks. Notably
column15: Joni Mitchell recorded lyrics to Mingus's tunes
column16: with ""The Dry Cleaner from Des Moines
column17: and ""Goodbye Porkpie Hat."" Vocalise artists around the world include Les Double Six
column19: and in Canada
column21: a contemporary jazz artist. In 1990
column23: a vocalese rendition of the Miles Davis song
column24: which featured Al Jarreau

column1: Some performers
column2: notably Slim Gaillard
column3: Harry Gibson
column4: Cab Calloway
column5: and Leo Watson
column6: combine vocalese improvisations with scat singing.

column1: Most vocalese lyrics are entirely syllabic
column2: as opposed to melismatic. This may lead to the use of many words sung quickly in a given phrase
column3: especially in the case of bebop."~0.43852354077283057

column1: 353~4~Vowel~1993~1999~"Vowels form one of the two principal classes of speech sound
column2: the other being that of consonants. Vowels vary in quality
column3: in loudness and also in quantity (length). They are usually voiced
column4: and are closely involved in prosodic variation such as tone
column5: intonation and stress. Vowel sounds are produced with an open vocal tract. The word vowel comes from the Latin word vocalis
column6: meaning ""vocal"" (i.e. relating to the voice). In English
column7: the word vowel is commonly used to refer both to vowel sounds and to the written symbols that represent them."~0.30125236819669193

column1: 354~4~Whale~40683~40689~"Whales are a widely distributed and diverse group of fully aquatic placental marine mammals. They are an informal grouping within the infraorder Cetacea
column2: usually excluding dolphins and porpoises. Whales
column3: dolphins and porpoises belong to the order Cetartiodactyla with even-toed ungulates and their closest living relatives are the hippopotamuses
column4: having diverged about 40 million years ago. The two parvorders of whales
column5: baleen whales (Mysticeti) and toothed whales (Odontoceti)
column6: are thought to have split apart around 34 million years ago. The whales comprise eight extant families: Balaenopteridae (the rorquals)
column7: Balaenidae (right whales)
column8: Cetotheriidae (the pygmy right whale)
column9: Eschrichtiidae (the grey whale)
column10: Monodontidae (belugas and narwhals)
column11: Physeteridae (the sperm whale)
column12: Kogiidae (the dwarf and pygmy sperm whale)
column13: and Ziphiidae (the beaked whales).

column1: Whales are creatures of the open ocean; they feed
column2: mate
column3: give birth
column4: suckle and raise their young at sea. So extreme is their adaptation to life underwater that they are unable to survive on land. Whales range in size from the 2.6 metres (8.5 ft) and 135 kilograms (298 lb) dwarf sperm whale to the 29.9 metres (98 ft) and 190 metric tons (210 short tons) blue whale
column5: which is the largest creature that has ever lived. The sperm whale is the largest toothed predator on earth. Several species exhibit sexual dimorphism
column6: in that the females are larger than males. Baleen whales have no teeth; instead they have plates of baleen
column7: a fringe-like structure used to expel water while retaining the krill and plankton which they feed on. They use their throat pleats to expand the mouth to take in huge gulps of water. Balaenids have heads that can make up 40% of their body mass to take in water. Toothed whales
column8: on the other hand
column9: have conical teeth designed for catching fish or squid. Baleen whales have a well developed sense of ""smell""
column10: whereas toothed whales have well-developed hearing − their hearing
column11: that is adapted for both air and water
column12: is so well developed that some can survive even if they are blind. Some species
column13: such as sperm whales
column14: are well adapted for diving to great depths to catch squid and other favoured prey.

column1: Whales have evolved from land-living mammals. As such whales must breathe air regularly
column2: although they can remain submerged under water for long periods of time. Some species such as the sperm whale are able to stay submerged for as much as 90 minutes. They have blowholes (modified nostrils) located on top of their heads
column3: through which air is taken in and expelled. They are warm-blooded
column4: and have a layer of fat
column5: or blubber
column6: under the skin. With streamlined fusiform bodies and two limbs that are modified into flippers
column7: whales can travel at up to 20 knots
column8: though they are not as flexible or agile as seals. Whales produce a great variety of vocalizations
column9: notably the extended songs of the humpback whale. Although whales are widespread
column10: most species prefer the colder waters of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres
column11: and migrate to the equator to give birth. Species such as humpbacks and blue whales are capable of travelling thousands of miles without feeding. Males typically mate with multiple females every year
column12: but females only mate every two to three years. Calves are typically born in the spring and summer months and females bear all the responsibility for raising them. Mothers of some species fast and nurse their young for one to two years.

column1: Once relentlessly hunted for their products
column2: whales are now protected by international law. The North Atlantic right whales nearly became extinct in the twentieth century
column3: with a population low of 450
column4: and the North Pacific grey whale population is ranked Critically Endangered by the IUCN. Besides whaling
column5: they also face threats from bycatch and marine pollution. The meat
column6: blubber and baleen of whales have traditionally been used by indigenous peoples of the Arctic. Whales have been depicted in various cultures worldwide
column7: notably by the Inuit and the coastal peoples of Vietnam and Ghana
column8: who sometimes hold whale funerals. Whales occasionally feature in literature and film
column9: as in the great white whale of Herman Melville's Moby Dick. Small whales
column10: such as belugas
column11: are sometimes kept in captivity and trained to perform tricks
column12: but breeding success has been poor and the animals often die within a few months of capture. Whale watching has become a form of tourism around the world."~0.1664473077688878

column1: 355~4~YouTube~29851~29858~"YouTube is an American video-sharing website headquartered in San Bruno
column2: California. The service was created by three former PayPal employees—Chad Hurley
column3: Steve Chen
column4: and Jawed Karim—in February 2005. Google bought the site in November 2006 for US$1.65 billion; YouTube now operates as one of Google's subsidiaries.

column1: YouTube allows users to upload
column2: view
column3: rate
column4: share
column5: add to favorites
column6: report
column7: comment on videos
column8: and subscribe to other users. It offers a wide variety of user-generated and corporate media videos. Available content includes video clips
column9: TV show clips
column10: music videos
column11: short and documentary films
column12: audio recordings
column13: movie trailers
column14: live streams
column15: and other content such as video blogging
column17: and educational videos. Most of the content on YouTube is uploaded by individuals
column19: the BBC
column21: and Hulu offer some of their material via YouTube as part of the YouTube partnership program. Unregistered users can only watch videos on the site
column22: while registered users are permitted to upload an unlimited number of videos and add comments to videos. Videos deemed potentially inappropriate are available only to registered users affirming themselves to be at least 18 years old.

column1: YouTube earns advertising revenue from Google AdSense
column2: a program which targets ads according to site content and audience. The vast majority of its videos are free to view
column3: but there are exceptions
column4: including subscription-based premium channels
column5: film rentals
column6: as well as YouTube Red
column7: a subscription service offering ad-free access to the website and access to exclusive content made in partnership with existing users. As of February 2017
column8: there are more than 400 hours of content uploaded to YouTube each minute
column9: and one billion hours of content are watched on YouTube every day. As of August 2017
column10: the website is ranked as the second-most popular site in the world by Alexa Internet
column11: a web traffic analysis company."~0.3207741040203005

column1: 356~4~Zee TV~31383~31389~"Zee TV (Hindi: ज़ी टीवी) is an Indian cable and satellite television channel owned and operated by Zee Entertainment Enterprises
column2: a media and entertainment company based in Mumbai
column3: Maharashtra. It airs programming in Hindi. The channel is also available in various nations of Southeast Asia
column4: Europe
column5: the Caribbean
column6: the Middle East
column7: Africa
column8: Australasia and North America. A part of the Essel Group
column9: it started to broadcast on 2 October 1992 as the first Hindi-language cable channel in India.

column1: Zee TV HD was launched on 15 August 2011 along with Zee Cinema HD
column2: Zee Studio HD. It overhauled its logo on 15 October 2017
column3: along with all other channels of the Zee Entertainment Enterprises."~0.29991102166776296

column1: 357~5~Accompaniment~664~677~"Accompaniment is the musical parts which provide the rhythmic and/or harmonic support for the melody or main themes of a song or instrumental piece. There are many different styles and types of accompaniment in different genres and styles of music. In homophonic music
column2: the main accompaniment approach used in popular music
column3: a clear vocal melody is supported by subordinate chords. In popular music and traditional music
column4: the accompaniment parts typically provide the ""beat"" for the music and outline the chord progression of the song or instrumental piece. The accompaniment for a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be played by a single musician playing an instrument such as piano
column5: pipe organ
column6: or guitar. While any instrument can in theory be used as an accompaniment instrument
column7: keyboard and guitar-family instruments tend to be used if there is only a single instrument
column8: as these instruments can play chords and basslines simultaneously (chords and a bassline are easier to play simultaneously on keyboard instruments
column9: but a fingerpicking guitarist can play chords and a bassline simultaneously on guitar). A solo singer can accompany herself by playing guitar or piano while she sings
column10: and in some rare cases
column11: a solo singer can even accompany himself or herself just using his or her voice and body (e.g.
column12: Bobby McFerrin).

column1: Alternatively
column2: the accompaniment to a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be provided by a musical ensemble
column3: ranging in size from a duo (e.g.
column4: cello and piano; guitar and double bass; synthesizer and percussion); a trio (e.g.
column5: a rock power trio of electric guitar
column6: electric bass and drum kit; an organ trio); a quartet (e.g.
column7: a string quartet in Classical music can accompany a solo singer; a rock band or rhythm section in rock and pop; a jazz quartet in jazz); all the way to larger ensembles
column8: such as concert bands
column9: Big Bands (in jazz)
column10: pit orchestras in musical theatre; and orchestras
column11: which
column12: in addition to playing symphonies
column13: can also provide accompaniment to a concerto solo instrumentalist or to solo singers in opera. With choral music
column14: the accompaniment to a vocal solo can be provided by other singers in the choir
column15: who sing harmony parts or countermelodies. Accompaniment parts range from so simple that a beginner can play them (e.g.
column16: simple three-note triad chords in a traditional folk song) to so complex that only an advanced player or singer can perform them (e.g.
column17: the piano parts in Schubert's Lieder art songs from the 19th century or vocal parts from a Renaissance music motet)."~0.33330237851433137

column1: 358~5~Acoustics~15239~15248~"Acoustics is the branch of physics that deals with the study of all mechanical waves in gases
column2: liquids
column3: and solids including topics such as vibration
column4: sound
column5: ultrasound and infrasound. A scientist who works in the field of acoustics is an acoustician while someone working in the field of acoustics technology may be called an acoustical engineer. The application of acoustics is present in almost all aspects of modern society with the most obvious being the audio and noise control industries.

column1: Hearing is one of the most crucial means of survival in the animal world
column2: and speech is one of the most distinctive characteristics of human development and culture. Accordingly
column3: the science of acoustics spreads across many facets of human society—music
column4: medicine
column5: architecture
column6: industrial production
column7: warfare and more. Likewise
column8: animal species such as songbirds and frogs use sound and hearing as a key element of mating rituals or marking territories. Art
column9: craft
column10: science and technology have provoked one another to advance the whole
column11: as in many other fields of knowledge. Robert Bruce Lindsay's 'Wheel of Acoustics' is a well accepted overview of the various fields in acoustics.

column1: The word ""acoustic"" is derived from the Greek word ἀκουστικός (akoustikos)
column2: meaning ""of or for hearing
column3: ready to hear"" and that from ἀκουστός (akoustos)
column4: ""heard
column5: audible""
column6: which in turn derives from the verb ἀκούω (akouo)
column7: ""I hear"".

column1: The Latin synonym is ""sonic""
column2: after which the term sonics used to be a synonym for acoustics and later a branch of acoustics. Frequencies above and below the audible range are called ""ultrasonic"" and ""infrasonic""

column1: 359~5~Aesthetics~60463~60473~"Aesthetics (; also spelled esthetics) is a branch of philosophy that explores the nature of art
column2: beauty
column3: and taste
column4: with the creation and appreciation of beauty.

column1: In its more technical epistemological perspective
column2: it is defined as the study of subjective and sensori-emotional values
column3: sometimes called judgments of sentiment and taste. Aesthetics studies how artists imagine
column4: create and perform works of art; how people use
column5: enjoy
column6: and criticize art; and what happens in their minds when they look at paintings
column7: listen to music
column8: or read poetry
column9: and understand what they see and hear. It also studies how they feel about art-- why they like some works and not others
column10: and how art can affect their moods
column11: beliefs
column12: and attitude toward life.  More broadly
column13: scholars in the field define aesthetics as ""critical reflection on art
column14: culture and nature"". In modern English
column15: the term aesthetic can also refer to a set of principles underlying the works of a particular art movement or theory: one speaks
column17: of the Cubist aesthetic."~0.12694731377813365

column1: 360~5~Albert Einstein~95216~95231~"Albert Einstein (14 March 1879 – 18 April 1955) was a German-born theoretical physicist who developed the theory of relativity
column2: one of the two pillars of modern physics (alongside quantum mechanics). His work is also known for its influence on the philosophy of science. He is best known by the general public for his mass–energy equivalence formula E = mc2 (which has been dubbed ""the world's most famous equation""). He received the 1921 Nobel Prize in Physics ""for his services to theoretical physics
column3: and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect""
column4: a pivotal step in the evolution of quantum theory.

column1: Near the beginning of his career
column2: Einstein thought that Newtonian mechanics was no longer enough to reconcile the laws of classical mechanics with the laws of the electromagnetic field. This led him to develop his special theory of relativity during his time at the Swiss Patent Office in Bern (1902–1909)
column3: Switzerland. However
column4: he realized that the principle of relativity could also be extended to gravitational fields and—with his subsequent theory of gravitation in 1916—he published a paper on general relativity. He continued to deal with problems of statistical mechanics and quantum theory
column5: which led to his explanations of particle theory and the motion of molecules. He also investigated the thermal properties of light which laid the foundation of the photon theory of light. In 1917
column6: he applied the general theory of relativity to model the large-scale structure of the universe.

column1: Between 1895 and 1914
column2: he lived in Switzerland (except for one year in Prague
column4: where he received his academic diploma from the Swiss Federal Polytechnic in Zürich (later the Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule
column5: ETH) in 1900. He later taught at that institute as a professor of theoretical physics between 1912 and 1914 before he left for Berlin. In 1901
column6: after being stateless for more than five years
column7: he acquired Swiss citizenship
column8: which he kept for the rest of his life. In 1905
column9: he was awarded a PhD by the University of Zürich. The same year
column10: his annus mirabilis (miracle year)
column11: he published four groundbreaking papers
column12: which were to bring him to the notice of the academic world
column13: at the age of 26.

column1: He was visiting the United States when Adolf Hitler came to power in 1933 and—being Jewish—did not go back to Germany
column2: where he had been a professor at the Berlin Academy of Sciences. He settled in the United States
column3: becoming an American citizen in 1940. On the eve of World War II
column4: he endorsed a letter to President Franklin D. Roosevelt alerting him to the potential development of ""extremely powerful bombs of a new type"" and recommending that the U.S. begin similar research. This eventually led to what would become the Manhattan Project. Einstein supported defending the Allied forces
column5: but generally denounced the idea of using the newly discovered nuclear fission as a weapon. Later
column6: with the British philosopher Bertrand Russell
column7: he signed the Russell–Einstein Manifesto
column8: which highlighted the danger of nuclear weapons. He was affiliated with the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton
column9: New Jersey
column10: until his death in 1955.

column1: Einstein published more than 300 scientific papers along with over 150 non-scientific works. His intellectual achievements and originality have made the word ""Einstein"" synonymous with ""genius"". Eugene Wigner wrote of Einstein in comparison to his contemporaries that ""Einstein's understanding was deeper even than Jansci von Neumann's. His mind was both more penetrating and more original than von Neumann's. And that is a very remarkable statement."""~0.12388091232527637
361~5~Album~2871~2875~"An album is a collection of audio recordings issued as a single item on CD
column2: record
column3: audio tape or another medium. Albums of recorded music were developed in the early 20th century
column4: first as books of individual 78rpm records
column5: then from 1948 as vinyl LP records played at ​33 1⁄3 rpm. Vinyl LPs are still issued
column6: though in the 21st-century album sales have mostly focused on compact disc (CD) and MP3 formats. However
column7: vinyl sales have been on the rise in recent years. The audio cassette was a format used alongside vinyl from the 1970s into the first decade of the 2000s.

column1: An album may be recorded in a recording studio (fixed or mobile)
column2: in a concert venue
column3: at home
column4: in the field
column5: or a mix of places. The time frame for completely recording an album varies between a few hours and several years. This process usually requires several takes with different parts recorded separately
column6: and then brought or ""mixed"" together. Recordings that are done in one take without overdubbing are termed ""live""
column7: even when done in a studio. Studios are built to absorb sound
column8: eliminating reverberation
column9: so as to assist in mixing different takes; other locations
column10: such as concert venues and some ""live rooms""
column11: allow for reverberation
column12: which creates a ""live"" sound. The majority of studio recordings contain an abundance of editing
column13: sound effects
column14: voice adjustments
column15: etc. With modern recording technology
column16: musicians can be recorded in separate rooms or at separate times while listening to the other parts using headphones; with each part recorded as a separate track.

column1: Album covers and liner notes are used
column2: and sometimes additional information is provided
column3: such as analysis of the recording
column4: and lyrics or librettos. Historically
column5: the term ""album"" was applied to a collection of various items housed in a book format. In musical usage the word was used for collections of short pieces of printed music from the early nineteenth century. Later
column6: collections of related 78rpm records were bundled in book-like albums (one side of a 78 rpm record could hold only about 3.5 minutes of sound). When long-playing records were introduced
column7: a collection of pieces on a single record was called an album; the word was extended to other recording media such as compact disc
column8: MiniDisc
column9: compact audio cassette
column10: and digital albums as they were introduced."~0.46606643433373895

column1: 362~5~Ancient Rome~39787~39793~"In historiography
column2: ancient Rome is Roman civilization from the founding of the city of Rome in the 8th century BC to the collapse of the Western Roman Empire in the 5th century AD
column3: encompassing the Roman Kingdom
column4: Roman Republic and Roman Empire until the fall of the western empire. The term is sometimes used to just refer to the kingdom and republic periods
column5: excluding the subsequent empire.

column1: The civilization began as an Italic settlement in the Italian peninsula
column2: dating from the 8th century BC
column3: that grew into the city of Rome and which subsequently gave its name to the empire over which it ruled and to the widespread civilisation the empire developed. The Roman empire expanded to become one of the largest empires in the ancient world
column4: though still ruled from the city
column5: with an estimated 50 to 90 million inhabitants (roughly 20% of the world's population) and covering 5.0 million square kilometres at its height in AD 117.

column1: In its many centuries of existence
column2: the Roman state evolved from a monarchy to a Classical Republic and then to an increasingly autocratic empire. Through conquest and assimilation
column3: it eventually dominated the Mediterranean region
column4: Western Europe
column5: Asia Minor
column6: North Africa
column7: and parts of Northern and Eastern Europe. It is often grouped into classical antiquity together with ancient Greece
column8: and their similar cultures and societies are known as the Greco-Roman world.

column1: Ancient Roman civilisation has contributed to modern government
column2: law
column3: politics
column4: engineering
column5: art
column6: literature
column7: architecture
column8: technology
column9: warfare
column10: religion
column11: language
column12: and society. Rome professionalised and expanded its military and created a system of government called res publica
column13: the inspiration for modern republics such as the United States and France. It achieved impressive technological and architectural feats
column14: such as the construction of an extensive system of aqueducts and roads
column15: as well as the construction of large monuments
column17: and public facilities.

column1: By the end of the Republic (27 BC)
column2: Rome had conquered the lands around the Mediterranean and beyond: its domain extended from the Atlantic to Arabia and from the mouth of the Rhine to North Africa. The Roman Empire emerged with the end of the Republic and the dictatorship of Augustus Caesar. 721 years of Roman-Persian Wars started in 92 BC with their first war against Parthia. It would become the longest conflict in human history
column3: and have major lasting effects and consequences for both empires. Under Trajan
column4: the Empire reached its territorial peak. Republican mores and traditions started to decline during the imperial period
column5: with civil wars becoming a prelude common to the rise of a new emperor. Splinter states
column6: such as the Palmyrene Empire
column7: would temporarily divide the Empire during the crisis of the 3rd century.

column1: Plagued by internal instability and attacked by various migrating peoples
column2: the western part of the empire broke up into independent ""barbarian"" kingdoms in the 5th century. This splintering is a landmark historians use to divide the ancient period of universal history from the pre-medieval ""Dark Ages"" of Europe. The eastern part of the empire endured through the 5th century and remained a power throughout the ""Dark Ages"" and medieval times until its fall in 1453 AD. Though the citizens of the empire made no distinction
column3: the empire is most commonly referred to as the ""Byzantine Empire"" by modern historians during the Middle Ages to differentiate between the state of antiquity and the nation it grew into."~0.12601182338314157

column1: 363~5~Anthropology~39589~39601~"Anthropology is the study of humans and human behaviour and societies in the past and present. Social anthropology and cultural anthropology study the norms and values of societies. Linguistic anthropology studies how language affects social life. Biological or physical anthropology studies the biological development of humans.
Archaeology
column2: which studies past human cultures through investigation of physical evidence
column3: is thought of as a branch of anthropology in the United States
column4: while in Europe
column5: it is viewed as a discipline in its own right or grouped under other related disciplines

column1: 364~5~Antonín Dvořák~50631~50645~"Antonín Leopold Dvořák ( d(ə)-VOR-zha(h)k; Czech: [ˈantoɲiːn ˈlɛopolt ˈdvor̝aːk]; 8 September 1841 – 1 May 1904) was a Czech composer. After Bedřich Smetana

column3: Dvořák frequently employed aspects
column4: specifically rhythms
column5: of the folk music of Moravia and his native Bohemia. Dvořák's own style has been described as ""the fullest recreation of a national idiom with that of the symphonic tradition
column6: absorbing folk influences and finding effective ways of using them.""

column1: Dvořák displayed his musical gifts at an early age
column2: being an apt violin student from age six. The first public performances of his works were in Prague in 1872 and
column3: with special success
column5: when he was aged 31. Seeking recognition beyond the Prague area
column6: he submitted a score of his First Symphony to a prize competition in Germany
column7: but did not win
column8: and the unreturned manuscript was lost until rediscovered many decades later. In 1874 he made a submission to the Austrian State Prize for Composition
column9: including scores of two further symphonies and other works. Although Dvořák was not aware of it
column10: Johannes Brahms was the leading member of the jury and was highly impressed. The prize was awarded to Dvořák in 1874 and again in 1876 and in 1877
column11: when Brahms and the prominent critic Eduard Hanslick
column12: also a member of the jury
column13: made themselves known to him. Brahms recommended Dvořák to his publisher
column14: Simrock
column15: who soon afterward commissioned what became the Slavonic Dances
column16: Op. 46. These were highly praised by the Berlin music critic Louis Ehlert in 1878
column17: the sheet music (of the original piano 4-hands version) had excellent sales
column18: and Dvořák's international reputation was launched at last.

column1: Dvořák's first piece of a religious nature
column2: his setting of Stabat Mater
column3: was premiered in Prague in 1880. It was very successfully performed in London in 1883
column4: leading to many other performances in the United Kingdom and United States. In his career
column5: Dvořák made nine invited visits to England
column6: often conducting performances of his own works. His Seventh Symphony was written for London. Visiting Russia in March 1890
column7: he conducted concerts of his own music in Moscow and Saint Petersburg. In 1891 Dvořák was appointed as a professor at the Prague Conservatory. In 1890–91
column8: he wrote his Dumky Trio
column9: one of his most successful chamber music pieces. In 1892
column10: Dvořák moved to the United States and became the director of the National Conservatory of Music of America in New York City. While in the United States
column11: Dvořák wrote his two most successful orchestral works: the Symphony From the New World
column12: which spread his reputation worldwide
column13: and his Cello Concerto
column14: one of the most highly regarded of all cello concerti. He also wrote his most appreciated piece of chamber music
column15: the American String Quartet
column16: during this time. But shortfalls in payment of his salary
column17: along with increasing recognition in Europe and an onset of homesickness
column18: led him to leave the United States and return to Bohemia in 1895.

column1: All of Dvořák's nine operas but his first have librettos in Czech and were intended to convey Czech national spirit
column2: as were some of his choral works. By far the most successful of the operas is Rusalka. Among his smaller works
column3: the seventh Humoresque and the song ""Songs My Mother Taught Me"" are also widely performed and recorded. He has been described as ""arguably the most versatile... composer of his time""."~0.38561265540696577

column1: 366~5~Archaeology~36523~36537~"Archaeology
column2: or archeology
column3: is the study of human activity through the recovery and analysis of material culture. The archaeological record consists of artifacts
column4: architecture
column5: biofacts or ecofacts
column6: and cultural landscapes. Archaeology can be considered both a social science and a branch of the humanities. In North America
column7: archaeology is considered a sub-field of anthropology
column8: while in Europe archaeology is often viewed as either a discipline in its own right or a sub-field of other disciplines.

column1: Archaeologists study human prehistory and history
column2: from the development of the first stone tools at Lomekwi in East Africa 3.3 million years ago up until recent decades. Archaeology as a field is distinct from the discipline of palaeontology
column3: the study of fossil remains. Archaeology is particularly important for learning about prehistoric societies
column4: for whom there may be no written records to study. Prehistory includes over 99% of the human past
column5: from the Paleolithic until the advent of literacy in societies across the world. Archaeology has various goals
column6: which range from understanding culture history to reconstructing past lifeways to documenting and explaining changes in human societies through time.

column1: The discipline involves surveying
column2: excavation and eventually analysis of data collected to learn more about the past. In broad scope
column3: archaeology relies on cross-disciplinary research. It draws upon anthropology
column4: history
column5: art history
column6: classics
column7: ethnology
column8: geography
column9: geology
column10: literary history
column11: linguistics
column12: semiology
column13: textual criticism
column14: physics
column15: information sciences
column17: statistics
column19: paleography
column21: paleozoology

column1: Archaeology developed out of antiquarianism in Europe during the 19th century
column2: and has since become a discipline practiced across the world. Archaeology has been used by nation-states to create particular visions of the past. Since its early development
column3: various specific sub-disciplines of archaeology have developed
column4: including maritime archaeology
column5: feminist archaeology and archaeoastronomy
column6: and numerous different scientific techniques have been developed to aid archaeological investigation. Nonetheless
column7: today
column8: archaeologists face many problems
column9: such as dealing with pseudoarchaeology
column10: the looting of artifacts
column11: a lack of public interest
column12: and opposition to the excavation of human remains."~0.16405741623087838

column1: 367~5~Aria~30604~30608~An aria ([ˈaːrja]; Italian: air; plural: arie [ˈaːrje]
column2: or arias in common usage
column3: diminutive form arietta [aˈrjetta] or ariette) in music was originally any expressive melody
column4: usually
column5: but not always
column6: performed by a singer. The term became used almost exclusively to describe a self-contained piece for one voice
column7: with or without instrumental or orchestral accompaniment
column8: normally part of a larger work. The typical context for arias is opera
column9: but vocal arias also feature in oratorios and cantatas
column10: sharing features of the operatic arias of their periods.~0.16984229076865212

column1: 368~5~Arnold Schoenberg~53129~53146~"Arnold Franz Walter Schoenberg or Schönberg (; German: [ˈaːʁnɔlt ˈʃøːnbɛʁk] ( listen); 13 September 1874 – 13 July 1951) was an Austrian composer
column2: music theorist
column3: and painter. He was associated with the expressionist movement in German poetry and art
column4: and leader of the Second Viennese School. With the rise of the Nazi Party
column5: Schoenberg's works were labelled degenerate music
column6: because they were modernist
column7: atonal and what even Paul Hindemith called ""sonic orgies"" and ""decadent intellectual efforts"" (Petropoulos 2014
column8: 94–95). He emigrated to the United States of America in 1934.

column1: Schoenberg's approach
column2: both in terms of harmony and development
column3: has been one of the most influential of 20th-century musical thought. Many European and American composers from at least three generations have consciously extended his thinking
column4: whereas others have passionately reacted against it.

column1: Schoenberg was known early in his career for simultaneously extending the traditionally opposed German Romantic styles of Brahms and Wagner. Later
column2: his name would come to personify innovations in atonality (although Schoenberg himself detested that term) that would become the most polemical feature of 20th-century art music. In the 1920s
column3: Schoenberg developed the twelve-tone technique
column4: an influential compositional method of manipulating an ordered series of all twelve notes in the chromatic scale. He also coined the term developing variation and was the first modern composer to embrace ways of developing motifs without resorting to the dominance of a centralized melodic idea.

column1: Schoenberg was also an influential teacher of composition; his students included Alban Berg
column2: Anton Webern
column3: Hanns Eisler
column4: Egon Wellesz
column5: Nikos Skalkottas
column6: and later John Cage
column7: Lou Harrison
column8: Earl Kim
column9: Roberto Gerhard
column10: Leon Kirchner
column11: Dika Newlin
column12: and other prominent musicians. Many of Schoenberg's practices
column13: including the formalization of compositional method and his habit of openly inviting audiences to think analytically
column14: are echoed in avant-garde musical thought throughout the 20th century. His often polemical views of music history and aesthetics were crucial to many significant 20th-century musicologists and critics
column15: including Theodor W. Adorno
column17: and Carl Dahlhaus
column18: as well as the pianists Artur Schnabel
column19: Rudolf Serkin
column21: and Glenn Gould.

column1: Schoenberg's archival legacy is collected at the Arnold Schönberg Center in Vienna."~0.3736916753914413
369~5~Artificial intelligence~64858~64881~"Artificial intelligence (AI
column2: also machine intelligence
column3: MI) is intelligence demonstrated by machines
column4: in contrast to the natural intelligence (NI) displayed by humans and other animals. In computer science AI research is defined as the study of ""intelligent agents"": any device that perceives its environment and takes actions that maximize its chance of successfully achieving its goals. Colloquially
column5: the term ""artificial intelligence"" is applied when a machine mimics ""cognitive"" functions that humans associate with other human minds
column6: such as ""learning"" and ""problem solving"". See glossary of artificial intelligence.

column1: The scope of AI is disputed: as machines become increasingly capable
column2: tasks considered as requiring ""intelligence"" are often removed from the definition
column3: a phenomenon known as the AI effect
column4: leading to the quip ""AI is whatever hasn't been done yet."" For instance
column5: optical character recognition is frequently excluded from ""artificial intelligence""
column6: having become a routine technology. Capabilities generally classified as AI as of 2017 include successfully understanding human speech
column7: competing at the highest level in strategic game systems (such as chess and Go)
column8: autonomous cars
column9: intelligent routing in content delivery network and military simulations.

column1: Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956
column2: and in the years since has experienced several waves of optimism
column3: followed by disappointment and the loss of funding (known as an ""AI winter"")
column4: followed by new approaches
column5: success and renewed funding. For most of its history
column6: AI research has been divided into subfields that often fail to communicate with each other. These sub-fields are based on technical considerations
column7: such as particular goals (e.g. ""robotics"" or ""machine learning"")
column8: the use of particular tools (""logic"" or ""neural networks"")
column9: or deep philosophical differences. Subfields have also been based on social factors (particular institutions or the work of particular researchers).

column1: The traditional problems (or goals) of AI research include reasoning
column2: knowledge representation
column3: planning
column4: learning
column5: natural language processing
column6: perception and the ability to move and manipulate objects. General intelligence is among the field's long-term goals. Approaches include statistical methods
column7: computational intelligence
column8: and traditional symbolic AI. Many tools are used in AI
column9: including versions of search and mathematical optimization
column10: neural networks and methods based on statistics
column11: probability and economics. The AI field draws upon computer science
column12: mathematics
column13: psychology
column14: linguistics
column15: philosophy and many others.

column1: The field was founded on the claim that human intelligence ""can be so precisely described that a machine can be made to simulate it"". This raises philosophical arguments about the nature of the mind and the ethics of creating artificial beings endowed with human-like intelligence
column2: issues which have been explored by myth
column3: fiction and philosophy since antiquity. Some people also consider AI to be a danger to humanity if it progresses unabatedly. Others believe that AI
column4: unlike previous technological revolutions
column5: will create a risk of mass unemployment.

column1: In the twenty-first century
column2: AI techniques have experienced a resurgence following concurrent advances in computer power
column3: large amounts of data
column4: and theoretical understanding; and AI techniques have become an essential part of the technology industry
column5: helping to solve many challenging problems in computer science."~0.09265212916014245

column1: 370~5~Asha Bhosle~73213~73224~"Asha Bhosle (born 8 September 1933)
column2: is an Indian singer. She is best known as a playback singer in Hindi cinema
column3: although she has a wider repertoire. Bhosle's career started in 1943 and has spanned over six decades. She has done playback singing for over a thousand Bollywood movies. In addition
column4: she has recorded several private albums and participated in numerous solo concerts in India and abroad. Bhosle is the sister of playback singer Lata Mangeshkar.

column1: Renowned for her voice range and often credited for her versatility
column2: Bhosle's work includes film music
column3: pop
column4: ghazals
column5: bhajans
column6: traditional Indian classical music
column7: folk songs
column8: qawwalis
column9: and Rabindra Sangeets. Apart from Hindi
column10: she has sung in over 20 Indian and foreign languages. In 2006
column11: Asha Bhosle stated that she had sung over 12
column12: 000 songs
column13: a figure repeated by several other sources. In 2011
column14: she was officially acknowledged by the Guinness Book of World Records as the most recorded artist in music history. The Government of India honoured her with the Dadasaheb Phalke Award in 2000 and the Padma Vibhushan in 2008. In 2013
column15: she made her debut as an actress in the film Mai
column16: and received critical acclaim for her performance."~0.4318385566265388

column1: 371~5~Audio mixer~73075~73088~"In sound recording and reproduction
column2: and sound reinforcement systems
column3: a mixing console is an electronic device for combining sounds of many different audio signals. Inputs to the console include microphones being used by singers and for picking up acoustic instruments
column4: signals from electric or electronic instruments
column5: or recorded music. Depending on the type
column6: a mixer is able to control analog or digital signals. The modified signals are summed to produce the combined output signals
column7: which can then be broadcast
column8: amplified through a sound reinforcement system or recorded.

column1: Mixing consoles are used in many applications
column2: including recording studios
column3: public address systems
column4: sound reinforcement systems
column5: nightclubs
column6: broadcasting
column7: television
column8: and film post-production. A typical
column9: simple application combines signals from microphones on stage into an amplifier that drives one set of loudspeakers for the audience. A DJ mixer may have only two channels
column10: for mixing two record players. A coffeehouse's tiny stage might only have a six channel mixer
column11: enough for two singer-guitarists and a percussionist. A nightclub stage's mixer for rock music shows may have 24 channels for mixing the signals from a rhythm section
column12: lead guitar and several vocalists. A mixing console in a professional recording studio may have as many as 96 channels.

column1: In practice
column2: mixers do more than simply mix signals. They can provide phantom power for condenser microphones; pan control
column3: which changes a sound's apparent position in the stereo soundfield; filtering and equalization
column4: which enables sound engineers to boost or cut selected frequencies to improve the sound; dynamic range compression
column5: which allows engineers to increase the overall gain of the system or channel without exceeding the dynamic limits of the system; routing facilities
column6: to send the signal from the mixer to another device
column7: such as a sound recording system or a control room; and monitoring facilities
column8: whereby one of a number of sources can be routed to loudspeakers or headphones for listening
column9: often without affecting the mixer's main output. Some mixers have onboard electronic effects
column10: such as reverb. Some mixers intended for small venue live performance applications may include an integrated power amplifier."~0.39737851757513654

column1: 372~5~Backbeat~23602~23610~"In music and music theory
column2: the beat is the basic unit of time
column3: the pulse (regularly repeating event)
column4: of the mensural level (or beat level). The beat is often defined as the rhythm listeners would tap their toes to when listening to a piece of music
column5: or the numbers a musician counts while performing
column6: though in practice this may be technically incorrect (often the first multiple level). In popular use
column7: beat can refer to a variety of related concepts including: tempo
column8: meter
column9: specific rhythms
column10: and groove.

column1: Rhythm in music is characterized by a repeating sequence of stressed and unstressed beats (often called ""strong"" and ""weak"") and divided into bars organized by time signature and tempo indications.
Metric levels faster than the beat level are division levels
column2: and slower levels are multiple levels. Beat has always been an important part of music. Some music genres such as disco will in general de-emphasize the beat
column3: while other such as funk emphasize the beat to accompany dance."~0.40014625244858204

column1: 373~5~Bali~57544~57548~"Bali (Balinese: ᬩᬮᬶ
column2: Indonesian: Pulau Bali
column3: Provinsi Bali) is an island and province of Indonesia. The province includes the island of Bali and a few smaller neighbouring islands
column4: notably Nusa Penida
column5: Nusa Lembongan and Nusa Ceningan. It is located at the westernmost end of the Lesser Sunda Islands
column6: with Java to the west and Lombok to the east. Its capital
column7: Denpasar
column8: is located in the southern part of the island.

column1: With a population of 3
column3: 757 in the 2010 census
column4: and 4
column6: 000 as of January 2014
column7: the island is home to most of Indonesia's Hindu minority. According to the 2010 Census
column8: 83.5% of Bali's population adhered to Balinese Hinduism
column9: followed by 13.4% Muslim
column10: Christianity at 2.5% and Buddhism 0.5%.

column1: Bali is a popular tourist destination
column2: which has seen a significant rise in tourists since the 1980s. Tourism-related business makes up 80% of its economy. It is renowned for its highly developed arts
column3: including traditional and modern dance
column4: sculpture
column5: painting
column6: leather
column7: metalworking and music. The Indonesian International Film Festival is held every year in Bali. In March 2017
column8: TripAdvisor named Bali as the world's top destination in its Traveller's Choice award.

column1: Bali is part of the Coral Triangle
column2: the area with the highest biodiversity of marine species. In this area alone
column3: over 500 reef-building coral species can be found. For comparison
column4: this is about 7 times as many as in the entire Caribbean. Most recently
column5: Bali was the host of the 2011 ASEAN Summit
column6: 2013 APEC and Miss World 2013. Bali is the home of the Subak irrigation system
column7: a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is also home to a unified confederation of kingdoms composed of 10 traditional royal Balinese houses
column8: where each house rules a specific geographic area. The confederation is the successor of the Bali Kingdom. The royal houses are not recognised by the government of Indonesia; however
column9: they have been operational since their establishment prior to Dutch colonisation."~0.08530985552567813

column1: 374~5~Ballet~14440~14446~"Ballet  (French: [balɛ]) is a type of performance dance that originated during the Italian Renaissance in the 15th century and later developed into a concert dance form in France and Russia. It has since become a widespread
column2: highly technical form of dance with its own vocabulary based on French terminology. It has been globally influential and has defined the foundational techniques used in many other dance genres/cultures. Ballet has been taught in various schools around the world
column3: which have historically incorporated their own cultures to evolve the art. See glossary of ballet.

column1: A ballet
column2: a work
column3: consists of the choreography and music for a ballet production. A well-known example of this is The Nutcracker
column4: a two-act ballet originally choreographed by Marius Petipa and Lev Ivanov with a music score by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky. Ballets are choreographed and performed by trained ballet dancers. Traditional classical ballets usually are performed with classical music accompaniment and use elaborate costumes and staging
column5: whereas modern ballets
column6: such as the neoclassical works of American choreographer George Balanchine
column7: often are performed in simple costumes (e.g.
column8: leotards and tights) and without the use of elaborate sets or scenery."~0.29924613593261784

column1: 375~5~Baroque~44362~44384~The Baroque (US:  or UK: ) is a highly ornate and often extravagant style of architecture
column2: art and music that flourished in Europe from the early 17th until the late 18th century. It followed the Renaissance style and preceded the Neoclassical style. It was encouraged by the Roman Catholic Church as a means to counter the simplicity and austerity of Protestant architecture
column3: art and music. The baroque style used contrast
column4: movement
column5: exuberant detail
column6: grandeur and surprise to achieve a sense of awe. The style began in the first third of the 17th century in Rome
column7: then spread rapidly to France
column8: northern Italy
column9: Spain and Portugal
column10: then to Austria and southern Germany. By the 1730s
column11: it had evolved into an even more flamboyant variant
column12: called rocaille or Rococo
column13: which appeared in France and central Europe until the late 18th century.~0.39815925539054986

column1: 376~5~Bassline~20290~20298~"A bassline (also known as a bass line or bass part) is the term used in many styles of music
column2: such as jazz
column3: blues
column4: funk
column5: dub and electronic
column6: traditional music
column7: or classical music for the low-pitched instrumental part or line played (in jazz and some forms of popular music) by a rhythm section instrument such as the electric bass
column8: double bass
column9: cello
column10: tuba or keyboard (piano
column11: Hammond organ
column12: electric organ
column13: or synthesizer). In unaccompanied solo performance
column14: basslines may simply be played in the lower register of any instrument such as guitar or piano while melody and/or further accompaniment is provided in the middle or upper register. In solo music for piano and pipe organ
column15: these instruments have an excellent lower register that can be used to play a deep bassline. On organs
column16: the bass line is typically played using the pedal keyboard and massive 16' and 32' bass pipes.

column1: Basslines in popular music often use ""riffs"" or ""grooves""
column2: which are usually simple
column3: appealing musical motifs or phrases that are repeated
column4: with variation
column5: throughout the song. ""The bass differs from other voices because of the particular role it plays in supporting and defining harmonic motion. It does so at levels ranging from immediate
column6: chord-by-chord events to the larger harmonic organization of a [sic] entire work."" Bassline riffs usually emphasize the chord tones of each chord (usually the root note
column7: the third note
column8: or the fifth note)
column9: which helps to define a song's key. At the same time
column10: basslines work along with the drum part and the other rhythm instruments to create a clear rhythmic pulse.

column1: The type of rhythmic pulse used in basslines varies widely in different types of music. In swing jazz and jump blues
column2: basslines are often created from a continuous sequence of quarter notes in a mostly scalar
column3: stepwise or arpeggio-based part called a ""walking bass line"". In Latin
column4: salsa music
column5: jazz fusion
column6: reggae
column7: electronica
column8: and some types of rock and metal
column9: basslines may be very rhythmically complex and syncopated. In bluegrass and traditional country music
column10: basslines often emphasize the root and fifth of each chord.

column1: Though basslines may be played by many different types of instruments and in a broad musical range
column2: they are generally played on bass instruments and in the range roughly at least an octave and a half below middle C (roughly the range of the bass clef). In classical music such as string quartets and symphonies
column3: basslines play the same harmonic and rhythmic role; however
column4: they are usually referred to as the ""bass voice"" or the ""bass part""."~0.41530200802142736

column1: 377~5~Bebop~19044~19049~"Bebop or bop is a style of jazz developed in the early to mid-1940s in the United States
column2: which features songs characterized by a fast tempo
column3: complex chord progressions with rapid chord changes and numerous changes of key
column4: instrumental virtuosity
column5: and improvisation based on a combination of harmonic structure
column6: the use of scales and occasional references to the melody.

column1: Bebop developed as the younger generation of jazz musicians expanded the creative possibilities of jazz beyond the popular
column2: dance-oriented swing style with a new ""musician's music"" that was not as danceable and demanded close listening. As bebop was not intended for dancing
column3: it enabled the musicians to play at faster tempos. Bebop musicians explored advanced harmonies
column4: complex syncopation
column5: altered chords
column6: extended chords
column7: chord substitutions
column8: asymmetrical phrasing
column9: and intricate melodies. Bebop groups used rhythm sections in a way that expanded their role. Whereas the key ensemble of the swing era was the big band of up to fourteen pieces playing in an ensemble-based style
column10: the classic bebop group was a small combo that consisted of saxophone (alto or tenor)
column11: trumpet
column12: piano
column13: double bass
column14: and drums playing music in which the ensemble played a supportive role for soloists. Rather than play heavily arranged music
column15: bebop musicians typically played the melody of a song (called the ""head"") with the accompaniment of the rhythm section
column16: followed by a section in which each of the performers improvised a solo
column17: then returned to the melody at the end of the song.

column1: Some of the most influential bebop artists
column2: who were typically composer-performers
column3: are: tenor sax players Dexter Gordon
column4: Sonny Rollins
column5: and James Moody; alto sax player Charlie Parker; trumpeters Fats Navarro
column6: Clifford Brown
column7: and Dizzy Gillespie; pianists Bud Powell
column8: Mary Lou Williams
column9: and Thelonious Monk; electric guitarist Charlie Christian
column10: and drummers Kenny Clarke
column11: Max Roach

column1: 378~5~Behavior~63275~63283~"Behavior (American English) or behaviour (Commonwealth English) is the range of actions and mannerisms made by individuals
column2: organisms
column3: systems
column4: or artificial entities in conjunction with themselves or their environment
column5: which includes the other systems or organisms around as well as the (inanimate) physical environment. It is the response of the system or organism to various stimuli or inputs
column6: whether internal or external
column7: conscious or subconscious
column8: overt or covert
column9: and voluntary or involuntary.

column1: Taking a behavior informatics perspective
column2: a behavior consists of behavior actor
column3: operation
column4: interactions
column5: and their properties. A behavior can be represented as a behavior vector."~0.05013370656988888

column1: 379~5~Bluegrass (music)~24181~24190~"Bluegrass music is a form of American roots music
column2: and is defined by its unique homage to America and its various cultural influences that truly define America. Influenced by the music of Appalachia
column3: bluegrass has mixed roots in Irish
column4: Scottish and English traditional music
column5: and was also later influenced by the music of African-Americans through incorporation of jazz elements.

column1: Settlers from Britain and Ireland arrived in Appalachia during the 18th century
column2: and brought with them the musical traditions of their homelands. These traditions consisted primarily of English and Scottish ballads—which were essentially unaccompanied narrative—and dance music
column3: such as Irish reels
column4: which were accompanied by a fiddle. Many older bluegrass songs come directly from the British Isles. Several Appalachian bluegrass ballads
column5: such as ""Pretty Saro""
column6: ""Cuckoo Bird"" and ""House Carpenter""
column7: come from England and preserve the English ballad tradition both melodically and lyrically. Others
column8: such as ""The Two Sisters""
column9: also come from England; however
column10: the lyrics are about Ireland. Some bluegrass fiddle songs popular in Appalachia
column11: such as ""Leather Britches""
column12: and ""Pretty Polly""
column13: have Scottish roots. The dance tune ""Cumberland Gap"" may be derived from the tune that accompanies the Scottish ballad ""Bonnie George Campbell"". Other songs have different names in different places; for instance in England there is an old ballad known as ""A Brisk Young Sailor Courted Me""
column14: but exactly the same song in North American bluegrass is known as ""I Wish My Baby Was Born"".

column1: In bluegrass
column2: as in some forms of jazz
column3: one or more instruments each takes its turn playing the melody and improvising around it
column4: while the others perform accompaniment; this is especially typified in tunes called breakdowns. This is in contrast to old-time music
column5: in which all instruments play the melody together or one instrument carries the lead throughout while the others provide accompaniment. Breakdowns are often characterized by rapid tempos and unusual instrumental dexterity and sometimes by complex chord changes.

column1: There are three major subgenres of bluegrass. Traditional bluegrass has musicians playing folk songs
column2: tunes with traditional chord progressions
column3: and using only acoustic instruments
column4: with an example being Bill Monroe. Progressive bluegrass groups may use electric instruments and import songs from other genres
column5: particularly rock & roll. Examples include Cadillac Sky and Bearfoot. Another subgenre
column6: bluegrass gospel
column7: uses Christian lyrics
column8: soulful three- or four-part harmony singing
column9: and sometimes the playing of instrumentals. A newer development in the bluegrass world is Neo-traditional bluegrass; exemplified by bands such as The Grascals and Mountain Heart; bands from this subgenre typically have more than one lead singer.

column1: Bluegrass music has attracted a diverse following worldwide. Bluegrass pioneer Bill Monroe characterized the genre as: ""Scottish bagpipes and ole-time fiddlin'. It's Methodist and Holiness and Baptist. It's blues and jazz
column2: and it has a high lonesome sound."""~0.3833997792459808
