column3: one or more instruments each takes its turn playing the melody and improvising around it
column4: while the others perform accompaniment; this is especially typified in tunes called breakdowns. This is in contrast to old-time music
column5: in which all instruments play the melody together or one instrument carries the lead throughout while the others provide accompaniment. Breakdowns are often characterized by rapid tempos and unusual instrumental dexterity and sometimes by complex chord changes.

column1: There are three major subgenres of bluegrass. Traditional bluegrass has musicians playing folk songs
column2: tunes with traditional chord progressions
column3: and using only acoustic instruments
column4: with an example being Bill Monroe. Progressive bluegrass groups may use electric instruments and import songs from other genres
column5: particularly rock & roll. Examples include Cadillac Sky and Bearfoot. Another subgenre
column6: bluegrass gospel
column7: uses Christian lyrics
column8: soulful three- or four-part harmony singing
column9: and sometimes the playing of instrumentals. A newer development in the bluegrass world is Neo-traditional bluegrass; exemplified by bands such as The Grascals and Mountain Heart; bands from this subgenre typically have more than one lead singer.

column1: Bluegrass music has attracted a diverse following worldwide. Bluegrass pioneer Bill Monroe characterized the genre as: ""Scottish bagpipes and ole-time fiddlin'. It's Methodist and Holiness and Baptist. It's blues and jazz
column2: and it has a high lonesome sound."""~0.3833997792459808

column1: 381~5~Blues~2418~2423~"Blues is a music genre and musical form originated by African Americans in the Deep South of the United States around the end of the 19th century. The genre developed from roots in African musical traditions
column2: African-American work songs
column3: spirituals
column4: and the folk music of white Americans of European heritage. Blues incorporated spirituals
column5: work songs
column6: field hollers
column7: shouts
column8: chants
column9: and rhymed simple narrative ballads. The blues form
column10: ubiquitous in jazz
column11: rhythm and blues and rock and roll
column12: is characterized by the call-and-response pattern
column13: the blues scale and specific chord progressions
column14: of which the twelve-bar blues is the most common. Blue notes (or ""worried notes"")
column15: usually thirds or fifths flattened in pitch
column16: are also an essential part of the sound. Blues shuffles or walking bass reinforce the trance-like rhythm and form a repetitive effect known as the groove.

column1: Blues as a genre is also characterized by its lyrics
column2: bass lines
column3: and instrumentation. Early traditional blues verses consisted of a single line repeated four times. It was only in the first decades of the 20th century that the most common current structure became standard: the AAB pattern
column4: consisting of a line sung over the four first bars
column5: its repetition over the next four
column6: and then a longer concluding line over the last bars. Early blues frequently took the form of a loose narrative
column7: often relating the racial discrimination and other challenges experienced by African-Americans.

column1: Many elements
column2: such as the call-and-response format and the use of blue notes
column3: can be traced back to the music of Africa. The origins of the blues are also closely related to the religious music of the Afro-American community
column4: the spirituals. The first appearance of the blues is often dated to after the ending of slavery and
column5: later
column6: the development of juke joints. It is associated with the newly acquired freedom of the former slaves. Chroniclers began to report about blues music at the dawn of the 20th century. The first publication of blues sheet music was in 1908. Blues has since evolved from unaccompanied vocal music and oral traditions of slaves into a wide variety of styles and subgenres. Blues subgenres include country blues
column7: such as Delta blues and Piedmont blues
column8: as well as urban blues styles such as Chicago blues and West Coast blues. World War II marked the transition from acoustic to electric blues and the progressive opening of blues music to a wider audience
column9: especially white listeners. In the 1960s and 1970s
column10: a hybrid form called blues rock developed
column11: which blended blues styles with rock music."~0.3015925498513589

column1: 382~5~Brahms~49058~49064~"Johannes Brahms (German: [joˈhanəs ˈbʁaːms]; 7 May 1833 – 3 April 1897) was a German composer and pianist of the Romantic period. Born in Hamburg into a Lutheran family
column2: Brahms spent much of his professional life in Vienna
column3: Austria. His reputation and status as a composer is such that he is sometimes grouped with Johann Sebastian Bach and Ludwig van Beethoven as one of the ""Three Bs"" of music
column4: a comment originally made by the nineteenth-century conductor Hans von Bülow.

column1: Brahms composed for symphony orchestra
column2: chamber ensembles
column3: piano
column4: organ
column5: and voice and chorus. A virtuoso pianist
column6: he premiered many of his own works. He worked with some of the leading performers of his time
column7: including the pianist Clara Schumann and the violinist Joseph Joachim (the three were close friends). Many of his works have become staples of the modern concert repertoire. An uncompromising perfectionist
column8: Brahms destroyed some of his works and left others unpublished.

column1: Brahms has been considered
column2: by his contemporaries and by later writers
column3: as both a traditionalist and an innovator. His music is firmly rooted in the structures and compositional techniques of the Classical masters. While many contemporaries found his music too academic
column4: his contribution and craftsmanship have been admired by subsequent figures as diverse as Arnold Schoenberg and Edward Elgar. The diligent
column5: highly constructed nature of Brahms's works was a starting point and an inspiration for a generation of composers. Embedded within his meticulous structures
column6: however
column7: are deeply romantic motifs."~0.39219884534221283

column1: 383~5~Byzantine Empire~41730~41746~"The Byzantine Empire
column2: also referred to as the Eastern Roman Empire
column3: was the continuation of the Roman Empire in the East during Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages
column4: when its capital city was Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul
column5: which had been founded as Byzantium). It survived the fragmentation and fall of the Western Roman Empire in the 5th century AD and continued to exist for an additional thousand years until it fell to the Ottoman Turks in 1453. During most of its existence
column6: the empire was the most powerful economic
column7: cultural
column8: and military force in Europe. Both ""Byzantine Empire"" and ""Eastern Roman Empire"" are historiographical terms created after the end of the realm; its citizens continued to refer to their empire as the Roman Empire (Greek: Βασιλεία τῶν Ῥωμαίων
column9: tr. Basileia tôn Rhōmaiōn; Latin: Imperium Romanum)
column10: or Romania (Ῥωμανία)
column11: and to themselves as ""Romans.""

column1: Several signal events from the 4th to 6th centuries mark the period of transition during which the Roman Empire's Greek East and Latin West divided. Constantine I (r. 324–337) reorganised the empire
column2: made Constantinople the new capital
column3: and legalised Christianity. Under Theodosius I (r. 379–395)
column4: Christianity became the Empire's official state religion and other religious practices were proscribed. Finally
column5: under the reign of Heraclius (r. 610–641)
column6: the Empire's military and administration were restructured and adopted Greek for official use instead of Latin. Thus
column7: although the Roman state continued and Roman state traditions were maintained
column8: modern historians distinguish Byzantium from ancient Rome insofar as it was centred on Constantinople
column9: oriented towards Greek rather than Latin culture
column10: and characterised by Orthodox Christianity.

column1: The borders of the Empire evolved significantly over its existence
column2: as it went through several cycles of decline and recovery. During the reign of Justinian I (r. 527–565)
column3: the Empire reached its greatest extent after reconquering much of the historically Roman western Mediterranean coast
column4: including North Africa
column5: Italy
column6: and Rome itself
column7: which it held for two more centuries. During the reign of Maurice (r. 582–602)
column8: the Empire's eastern frontier was expanded and the north stabilised. However
column9: his assassination caused the Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628
column10: which exhausted the Empire's resources and contributed to major territorial losses during the Early Muslim conquests of the seventh century. In a matter of years the Empire lost its richest provinces
column11: Egypt and Syria
column12: to the Arabs.

column1: During the Macedonian dynasty (10th–11th centuries)
column2: the Empire again expanded and experienced the two-century long Macedonian Renaissance
column3: which came to an end with the loss of much of Asia Minor to the Seljuk Turks after the Battle of Manzikert in 1071. This battle opened the way for the Turks to settle in Anatolia.

column1: The Empire recovered again during the Komnenian restoration
column2: such that by the 12th century Constantinople was the largest and wealthiest European city. However
column3: it was delivered a mortal blow during the Fourth Crusade
column4: when Constantinople was sacked in 1204 and the territories that the Empire formerly governed were divided into competing Byzantine Greek and Latin realms. Despite the eventual recovery of Constantinople in 1261
column5: the Byzantine Empire remained only one of several small rival states in the area for the final two centuries of its existence. Its remaining territories were progressively annexed by the Ottomans over the 15th century. The Fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Empire in 1453 finally ended the Byzantine Empire. The last of the imperial Byzantine successor states
column6: the Empire of Trebizond
column7: would be conquered by the Ottomans eight years later in the 1461 Siege of Trebizond."~0.12319013857681588

column1: 384~5~CD player~3053~3062~"A CD player is an electronic device that plays audio compact discs
column2: which are a digital optical disc data storage format. CD players were first sold to consumers in 1982. CDs typically contain recordings of audio material such as music. CD players are often a part of home stereo systems
column3: car audio systems
column4: and personal computers. With the exception of CD boomboxes
column5: most CD players do not produce sound by themselves. Most CD players only produce an output signal via a headphone jack and/or RCA jacks. To listen to music using a CD player with a headphone output jack
column6: the user plugs headphones or earphones into the headphone jack. To use a CD player in a home stereo system
column7: the user connects an RCA cable to the RCA jacks or other outputs and connects it to a hi-fi (or other amplifier) and loudspeakers for listening to music. They are also manufactured as portable devices
column8: which are battery powered and typically used with headphones.

column1: Modern units can play other formats in addition to PCM audio coding used in CDs
column2: such as MP3
column3: AAC and WMA. DJs playing dance music at clubs often use specialized players with an adjustable playback speed to alter the pitch and tempo of the music. Audio engineers using CD players to play music for an event through a sound reinforcement system use professional audio-grade CD players. CD playback functionality is also valuable on CD-ROM/DVD-ROM drive equipped computers as well as on DVD players and CD-ROM/DVD-ROM based game consoles."~0.11427073171375388

column1: 385~5~Cabaret~73565~73572~Cabaret (English: ) is a form of theatrical entertainment featuring music
column2: song
column3: dance
column4: recitation
column5: or drama. It is mainly distinguished by the performance venue
column6: which might be a pub
column7: a restaurant or a nightclub with a stage for performances. The audience
column8: often dining or drinking
column9: does not typically dance but usually sits at tables. Performances are usually introduced by a master of ceremonies or MC. The entertainment
column10: as done by an ensemble of actors and according to its European origins
column11: is often (but not always) oriented towards adult audiences and of a clearly underground nature. In the United States striptease
column12: burlesque
column13: drag shows
column14: or a solo vocalist with a pianist
column15: as well as the venues which offer this entertainment

column1: 386~5~Cadenza~14252~14260~"In music
column2: a cadenza (from Italian: cadenza [kaˈdɛntsa]
column3: meaning cadence; plural
column4: cadenze [kaˈdɛntse]) is
column5: generically
column6: an improvised or written-out ornamental passage played or sung by a soloist or soloists
column7: usually in a ""free"" rhythmic style
column8: and often allowing virtuosic display. During this time the accompaniment will rest
column9: or sustain a note or chord. Thus an improvised cadenza is indicated in written notation by a fermata in all parts. A cadenza usually will occur over the final or penultimate note in a piece
column10: or over the final or penultimate note in an important subsection of a piece. It can also be found before a final coda or ritornello."~0.3003498257656886

column1: 387~5~Cassette player~5735~5759~"A cassette deck is a type of tape machine for playing and recording audio compact cassettes. Consumer electronics formerly used the term deck to distinguish them from a tape recorder
column2: the ""deck"" being part of a stereo component system
column3: while a ""tape recorder"" was more portable and usually had a self-contained power amplifier (and often speakers).

column1: Although the two terms became used interchangeably
column2: a recorder is typically thought of as a low-fidelity portable device
column3: while a deck is considered a high fidelity component."~0.2558286994908735

column1: 388~5~Catholic church~42198~42213~"The Catholic Church
column2: also known as the Roman Catholic Church
column3: is the largest Christian church
column4: with more than 1.29 billion members worldwide. As one of the oldest religious institutions in the world
column5: it has played a prominent role in the history and development of Western civilisation. Headed by the Bishop of Rome
column6: known as the Pope
column7: the church's doctrines are summarised in the Nicene Creed. Its central administration
column8: the Holy See
column9: is in the Vatican City
column10: enclaved within Rome
column11: Italy.

column1: The Catholic Church teaches that it is the One
column2: Holy
column3: Catholic and Apostolic church founded by Jesus Christ
column4: that its bishops are the successors of Christ's apostles
column5: and that the Pope is the successor to Saint Peter to whom primacy was conferred by Jesus Christ. It maintains that it practises the original Christian faith
column6: reserving infallibility
column7: passed down by sacred tradition. The Latin Church
column8: the Eastern Catholic Churches
column9: and institutes such as mendicant orders and enclosed monastic orders reflect a variety of theological and spiritual emphases in the Church.

column1: Of its seven sacraments the Eucharist is the principal one
column2: celebrated liturgically in the Mass. The church teaches that through consecration by a priest the sacrificial bread and wine become the body and blood of Christ. The Virgin Mary is venerated in the Catholic Church as Mother of God and Queen of Heaven
column3: honoured in dogmas and devotions. Its teaching includes sanctification through faith and evangelisation of the Gospel and Catholic social teaching
column4: which emphasises support for the sick
column5: the poor
column6: and the afflicted through the corporal and spiritual works of mercy. The Catholic Church is the largest non-government provider of education and health care in the world.

column1: The Catholic Church has influenced Western philosophy
column2: culture
column3: science
column4: and art. The Catholic Church shared communion with the Eastern Orthodox Church until the East–West Schism in 1054
column5: disputing particularly the authority of the Pope
column6: as well as with the Oriental Orthodox churches prior to the Chalcedonian schism in 451 over differences in Christology. Catholics live all over the world through missions
column7: diaspora
column8: and conversions. Since the 20th century the majority reside in the southern hemisphere due to secularisation in Europe
column9: and increased persecution in the Middle East. From the late 20th century
column10: the Catholic Church has been criticised for its doctrines on sexuality
column11: its refusal to ordain women and its handling of sexual abuse cases."~0.17595564815252507

column1: 389~5~Chaconne~34102~34110~"A chaconne (; French: [ʃakɔn]; Spanish: chacona; Italian: ciaccona
column2: pronounced [tʃakˈkoːna]; earlier English: chacony) is a type of musical composition popular in the baroque era when it was much used as a vehicle for variation on a repeated short harmonic progression
column3: often involving a fairly short repetitive bass-line (ground bass) which offered a compositional outline for variation
column4: decoration
column5: figuration and melodic invention. In this it closely resembles the passacaglia.

column1: The ground bass
column2: if there is one
column3: may typically descend stepwise from the tonic to the dominant pitch of the scale; the harmonies given to the upper parts may emphasize the circle of fifths or a derivative pattern thereof."~0.3142104963445954

column1: 390~5~Chantey~2018~2026~The chanter is the part of the bagpipe upon which the player creates the melody. It consists of a number of finger-holes
column2: and in its simpler forms looks similar to a recorder. On more elaborate bagpipes
column3: such as the Northumbrian bagpipes or the Uilleann pipes
column4: it also may have a number of keys
column5: to increase the instrument's range and/or the number of keys (in the modal sense) it can play in. Like the rest of the bagpipe
column6: they are often decorated with a variety of substances
column7: including metal (silver/nickel/gold/brass)
column8: bone
column9: ivory
column10: or plastic mountings.~0.30535801244380745

column1: 391~5~Charles Darwin~65984~65998~"Charles Robert Darwin
column2: (; 12 February 1809 – 19 April 1882) was an English naturalist
column3: geologist and biologist
column4: best known for his contributions to the science of evolution. He established that all species of life have descended over time from common ancestors and
column5: in a joint publication with Alfred Russel Wallace
column6: introduced his scientific theory that this branching pattern of evolution resulted from a process that he called natural selection
column7: in which the struggle for existence has a similar effect to the artificial selection involved in selective breeding.

column1: Darwin published his theory of evolution with compelling evidence in his 1859 book On the Origin of Species
column2: overcoming scientific rejection of earlier concepts of transmutation of species. By the 1870s
column3: the scientific community and a majority of the educated public had accepted evolution as a fact. However
column4: many favoured competing explanations and it was not until the emergence of the modern evolutionary synthesis from the 1930s to the 1950s that a broad consensus developed in which natural selection was the basic mechanism of evolution. Darwin's scientific discovery is the unifying theory of the life sciences
column5: explaining the diversity of life.

column1: Darwin's early interest in nature led him to neglect his medical education at the University of Edinburgh; instead
column2: he helped to investigate marine invertebrates. Studies at the University of Cambridge (Christ's College) encouraged his passion for natural science. His five-year voyage on HMS Beagle established him as an eminent geologist whose observations and theories supported Charles Lyell's uniformitarian ideas
column3: and publication of his journal of the voyage made him famous as a popular author.

column1: Puzzled by the geographical distribution of wildlife and fossils he collected on the voyage
column2: Darwin began detailed investigations
column3: and in 1838 conceived his theory of natural selection. Although he discussed his ideas with several naturalists
column4: he needed time for extensive research and his geological work had priority. He was writing up his theory in 1858 when Alfred Russel Wallace sent him an essay that described the same idea
column5: prompting immediate joint publication of both of their theories. Darwin's work established evolutionary descent with modification as the dominant scientific explanation of diversification in nature. In 1871 he examined human evolution and sexual selection in The Descent of Man
column6: and Selection in Relation to Sex
column7: followed by The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals (1872). His research on plants was published in a series of books
column8: and in his final book
column9: The Formation of Vegetable Mould
column10: through the Actions of Worms (1881)
column11: he examined earthworms and their effect on soil.

column1: Darwin has been described as one of the most influential figures in human history
column2: and he was honoured by burial in Westminster Abbey."~0.12728898776405695

column1: 392~5~Choir~3435~3440~"A choir () (also known as a quire
column2: chorale or chorus) is a musical ensemble of singers. Choral music
column3: in turn
column4: is the music written specifically for such an ensemble to perform. Choirs may perform music from the classical music repertoire
column5: which spans from the Medieval era to the present
column6: or popular music repertoire. Most choirs are led by a conductor
column7: who leads the performances with arm and face gestures.

column1: A body of singers who perform together as a group is called a choir or chorus. The former term is very often applied to groups affiliated with a church (whether or not they actually occupy the choir) and the second to groups that perform in theatres or concert halls
column2: but this distinction is far from rigid. Choirs may sing without instrumental accompaniment
column3: with the accompaniment of a piano or pipe organ
column4: with a small ensemble (e.g.
column5: harpsichord
column6: cello and double bass for a Baroque piece)
column7: or with a full orchestra of 70 to 100 musicians.

column1: The term ""Choir"" has the secondary definition of a subset of an ensemble; thus one speaks of the ""woodwind choir"" of an orchestra
column2: or different ""choirs"" of voices or instruments in a polychoral composition. In typical 18th- to 21st-century oratorios and masses
column3: chorus or choir is usually understood to imply more than one singer per part
column4: in contrast to the quartet of soloists also featured in these works."~0.4399096153385143

column1: 393~5~Christoph Willibald Gluck~48260~48285~"Christoph Willibald (Ritter von) Gluck (German: [ˈkʁɪstɔf ˈvɪlɪbalt ˈɡlʊk]; 2 July 1714 – 15 November 1787) was a composer of Italian and French opera in the early classical period. Born in the Upper Palatinate (now part of Germany) and raised in Bohemia
column2: he gained prominence at the Habsburg court at Vienna
column3: where he brought about the practical reform of opera's dramaturgical practices for which many intellectuals had been campaigning. With a series of radical new works in the 1760s
column4: among them Orfeo ed Euridice and Alceste
column5: he broke the stranglehold that Metastasian opera seria had enjoyed for much of the century.

column1: The strong influence of French opera in these works encouraged Gluck to move to Paris
column2: which he did in November 1773. Fusing the traditions of Italian opera and the French national genre into a new synthesis
column3: Gluck wrote eight operas for the Parisian stage. One
column4: Iphigénie en Tauride
column5: was a great success and is generally acknowledged to be his finest work. Though he was extremely popular and widely credited with bringing about a revolution in French opera
column6: Gluck's mastery of the Parisian operatic scene was never absolute
column7: and after the poor reception of his Echo et Narcisse
column8: he left Paris in disgust and returned to Vienna to live out the remainder of his life."~0.30125821782953766

column1: 394~5~Clara Schumann~70736~70750~Clara Schumann (née Clara Josephine Wieck; 13 September 1819 – 20 May 1896) was a German musician and composer
column2: considered one of the most distinguished pianists of the Romantic era. She exerted her influence over a 61-year concert career
column3: changing the format and repertoire of the piano recital and the tastes of the listening public. Her husband was the composer Robert Schumann. Together they encouraged Johannes Brahms. She was the first to perform publicly any work by Brahms. She later premiered some other pieces by Brahms
column4: notably the Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel. Clara Schumann was featured on the 100 deutsche marks banknote from 2 January 1989 until the adoption of the euro

column1: 395~5~Classical music~2086~2095~"Classical music is art music produced or rooted in the traditions of Western culture
column2: including both liturgical (religious) and secular music. While a more precise term is also used to refer to the period from 1750 to 1820 (the Classical period)
column3: this article is about the broad span of time from before the 6th century AD to the present day
column4: which includes the Classical period and various other periods. The central norms of this tradition became codified between 1550 and 1900
column5: which is known as the common-practice period. The major time divisions of Western art music are as follows:

column1: the ancient music period
column2: before 500 AD

column1: the early music period
column2: which includes

column1: the Medieval (500–1400) including
the ars antiqua (1170–1310)
the ars nova (1310–1377)
the ars subtilior (1360–1420)
the Renaissance (1400–1600) eras.
the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
the common-practice period
column2: which includes

column1: the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
Classical (1750–1820)
Romantic eras (c.1780–1910)
the 20th century (1901–2000) which includes
the modern (1890–1930) that overlaps from the late-19th century
the high modern (1930–present)
impressionism (1875–1925) that also overlaps from the late-19th century
neoclassicism (1920–1950)
column2: predominantly in the inter-war period

column1: the postmodern (1930–present) eras
the experimental (1950–present)
contemporary (1945 or 1975–present)
European art music is largely distinguished from many other non-European classical and some popular musical forms by its system of staff notation
column2: in use since about the 11th century. Western staff notation is used by composers to indicate to the performer the pitches (which form the melodies
column3: basslines and chords)
column4: tempo
column5: metre and rhythms for a piece of music. This can leave less room for practices such as improvisation and ad libitum ornamentation
column6: which are frequently heard in non-European art music and in popular-music styles such as jazz and blues. Another difference is that whereas most popular styles adopt the song (strophic) form or a derivation of this form
column7: classical music has been noted for its development of highly sophisticated forms of instrumental music such as the symphony
column8: concerto
column9: fugue
column10: sonata
column11: and mixed vocal and instrumental styles such as opera
column12: cantata
column13: and mass.

column1: The term ""classical music"" did not appear until the early 19th century
column2: in an attempt to distinctly canonize the period from Johann Sebastian Bach to Ludwig van Beethoven as a golden age. The earliest reference to ""classical music"" recorded by the Oxford English Dictionary is from about 1829."~0.4445589816771897

column1: 396~5~Cognitive science~64600~64617~"Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary
column2: scientific study of the mind and its processes. It examines the nature
column3: the tasks
column4: and the functions of cognition (in a broad sense). Cognitive scientists study intelligence and behavior
column5: with a focus on how nervous systems represent
column6: process
column7: and transform information. Mental faculties of concern to cognitive scientists include language
column8: perception
column9: memory
column10: attention
column11: reasoning
column12: and emotion; to understand these faculties
column13: cognitive scientists borrow from fields such as linguistics
column14: psychology
column15: artificial intelligence
column17: neuroscience
column18: and anthropology. The typical analysis of cognitive science spans many levels of organization
column19: from learning and decision to logic and planning; from neural circuitry to modular brain organization. The fundamental concept of cognitive science is that ""thinking can best be understood in terms of representational structures in the mind and computational procedures that operate on those structures.""

column1: The cognitive sciences began as an intellectual movement in the 1950s often referred to as the cognitive revolution."~0.09237880575945236
397~5~Composer~1404~1412~"A composer (Latin compōnō; literally ""one who puts together"") is a musician who is an author of music in any form
column2: including vocal music (for a singer or choir)
column3: instrumental music

column6: including
column7: for example
column8: classical music
column9: musical theatre
column10: blues
column11: folk music
column12: jazz
column13: and popular music. Composers often express their works in a written musical score using musical notation.

column1: Many composers are
column2: or were
column3: also skilled performers of music."~0.3128098051557017

column1: 398~5~Concert band~6231~6243~"A concert band
column2: also called wind ensemble
column3: symphonic band
column4: wind symphony
column5: wind orchestra
column6: wind band
column7: or symphonic winds
column8: is a performing ensemble consisting of members of the woodwind
column9: brass
column10: and percussion families of instruments
column11: along with the double bass or bass guitar. On rare occasions
column12: additional non traditional instruments may be added to such ensembles such as piano
column13: harp
column14: synthesizer
column15: or electric guitar.

column1: A concert band's repertoire includes original wind compositions

column3: light music

column5: a concert band is distinguished from the marching band in that its primary function is as a concert ensemble. The standard repertoire for the concert band does
column6: however
column7: contain concert marches."~0.4129742842481078

column1: 399~5~Concert hall~67814~67826~"A concert hall is a cultural building with a stage that serves as a performance venue and an auditorium filled with seats. While early halls built in the 18th and 19th century were designed for classical orchestra
column2: concerto and opera concerts and ballet performances
column3: halls built in the 20th and 21st century were often built to accommodate a wider range of performance types
column4: including musicals. In the 2010s
column5: popular music such as rock music and traditional music such as folk music are also performed in these venues. Many concert halls exist as one of several halls or performance spaces within a larger performing arts center. In many towns
column6: the concert hall is combined with a convention center. Concert halls typically also contain orchestral rehearsal rooms. Many larger cities have both public and private concert halls. Particularly in smaller cities with fewer alternative venues
column7: concert halls may also be used to accommodate other activities
column8: from theatrical performances to academic presentations and university graduation ceremonies.

column1: This list does not include other venues such as sports stadia
column2: dramatic theatres or convention centres that may occasionally be used for concerts.

column1: The list is organised alphabetically by geo-political region or continent and then by country within each region."~0.28282248252420816

401~5~Conducting~71957~71967~Conducting is the art of directing a musical performance
column2: such as an orchestral or choral concert. It has been defined as ""the art of directing the simultaneous performance of several players or singers by the use of gesture."" column4: ensure correct entries by various members of the ensemble

column1: Conductors act as guides to the orchestras or choirs they conduct. They choose the works to be performed and study their scores
column2: to which they may make certain adjustments (e.g.
column3: regarding tempo

column5: phrasing

column7: and so on)

column12: hearing auditions and selecting members

column15: concert bands and other sizable musical ensembles such as big bands are usually led by conductors."~0.11167776473583427

column1: 402~5~Counterpoint~34286~34298~"In music

column1: 403~5~Counting~81222~81230~"Counting is the action of finding the number of elements of a finite set of objects. The traditional way of counting consists of continually increasing a (mental or spoken) counter by a unit for every element of the set
column2: in some order
column3: while marking (or displacing) those elements to avoid visiting the same element more than once
column4: until no unmarked elements are left; if the counter was set to one after the first object
column5: the value after visiting the final object gives the desired number of elements. The related term enumeration refers to uniquely identifying the elements of a finite (combinatorial) set or infinite set by assigning a number to each element.

column1: Counting sometimes involves numbers other than one; for example
column2: when counting money
column3: counting out change
column4: ""counting by twos"" (2
column11: or ""counting by fives"" (5

column1: There is archaeological evidence suggesting that humans have been counting for at least 50
column2: 000 years. Counting was primarily used by ancient cultures to keep track of social and economic data such as number of group members
column3: prey animals
column4: property
column5: or debts (i.e.
column6: accountancy). The development of counting led to the development of mathematical notation
column7: numeral systems

column1: 404~5~Country music~2339~2352~"Country music ()

column1: 405~5~Cultural Revolution~91448~91467~"The Cultural Revolution
column2: formally the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution
column3: was a sociopolitical movement in China from 1966 until 1976. Launched by Mao Zedong
column4: then Chairman of the Communist Party of China
column5: its stated goal was to preserve 'true' Communist ideology in the country by purging remnants of capitalist and traditional elements from Chinese society
column6: and to re-impose Maoist thought as the dominant ideology within the Party. The Revolution marked Mao's return to a position of power after the Great Leap Forward. The movement paralyzed China politically and negatively affected the country's economy and society to a significant degree.

column1: The movement was launched in May 1966
column2: after Mao alleged that bourgeois elements had infiltrated the government and society at large
column3: aiming to restore capitalism. To eliminate his rivals within the Communist Party of China
column4: Mao insisted that these ""revisionists"" be removed through violent class struggle. China's youth responded to Mao's appeal by forming Red Guard groups around the country. The movement spread into the military
column5: urban workers
column6: and the Communist Party leadership itself. It resulted in widespread factional struggles in all walks of life. In the top leadership
column7: it led to a mass purge of senior officials
column8: most notably Liu Shaoqi and Deng Xiaoping. During the same period
column9: Mao's personality cult grew to immense proportions.

column1: In the violent struggles that ensued across the country
column2: millions of people were persecuted and suffered a wide range of abuses including public humiliation
column3: arbitrary imprisonment
column4: torture
column5: hard labor
column6: sustained harassment
column7: seizure of property and sometimes execution. A large segment of the population was forcibly displaced
column8: most notably the transfer of urban youth to rural regions during the Down to the Countryside Movement. Historical relics and artifacts were destroyed. Cultural and religious sites were ransacked.

column1: Mao officially declared the Cultural Revolution to have ended in 1969
column2: but its active phase lasted until the death of military leader Lin Biao in 1971. After Mao's death and the arrest of the Gang of Four in 1976
column3: reformers led by Deng Xiaoping gradually began to dismantle the Maoist policies associated with the Cultural Revolution. In 1981
column4: the Party declared that the Cultural Revolution was ""responsible for the most severe setback and the heaviest losses suffered by the Party
column5: the country
column6: and the people since the founding of the People's Republic""."~0.16227987821578815

column1: 406~5~Culture~25~33~"Culture () is the social behavior and norms found in human societies. Culture is considered a central concept in anthropology
column2: encompassing the range of phenomena that are transmitted through social learning in human societies. Some aspects of human behavior
column3: social practices such as culture
column4: expressive forms such as art
column5: music
column6: dance
column7: ritual
column8: religion
column9: and technologies such as tool usage
column10: cooking
column11: shelter
column12: and clothing are said to be cultural universals
column13: found in all human societies. The concept of material culture covers the physical expressions of culture
column14: such as technology
column15: architecture and art
column16: whereas the immaterial aspects of culture such as principles of social organization (including practices of political organization and social institutions)
column17: mythology
column19: literature (both written and oral)
column20: and science comprise the intangible cultural heritage of a society.

column1: In the humanities
column2: one sense of culture as an attribute of the individual has been the degree to which they have cultivated a particular level of sophistication in the arts
column3: sciences
column4: education
column5: or manners. The level of cultural sophistication has also sometimes been seen to distinguish civilizations from less complex societies. Such hierarchical perspectives on culture are also found in class-based distinctions between a high culture of the social elite and a low culture
column6: popular culture
column7: or folk culture of the lower classes
column8: distinguished by the stratified access to cultural capital. In common parlance
column9: culture is often used to refer specifically to the symbolic markers used by ethnic groups to distinguish themselves visibly from each other such as body modification
column10: clothing or jewelry. Mass culture refers to the mass-produced and mass mediated forms of consumer culture that emerged in the 20th century. Some schools of philosophy
column11: such as Marxism and critical theory
column12: have argued that culture is often used politically as a tool of the elites to manipulate the lower classes and create a false consciousness
column13: and such perspectives are common in the discipline of cultural studies. In the wider social sciences
column14: the theoretical perspective of cultural materialism holds that human symbolic culture arises from the material conditions of human life
column15: as humans create the conditions for physical survival
column16: and that the basis of culture is found in evolved biological dispositions.

column1: When used as a count noun
column2: a ""culture"" is the set of customs
column3: traditions
column4: and values of a society or community
column5: such as an ethnic group or nation. Culture is the set of knowledge acquired over time. In this sense
column6: multiculturalism values the peaceful coexistence and mutual respect between different cultures inhabiting the same planet. Sometimes ""culture"" is also used to describe specific practices within a subgroup of a society
column7: a subculture (e.g. ""bro culture"")
column8: or a counterculture. Within cultural anthropology
column9: the ideology and analytical stance of cultural relativism holds that cultures cannot easily be objectively ranked or evaluated because any evaluation is necessarily situated within the value system of a given culture. Yet within philosophy
column10: this stance of cultural relativism is undermined and made inapplicable since such value judgement is itself a product of a given culture."~0.2375439691798445

column1: 407~5~Cymbal~37492~37499~A cymbal is a common percussion instrument. Often used in pairs

column2: pronounced [da kˈkaːpo]
column3: is an Italian musical term that means ""from the beginning"" (literally
column4: ""from the head""). It is often abbreviated as D.C. The term is a directive to repeat the previous part of music
column5: often used to save space
column6: and thus is an easier way of saying to repeat the music from the beginning.

column1: In small pieces
column2: this might be the same thing as a repeat. But in larger works
column3: D.C. might occur after one or more repeats of small sections
column4: indicating a return to the very beginning. The resulting structure of the piece is generally in ternary form. Sometimes
column5: the composer describes the part to be repeated
column6: for example: Menuet da capo. In opera
column7: where an aria of this structure is called a da capo aria
column8: the repeated section is often adorned with grace notes.

column1: The word Fine (Ital. 'end') is generally placed above the stave at the point where the movement ceases after a 'Da capo' repetition. Its place is occasionally taken by a pause (see fermata).""
Variations of the direction are:
Da Capo al Fine (often abbreviated as D.C. al Fine): Repeat from beginning to the end
column2: or up to the word Fine (should that appear at the end of the passage)—the word Fine itself signifying the end.

column1: Da Capo al Coda (often abbreviated as D.C. al Coda): Repeat from beginning to an indicated place and then play the tail part (the ""Coda""). It directs the musician to go back and repeat the music from the beginning (""Capo"")
column2: and to continue playing until one reaches the first coda symbol. Upon reaching the first coda symbol
column3: skip to the second coda symbol (which signifies the ending of the piece)
column4: and continue playing until the end. The portion of the piece from the second coda to the end is often referred to as the ""coda"" of the piece
column5: or quite literally as the ""end"". This may also be instructed by simply using the words al Coda after which the musician is to skip to the written word Coda.

column1: Da Capo al Segno (often abbreviated as D.C. al Segno): It means ""From the beginning to the sign (𝄋)"".

column1: 410~5~Descant~34337~34345~"Descant
column2: discant
column3: or discantus can refer to several different things in music
column4: depending on the period in question; etymologically
column5: the word means a voice (cantus) above or removed from others.

column1: A descant is a form of medieval music in which one singer sang a fixed melody
column2: and others accompanied with improvisations. The word in this sense comes from the term discantus supra librum (descant ""above the book"")
column3: and is a form of Gregorian chant in which only the melody is notated but an improvised polyphony is understood. The discantus supra librum had specific rules governing the improvisation of the additional voices.

column4: by the Renaissance

column4: florid melody sung by a few sopranos as a decoration for a hymn."~0.29154570815650943

column1: 411~5~Dhrupad~93177~93184~"Dhrupad is a genre in Hindustani classical music. It is the oldest form of compositions in classical music and a form that is also found in the South Indian (Carnatic) tradition. It is a Sanskrit name
column2: derived from the words dhruva (immovable
column3: permanent) and pad (verse)

column5: and it is discussed in the Hindu Sanskrit text Natyashastra (~200 BCE – 200 CE). It is also described in other ancient and medieval Sanskrit texts
column6: such as chapter 33 of Book 10 in the Bhagavata Purana (~800–1000 CE)
column7: where the theories of music and devotional songs for Krishna are summarized.

column1: The term denotes both the verse form of the poetry and the style in which it is sung.It is spiritual
column2: heroic
column3: thoughtful
column4: virtuous
column5: embedding moral wisdom or solemn form of song-music combination. Thematic matter ranges from the religious and spiritual (mostly in praise of Hindu deities) to royal panegyrics
column6: musicology and romance.

column1: A Dhrupad has at least four stanzas
column2: called Sthayi (or Asthayi)
column3: Antara
column4: Sancari and Abhoga. The Sthayi part is a melody that uses the middle octave's first tetrachord and the lower octave notes. The Antara part uses the middle octave's second tetrachord and the higher octave notes. The Samcari part is the development phase
column5: which holistically builds using parts of Sthayi and Antara already played
column6: and it uses melodic material built with all the three octave notes. The Abhoga is the concluding section
column7: that brings the listener back to the familiar starting point of Sthayi
column8: albeit with rhythmic variations
column9: with diminished notes like a gentle goodbye
column10: that are ideally mathematical fractions such as dagun (half)
column11: tigun (third) or caugun (fourth). Sometimes a fifth stanza called Bhoga is included. Though usually related to philosophical or Bhakti (emotional devotion to a god or goddess) themes
column12: some Dhrupads were composed to praise kings."~0.46124579710934566

column1: 412~5~Disc jockey~76425~76436~"A disc jockey
column2: often abbreviated as DJ
column3: is a person who plays existing recorded music for a live audience. Most common types of DJs include radio DJ
column4: club DJ who performs at a nightclub or music festival
column5: and turntablist who uses record players
column6: usually turntables
column7: to manipulate sounds on phonograph records. Originally
column8: the ""disc"" in ""disc jockey"" referred to gramophone records
column9: but now ""DJ"" is used as an all-encompassing term to describe someone who mixes recorded music from any source
column10: including cassettes
column11: CDs
column12: or digital audio files on a CDJ or laptop. The title ""DJ"" is commonly used by DJs in front of their real names or adopted pseudonyms or stage names.

column1: DJs use equipment that can play at least two sources of recorded music simultaneously and mix them together to create seamless transitions between recordings and develop unique mixes of songs. Often
column2: this involves aligning the beats of the music sources so their rhythms do not clash when played together

Mixers are also used to pre-listen to sources of recorded music in headphones and adjust upcoming tracks to mix with currently playing music. DJ software can be used with a DJ controller device to mix audio files on a computer instead of a console mixer. DJs may also use a microphone to speak to the audience; effects units such as reverb to create sound effects; and electronic musical instruments such as drum machines and synthesizers."~0.3927413976442509

column1: 413~5~Dissertation~86910~86916~"A thesis or dissertation is a document submitted in support of candidature for an academic degree or professional qualification presenting the author's research and findings. In some contexts

column4: and the required minimum study period may thus vary significantly in duration.

414~5~Divertimento~46630~46642~"Divertimento  (Italian: [divertiˈmento]; from the Italian divertire ""to amuse"") is a musical genre

The mood of the divertimento is most often lighthearted (as a result of being played at social functions) and it is generally composed for a small ensemble. The term is used to describe a wide variety of secular (non-religious) instrumental works for soloist or chamber ensemble. It is usually a kind of music entertainment

column2: sometimes referred to as hot jazz or traditional jazz

Their 1917 recordings fostered popular awareness of this new style of music. At that time

That reflected the fact that virtually all of the recorded repertoire of New Orleans musicians was from the period when the format was already evolving beyond the traditional New Orleans format. ""Dixieland"" may in that sense be regarded as denoting the jazz revival movement of the late 1930s to the 1950s as much as any particular subgenre of jazz. The essential elements that were accepted as within the style were the traditional front lines consisting of trumpets

column1: 417~5~Egypt~37005~37010~"Egypt ( ( listen) EE-jipt; Arabic: مِصر‎ Miṣr
column2: Egyptian Arabic: مَصر‎ Maṣr
column3: Coptic: Ⲭⲏⲙⲓ Khēmi)

column1: Egypt emerged as one of the world's first nation states in the tenth millennium BC. Considered a cradle of civilisation

column3: agriculture
column4: urbanisation
column5: organised religion and central government. Iconic monuments such as the Giza Necropolis and its Great Sphinx

column7: Thebes

column15: Persian
column17: Arab

column1: Modern Egypt dates back to 1922

column1: With over 95 million inhabitants

column6: 000 square kilometres (15
column7: 000 sq mi)

column1: 418~5~Egyptians~37028~37037~"Egyptians (Egyptian Arabic: مَصريين‎  IPA: [mɑsˤɾɪjˈjiːn]; Maṣreyyīn; Arabic: مِصريّون‎; Coptic: ⲛⲓⲣⲉⲙⲛ̀ⲭⲏⲙⲓ Ni/rem/en/kīmi) are an ethnic group native to Egypt and the citizens of that country sharing a common culture and a common dialect known as Egyptian Arabic.
Egyptian identity is closely tied to geography. The population of Egypt is concentrated in the lower Nile Valley
column2: the small strip of cultivable land stretching from the First Cataract to the Mediterranean and enclosed by desert both to the east and to the west. This unique geography has been the basis of the development of Egyptian society since antiquity.

column1: 419~5~Electroencephalography~64462~64484~"Electroencephalography (EEG) is an electrophysiological monitoring method to record electrical activity of the brain. It is typically noninvasive
column2: with the electrodes placed along the scalp
column3: although invasive electrodes are sometimes used such as in electrocorticography. EEG measures voltage fluctuations resulting from ionic current within the neurons of the brain. In clinical contexts
column4: EEG refers to the recording of the brain's spontaneous electrical activity over a period of time
column5: as recorded from multiple electrodes placed on the scalp. Diagnostic applications generally focus either on event-related potentials or on the spectral content of EEG. The former investigates potential fluctuations time locked to an event like stimulus onset or button press. The latter analyses the type of neural oscillations (popularly called ""brain waves"") that can be observed in EEG signals in the frequency domain.

column1: EEG is most often used to diagnose epilepsy

column1: Derivatives of the EEG technique include evoked potentials (EP)

column1: 421~5~Emotion~63094~63105~"Emotion is any conscious experience characterized by intense mental activity and a certain degree of pleasure or displeasure. Scientific discourse has drifted to other meanings and there is no consensus on a definition. Emotion is often intertwined with mood
column2: temperament
column3: personality
column4: disposition
column5: and motivation. In some theories
column6: cognition is an important aspect of emotion. Those acting primarily on the emotions they are feeling may seem as if they are not thinking

column9: the realization of our believing that we are in a dangerous situation and the subsequent arousal of our body's nervous system (rapid heartbeat and breathing
column10: sweating
column11: muscle tension) is integral to the experience of our feeling afraid. Other theories
column12: however
column13: claim that emotion is separate from and can precede cognition.

column1: Emotions are complex. According to some theories
column2: they are states of feeling that result in physical and psychological changes that influence our behavior. The physiology of emotion is closely linked to arousal of the nervous system with various states and strengths of arousal relating
column3: apparently
column4: to particular emotions. Emotion is also linked to behavioral tendency. Extroverted people are more likely to be social and express their emotions
column5: while introverted people are more likely to be more socially withdrawn and conceal their emotions. Emotion is often the driving force behind motivation
column6: positive or negative. According to other theories
column7: emotions are not causal forces but simply syndromes of components

column9: feeling
column10: behavior
column11: and physiological changes

column8: behaviorists with instrumental behavior
column9: psychophysiologists with physiological changes
column10: and so on. More recently
column11: emotion is said to consist of all the components. The different components of emotion are categorized somewhat differently depending on the academic discipline. In psychology and philosophy
column12: emotion typically includes a subjective
column13: conscious experience characterized primarily by psychophysiological expressions
column14: biological reactions
column15: and mental states. A similar multicomponential description of emotion is found in sociology. For example
column16: Peggy Thoits described emotions as involving physiological components
column17: cultural or emotional labels (anger
column19: etc.)
column21: and the appraisal of situations and contexts.

In addition PET scans and fMRI scans help study the affective processes in the brain.

column1: 423~5~Ethnicity~66465~66474~"An ethnic group
column2: or an ethnicity

column4: language

column9: history
column10: homeland

column13: mythology and ritual
column14: cuisine

column1: Ethnic groups

column3: often continue to speak related languages and share a similar gene pool. By way of language shift
column4: acculturation
column5: adoption and religious conversion
column6: it is sometimes possible for individuals or groups to leave one ethnic group and become part of another (except for ethnic groups emphasizing racial purity as a key membership criterion).

column3: etc.)
column4: generally related to cultures of more recent immigrants

column1: The largest ethnic groups in modern times comprise hundreds of millions of individuals (Han Chinese being the largest)
column2: while the smallest are limited to a few dozen individuals (numerous indigenous peoples worldwide). Larger ethnic groups may be subdivided into smaller sub-groups known variously as tribes or clans

column1: 424~5~Ethnomusicology~69762~69777~"Ethnomusicology is the study of music from the cultural and social aspects of the people who make it. It encompasses distinct theoretical and methodical approaches that emphasize cultural
column2: social
column3: material
column4: cognitive

column8: sociological and intercultural perspectives. Bruno Nettl once characterized ethnomusicology as a product of Western thinking

Of the vast number of études from that era some are still used as teaching material (particularly pieces by Carl Czerny and Muzio Clementi)
column6: and a few

column1: 426~5~Evolutionary theory~65963~65982~"Evolution is change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations. Evolutionary processes give rise to biodiversity at every level of biological organisation
column2: including the levels of species
column3: individual organisms
column4: and molecules.

column1: Repeated formation of new species (speciation)
column2: change within species (anagenesis)
column3: and loss of species (extinction) throughout the evolutionary history of life on Earth are demonstrated by shared sets of morphological and biochemical traits
column4: including shared DNA sequences. These shared traits are more similar among species that share a more recent common ancestor
column5: and can be used to reconstruct a biological ""tree of life"" based on evolutionary relationships (phylogenetics)
column6: using both existing species and fossils. The fossil record includes a progression from early biogenic graphite
column7: to microbial mat fossils
column8: to fossilised multicellular organisms. Existing patterns of biodiversity have been shaped both by speciation and by extinction.

column1: In the mid-19th century
column2: Charles Darwin formulated the scientific theory of evolution by natural selection
column3: published in his book On the Origin of Species (1859). Evolution by natural selection is a process first demonstrated by the observation that often
column4: more offspring are produced than can possibly survive. This is followed by three observable facts about living organisms: 1) traits vary among individuals with respect to morphology
column5: physiology
column6: and behaviour (phenotypic variation)
column7: 2) different traits confer different rates of survival and reproduction (differential fitness)
column8: and 3) traits can be passed from generation to generation (heritability of fitness). Thus
column9: in successive generations members of a population are replaced by progeny of parents better adapted to survive and reproduce in the biophysical environment in which natural selection takes place.

column1: This teleonomy is the quality whereby the process of natural selection creates and preserves traits that are seemingly fitted for the functional roles they perform. The processes by which the changes occur
column2: from one generation to another
column3: are called evolutionary processes or mechanisms. The four most widely recognised evolutionary processes are natural selection (including sexual selection)
column4: genetic drift
column5: mutation and gene migration due to genetic admixture. Natural selection and genetic drift sort variation; mutation and gene migration create variation.

column1: Consequences of selection can include meiotic drive (unequal transmission of certain alleles)
column2: nonrandom mating and genetic hitchhiking. In the early 20th century the modern evolutionary synthesis integrated classical genetics with Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection through the discipline of population genetics. The importance of natural selection as a cause of evolution was accepted into other branches of biology. Moreover
column3: previously held notions about evolution
column4: such as orthogenesis
column5: evolutionism
column6: and other beliefs about innate ""progress"" within the largest-scale trends in evolution
column7: became obsolete. Scientists continue to study various aspects of evolutionary biology by forming and testing hypotheses
column8: constructing mathematical models of theoretical biology and biological theories
column9: using observational data
column10: and performing experiments in both the field and the laboratory.

column1: All life on Earth shares a common ancestor known as the last universal common ancestor (LUCA)
column2: which lived approximately 3.5–3.8 billion years ago. A December 2017 report stated that 3.45 billion-year-old Australian rocks once contained microorganisms
column3: the earliest direct evidence of life on Earth. Nonetheless
column4: this should not be assumed to be the first living organism on Earth; a study in 2015 found ""remains of biotic life"" from 4.1 billion years ago in ancient rocks in Western Australia. In July 2016
column5: scientists reported identifying a set of 355 genes from the LUCA of all organisms living on Earth. More than 99 percent of all species that ever lived on Earth are estimated to be extinct. Estimates of Earth's current species range from 10 to 14 million
column6: of which about 1.9 million are estimated to have been named and 1.6 million documented in a central database to date. More recently
column7: in May 2016
column8: scientists reported that 1 trillion species are estimated to be on Earth currently with only one-thousandth of one percent described.

column1: In terms of practical application
column2: an understanding of evolution has been instrumental to developments in numerous scientific and industrial fields
column3: including agriculture
column4: human and veterinary medicine
column5: and the life sciences in general. Discoveries in evolutionary biology have made a significant impact not just in the traditional branches of biology but also in other academic disciplines
column6: including biological anthropology
column7: and evolutionary psychology. Evolutionary computation
column8: a sub-field of artificial intelligence
column9: involves the application of Darwinian principles to problems in computer science."~0.12099337949283512

column1: 427~5~Experience~61297~61307~"Experience is the knowledge or mastery of an event or subject gained through involvement in or exposure to it. Terms in philosophy such as ""empirical knowledge"" or ""a posteriori knowledge"" are used to refer to knowledge based on experience. A person with considerable experience in a specific field can gain a reputation as an expert. The concept of experience generally refers to know-how or procedural knowledge
column2: rather than propositional knowledge: on-the-job training rather than book-learning.

column1: The interrogation of experience has a long term tradition in continental philosophy. Experience plays an important role in the philosophy of Søren Kierkegaard. The German term Erfahrung

column4: connoting the coherency of life's experiences.

column1: Certain religious traditions (such as Buddhism
column2: Surat Shabd Yoga
column3: mysticism and Pentecostalism) and educational paradigms with
column4: for example
column5: the conditioning of military recruit-training (also known as ""boot camps"")
column6: stress the experiential nature of human epistemology. This stands in contrast to alternatives: traditions of dogma
column7: logic or reasoning. Participants in activities such as tourism
column8: extreme sports and recreational drug-use also tend to stress the importance of experience.

column1: The history of the word experience aligns it closely with the concept of experiment."~0.15362719787703688

column3: and social movements that share a common goal: to define
column4: establish
column5: and achieve political
column6: economic
column7: personal
column8: and social equality of sexes. This includes seeking to establish educational and professional opportunities for women that are equal to those for men.

column1: Feminist movements have campaigned and continue to campaign for women's rights
column2: including the right to vote
column3: to hold public office
column4: to work
column5: to earn fair wages or equal pay
column6: to own property
column7: to receive education
column8: to enter contracts
column9: to have equal rights within marriage
column10: and to have maternity leave. Feminists have also worked to ensure access to legal abortions and social integration
column11: and to protect women and girls from rape
column12: sexual harassment
column13: and domestic violence. Changes in dress and acceptable physical activity have often been part of feminist movements.

column1: Feminist campaigns are generally considered to be a main force behind major historical societal changes for women's rights

column4: gender neutrality in English

column2: pl. femurs or femora ) or thigh bone
column3: is the most proximal (closest to the hip joint) bone of the leg in tetrapod vertebrates capable of walking or jumping
column4: such as most land mammals
column5: birds
column6: many reptiles such as lizards
column7: and amphibians such as frogs. In vertebrates with four legs such as dogs and horses

column1: 430~5~Fermata~28598~28606~"A fermata [ferˈmaːta] (""from fermare
column2: to stay
column3: or stop

column5: pause
column6: colloquially a birdseye or cyclops eye
column7: or as a grand pause when placed on a note or a rest) is a symbol of musical notation indicating that the note should be prolonged beyond the normal duration its note value would indicate. Exactly how much longer it is held is up to the discretion of the performer or conductor
column8: but twice as long is common. It is usually printed above but can be occasionally below (when it is upside down) the note to be extended.

column1: When a fermata is placed over a bar or double-bar
column2: it is used to indicate the end of a phrase or section of a work. In a concerto
column3: it indicates the point at which the soloist is to play a cadenza.

column1: A fermata can occur at the end of a piece (or movement) or in the middle of a piece. It can be followed by either a brief rest or more notes.
Fermata is the Italian name for the sign (𝄐)
column2: which in English is commonly called a Pause
column3: and signifies that the note over which it is placed should be held on beyond its natural duration. It is sometimes put over a bar or double bar
column4: in which case it intimates a short interval of silence.

column1: Other names for a fermata are corona (Italian)

column4: and calderón (Spanish).

431~5~Fiddler~25498~25506~A fiddle is a bowed string musical instrument

column1: 434~5~Flute~36094~36100~"The flute is a family of musical instruments in the woodwind group. Unlike woodwind instruments with reeds

column1: 435~5~Folk music~37587~37597~"Folk music includes both traditional music and the genre that evolved from it during the 20th century folk revival. The term originated in the 19th century

This form of music is sometimes called contemporary folk music or folk revival music to distinguish it from earlier folk forms. Smaller
column3: similar revivals have occurred elsewhere in the world at other times

column1: 436~5~Franz Schubert~48374~48388~"Franz Peter Schubert (German: [ˈfʁant͡s ˈʃuːbɐt]; 31 January 1797 – 19 November 1828) was an Austrian composer.

column2: a fugue ( fewg) is a contrapuntal compositional technique in two or more voices
column3: built on a subject (a musical theme) that is introduced at the beginning in imitation (repetition at different pitches) and which recurs frequently in the course of the composition. It is not to be confused with a fuguing tune
column4: which is a style of song popularized by and mostly limited to early American (i.e. shape note or ""Sacred Harp"") music and West Gallery music. A fugue usually has three main sections: an exposition
column5: a development and a final entry that contains the return of the subject in the fugue's tonic key. Some fugues have a recapitulation.

column1: In the Middle Ages
column2: the term was widely used to denote any works in canonic style; by the Renaissance
column3: it had come to denote specifically imitative works. Since the 17th century
column4: the term fugue has described what is commonly regarded as the most fully developed procedure of imitative counterpoint.

column1: Most fugues open with a short main theme
column2: the subject
column3: which then sounds successively in each voice (after the first voice is finished stating the subject
column4: a second voice repeats the subject at a different pitch
column5: and other voices repeat in the same way); when each voice has entered
column6: the exposition is complete. This is often followed by a connecting passage
column7: or episode
column8: developed from previously heard material; further ""entries"" of the subject then are heard in related keys. Episodes (if applicable) and entries are usually alternated until the ""final entry"" of the subject
column9: by which point the music has returned to the opening key
column10: or tonic
column11: which is often followed by closing material
column12: the coda. In this sense
column13: a fugue is a style of composition
column14: rather than a fixed structure.

column1: The form evolved during the 18th century from several earlier types of contrapuntal compositions
column2: such as imitative ricercars
column3: capriccios
column4: canzonas
column5: and fantasias. The famous fugue composer Johann Sebastian Bach (1685–1750) shaped his own works after those of Johann Jakob Froberger (1616–1667)
column6: Johann Pachelbel (1653–1706)
column7: Girolamo Frescobaldi (1583–1643)
column8: Dieterich Buxtehude (c. 1637–1707) and others. With the decline of sophisticated styles at the end of the baroque period
column9: the fugue's central role waned
column10: eventually giving way as sonata form and the symphony orchestra rose to a dominant position. Nevertheless
column11: composers continued to write and study fugues for various purposes; they appear in the works of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756–1791) and Ludwig van Beethoven (1770–1827)
column12: as well as modern composers such as Dmitri Shostakovich (1906–1975)."~0.2859207020863408

column1: 438~5~Functional magnetic resonance imaging~64345~64382~"Functional magnetic resonance imaging or functional MRI (fMRI) measures brain activity by detecting changes associated with blood flow. This technique relies on the fact that cerebral blood flow and neuronal activation are coupled. When an area of the brain is in use
column2: blood flow to that region also increases.

column1: The primary form of fMRI uses the blood-oxygen-level dependent (BOLD) contrast
column2: discovered by Seiji Ogawa. This is a type of specialized brain and body scan used to map neural activity in the brain or spinal cord of humans or other animals by imaging the change in blood flow (hemodynamic response) related to energy use by brain cells. Since the early 1990s
column3: fMRI has come to dominate brain mapping research because it does not require people to undergo shots or surgery
column4: to ingest substances
column5: or to be exposed to ionising radiation. This measure is frequently corrupted by noise from various sources; hence
column6: statistical procedures are used to extract the underlying signal. The resulting brain activation can be graphically represented by color-coding the strength of activation across the brain or the specific region studied. The technique can localize activity to within millimeters but
column7: using standard techniques
column8: no better than within a window of a few seconds. Other methods of obtaining contrast are arterial spin labeling and diffusion MRI. The latter procedure is similar to BOLD fMRI but provides contrast based on the magnitude of diffusion of water molecules in the brain.

column1: fMRI is used both in the research world
column2: and to a lesser extent
column3: in the clinical world. It can also be combined and complemented with other measures of brain physiology such as EEG and NIRS. Newer methods which improve both spatial and time resolution are being researched
column4: and these largely use biomarkers other than the BOLD signal. Some companies have developed commercial products such as lie detectors based on fMRI techniques
column5: but the research is not believed to be ripe enough for widespread commercialization."~0.13366187264232007

column1: 439~5~Funk~3399~3403~"Funk is a music genre that originated in the mid-1960s when African American musicians created a rhythmic
column2: danceable new form of music through a mixture of soul music
column3: jazz
column4: and rhythm and blues (R&B). Funk de-emphasizes melody and chord progressions used in other related genres and brings a strong rhythmic groove of a bass line played by an electric bassist and a drum part played by a drummer to the foreground. Like much of African-inspired music
column5: funk typically consists of a complex groove with rhythm instruments playing interlocking grooves. Funk uses the same richly colored extended chords found in bebop jazz

column7: or dominant seventh chords with altered ninths.

column1: Funk originated in the mid-1960s
column2: with James Brown's development of a signature groove that emphasized the downbeat—with heavy emphasis on the first beat of every measure (""The One"")
column3: and the application of swung 16th notes and syncopation on all bass lines
column4: drum patterns
column5: and guitar riffs. Other musical groups
column6: including Sly and the Family Stone
column7: the Meters
column8: and Parliament-Funkadelic
column9: soon began to adopt and develop Brown's innovations. While much of the written history of funk focuses on men
column10: there have been notable funk women
column11: including Chaka Khan
column12: Labelle
column13: Lyn Collins
column14: Brides of Funkenstein
column15: Klymaxx
column17: and Betty Davis.
