column2: a form of post-disco dance music; electro music
column3: a hybrid of electronic music and funk; funk metal (e.g.
column4: Living Colour
column5: Faith No More); G-funk
column6: a mix of gangsta rap and funk; Timba
column7: a form of funky Cuban popular dance music; and funk jam (e.g.
column8: Phish). Funk samples and breakbeats have been used extensively in genres including hip hop
column9: and various forms of electronic dance music
column10: such as house music
column11: old-school rave
column12: breakbeat
column13: and drum and bass. It is also the main influence of go-go
column14: a subgenre associated with funk."~0.3269880293133751

column1: 440~5~Gamelan~83347~83354~"Gamelan () is the traditional ensemble music of Java and Bali in Indonesia
column2: made up predominantly of percussive instruments. The most common instruments used are metallophones played by mallets and a set of hand-played drums called kendhang which register the beat. Other instruments include xylophones
column3: bamboo flutes
column4: a bowed instrument called a rebab
column5: and even vocalists called sindhen.

column1: Although the popularity of gamelan has declined since the introduction of pop music
column2: gamelan is still commonly played on formal occasions and in many traditional Indonesian ceremonies. For most Indonesians
column3: gamelan is an integral part of Indonesian culture."~0.3690770849810545

column1: 441~5~Georg Philipp Telemann~45354~45376~"Georg Philipp Telemann (24 March [O.S. 14 March] 1681 – 25 June 1767) (German pronunciation: [ˈteːləman]) was a German Baroque composer and multi-instrumentalist. Almost completely self-taught in music
column2: he became a composer against his family's wishes. After studying in Magdeburg
column3: Zellerfeld
column4: and Hildesheim
column5: Telemann entered the University of Leipzig to study law
column6: but eventually settled on a career in music. He held important positions in Leipzig
column7: Sorau
column8: Eisenach
column9: and Frankfurt before settling in Hamburg in 1721
column10: where he became musical director of the five main churches. While Telemann's career prospered
column11: his personal life was always troubled: his first wife died only a few months after their marriage
column12: and his second wife had extramarital affairs and accumulated a large gambling debt before leaving Telemann.

column1: Telemann is one of the most prolific composers in history (at least in terms of surviving oeuvre) and was considered by his contemporaries to be one of the leading German composers of the time—he was compared favorably both to his friend Johann Sebastian Bach
column2: who made Telemann the godfather and namesake of his son Carl Philipp Emanuel
column3: and to George Frideric Handel
column4: whom Telemann also knew personally. Telemann's music incorporates several national styles (French
column5: Italian
column6: German) and is even at times influenced by Polish popular music. He remained at the forefront of all new musical tendencies and his music is an important link between the late Baroque and early Classical styles."~0.39304622256465893

column1: 442~5~George Frideric Handel~45330~45352~"George Frideric (or Frederick) Handel (; born Georg Friedrich Händel German: [ˈhɛndəl] ( listen); 23 February 1685 (O.S.) [(N.S.) 5 March] – 14 April 1759) was a German
column2: later British
column3: Baroque composer who spent the bulk of his career in London
column4: becoming well-known for his operas
column5: oratorios
column6: anthems
column7: and organ concertos. Handel received important training in Halle-upon-Saale and worked as a composer in Hamburg and Italy before settling in London in 1712; he became a naturalised British subject in 1727. He was strongly influenced both by the great composers of the Italian Baroque and by the middle-German polyphonic choral tradition.

column1: Within 15 years
column2: Handel had started three commercial opera companies to supply the English nobility with Italian opera. Musicologist Winton Dean writes that his operas show that ""Handel was not only a great composer; he was a dramatic genius of the first order."" As Alexander's Feast (1736) was well received
column3: Handel made a transition to English choral works. After his success with Messiah (1742) he never composed an Italian opera again. Almost blind
column4: and having lived in England for nearly fifty years
column5: he died in 1759
column6: a respected and rich man. His funeral was given full state honours
column7: and he was buried in Westminster Abbey in London.

column1: Born the same year as Johann Sebastian Bach and Domenico Scarlatti
column2: Handel is regarded as one of the greatest composers of the Baroque era
column3: with works such as Messiah
column4: Water Music
column5: and Music for the Royal Fireworks remaining steadfastly popular. One of his four Coronation Anthems
column6: Zadok the Priest (1727)
column7: composed for the coronation of George II
column8: has been performed at every subsequent British coronation
column9: traditionally during the sovereign's anointing. Another of his English oratorios
column10: Solomon (1748)
column11: has also remained popular
column12: with the Sinfonia that opens act 3 (known more commonly as ""The Arrival of the Queen of Sheba"") featuring at the 2012 London Olympics opening ceremony. Handel composed more than forty operas in over thirty years
column13: and since the late 1960s
column14: with the revival of baroque music and historically informed musical performance
column15: interest in Handel's operas has grown."~0.41160695528911484

column1: 443~5~George Gershwin~92553~92568~"George Jacob Gershwin (; September 26
column3: 1937) was an American composer and pianist. Gershwin's compositions spanned both popular and classical genres
column4: and his most popular melodies are widely known. Among his best-known works are the orchestral compositions Rhapsody in Blue (1924) and An American in Paris (1928)
column5: as well as the contemporary opera Porgy and Bess (1935).

column1: Gershwin studied piano under Charles Hambitzer and composition with Rubin Goldmark
column2: Henry Cowell and Joseph Brody. He began his career as a song plugger
column3: but soon started composing Broadway theatre works with his brother Ira Gershwin and Buddy DeSylva. He moved to Paris intending to study with Nadia Boulanger
column4: who refused him
column5: where he subsequently composed An American in Paris. After returning to New York City
column6: he wrote Porgy and Bess
column7: with Ira
column8: and the author DuBose Heyward. Initially a commercial failure
column9: Porgy and Bess later went on to be considered one of the most important American operas of the Twentieth century
column10: and an American cultural classic.

column1: Gershwin moved to Hollywood and composed numerous film scores until his death in 1937 from glioblastoma multiforme
column2: a malignant brain tumor.

column1: Gershwin's compositions have been adapted for use in many films and for television
column2: and several became jazz standards recorded and covered in many variations. Many celebrated singers and musicians have performed his songs."~0.41001387315005816

column1: 444~5~Glenn Branca~62456~62468~Glenn Branca (born October 6
column2: 1948) is an American avant-garde composer and guitarist known for his use of volume
column3: alternative guitar tunings
column4: repetition
column5: droning
column6: and the harmonic series. Branca received a 2009 Foundation for Contemporary Arts Grants to Artists Award.~0.37327560540406557

column1: 445~5~Globalization~91977~91999~"Globalisation (or globalization
column2: American spelling) is the trend of increasing interaction between people on a worldwide scale due to advances in transportation and communication technology
column3: nominally beginning with the steamship and the telegraph in the early to mid-1800s. With increased interactions between nation-states and individuals came the growth of international trade
column4: ideas
column5: and culture. Globalization is primarily an economic process of integration that has social and cultural aspects
column6: but conflicts and diplomacy are also large parts of the history of globalization.

column1: Economically
column2: globalization involves goods and services
column3: and the economic resources of capital
column4: technology
column5: and data. The steam locomotive
column6: steamship
column7: jet engine
column8: and container ships are some of the advances in the means of transport while the rise of the telegraph and its modern offspring
column9: the Internet and mobile phones show development in telecommunications infrastructure. All of these improvements have been major factors in globalization and have generated further interdependence of economic and cultural activities.

column1: Though many scholars place the origins of globalization in modern times
column2: others trace its history long before the European Age of Discovery and voyages to the New World
column3: some even to the third millennium BC. Large-scale globalization began in the 1820s. In the late 19th century and early 20th century
column4: the connectivity of the world's economies and cultures grew very quickly. The term globalization is recent
column5: only establishing its current meaning in the 1970s.

column2: the International Monetary Fund (IMF) identified four basic aspects of globalization: trade and transactions
column3: capital and investment movements
column4: migration and movement of people
column5: and the dissemination of knowledge. Further
column6: environmental challenges such as global warming
column7: cross-boundary water
column8: air pollution
column9: and over-fishing of the ocean are linked with globalization. Globalizing processes affect and are affected by business and work organization
column10: economics
column11: socio-cultural resources
column12: and the natural environment. Academic literature commonly subdivides globalization into three major areas: economic globalization
column13: cultural globalization
column14: and political globalization."~0.06361647225085594

column1: 446~5~Graphic equalizer~27747~27765~"Equalization or equalisation is the process of adjusting the balance between frequency components within an electronic signal. The most well known use of equalization is in sound recording and reproduction but there are many other applications in electronics and telecommunications. The circuit or equipment used to achieve equalization is called an equalizer. These devices strengthen (boost) or weaken (cut) the energy of specific frequency bands or ""frequency ranges"".
In sound recording and reproduction
column2: equalization is the process commonly used to alter the frequency response of an audio system using linear filters. Most hi-fi equipment uses relatively simple filters to make bass and treble adjustments. Graphic and parametric equalizers have much more flexibility in tailoring the frequency content of an audio signal. An equalizer is the circuit or equipment used to achieve equalization. Since equalizers
column3: ""adjust the amplitude of audio signals at particular frequencies
column4: they are
column5: ""in other words
column6: frequency-specific volume knobs.""

column1: In the field of audio electronics
column2: the term ""equalization"" (or ""EQ"") has come to include the adjustment of frequency responses for practical or aesthetic reasons
column3: often resulting in a net response that is not truly equalized. The term EQ specifically refers to this variant of the term. Stereos and basic guitar amplifiers typically have adjustable equalizers which boost or cut bass or treble frequencies. Mid- to high-priced guitar and bass amplifiers usually have more bands of frequency control
column4: such as bass
column5: mid-range and treble or bass
column6: low-mid
column7: high-mid
column8: and treble. Some amps have an additional knob for controlling very high frequencies. Broadcast and recording studios use sophisticated equalizers capable of much more detailed adjustments
column9: such as eliminating unwanted sounds or making certain instruments or voices more prominent.

column1: Equalizers are used in recording studios
column2: radio studios and production control rooms
column3: and live sound reinforcement and in instrument amplifiers
column4: such as guitar amplifiers
column5: to correct or adjust the response of microphones
column6: instrument pick-ups
column7: loudspeakers
column8: and hall acoustics. Equalization may also be used to eliminate or reduce unwanted sounds (e.g.
column9: low hum coming from a guitar amplifier)
column10: make certain instruments or voices more (or less) prominent
column11: enhance particular aspects of an instrument's tone
column12: or combat feedback (howling) in a public address system. Equalizers are also used in music production to adjust the timbre of individual instruments and voices by adjusting their frequency content and to fit individual instruments within the overall frequency spectrum of the mix.

column1: The most common equalizers in music production are parametric
column2: semi-parametric
column3: graphic
column4: peak
column5: and program equalizers. Graphic equalizers are often included in consumer audio equipment and software which plays music on home computers. Parametric equalizers require more expertise than graphic equalizers
column6: and they can provide more specific compensation or alteration around a chosen frequency. This may be used in order to remove unwanted resonances or boost certain frequencies. An acoustic guitarist who finds that her instrument sounds too ""boomy"" may ask the audio engineer to reduce the low frequency range response
column7: to correct this issue. A guitarist who finds that the instrument sound in the PA has too much finger noise may ask the engineer to reduce the higher frequency range response."~0.40250657725749095

column1: 447~5~Greek mythology~4081~4096~"Greek mythology is the body of myths and teachings that belong to the ancient Greeks
column2: concerning their gods and heroes
column3: the nature of the world
column4: and the origins and significance of their own cult and ritual practices. It was a part of the religion in ancient Greece. Modern scholars refer to and study the myths in an attempt to shed light on the religious and political institutions of ancient Greece and its civilization
column5: and to gain understanding of the nature of myth-making itself.

column1: Greek mythology has had an extensive influence on the culture
column2: arts
column3: and literature of Western civilization and remains part of Western heritage and language. Poets and artists from ancient times to the present have derived inspiration from Greek mythology and have discovered contemporary significance and relevance in the themes.

column1: Greek mythology is explicitly embodied in a large collection of narratives
column2: and implicitly in Greek representational arts
column3: such as ancient vase-paintings and votive gifts. Greek myth attempts to explain the origins of the world
column4: and details the lives and adventures of a wide variety of gods
column5: goddesses
column6: heroes
column7: heroines and mythological creatures. These accounts initially were disseminated in an oral-poetic tradition most likely by Minoan and Mycenaean singers starting in the 18th century BC; today the Greek myths are known primarily from ancient Greek literature. The oldest known Greek literary sources
column8: Homer's epic poems Iliad and Odyssey
column9: focus on the Trojan War and its aftermath. Two poems by Homer's near contemporary Hesiod
column10: the Theogony and the Works and Days
column11: contain accounts of the genesis of the world
column12: the succession of divine rulers
column13: the succession of human ages
column14: the origin of human woes
column15: and the origin of sacrificial practices. Myths are also preserved in the Homeric Hymns
column16: in fragments of epic poems of the Epic Cycle
column17: in lyric poems
column18: in the works of the tragedians and comedians of the fifth century BC
column19: in writings of scholars and poets of the Hellenistic Age
column20: and in texts from the time of the Roman Empire by writers such as Plutarch and Pausanias.

column1: Archaeological findings provide a principal source of detail about Greek mythology
column2: with gods and heroes featured prominently in the decoration of many artifacts. Geometric designs on pottery of the eighth century BC depict scenes from the Trojan cycle as well as the adventures of Heracles. In the succeeding Archaic
column3: Classical
column4: and Hellenistic periods
column5: Homeric and various other mythological scenes appear
column6: supplementing the existing literary evidence."~0.15865149573966442

column1: 448~5~Greeks~39776~39782~"The Greeks or Hellenes (; Greek: Έλληνες
column2: Éllines [ˈelines]) are an ethnic group native to Greece
column3: Cyprus
column4: southern Albania
column5: Italy
column6: Turkey
column7: Egypt and
column8: to a lesser extent
column9: other countries surrounding the Mediterranean Sea. They also form a significant diaspora
column10: with Greek communities established around the world.

column1: Greek colonies and communities have been historically established on the shores of the Mediterranean Sea and Black Sea
column2: but the Greek people have always been centered on the Aegean and Ionian seas
column3: where the Greek language has been spoken since the Bronze Age. Until the early 20th century
column4: Greeks were distributed between the Greek peninsula
column5: the western coast of Asia Minor
column6: the Black Sea coast
column7: Cappadocia in central Anatolia
column8: Egypt
column9: the Balkans
column10: Cyprus
column11: and Constantinople. Many of these regions coincided to a large extent with the borders of the Byzantine Empire of the late 11th century and the Eastern Mediterranean areas of ancient Greek colonization. The cultural centers of the Greeks have included Athens
column12: Thessalonica
column13: Alexandria
column14: Smyrna
column15: and Constantinople at various periods.

column1: Most ethnic Greeks live nowadays within the borders of the modern Greek state and Cyprus. The Greek genocide and population exchange between Greece and Turkey nearly ended the three millennia-old Greek presence in Asia Minor. Other longstanding Greek populations can be found from southern Italy to the Caucasus and southern Russia and Ukraine and in the Greek diaspora communities in a number of other countries. Today
column2: most Greeks are officially registered as members of the Greek Orthodox Church.

column1: Greeks have greatly influenced and contributed to culture
column2: arts
column3: exploration
column4: literature
column5: philosophy
column6: politics
column7: architecture
column8: music
column9: mathematics
column10: science and technology
column11: business
column12: cuisine
column13: and sports
column14: both historically and contemporarily."~0.11571814536791997

column1: 449~5~Gregorian chant~42719~42734~"Gregorian chant is the central tradition of Western plainchant
column2: a form of monophonic
column3: unaccompanied sacred song of the Roman Catholic Church. Gregorian chant developed mainly in western and central Europe during the 9th and 10th centuries
column4: with later additions and redactions. Although popular legend credits Pope St. Gregory the Great with inventing Gregorian chant
column5: scholars believe that it arose from a later Carolingian synthesis of Roman chant and Gallican chant.

column1: Gregorian chants were organized initially into four
column2: then eight
column3: and finally 12 modes. Typical melodic features include a characteristic ambitus
column4: and also characteristic intervallic patterns relative to a referential mode final
column5: incipits and cadences
column6: the use of reciting tones at a particular distance from the final
column7: around which the other notes of the melody revolve
column8: and a vocabulary of musical motifs woven together through a process called centonization to create families of related chants. The scale patterns are organized against a background pattern formed of conjunct and disjunct tetrachords
column9: producing a larger pitch system called the gamut. The chants can be sung by using six-note patterns called hexachords. Gregorian melodies are traditionally written using neumes
column10: an early form of musical notation from which the modern four-line and five-line staff developed. Multi-voice elaborations of Gregorian chant
column11: known as organum
column12: were an early stage in the development of Western polyphony.

column1: Gregorian chant was traditionally sung by choirs of men and boys in churches
column2: or by men and women of religious orders in their chapels. It is the music of the Roman Rite
column3: performed in the Mass and the monastic Office. Although Gregorian chant supplanted or marginalized the other indigenous plainchant traditions of the Christian West to become the official music of the Christian liturgy
column4: Ambrosian chant still continues in use in Milan
column5: and there are musicologists exploring both that and the Mozarabic chant of Christian Spain. Although Gregorian chant is no longer obligatory
column6: the Roman Catholic Church still officially considers it the music most suitable for worship. During the 20th century
column7: Gregorian chant underwent a musicological and popular resurgence."~0.46274659097626447

column1: 450~5~Grosse Fuge~1761~1772~"The Große Fuge (or Grosse Fuge
column2: also known in English as Great Fugue or Grand Fugue)
column4: is a single-movement composition for string quartet by Ludwig van Beethoven. An immense double fugue
column5: it was universally condemned by contemporary critics. A reviewer writing for Allgemeine musikalische Zeitung in 1826 described the fugue as ""incomprehensible
column6: like Chinese"" and ""a confusion of Babel"". However
column7: critical opinion of the work has risen steadily since the beginning of the 20th century. The work is now considered among Beethoven's greatest achievements. Igor Stravinsky said of it
column8: ""[it is] an absolutely contemporary piece of music that will be contemporary forever.""

column1: The Große Fuge originally served as the final movement of his Quartet No. 13 in B♭ major (Op. 130)
column2: written in 1825. But Beethoven's publisher
column3: who was concerned about the dismal commercial prospects of the piece
column4: urged Beethoven to replace the fugue with a new finale. Beethoven complied
column5: and the Große Fuge was published separately in 1827 as Op. 133. It was composed when Beethoven was almost completely deaf
column6: and is considered to be part of his set of late quartets. It was first performed in 1826
column7: as the finale of the B♭ quartet
column8: by the Schuppanzigh Quartet.

column1: Analysts describe the Große Fuge as ""inaccessible""
column2: ""eccentric""
column3: ""filled with paradoxes""
column4: and ""Armaggedon"". ""[It] stands out as the most problematic single work in Beethoven's output and … doubtless in the entire literature of music
column5: writes critic and musicologist Joseph Kerman of the fugue.

column1: Also
column2: writes violinist and composer David Matthews
column3: ""it is fiendishly difficult to play."""~0.34898015748124306

column1: 451~5~Guillaume Dufay~43770~43785~"Guillaume Du Fay (French: [dy fa(j)i]; also Dufay
column2: Du Fayt; 5 August
column3: c. 1397 – 27 November 1474) was a Franco-Flemish composer of the early Renaissance. A central figure in the Burgundian School

His unique and complex motet ""Nuper rosarum flores"" demonstrates the influential exchange of musical ideas among artists around the world during the early Renaissance period."~0.32494093981044136

column1: 452~5~Guitar solo~56484~56495~"A guitar solo is a melodic passage
column2: instrumental section
column3: or entire piece of music written for a classical guitar
column4: electric guitar or an acoustic guitar. In 20th and 21st century traditional music and popular music such as blues
column5: swing
column6: jazz
column7: jazz fusion
column8: rock and metal guitar solos often contain virtuoso techniques and varying degrees of improvisation. Guitar solos on classical guitar
column9: which are typically written in musical notation
column10: are also used in classical music forms such as chamber music and concertos.

column1: Guitar solos range from unaccompanied works for a single guitar to compositions with accompaniment from a few other instruments or a large ensemble. The accompaniment musicians for a guitar solo can range from a small ensemble such as a jazz quartet or a rock band
column2: to a large ensemble such as an orchestra or big band. Unaccompanied acoustic guitar music is found in folk and classical music dating as far back as the instrument has existed
column3: and the use of an acoustic guitar as a solo voice within an ensemble dates back at least to the Baroque concerto."~0.31258593795286715

column1: 453~5~Gustav Mahler~50651~50664~"Gustav Mahler (German: [ˈmaːlɐ]; 7 July 1860 – 18 May 1911) was an Austro-Bohemian late-Romantic composer
column2: and one of the leading conductors of his generation. As a composer he acted as a bridge between the 19th century Austro-German tradition and the modernism of the early 20th century. While in his lifetime his status as a conductor was established beyond question
column3: his own music gained wide popularity only after periods of relative neglect which included a ban on its performance in much of Europe during the Nazi era. After 1945 his compositions were rediscovered and championed by a new generation of listeners; Mahler then became one of the most frequently performed and recorded of all composers
column4: a position he has sustained into the 21st century.

column1: Born in Bohemia (then part of Austrian Empire) as a German-speaking Jew of humble circumstances
column2: Mahler displayed his musical gifts at an early age. After graduating from the Vienna Conservatory in 1878
column3: he held a succession of conducting posts of rising importance in the opera houses of Europe
column4: culminating in his appointment in 1897 as director of the Vienna Court Opera (Hofoper). During his ten years in Vienna
column5: Mahler—who had converted to Catholicism to secure the post—experienced regular opposition and hostility from the anti-Semitic press. Nevertheless
column6: his innovative productions and insistence on the highest performance standards ensured his reputation as one of the greatest of opera conductors
column7: particularly as an interpreter of the stage works of Wagner
column8: Mozart
column9: and Tchaikovsky. Late in his life he was briefly director of New York's Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic.

column1: Mahler's œuvre is relatively limited; for much of his life composing was necessarily a part-time activity while he earned his living as a conductor. Aside from early works such as a movement from a piano quartet composed when he was a student in Vienna
column2: Mahler's works are generally designed for large orchestral forces
column3: symphonic choruses and operatic soloists. These works were frequently controversial when first performed
column4: and several were slow to receive critical and popular approval; exceptions included his Second Symphony
column5: Third Symphony
column6: and the triumphant premiere of his Eighth Symphony in 1910. Some of Mahler's immediate musical successors included the composers of the Second Viennese School
column7: notably Arnold Schoenberg
column8: Alban Berg and Anton Webern. Dmitri Shostakovich and Benjamin Britten are among later 20th-century composers who admired and were influenced by Mahler. The International Gustav Mahler Institute was established in 1955 to honour the composer's life and work."~0.34000669768986436

column1: 454~5~Hammond organ~27931~27939~"The Hammond organ is an electric organ
column2: invented by Laurens Hammond and John M. Hanert and first manufactured in 1935. Various models have been produced
column3: most of which use sliding drawbars to specify a variety of sounds. Until 1975
column4: Hammond organs generated sound by creating an electric current from rotating a metal tonewheel near an electromagnetic pickup
column5: and then strengthening the signal with an amplifier so it can drive a speaker cabinet. Around two million Hammond organs have been manufactured. The organ is commonly used with
column6: and associated with
column7: the Leslie speaker.

column1: The organ was originally marketed and sold by the Hammond Organ Company to churches as a lower-cost alternative to the wind-driven pipe organ
column2: or instead of a piano. It quickly became popular with professional jazz musicians in organ trios
column3: a small group centered on the Hammond organ. Organ trios were hired by jazz club owners
column4: who found that organ trios were a much cheaper alternative to hiring a big band. Jimmy Smith's use of the Hammond B-3
column5: with its additional harmonic percussion feature
column6: inspired a generation of organ players
column7: and its use became more widespread in the 1960s and 1970s in rhythm and blues
column8: rock
column9: and reggae
column10: as well as being an important instrument in progressive rock.

column1: The Hammond Organ Company struggled financially during the 1970s
column2: as they abandoned tonewheel organs and switched to manufacturing instruments using integrated circuits. These instruments were not as popular with musicians as the tonewheels had been
column3: and the company went out of business in 1985. The Hammond name was purchased by the Suzuki Musical Instrument Corporation
column4: which proceeded to manufacture digital simulations of the most popular tonewheel organs. This culminated in the production of the ""New B-3"" in 2002
column5: which provided an accurate recreation of the original B-3 organ using modern digital technology.

column1: Hammond-Suzuki continues to manufacture a variety of organs for both professional players and churches. Other companies
column2: such as Korg
column3: Roland
column4: and Clavia
column5: have also achieved success in providing more lightweight and portable emulations of the original tonewheel organs. The sound of a tonewheel Hammond can also be emulated using modern software such as Native Instruments B4."~0.4133677478309372

column1: 455~5~Harappa~38071~38078~"Harappa (Punjabi pronunciation: [ɦəɽəppaː]; Urdu/Punjabi: ہڑپّہ‬) is an archaeological site in Punjab
column2: Pakistan
column3: about 24 km (15 mi) west of Sahiwal. The site takes its name from a modern village located near the former course of the Ravi River which now runs 8 km (5.0 mi) in north. The current village of Harappa is less than 1 km (0.62 mi) from the ancient site. Although modern Harappa has a legacy railway station from the period of the British Raj
column4: it is today just a small crossroads town of population 15

column1: The site of the ancient city contains the ruins of a Bronze Age fortified city
column2: which was part of the Indus Valley Civilization centered in Sindh and the Punjab
column3: and then the Cemetery H culture. The city is believed to have had as many as 23
column4: 500 residents and occupied about 150 hectares (370 acres) with clay brick houses at its greatest extent during the Mature Harappan phase (2600–1900 BC)
column5: which is considered large for its time. Per archaeological convention of naming a previously unknown civilization by its first excavated site
column6: the Indus Valley Civilization is also called the Harappan Civilization.

column1: The ancient city of Harappa was heavily damaged under British rule
column2: when bricks from the ruins were used as track ballast in the construction of the Lahore–Multan Railway. In 2005
column3: a controversial amusement park scheme at the site was abandoned when builders unearthed many archaeological artifacts during the early stages of building work. A plea from the Pakistani archaeologist Ahmad Hasan Dani to the Ministry of Culture resulted in a restoration of the site."~0.11086203238637163

column1: 456~5~Hard rock~2710~2719~"Hard rock is a loosely defined subgenre of rock music that began in the mid-1960s
column2: with the garage
column3: psychedelic and blues rock movements. It is typified by a heavy use of aggressive vocals
column4: distorted electric guitars
column5: bass guitar
column6: drums
column7: and often accompanied with keyboards.

column1: Hard rock developed into a major form of popular music in the 1970s
column2: with notable bands such as AC/DC
column3: the Who
column4: Led Zeppelin
column5: Queen
column6: Black Sabbath
column7: Deep Purple
column8: Aerosmith
column9: KISS and Van Halen. During the 1980s
column10: some hard rock bands moved away from their hard rock roots and more towards pop rock
column11: while others began to return to a hard rock sound. Established bands made a comeback in the mid-1980s and it reached a commercial peak in the 1980s
column12: with glam metal bands like Bon Jovi and Def Leppard and the rawer sounds of Guns N' Roses
column13: which followed up with great success in the later part of that decade. Hard rock began losing popularity with the commercial success of R&B
column14: hip-hop
column15: urban pop
column16: grunge and later Britpop in the 1990s.

column1: Despite this
column2: many post-grunge bands adopted a hard rock sound and in the 2000s there came a renewed interest in established bands
column3: attempts at a revival
column4: and new hard rock bands that emerged from the garage rock and post-punk revival scenes. Out of this movement came garage rock bands like the White Stripes
column5: the Strokes
column6: and
column7: later on
column8: the Black Keys. In the 2000s
column9: only a few hard rock bands from the 1970s and 1980s managed to sustain highly successful recording careers."~0.3087902968588062

column1: 457~5~Hardcore punk~1842~1855~"Hardcore punk (often abbreviated to hardcore) is a punk rock music genre and subculture that originated in the late 1970s. It is generally faster
column2: harder
column3: and more aggressive than other forms of punk rock. Its roots can be traced to earlier punk scenes in San Francisco and Southern California which arose as a reaction against the still predominant hippie cultural climate of the time. It was also inspired by New York punk rock and early proto-punk. New York punk had a harder-edged sound than its San Francisco counterpart
column4: featuring anti-art expressions of masculine anger
column5: energy and subversive humor. Hardcore punk generally disavows commercialism
column6: the established music industry and ""anything similar to the characteristics of mainstream rock"" and often addresses social and political topics with ""confrontational
column7: politically-charged lyrics"".

column1: Hardcore sprouted underground scenes across the United States in the early 1980s
column2: particularly in Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: New York
column5: New Jersey
column6: and Boston—as well as in Australia
column7: Canada and the United Kingdom. Hardcore has spawned the straight edge movement and its associated submovements
column8: hardline and youth crew. Hardcore was heavily involved in the rise of the independent record labels in the 1980s and with the DIY ethics in underground music scenes. It has also influenced various music genres that have experienced widespread commercial success
column9: including alternative rock
column10: thrash metal
column11: emo and metalcore.

column1: While traditional hardcore has never experienced mainstream commercial success
column2: some of its early pioneers have garnered appreciation over time. Black Flag's Damaged
column3: Minutemen's Double Nickels on the Dime and Hüsker Dü's New Day Rising were included in Rolling Stone's list of The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time in 2003 and Dead Kennedys have seen one of their albums reach gold status over a period of 25 years. In 2011
column4: Rolling Stone writer David Fricke placed Greg Ginn of Black Flag 99th place in his 100 Greatest Guitarists list. Although the music genre started in English-speaking western countries
column5: notable hardcore scenes have existed in Italy
column6: Brazil
column7: Japan
column8: Europe and the Middle East."~0.39321347426417264

column1: 458~5~Harmonic~87825~87834~"A harmonic is any member of the harmonic series
column2: a divergent infinite series. Its name derives from the concept of overtones
column3: or harmonics in musical instruments: the wavelengths of the overtones of a vibrating string or a column of air (as with a tuba) are derived from the string's (or air column's) fundamental wavelength. Every term of the series (i.e.
column4: the higher harmonics) after the first is the ""harmonic mean"" of the neighboring terms. The phrase ""harmonic mean"" likewise derives from music.

column1: The term is employed in various disciplines
column2: including music
column3: physics
column4: acoustics
column5: electronic power transmission
column6: radio technology
column7: and other fields. It is typically applied to repeating signals
column8: such as sinusoidal waves. A harmonic of such a wave is a wave with a frequency that is a positive integer multiple of the frequency of the original wave
column9: known as the fundamental frequency. The original wave is also called the 1st harmonic
column10: the following harmonics are known as higher harmonics. As all harmonics are periodic at the fundamental frequency
column11: the sum of harmonics is also periodic at that frequency. For example
column12: if the fundamental frequency is 50 Hz
column13: a common AC power supply frequency
column14: the frequencies of the first three higher harmonics are 100 Hz (2nd harmonic)
column15: 150 Hz (3rd harmonic)
column16: 200 Hz (4th harmonic) and any addition of waves with these frequencies is periodic at 50 Hz.

column1: An nth characteristic mode
column2: for n > 1
column3: will have nodes that are not vibrating. For example
column4: the 3rd characteristic mode will have nodes at

column1: {\displaystyle {\tfrac {1}{3}}}
L and
{\displaystyle {\tfrac {2}{3}}}
L
column2: where L is the length of the string. In fact
column3: each nth characteristic mode
column4: for n a multiple of 3
column5: will not have nodes at these points. These other characteristic modes will be vibrating at the positions

column1: {\displaystyle {\tfrac {1}{3}}}
L and
{\displaystyle {\tfrac {2}{3}}}
L. If the player gently touches one of these positions
column2: then these other characteristic modes will be suppressed. The tonal harmonics from these other characteristic modes will then also be suppressed. Consequently
column3: the tonal harmonics from the nth characteristic modes
column4: where n is a multiple of 3
column5: will be made relatively more prominent.

column1: In music
column2: harmonics are used on string instruments and wind instruments as a way of producing sound on the instrument
column3: particularly to play higher notes and
column4: with strings
column5: obtain notes that have a unique sound quality or ""tone colour"". On strings
column6: harmonics that are bowed have a ""glassy""
column7: pure tone. On stringed instruments
column8: harmonics are played by touching (but not fully pressing down the string) at an exact point on the string while sounding the string (plucking
column9: bowing
column10: etc.); this allows the harmonic to sound
column11: a pitch which is always higher than the fundamental frequency of the string."~0.17729932449731695

column1: 459~5~Harmony~149~156~"In music
column2: harmony considers the process by which the composition of individual sounds
column3: or superpositions of sounds
column4: is analysed by hearing. Usually
column5: this means simultaneously occurring frequencies
column6: pitches (tones
column7: notes)
column8: or chords.

column1: The study of harmony involves chords and their construction and chord progressions and the principles of connection that govern them.
Harmony is often said to refer to the ""vertical"" aspect of music
column2: as distinguished from melodic line
column3: or the ""horizontal"" aspect.

column1: Counterpoint
column2: which refers to the relationship between melodic lines
column3: and polyphony
column4: which refers to the simultaneous sounding of separate independent voices
column5: are thus sometimes distinguished from harmony.

column1: In popular and jazz harmony
column2: chords are named by their root plus various terms and characters indicating their qualities. In many types of music
column3: notably baroque
column4: romantic
column5: modern
column6: and jazz
column7: chords are often augmented with ""tensions"". A tension is an additional chord member that creates a relatively dissonant interval in relation to the bass.

column1: Typically
column2: in the classical common practice period a dissonant chord (chord with tension) ""resolves"" to a consonant chord. Harmonization usually sounds pleasant to the ear when there is a balance between the consonant and dissonant sounds. In simple words
column3: that occurs when there is a balance between ""tense"" and ""relaxed"" moments."~0.23441450138279762

column1: 460~5~Harp~19579~19584~"The harp is a stringed musical instrument that has a number of individual strings running at an angle to its soundboard; the strings are plucked with the fingers. Harps have been known since antiquity in Asia
column2: Africa and Europe
column3: dating back at least as early as 3500 BCE. The instrument had great popularity in Europe during the Middle Ages and Renaissance
column4: where it evolved into a wide range of variants with new technologies
column5: and was disseminated to Europe's colonies
column6: finding particular popularity in Latin America. Although some ancient members of the harp family died out in the Near East and South Asia
column7: descendants of early harps are still played in Myanmar and parts of Africa
column8: and other defunct variants in Europe and Asia have been utilized by musicians in the modern era.

column1: Harps vary globally in many ways. In terms of size
column2: many smaller harps can be played on the lap
column3: whereas larger harps are quite heavy and rest on the floor. Different harps may use strings of catgut
column4: nylon
column5: metal
column6: or some combination. While all harps have a neck
column7: resonator
column8: and strings
column9: frame harps have a pillar at their long end to support the strings
column10: while open harps
column11: such as arch harps and bow harps
column12: do not. Modern harps also vary in techniques used to extend the range and chromaticism (e.g.
column13: adding sharps and flats) of the strings
column14: such as adjusting a string's note mid-performance with levers or pedals which modify the pitch. The pedal harp is a standard instrument in the orchestra of the Romantic music era (ca. 1800–1910) and the contemporary music era."~0.27496656903939126

column1: 461~5~Harpsichord~19579~19590~"A harpsichord is a musical instrument played by means of a keyboard
column2: a row of levers which the player presses. When the player presses one or more keys
column3: a mechanism that plucks one or more strings with a small quill is triggered.

column1: Harpsichord"" designates the whole family of similar plucked-keyboard instruments
column2: including the smaller virginals
column3: muselar
column4: and spinet. The harpsichord was widely used in Renaissance and Baroque music. During the late 18th century
column5: it gradually disappeared from the musical scene
column6: with the rise of the piano. In the 20th century
column7: it made a resurgence
column8: being used in historically informed performances of older music
column9: in new compositions
column10: and in some styles of popular music."~0.3884102667046693

column1: 462~5~Harry Partch~62232~62244~"Harry Partch (June 24
column2: 1901 – September 3
column3: 1974) was an American composer
column4: music theorist
column5: and creator of musical instruments. He composed using scales of unequal intervals in just intonation
column6: and was one of the first 20th-century composers in the West to work systematically with microtonal scales. He built custom-made instruments in these tunings on which to play his compositions
column7: and described his theory and practice in his book Genesis of a Music (1947).

column1: Partch composed with scales dividing the octave into 43 unequal tones derived from the natural harmonic series; these scales allowed for more tones of smaller intervals than in standard Western tuning
column2: which uses twelve equal intervals to the octave. To play his music
column3: Partch built a large number of unique instruments
column4: with such names as the Chromelodeon
column5: the Quadrangularis Reversum
column6: and the Zymo-Xyl. Partch described his music as corporeal
column7: and distinguished it from abstract music
column8: which he perceived as the dominant trend in Western music since the time of Bach. His earliest compositions were small-scale pieces to be intoned to instrumental backing; his later works were large-scale
column9: integrated theater productions in which he expected each of the performers to sing
column10: dance
column11: speak
column12: and play instruments. Ancient Greek theatre and Japanese Noh and kabuki heavily influenced his music theatre.

column1: Encouraged by his mother
column2: Partch learned several instruments at a young age. By fourteen
column3: he was composing
column4: and in particular took to setting dramatic situations. He dropped out of the University of Southern California's School of Music in 1922 over dissatisfaction with the quality of his teachers. He took to self-study in San Francisco's libraries
column5: where he discovered Hermann von Helmholtz's Sensations of Tone
column6: which convinced him to devote himself to music based on scales tuned in just intonation. In 1930
column7: he burned all his previous compositions in a rejection of the European concert tradition. Partch frequently moved around the US. Early in his career
column8: he was a transient worker
column9: and sometimes a hobo; later he depended on grants
column10: university appointments
column11: and record sales to support himself. In 1970
column12: supporters created the Harry Partch Foundation to administer Partch's music and instruments."~0.47987737673710407

column1: 463~5~Hebrews~39749~39756~"Hebrews (Hebrew: עברים or עבריים
column2: Tiberian ʿIḇrîm
column3: ʿIḇriyyîm; Modern Hebrew ʿIvrim
column4: ʿIvriyyim; ISO 259-3 ʕibrim
column5: ʕibriyim) is a term appearing 34 times within 32 verses of the Hebrew Bible. While the term was not an ethnonym
column6: it is mostly taken as synonymous with the Semitic-speaking Israelites
column7: especially in the pre-monarchic period when they were still nomadic
column8: but in some instances it may also be used in a wider sense
column9: referring to the Phoenicians
column10: or to other ancient groups
column11: such as the group known as Shasu of Yhw on the eve of the Bronze Age collapse.

column1: By the Roman Empire
column2: Greek Hebraios could refer to the Jews in general
column3: as Strong's Hebrew Dictionary puts it ""any of the Jewish Nation"" and at other times more specifically to the Jews living in Judea. In Early Christianity
column4: the Greek term Ἑβραῖος refers to Jewish Christians as opposed to the gentile Christians and Judaizers (Acts 6:1 among others). Ἰουδαία is the province where the Temple was located.

column1: In Armenian
column2: Italian
column3: Modern Greek
column4: Serbian
column5: Bulgarian
column6: Russian
column7: Romanian
column8: and a few other modern languages because of pejorative connotation of the word corresponding to the word Jew
column9: ""Hebrew"" is the primary word used for a Jew. The name corresponding for Hebrew is used also in the Kurdish and was once used also in French.

column1: With the revival of the Hebrew language and the emergence of the Hebrew Yishuv
column2: the term has been applied to the people of this new society or anything associated with it."~0.14795028455086334

column1: 464~5~Higher education~81061~81085~"Higher education (also called post-secondary education
column2: third level or tertiary education) is an optional final stage of formal learning that occurs after completion of secondary education. Often delivered at universities
column3: academies
column4: colleges
column5: seminaries
column6: conservatories
column7: and institutes of technology
column8: higher education is also available through certain college-level institutions
column9: including vocational schools
column10: trade schools
column11: and other career colleges that award academic degrees or professional certifications. Tertiary education at non-degree level is sometimes referred to as further education or continuing education as distinct from higher education. The right of access to higher education is mentioned in a number of international human rights instruments. The UN International Covenant on Economic
column12: Social and Cultural Rights of 1966 declares
column13: in Article 13
column14: that ""higher education shall be made equally accessible to all
column15: on the basis of capacity
column17: and in particular by the progressive introduction of free education"". In Europe
column18: Article 2 of the First Protocol to the European Convention on Human Rights
column19: adopted in 1950
column20: obliges all signatory parties to guarantee the right to education.

column1: In the days when few pupils progressed beyond primary education or basic education
column2: the term ""higher education"" was often used to refer to secondary education
column3: which can create some confusion. This is the origin of the term high school for various schools for children between the ages of 14 and 18 (United States) or 11 and 18 (UK and Australia).

column1: Higher education includes teaching
column2: research
column3: exacting applied work (e.g. in medical schools and dental schools)
column4: and social services activities of universities. Within the realm of teaching
column5: it includes both the undergraduate level
column6: and beyond that
column7: graduate-level (or postgraduate level). The latter level of education is often referred to as graduate school
column8: especially in North America. In addition to the skills that are specific to any particular degree
column9: potential employers in any profession are looking for evidence of critical thinking and analytical reasoning skills
column10: teamworking skills
column11: information literacy
column12: ethical judgment
column13: decision-making skills
column14: fluency in speaking and writing
column15: problem solving skills
column16: and a wide knowledge of liberal arts and sciences.

column1: Since World War II
column2: developed and many developing countries have increased the participation of the age group who mostly studies higher education from the elite rate
column3: of up to 15 per cent
column4: to the mass rate of 16 to 50 per cent. In many developed countries
column5: participation in higher education has continued to increase towards universal or
column6: what Trow later called
column7: open access
column8: where over half of the relevant age group participate in higher education. Higher education is important to national economies
column9: both as an industry
column10: in its own right
column11: and as a source of trained and educated personnel for the rest of the economy. College educated workers have commanded a measurable wage premium and are much less likely to become unemployed than less educated workers. However
column12: the admission of so many students of only average ability to higher education inevitably requires a decline in academic standards
column13: facilitated by grade inflation. Also
column14: the supply of graduates in many fields of study is exceeding the demand for their skills
column15: which aggravates graduate unemployment
column17: credentialism and educational inflation."~0.08406642601463754

column1: 465~5~Hindu~36700~36705~"Hindu ( pronunciation ) refers to any person who regards themselves as culturally
column2: ethnically
column3: or religiously adhering to aspects of Hinduism. It has historically been used as a geographical
column4: cultural
column5: and later religious identifier for people indigenous to South Asia.

column1: The historical meaning of the term Hindu has evolved with time. Starting with the Persian and Greek references to the land of the Indus in the 1st millennium BCE through the texts of the medieval era
column2: the term Hindu implied a geographic
column3: ethnic or cultural identifier for people living in the Indian subcontinent around or beyond the Sindhu (Indus) river. By the 16th century
column4: the term began to refer to residents of the subcontinent who were not Turkic or Muslims.

column1: The historical development of Hindu self-identity within the local South Asian population
column2: in a religious or cultural sense
column3: is unclear. Competing theories state that Hindu identity developed in the British colonial era
column4: or that it developed post-8th century CE after the Islamic invasion and medieval Hindu-Muslim wars. A sense of Hindu identity and the term Hindu appears in some texts dated between the 13th and 18th century in Sanskrit and regional languages. The 14th- and 18th-century Indian poets such as Vidyapati
column5: Kabir and Eknath used the phrase Hindu dharma (Hinduism) and contrasted it with Turaka dharma (Islam). The Christian friar Sebastiao Manrique used the term 'Hindu' in religious context in 1649. In the 18th century
column6: the European merchants and colonists began to refer to the followers of Indian religions collectively as Hindus
column7: in contrast to Mohamedans for Mughals and Arabs following Islam. By the mid-19th century
column8: colonial orientalist texts further distinguished Hindus from Buddhists
column9: Sikhs and Jains
column10: but the colonial laws continued to consider all of them to be within the scope of the term Hindu until about mid-20th century. Scholars state that the custom of distinguishing between Hindus
column11: Buddhists
column12: Jains and Sikhs is a modern phenomenon. Hindoo is an archaic spelling variant
column13: whose use today may be considered derogatory.

column1: At more than 1.03 billion
column2: Hindus are the world's third largest group after Christians and Muslims. The vast majority of Hindus
column3: approximately 966 million
column4: live in India
column5: according to India's 2011 census. After India
column6: the next 9 countries with the largest Hindu populations are
column7: in decreasing order: Nepal
column8: Bangladesh
column9: Indonesia
column10: Pakistan
column11: Sri Lanka
column12: United States
column13: Malaysia
column14: United Kingdom and Myanmar. These together accounted for 99% of the world's Hindu population
column15: and the remaining nations of the world together had about 6 million Hindus in 2010."~0.1273411379788928

column1: 466~5~Hindustani classical music~38538~38548~"Hindustani classical music ([hin̪d̪us̪t̪ɑːn̪i]) is the traditional music of northern areas of the Indian subcontinent
column2: including the modern states of India
column3: Nepal
column4: Bangladesh and Pakistan. It may also be called North Indian classical music or Shāstriya Sangīt. Its origins date from the 12th century CE
column5: when it diverged from Carnatic music
column6: the classical tradition of southern parts of the subcontinent.

column1: Hindustani classical music has strongly influenced Indonesian classical music and Dangdut popular music
column2: especially in instrumentation
column3: melody
column4: and beat. Besides vocal music
column5: which is considered to be of primary importance
column6: its main instruments are the sitar and sarod. Classical music can be divided into melody and rhythm; there is no concept of harmony."~0.4561405254072717

column1: 467~5~Humanities~82428~82438~"Humanities are academic disciplines that study aspects of human society and culture. In the renaissance
column2: the term contrasted with divinity and referred to what is now called classics
column3: the main area of secular study in universities at the time. Today
column4: the humanities are more frequently contrasted with natural
column5: and sometimes social
column6: sciences as well as professional training.

column1: The humanities use methods that are primarily critical
column2: or speculative
column3: and have a significant historical element—as distinguished from the mainly empirical approaches of the natural sciences
column4: yet
column5: unlike the sciences
column6: it has no central discipline. The humanities include ancient and modern languages
column7: literature
column8: philosophy
column9: geography
column10: history
column11: religion
column12: art and musicology.

column1: Scholars in the humanities are ""humanity scholars"" or humanists. The term ""humanist"" also describes the philosophical position of humanism
column2: which some ""antihumanist"" scholars in the humanities refuse. The Renaissance scholars and artists were also called humanists. Some secondary schools offer humanities classes usually consisting of English literature
column3: global studies and art.

column1: Human disciplines like history and cultural anthropology study subject matters that the manipulative experimental method does not apply to—and instead mainly use the comparative method and comparative research."~0.17469546251305273
468~5~Hymn~81710~81715~"A hymn is a type of song
column2: usually religious
column3: specifically written for the purpose of adoration or prayer
column4: and typically addressed to a deity or deities
column5: or to a prominent figure or personification. The word hymn derives from Greek ὕμνος (hymnos)
column6: which means ""a song of praise"". A writer of hymns is known as a hymnodist. The singing or composition of hymns is called hymnody. Collections of hymns are known as hymnals or hymn books. Hymns may or may not include instrumental accompaniment.

column1: Although most familiar to speakers of English in the context of Christianity
column2: hymns are also a fixture of other world religions
column3: especially on the Indian subcontinent. Hymns also survive from antiquity
column4: especially from Egyptian and Greek cultures. Some of the oldest surviving examples of notated music are hymns with Greek texts."~0.47551955514348854

column1: 469~5~Hypnotism~63083~63092~"Hypnosis is a state of human consciousness involving focused attention and reduced peripheral awareness and an enhanced capacity to respond to suggestion. The term may also refer to an art
column2: skill
column3: or act of inducing hypnosis.

column1: Theories explaining what occurs during hypnosis fall into two groups. Altered state theories see hypnosis as an altered state of mind or trance
column2: marked by a level of awareness different from the ordinary conscious state. In contrast
column3: nonstate theories see hypnosis as a form of imaginative role enactment.

column1: During hypnosis
column2: a person is said to have heightened focus and concentration. The person can concentrate intensely on a specific thought or memory
column3: while blocking out sources of distraction. Hypnotised subjects are said to show an increased response to suggestions. Hypnosis is usually induced by a procedure known as a hypnotic induction involving a series of preliminary instructions and suggestion. The use of hypnotism for therapeutic purposes is referred to as ""hypnotherapy""
column4: while its use as a form of entertainment for an audience is known as ""stage hypnosis"". Stage hypnosis is often performed by mentalists practicing the art form of mentalism."~0.16627976152169277

column1: 470~5~ITunes~79866~79872~"iTunes ( or ) is a media player
column2: media library
column3: Internet radio broadcaster
column4: and mobile device management application developed by Apple Inc. It was announced on January 9
column5: 2001. It is used to play
column6: download
column7: and organize digital multimedia files
column8: including music and video
column9: on personal computers running the macOS and Windows operating systems. Content must be purchased through the iTunes Store
column10: whereas iTunes is the software letting users manage their purchases.

column1: The original and main focus of iTunes is music
column2: with a library offering organization
column3: collection
column4: and storage of users' music collections. It can be used to rip songs from CDs
column5: as well as play content with the use of dynamic

column8: Apple expanded on the core features with video support
column9: later also adding podcasts
column10: e-books
column11: and a section for managing mobile apps for Apple's iOS operating system
column12: the last of which it discontinued in 2017.

column1: The original iPhone smartphone required iTunes for activation
column2: and up until 2011

column4: though it can still be used for backup and restoration of phone contents

column1: 471~5~Igor Stravinsky~53112~53127~"Igor Fyodorovich Stravinsky (Russian: И́горь Фёдорович Страви́нский
column2: IPA: [ˈiɡərʲ ˈfʲɵdərəvʲɪtɕ strɐˈvʲinskʲɪj]; 17 June [O.S. 5 June] 1882 – 6 April 1971) was a Russian-born composer
column3: pianist
column4: and conductor. He is widely considered one of the most important and influential composers of the 20th century.

column1: Stravinsky's compositional career was notable for its stylistic diversity. He first achieved international fame with three ballets commissioned by the impresario Serge Diaghilev and first performed in Paris by Diaghilev's Ballets Russes: The Firebird (1910)
column2: Petrushka (1911)
column3: and The Rite of Spring (1913). The last of these transformed the way in which subsequent composers thought about rhythmic structure and was largely responsible for Stravinsky's enduring reputation as a musical revolutionary who pushed the boundaries of musical design. His ""Russian phase"" which continued with works such as Renard
column4: the Soldier's Tale and Les Noces
column5: was followed in the 1920s by a period in which he turned to neoclassical music. The works from this period tended to make use of traditional musical forms (concerto grosso
column6: fugue and symphony)
column7: drawing on earlier styles

column11: and of instrumentation."~0.31802870535969807

column1: 472~5~Immanuel Kant~61528~61532~"Immanuel Kant (; German: [ɪˈmaːnu̯eːl kant]; 22 April 1724 – 12 February 1804) was a German philosopher who is a central figure in modern philosophy. Kant argues that the human mind creates the structure of human experience
column2: that reason is the source of morality
column3: that aesthetics arises from a faculty of disinterested judgment
column4: that space and time are forms of human sensibility
column5: and that the world as it is ""in-itself"" is independent of humanity's concepts of it. Kant took himself to have effected a ""Copernican revolution"" in philosophy
column6: akin to Copernicus' reversal of the age-old belief that the sun revolves around the earth. Kant's beliefs continue to have a major influence on contemporary philosophy
column7: especially the fields of metaphysics
column8: epistemology
column9: ethics
column10: political theory
column11: and aesthetics.

column1: Politically
column2: Kant is one of the earliest exponents of the idea that perpetual peace could be secured through universal democracy and international cooperation. He believed that this will be the eventual outcome of universal history
column3: although it is not rationally planned. The exact nature of Kant's religious ideas continues to be the subject of especially heated philosophical dispute
column4: as viewpoints are ranging from the idea that Kant was an early and radical exponent of atheism who finally exploded the ontological argument for God's existence
column5: to more critical treatments epitomized by Nietzsche who claimed that Kant had ""theologian blood"" and that Kant was merely a sophisticated apologist for traditional Christian religious belief
column6: writing that ""Kant wanted to prove
column7: in a way that would dumbfound the common man
column8: that the common man was right: that was the secret joke of this soul.""

column1: In one of Kant's major works
column2: the Critique of Pure Reason (Kritik der reinen Vernunft
column4: he attempted to explain the relationship between reason and human experience and to move beyond the failures of traditional philosophy and metaphysics. Kant wanted to put an end to an era of futile and speculative theories of human experience
column5: while resisting the skepticism of thinkers such as David Hume. Kant regarded himself as ending and showing the way beyond the impasse which modern philosophy had led to between rationalists and empiricists
column6: and is widely held to have synthesized these two early modern traditions in his thought.

column1: Kant argued that our experiences are structured by necessary features of our minds. In his view
column2: the mind shapes and structures experience so that
column3: on an abstract level
column4: all human experience shares certain essential structural features. Among other things
column5: Kant believed that the concepts of space and time are integral to all human experience
column6: as are our concepts of cause and effect. One important consequence of this view is that our experience of things is always of the phenomenal world as conveyed by our senses: we do not have direct access to things in themselves
column7: the so-called noumenal world. Kant published other important works on ethics
column8: religion
column9: law
column10: aesthetics
column11: astronomy
column12: and history. These included the Critique of Practical Reason (Kritik der praktischen Vernunft
column14: the Metaphysics of Morals (Die Metaphysik der Sitten
column17: and the Critique of Judgment (Kritik der Urteilskraft
column19: which looks at aesthetics and teleology."~0.14348073083747173

474~5~Improvisation~2171~2184~Improvisation is creating or performing something spontaneously or making something from whatever is available. Improvisation

column1: 475~5~Indonesia~83013~83022~"Indonesia ( ( listen) IN-də-NEE-zhə or  IN-doh-NEE-zee-ə; Indonesian: [ɪndonesia])
column2: officially the Republic of Indonesia (Indonesian: Republik Indonesia [rɛpublik ɪndonesia])
column3: is a unitary sovereign state and transcontinental country located mainly in Southeast Asia
column4: with some territories in Oceania. Situated between the Indian and Pacific oceans
column5: it is the world's largest island country
column6: with more than thirteen thousand islands. At 1
column8: 569 square kilometres (735
column9: 358 square miles)
column10: Indonesia is the world's 14th largest country in terms of land area and the 7th largest in terms of combined sea and land area. With over 261 million people
column11: it is the world's 4th most populous country as well as the most populous Austronesian and Muslim-majority country. Java
column12: the world's most populous island
column13: contains more than half of the country's population.

column1: Indonesia's republican form of government includes an elected parliament and president. Indonesia has 34 provinces
column2: of which five have Special status. Its capital is Jakarta
column3: which is the second most populous urban area in the world. The country shares land borders with Papua New Guinea
column4: East Timor
column5: and the eastern part of Malaysia. Other neighbouring countries include Singapore
column6: Vietnam
column7: the Philippines
column8: Australia
column9: Palau
column10: and India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands. Despite its large population and densely populated regions
column11: Indonesia has vast areas of wilderness that support a high level of biodiversity. The country has abundant natural resources like oil and natural gas
column12: tin

column14: palm oil
column15: tea
column17: cacao

column21: Japan

column1: The Indonesian archipelago has been an important region for trade since at least the 7th century
column2: when Srivijaya and then later Majapahit traded with Chinese dynasties and Indian kingdoms. Local rulers gradually absorbed foreign cultural
column3: religious and political models from the early centuries CE
column4: and Hindu and Buddhist kingdoms flourished. Indonesian history has been influenced by foreign powers drawn to its natural resources. Muslim traders and Sufi scholars brought Islam
column5: while European powers brought Christianity and fought one another to monopolise trade in the Spice Islands of Maluku during the Age of Discovery. Following a period of Dutch colonialism starting from Amboina and Batavia
column6: and eventually all of the archipelago including Timor and Western New Guinea
column7: at times interrupted by Portuguese
column8: French and British rule
column9: Indonesia secured its independence after World War II.

column1: Indonesia consists of hundreds of distinct native ethnic and linguistic groups
column2: with the largest—and politically dominant—ethnic group being the Javanese. A shared identity has developed
column3: defined by a national language

column5: religious pluralism within a Muslim-majority population
column6: and a history of colonialism and rebellion against it. Indonesia's national motto
column7: ""Bhinneka Tunggal Ika"" (""Unity in Diversity"" literally
column8: ""many
column9: yet one"")
column10: articulates the diversity that shapes the country. Indonesia's economy is the world's 16th largest by nominal GDP and the 7th largest by GDP at PPP. Indonesia is a member of several multilateral organisations
column11: including the UN
column12: WTO
column13: IMF and G20 major economies. It is also a founding member of Non-Aligned Movement
column14: Association of Southeast Asian Nations
column15: Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation
column17: Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and Organisation of Islamic Cooperation."~0.1141426815935043

column1: 476~5~Industrial revolution~51058~51079~"The Industrial Revolution was the transition to new manufacturing processes in the period from about 1760 to sometime between 1820 and 1840. This transition included going from hand production methods to machines
column2: new chemical manufacturing and iron production processes
column3: the increasing use of steam power
column4: the development of machine tools and the rise of the factory system.

column1: Textiles were the dominant industry of the Industrial Revolution in terms of employment
column2: value of output and capital invested. The textile industry was also the first to use modern production methods.

column1: The Industrial Revolution began in Great Britain
column2: and many of the technological innovations were of British origin. By the mid-18th century Britain was the world's leading commercial nation
column3: controlling a global trading empire with colonies in North America and Africa
column4: and with some political influence on the Indian subcontinent
column5: through the activities of the East India Company. The development of trade and the rise of business were major causes of the Industrial Revolution.

column1: The Industrial Revolution marks a major turning point in history; almost every aspect of daily life was influenced in some way. In particular
column2: average income and population began to exhibit unprecedented sustained growth. Some economists say that the major impact of the Industrial Revolution was that the standard of living for the general population began to increase consistently for the first time in history
column3: although others have said that it did not begin to meaningfully improve until the late 19th and 20th centuries.

column1: GDP per capita was broadly stable before the Industrial Revolution and the emergence of the modern capitalist economy
column2: while the Industrial Revolution began an era of per-capita economic growth in capitalist economies. Economic historians are in agreement that the onset of the Industrial Revolution is the most important event in the history of humanity since the domestication of animals and plants.

column1: The precise start and end of the Industrial Revolution is still debated among historians
column2: as is the pace of economic and social changes. Eric Hobsbawm held that the Industrial Revolution began in Britain in the 1780s and was not fully felt until the 1830s or 1840s
column3: while T. S. Ashton held that it occurred roughly between 1760 and 1830. Rapid industrialization first began in Britain
column4: starting with mechanized spinning in the 1780s
column5: with high rates of growth in steam power and iron production occurring after 1800. Mechanized textile production spread from Great Britain to continental Europe and the United States in the early 19th century
column6: with important centres of textiles
column7: iron and coal emerging in Belgium and the United States and later textiles in France.

column1: An economic recession occurred from the late 1830s to the early 1840s when the adoption of the original innovations of the Industrial Revolution
column2: such as mechanized spinning and weaving
column3: slowed and their markets matured. Innovations developed late in the period
column4: such as the increasing adoption of locomotives
column5: steamboats and steamships
column6: hot blast iron smelting and new technologies
column7: such as the electrical telegraph
column8: widely introduced in the 1840s and 1850s
column9: were not powerful enough to drive high rates of growth. Rapid economic growth began to occur after 1870
column10: springing from a new group of innovations in what has been called the Second Industrial Revolution. These new innovations included new steel making processes
column11: the large-scale manufacture of machine tools and the use of increasingly advanced machinery in steam-powered factories."~0.11431404043157231

column2: or singing

column1: 479~5~Intellect~48743~48752~"Intellect is a term used in studies of the human mind
column2: and refers to the ability of the mind to come to correct conclusions about what is true or real
column3: and about how to solve problems. Historically the term comes from the Greek philosophical term nous
column4: which was translated into Latin as intellectus (derived from the verb intelligere
column5: ""to understand""
column6: from inter
column7: ""between"" and legere
column8: ""to choose"") and into French and then English as intelligence (other than intellect). Intellect is in fact considered as a branch of intelligence (see Intellect vs intelligence).

column1: Discussion of the intellect can be divided into two broad areas. In both of these areas
column2: the terms ""intellect"" and ""intelligence"" have continued to be used as related words.

column1: In philosophy
column2: especially in classical and medieval philosophy the intellect or nous is an important subject connected to the question of how humans can know things. Especially during late antiquity and the Middle Ages
column3: the intellect was often proposed as a concept which could reconcile philosophical and scientific understandings of nature with monotheistic religious understandings
column4: by making the intellect a link between each human soul
column5: and the divine intellect (or intellects) of the cosmos itself. (During the Latin Middle Ages a distinction developed whereby the term ""intelligence"" was typically used to refer to the incorporeal beings which governed the celestial spheres in many of these accounts.) Also see: passive intellect and active intellect.

column1: In modern psychology and neuroscience
column2: intelligence and intellect are used as terms describing mental ability (or abilities) that allow people to understand. A distinction is sometimes made whereby intellect is considered to be related to ""facts"" in contrast to intelligence concerning ""feelings"". Intellect refers to the cognition and rational mental processes gained through external input rather than internal.

column1: A person who uses intelligence (thought and reason) and critical or analytical reasoning in either a professional or a personal capacity is often referred to as an intellectual.

~0.06791326126118477
480~5~Intelligence~63806~63818~Intelligence has been defined in many different ways including as one's capacity for logic
column2: understanding
column3: self-awareness
column4: learning
column5: emotional knowledge
column6: reasoning
column7: planning
column8: creativity
column9: and problem solving. It can be more generally described as the ability to perceive or infer information
column10: and to retain it as knowledge to be applied towards adaptive behaviors within an environment or context.

column1: Intelligence is most widely studied in humans
column2: but has also been observed in non-human animals and in plants. Artificial intelligence is intelligence in machines. It is commonly implemented in computer systems using program software."~0.09127290310026007
