column1: 482~5~Iran~38577~38583~"Iran (Persian: ایران‎ Irān [ʔiːˈɾɒːn] ( listen))
column2: also known as Persia ()
column3: officially the Islamic Republic of Iran (Persian: جمهوری اسلامی ایران‎‎ Jomhuri-ye Eslāmi-ye Irān ( listen))
column4: is a sovereign state in Western Asia. With over 81 million inhabitants
column5: Iran is the world's 18th-most-populous country. Comprising a land area of 1
column8: 372 sq mi)
column9: it is the second-largest country in the Middle East and the 17th-largest in the world. Iran is bordered to the northwest by Armenia and the Republic of Azerbaijan
column10: to the north by the Caspian Sea
column11: to the northeast by Turkmenistan
column12: to the east by Afghanistan and Pakistan
column13: to the south by the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman
column14: and to the west by Turkey and Iraq. The country's central location in Eurasia and Western Asia
column15: and its proximity to the Strait of Hormuz
column16: give it geostrategic importance. Tehran is the country's capital and largest city
column17: as well as its leading economic and cultural center.

column1: Iran is home to one of the world's oldest civilizations
column2: beginning with the formation of the Elamite kingdoms in the fourth millennium BC. It was first unified by the Iranian Medes in the seventh century BC
column3: and reached its greatest extent during the Achaemenid Empire founded by Cyrus the Great in the sixth century BC
column4: stretching from Eastern Europe to the Indus Valley
column5: becoming a larger empire than previously ever existed in the world. The Iranian realm fell to Alexander the Great in the fourth century BC
column6: but reemerged shortly after as the Parthian Empire
column7: followed by the Sasanian Empire
column8: which became a leading world power for the next four centuries.

column1: Arab Muslims conquered the empire in the seventh century AD
column2: ultimately leading to the displacement of the indigenous faiths of Zoroastrianism and Manichaeism with Islam. Iran made major contributions to the Islamic Golden Age that followed
column3: producing many influential figures in art and science. After two centuries
column4: a period of various native Muslim dynasties began
column5: which were later conquered by the Turks and the Mongols. The rise of the Safavids in the 15th century led to the reestablishment of a unified Iranian state and national identity
column6: which followed the country's conversion to Shia Islam
column7: marking a turning point in Iranian and Muslim history. By the 18th century
column8: under Nader Shah
column9: Iran briefly possessed what was arguably the most powerful empire at the time. The 19th-century conflicts with the Russian Empire led to significant territorial losses. Popular unrest culminated in the Constitutional Revolution of 1906
column10: which established a constitutional monarchy and the country's first legislature. Following the coup of 1953 instigated by the United Kingdom and the United States
column11: Iran gradually became closely aligned with the West
column12: and grew increasingly autocratic. Growing dissent against foreign influence and political repression led to the 1979 Revolution
column13: which followed the establishment of an Islamic republic
column14: a political system which includes elements of a parliamentary democracy vetted and supervised by a theocracy governed by an autocratic ""Supreme Leader"". During the 1980s
column15: the country was engaged in a war with Iraq
column16: which lasted for almost nine years and resulted in a high number of casualties and financial loss for both sides.

column1: According to international reports
column2: Iran's human rights record is exceptionally poor. The regime in Iran has frequently persecuted and arrested critics of the government and its Supreme Leader. Women's rights in Iran are described as seriously inadequate
column3: and children's rights have been severely violated
column4: with more child offenders being executed in Iran than in any other country in the world.  Since the 2000s
column5: Iran's controversial nuclear program has raised concerns
column6: which is part of the basis of the international sanctions against the country. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action
column7: an agreement reached between Iran and the P5+1
column8: was created on 14 July 2015
column9: aimed to loosen the nuclear sanctions in exchange for Iran's restriction in producing enriched uranium.

column1: Iran is a founding member of the UN
column2: ECO
column3: NAM
column4: OIC
column5: and OPEC. It is a major regional and middle power
column6: and its large reserves of fossil fuels – which include the world's largest natural gas supply and the fourth-largest proven oil reserves – exert considerable influence in international energy security and the world economy.

column1: The country's rich cultural legacy is reflected in part by its 22 UNESCO World Heritage Sites
column2: the third-largest number in Asia and eleventh-largest in the world. Iran is a multicultural country comprising numerous ethnic and linguistic groups
column3: the largest being Persians (61%)
column4: Azeris (16%)
column5: Kurds (10%)

column1: 483~5~Jam session~7364~7376~"A jam session is a relatively informal musical event
column2: process
column3: or activity where musicians
column4: typically instrumentalists
column5: play improvised solos and vamp on tunes
column6: songs and chord progressions. To ""jam"" is to improvise music without extensive preparation or predefined arrangements
column7: except for when the group is playing well-known jazz standards or covers of existing popular songs. Original jam sessions
column8: also 'free flow sessions'
column9: are often used by musicians to develop new material (music) and find suitable arrangements. Both styles can be used simply as a social gathering and communal practice session. Jam sessions may be based upon existing songs or forms
column10: may be loosely based on an agreed chord progression or chart suggested by one participant
column11: or may be wholly improvisational. Jam sessions can range from very loose gatherings of amateurs to evenings where a jam session coordinator or host acts as a ""gatekeeper"" to ensure that only appropriate-level performers take the stage
column12: to sophisticated improvised recording sessions by professionals which are intended to be broadcast live on radio or TV or edited and released to the public."~0.3512775496250732

column1: 484~5~Jazz~1803~1807~"Jazz is a music genre that originated in the African-American communities of New Orleans
column2: United States
column3: in the late 19th and early 20th centuries
column4: and developed from roots in blues and ragtime. Jazz is seen by many as 'America's classical music'. Since the 1920s Jazz Age
column5: jazz has become recognized as a major form of musical expression. It then emerged in the form of independent traditional and popular musical styles
column6: all linked by the common bonds of African-American and European-American musical parentage with a performance orientation. Jazz is characterized by swing and blue notes
column7: call and response vocals
column8: polyrhythms and improvisation. Jazz has roots in West African cultural and musical expression
column9: and in African-American music traditions including blues and ragtime
column10: as well as European military band music. Although the foundation of jazz is deeply rooted within the black experience of the United States
column11: different cultures have contributed their own experience and styles to the art form as well. Intellectuals around the world have hailed jazz as ""one of America's original art forms"".

column1: As jazz spread around the world
column2: it drew on different national
column3: regional
column4: and local musical cultures
column5: which gave rise to many distinctive styles. New Orleans jazz began in the early 1910s
column6: combining earlier brass-band marches
column7: French quadrilles
column8: biguine

column11: Kansas City jazz

column13: bluesy

column15: shifting jazz from danceable popular music toward a more challenging ""musician's music"" which was played at faster tempos and used more chord-based improvisation. Cool jazz developed near the end of the 1940s
column17: smoother sounds and long

column4: and in the mid-1950s
column5: hard bop emerged
column6: which introduced influences from rhythm and blues
column7: gospel
column8: and blues

column11: or musical scale

column14: electric instruments
column15: and highly amplified stage sound. In the early 1980s
column16: a commercial form of jazz fusion called smooth jazz became successful
column17: garnering significant radio airplay. Other styles and genres abound in the 2000s
column18: such as Latin and Afro-Cuban jazz."~0.3914129811643778

column1: 485~5~Jazz band~60302~60315~"A jazz band (jazz ensemble or jazz combo) is a musical ensemble that plays jazz music. Jazz bands vary in the quantity of its members and the style of jazz that they play but it is common to find a jazz band made up of a rhythm section and a horn section.
The size of a jazz band is closely related to the style of jazz they play as well as the type of venues in which they play. Smaller jazz bands
column2: also known as combos
column3: are common in night clubs and other small venues and will be made up of three to seven musicians; whereas big bands are found in dance halls and other larger venues.

column2: to a smaller trio or quartet. The term jazz trio can refer to a three piece band with a pianist
column3: double bass player and a drummer. Some bands use vocalists

column1: 489~5~Language~14869~14877~"Language is a system that consists of the development

column1: The scientific study of language is called linguistics. Questions concerning the philosophy of language
column2: such as whether words can represent experience

Thinkers such as Rousseau have argued that language originated from emotions while others like Kant have held that it originated from rational and logical thought. 20th-century philosophers such as Wittgenstein argued that philosophy is really the study of language. Major figures in linguistics include Ferdinand de Saussure and Noam Chomsky.

column1: Estimates of the number of human languages in the world vary between 5

column1: Languages evolve and diversify over time

A group of languages that descend from a common ancestor is known as a language family. The Indo-European family is the most widely spoken and includes languages as diverse as English

496~5~Lullaby~25242~25249~A lullaby, or cradle song, is a soothing song or piece of music that is usually played for (or sung to) children. The purposes of lullabies vary. In some societies they are used to pass down cultural knowledge or tradition. In addition, lullabies are often used for the developing of communication skills, indication of emotional intent, maintenance of infants' undivided attention, modulation of infants' arousal, and regulation of behavior. Perhaps one of the most important uses of lullabies is as a sleep aid for infants. As a result, the music is often simple and repetitive. Lullabies can be found in many countries, and have existed since ancient times.~0.5122138824468758

The sensory processor allows information from the outside world to be sensed in the form of chemical and physical stimuli and attended to with various levels of focus and intent. Working memory serves as an encoding and retrieval processor. Information in the form of stimuli is encoded in accordance with explicit or implicit functions by the working memory processor. The working memory also retrieves information from previously stored material. Finally
column5: the function of long-term memory is to store data through various categorical models or systems (Baddely

column1: Explicit and implicit functions of memory are also known as declarative and non-declarative systems (Squire
column2: 2009). These systems involve the purposeful intention of memory retrieval and storage
column3: or lack thereof. Declarative
column4: or explicit
column5: memory is the conscious storage and recollection of data (Graf & Schacter
column6: 1985). Under declarative memory resides semantic and episodic memory. Semantic memory refers to memory that is encoded with specific meaning (Eysenck
column8: while episodic memory refers to information that is encoded along a spatial and temporal plane (Schacter & Addis
column9: 2007; Szpunar
column10: 2010). Declarative memory is usually the primary process thought of when referencing memory (Eysenck

column1: Non-declarative
column2: or implicit
column3: memory is the unconscious storage and recollection of information (Foerde & Poldrack
column4: 2009). An example of a non-declarative process would be the unconscious learning or retrieval of information by way of procedural memory
column5: or a priming phenomenon (Eysenck
column6: 2012; Foerde & Poldrack
column7: 2009; Tulving & Schacter
column8: 1990). Priming is the process of subliminally arousing specific responses from memory and shows that not all memory is consciously activated (Tulving & Schacter
column10: whereas procedural memory is the slow and gradual learning of skills that often occurs without conscious attention to learning (Eysenck
column11: 2012; Foerde & Poldrack

column1: Memory is not a perfect processor
column2: and is affected by many factors. The manner information is encoded
column3: stored
column4: and retrieved can all be corrupted. The amount of attention given new stimuli can diminish the amount of information that becomes encoded for storage (Eysenck
column5: 2012). Also
column6: the storage process can become corrupted by physical damage to areas of the brain that are associated with memory storage
column7: such as the hippocampus (Squire
column8: 2009). Finally
column9: the retrieval of information from long-term memory can be disrupted because of decay within long-term memory (Eysenck
column10: 2012). Normal functioning
column11: decay over time
column12: and brain damage all affect the accuracy and capacity of memory.

column1: Memory loss is usually described as forgetfulness or amnesia."~0.23948010193436176
507~5~Mental disorder~94681~94695~"A mental disorder
column2: also called a mental illness or psychiatric disorder
column3: is a behavioral or mental pattern that causes significant distress or impairment of personal functioning. Such features may be persistent
column4: relapsing and remitting
column5: or occur as a single episode. Many disorders have been described
column6: with signs and symptoms that vary widely between specific disorders. Such disorders may be diagnosed by a mental health professional.

column1: The causes of mental disorders are often unclear. Theories may incorporate findings from a range of fields. Mental disorders are usually defined by a combination of how a person behaves
column2: feels
column3: perceives
column4: or thinks. This may be associated with particular regions or functions of the brain
column5: often in a social context. A mental disorder is one aspect of mental health. Cultural and religious beliefs
column6: as well as social norms
column7: should be taken into account when making a diagnosis.

column1: Services are based in psychiatric hospitals or in the community
column2: and assessments are carried out by psychiatrists
column3: psychologists
column4: and clinical social workers
column5: using various methods such as psychometric tests but often relying on observation and questioning. Treatments are provided by various mental health professionals. Psychotherapy and psychiatric medication are two major treatment options. Other treatments include social interventions
column6: peer support
column7: and self-help. In a minority of cases there might be involuntary detention or treatment. Prevention programs have been shown to reduce depression.

column1: Common mental disorders include depression
column2: which affects about 400 million
column3: dementia which affects about 35 million
column4: and schizophrenia
column5: which affects about 21 million people globally. Stigma and discrimination can add to the suffering and disability associated with mental disorders
column6: leading to various social movements attempting to increase understanding and challenge social exclusion."~0.12073356756632748

column1: 508~5~Mentoring~85224~85233~"Mentorship is a relationship in which a more experienced or more knowledgeable person helps to guide a less experienced or less knowledgeable person. The mentor may be older or younger than the person being mentored
column2: but he or she must have a certain area of expertise. It is a learning and development partnership between someone with vast experience and someone who wants to learn. Mentorship experience and relationship structure affect the ""amount of psychosocial support
column3: career guidance
column4: role modeling
column5: and communication that occurs in the mentoring relationships in which the protégés and mentors engaged.""

column1: The person in receipt of mentorship may be referred to as a protégé (male)
column2: a protégée (female)
column3: an apprentice or
column4: in the 2000s
column5: a mentee. The mentor may be referred to as a godfather/godmother or a rabbi.

column1: Mentoring"" is a process that always involves communication and is relationship-based
column2: but its precise definition is elusive
column3: with more than 50 definitions currently in use. One definition of the many that have been proposed
column4: is

column1: Mentoring is a process for the informal transmission of knowledge
column2: social capital
column3: and the psychosocial support perceived by the recipient as relevant to work
column4: career
column5: or professional development; mentoring entails informal communication
column6: usually face-to-face and during a sustained period of time
column7: between a person who is perceived to have greater relevant knowledge
column8: wisdom
column9: or experience (the mentor) and a person who is perceived to have less (the protégé)"".

column1: Mentoring in Europe has existed since at least Ancient Greek times. Since the 1970s it has spread in the United States mainly in training contexts
column2: with important historical links to the movement advancing workplace equity for women and minorities
column3: and it has been described as ""an innovation in American management""."~0.08985152699118026

column1: 509~5~Metaphysics~60692~60703~"Metaphysics is a branch of philosophy exploring the fundamental questions
column2: including the nature of concepts like being
column3: existence
column4: and reality. It has two branches – cosmology and ontology. Traditional metaphysics seeks to answer
column5: in a ""suitably abstract and fully general manner""
column6: the questions:

column1: What is there?
And what is it like?
Topics of metaphysical investigation include existence
column2: objects and their properties
column3: space and time
column4: cause and effect
column5: and possibility. A central branch of metaphysics is ontology
column6: the investigation into the basic categories of being and how they relate to one another.

column1: There are two broad conceptions about what ""world"" is studied by metaphysics. The strong
column2: classical view assumes that the objects studied by metaphysics exist independently of any observer
column3: so that the subject is the most fundamental of all sciences. The modern view assumes that the objects studied by metaphysics exist inside the mind of an observer
column4: so the subject becomes a form of introspection and conceptual analysis. Some philosophers
column5: notably Kant
column6: discuss both of these ""worlds"" and what can be inferred about each one.

column1: Some philosophers
column2: such as the logical positivists
column3: and many scientists reject the entire subject of metaphysics as meaningless and unverifiable
column4: while others disagree and think that it is legitimate."~0.16181381927703234

column1: 510~5~Middle Ages~42022~42033~"In the history of Europe
column2: the Middle Ages (or Medieval Period) lasted from the 5th to the 15th century. It began with the fall of the Western Roman Empire and merged into the Renaissance and the Age of Discovery. The Middle Ages is the middle period of the three traditional divisions of Western history: classical antiquity
column3: the medieval period
column4: and the modern period. The medieval period is itself subdivided into the Early
column5: High
column6: and Late Middle Ages.

column1: Population decline
column2: counterurbanisation
column3: invasion
column4: and movement of peoples
column5: which had begun in Late Antiquity
column6: continued in the Early Middle Ages. The large-scale movements of the Migration Period
column7: including various Germanic peoples
column8: formed new kingdoms in what remained of the Western Roman Empire. In the seventh century
column9: North Africa and the Middle East—once part of the Byzantine Empire—came under the rule of the Umayyad Caliphate
column10: an Islamic empire
column11: after conquest by Muhammad's successors. Although there were substantial changes in society and political structures
column12: the break with classical antiquity was not complete. The still-sizeable Byzantine Empire survived in the east and remained a major power. The empire's law code
column13: the Corpus Juris Civilis or ""Code of Justinian""
column14: was rediscovered in Northern Italy in 1070 and became widely admired later in the Middle Ages. In the West
column15: most kingdoms incorporated the few extant Roman institutions. Monasteries were founded as campaigns to Christianise pagan Europe continued. The Franks
column17: briefly established the Carolingian Empire during the later 8th and early 9th century. It covered much of Western Europe but later succumbed to the pressures of internal civil wars combined with external invasions: Vikings from the north
column19: and Saracens from the south.

column1: During the High Middle Ages
column2: which began after 1000
column3: the population of Europe increased greatly as technological and agricultural innovations allowed trade to flourish and the Medieval Warm Period climate change allowed crop yields to increase. Manorialism
column4: the organisation of peasants into villages that owed rent and labour services to the nobles
column5: and feudalism
column6: the political structure whereby knights and lower-status nobles owed military service to their overlords in return for the right to rent from lands and manors
column7: were two of the ways society was organised in the High Middle Ages. The Crusades
column8: first preached in 1095
column9: were military attempts by Western European Christians to regain control of the Holy Land from Muslims. Kings became the heads of centralised nation states
column10: reducing crime and violence but making the ideal of a unified Christendom more distant. Intellectual life was marked by scholasticism
column11: a philosophy that emphasised joining faith to reason
column12: and by the founding of universities. The theology of Thomas Aquinas
column13: the paintings of Giotto
column14: the poetry of Dante and Chaucer
column15: the travels of Marco Polo
column16: and the Gothic architecture of cathedrals such as Chartres are among the outstanding achievements toward the end of this period and into the Late Middle Ages.

column1: The Late Middle Ages was marked by difficulties and calamities including famine
column2: plague
column3: and war
column4: which significantly diminished the population of Europe; between 1347 and 1350
column5: the Black Death killed about a third of Europeans. Controversy
column6: heresy
column7: and the Western Schism within the Catholic Church paralleled the interstate conflict
column8: civil strife
column9: and peasant revolts that occurred in the kingdoms. Cultural and technological developments transformed European society
column10: concluding the Late Middle Ages and beginning the early modern period."~0.13816289863981646

column1: 511~5~Mix tape~5800~5809~"Generally
column2: a mixtape (also mix-tape or mix tape) is a home-made compilation of music (typically copyrighted songs taken from other sources) recorded in a specific order
column3: traditionally onto a cassette tape
column4: though later replaced by CD or digital playlist formats. The songs can be sequential
column5: or made into a continuous program by beatmatching the songs and creating seamless transitions at their beginnings and endings by use of fades or abrupt edits. Compilations may include a selection of favorite songs
column6: or music linked by theme or mood
column7: perhaps tailored to the tape's intended recipient.

column1: Writing in 2004
column2: essayist Geoffrey O'Brien called the personal mix tape ""perhaps the most widely practiced American art form"".

column1: In hip hop and R&B culture
column2: however
column3: the term mixtape is used to describe certain types of recordings
column4: typically self-produced and independently released albums
column5: that are issued free of charge to gain publicity or circumvent possible copyright infringement."~0.287614393021577

column1: 512~5~Muse~786~791~"The Muses (/ˈmjuːzɪz/; Ancient Greek: Μοῦσαι
column2: Moũsai) are the inspirational goddesses of literature
column3: science
column4: and the arts in Greek mythology. They were considered the source of the knowledge embodied in the poetry
column5: lyric songs
column6: and myths that were related orally for centuries in these ancient cultures. They were later adopted by the Romans as a part of their pantheon.

column1: In current English usage
column2: ""muse"" can refer in general to a person who inspires an artist
column3: musician

column1: 514~5~Music composition~2065~2076~"Musical composition can refer to an original piece of music
column2: either a song or an instrumental music piece
column3: the structure of a musical piece
column4: or the process of creating or writing a new song or piece of music. People who create new compositions are called composers in classical music. In popular music and traditional music
column5: the creators of new songs are usually called songwriters; with songs
column6: the person who writes new words for a song is the lyricist. ""Composition"" is the act or practice of creating a song or other piece of music. In many cultures
column7: including Western classical music
column8: the act of composing typically includes the creation of music notation
column9: such as a sheet music ""score""
column10: which is then performed by the composer or by other instrumental musicians or singers. In popular music and traditional music
column11: songwriting may involve the creation of a basic outline of the song
column12: called the lead sheet
column13: which sets out the melody
column14: lyrics and chord progression. In classical music
column15: orchestration (choosing the instruments of a large music ensemble such as an orchestra which will play the different parts of music
column17: accompaniment
column19: bassline and so on) is typically done by the composer
column20: but in musical theatre and in pop music
column21: songwriters may hire an arranger to do the orchestration. In some cases
column22: a pop or traditional songwriter may not use written notation at all
column23: and instead compose the song in their mind and then play
column24: sing and/or record it from memory. In jazz and popular music
column25: notable sound recordings by influential performers are given the weight that written or printed scores play in classical music.

column1: Although a musical composition often uses musical notation and has a single author
column2: this is not always the case. A work of music can have multiple composers
column3: which often occurs in popular music when all of the members of a band collaborates to write a song
column4: or in musical theatre
column5: when one person writes the melodies
column6: a second person writes the lyrics
column7: and a third person orchestrates the songs. A piece of music can also be composed with words
column8: images
column9: or
column10: since the 20th century
column11: with computer programs that explain or notate how the singer or musician should create musical sounds. Examples range from 20th century avant-garde music that uses graphic notation
column12: to text compositions such as Karlheinz Stockhausen's Aus den sieben Tagen
column13: to computer programs that select sounds for musical pieces. Music that makes heavy use of randomness and chance is called aleatoric music
column14: and is associated with contemporary composers active in the 20th century
column15: such as John Cage
column17: and Witold Lutosławski. A more commonly known example of chance-based music is the sound of wind chimes jingling in a breeze. The study of composition has traditionally been dominated by examination of methods and practice of Western classical music
column18: but the definition of composition is broad enough to include the creation of popular music and traditional music songs and instrumental pieces
column19: and to include spontaneously improvised works like those of free jazz performers and African percussionists such as Ewe drummers.

column1: Although in the 2000s
column2: composition is considered to consist of the manipulation of each aspect of music (harmony
column3: melody
column4: form
column5: rhythm
column6: and timbre)
column7: according to Jean-Benjamin de Laborde (1780

column1: Composition consists in two things only. The first is the ordering and disposing of several sounds...in such a manner that their succession pleases the ear. This is what the Ancients called melody. The second is the rendering audible of two or more simultaneous sounds in such a manner that their combination is pleasant. This is what we call harmony
column2: and it alone merits the name of composition."~0.28042178988665156

column1: 515~5~Music festival~57809~57823~"A music festival is a community event oriented towards live performances of singing and instrument playing that is often presented with a theme such as musical genre (e.g.
column2: blues
column3: folk
column4: jazz
column5: classical music)
column6: nationality
column7: or locality of musicians
column8: or holiday. Some festivals are focused on women’s music.

column1: They are commonly held outdoors
column2: with tents or roofed temporary stages for the performers. Often music festivals host other attractions such as food and merchandise vending
column3: dance
column4: crafts
column5: performance art
column6: and social or cultural activities. At music festivals associated with charitable causes
column7: there may be information about social or political issues. Many festivals are annual
column8: or repeat at some other interval. Some
column9: including many rock festivals
column10: are held only once.

column1: Some festivals are organized as for-profit concerts and others are benefits for a specific charitable cause. Another type of music festival is the educative type
column2: organized annually in local communities
column3: regionally
column4: or nationally
column5: for the benefit of amateur musicians of all ages and grades of achievement."~0.4010520751824004

column1: 517~5~Musical instrument~36768~36786~"A musical instrument is an instrument created or adapted to make musical sounds. In principle
column2: any object that produces sound can be considered a musical instrument—it is through purpose that the object becomes a musical instrument. The history of musical instruments dates to the beginnings of human culture. Early musical instruments may have been used for ritual
column3: such as a trumpet to signal success on the hunt
column4: or a drum in a religious ceremony. Cultures eventually developed composition and performance of melodies for entertainment. Musical instruments evolved in step with changing applications.

column1: The date and origin of the first device considered a musical instrument is disputed. The oldest object that some scholars refer to as a musical instrument
column2: a simple flute
column3: dates back as far as 67
column4: 000 years. Some consensus dates early flutes to about 37
column5: 000 years ago. However
column6: most historians believe that determining a specific time of musical instrument invention is impossible due to the subjectivity of the definition and the relative instability of materials used to make them. Many early musical instruments were made from animal skins
column7: bone
column8: wood
column9: and other non-durable materials.

column1: Musical instruments developed independently in many populated regions of the world. However
column2: contact among civilizations caused rapid spread and adaptation of most instruments in places far from their origin. By the Middle Ages
column3: instruments from Mesopotamia were in maritime Southeast Asia
column4: and Europeans played instruments from North Africa. Development in the Americas occurred at a slower pace
column5: but cultures of North
column6: Central
column7: and South America shared musical instruments. By 1400
column8: musical instrument development slowed in many areas and was dominated by the Occident.

column1: Musical instrument classification is a discipline in its own right
column2: and many systems of classification have been used over the years. Instruments can be classified by their effective range
column3: their material composition
column4: their size
column5: etc. However
column6: the most common academic method
column7: Hornbostel-Sachs
column8: uses the means by which they produce sound. The academic study of musical instruments is called organology."~0.329967494360614

column1: 518~5~Musical theatre~29732~29748~"Musical theatre is a form of theatrical performance that combines songs
column2: spoken dialogue
column3: acting and dance. The story and emotional content of a musical – humor
column4: pathos
column5: love
column6: anger – are communicated through the words
column7: music
column8: movement and technical aspects of the entertainment as an integrated whole. Although musical theatre overlaps with other theatrical forms like opera and dance
column9: it may be distinguished by the equal importance given to the music as compared with the dialogue
column10: movement and other elements. Since the early 20th century
column11: musical theatre stage works have generally been called
column12: simply
column13: musicals.

column1: Although music has been a part of dramatic presentations since ancient times
column2: modern Western musical theatre emerged during the 19th century
column3: with many structural elements established by the works of Gilbert and Sullivan in Britain and those of Harrigan and Hart in America. These were followed by the numerous Edwardian musical comedies and the musical theatre works of American creators like George M. Cohan. The Princess Theatre musicals and other smart shows like Of Thee I Sing (1931) were artistic steps forward beyond revues and other frothy entertainments of the early 20th century and led to such groundbreaking works as Show Boat (1927) and Oklahoma! (1943). Some of the most famous musicals through the decades that followed include West Side Story (1957)
column4: The Fantasticks (1960)
column5: Hair (1967)
column6: A Chorus Line (1975)
column7: Les Misérables (1985)
column8: The Phantom of the Opera (1986)
column9: Rent (1996)
column10: The Producers (2001)
column11: Wicked (2003) and Hamilton (2015).

column1: Musicals are performed around the world. They may be presented in large venues
column2: such as big-budget Broadway or West End productions in New York City or London. Alternatively
column3: musicals may be staged in smaller fringe theatre
column4: Off-Broadway or regional theatre productions
column5: or on tour. Musicals are often presented by amateur and school groups in churches
column6: schools and other performance spaces. In addition to the United States and Britain
column7: there are vibrant musical theatre scenes in continental Europe
column8: Asia
column9: Australasia
column10: Canada and Latin America."~0.2795740849507093

column1: 519~5~Musician~3550~3558~"A musician is a person who plays a musical instrument or is musically talented. Anyone who composes
column2: conducts
column3: or performs music may be referred to as a musician. A musician who plays a musical instrument is also known as an instrumentalist.

column1: Musicians can specialize in any musical style
column2: and some musicians play in a variety of different styles depending on cultures and background. Examples of a musician's possible skills include performing
column3: conducting
column4: singing
column5: rapping
column6: producing
column7: composing
column8: arranging
column9: and the orchestration of music."~0.42376265067666796

column1: 520~5~Musicologist~62260~62273~"Musicology (from Greek μουσική (mousikē)
column2: meaning 'music'
column3: and -λογία (-logia)
column4: meaning 'study of') is the scholarly analysis and research-based study of music. Musicology is part of the humanities. A scholar who participates in musical research is a musicologist.

column1: Traditionally
column2: historical musicology (commonly termed ""music history"") has been the most prominent sub-discipline of musicology. In the 2010s
column3: historical musicology is one of several large musicology sub-disciplines. Historical musicology
column4: ethnomusicology
column5: and systematic musicology are approximately equal in size. Ethnomusicology is the study of music in its cultural context. Systematic musicology includes music acoustics
column6: the science and technology of acoustical musical instruments
column7: and the musical implications of physiology
column8: psychology
column9: sociology
column10: philosophy and computing. Cognitive musicology is the set of phenomena surrounding the computational modeling of music. In some countries
column11: music education is a prominent sub-field of musicology
column12: while in others it is regarded as a distinct academic field
column13: or one more closely affiliated with teacher education
column14: educational research
column15: and related fields. Like music education
column16: music therapy is a specialized form of applied musicology which is sometimes considered more closely affiliated with health fields
column17: and other times regarded as part of musicology proper."~0.32783228290582317

column1: 522~5~Nationalism~49318~49331~"Nationalism is a political
column2: social
column3: and economic system characterized by promoting the interests of a particular nation particularly with the aim of gaining and maintaining self-governance
column4: or full sovereignty
column5: over the group's homeland. The political ideology therefore holds that a nation should govern itself
column6: free from unwanted outside interference
column7: and is linked to the concept of self-determination. Nationalism is further oriented towards developing and maintaining a national identity based on shared characteristics such as culture
column8: language

The adoption of national identity in terms of historical development has commonly been the result of a response by influential groups unsatisfied with traditional identities due to inconsistency between their defined social order and the experience of that social order by its members

column1: 528~5~Opera~2983~2988~"Opera (Italian: [ˈɔːpera]; English plural: operas; Italian plural: opere [ˈɔːpere]) is an art form in which singers and musicians perform a dramatic work combining text (libretto) and musical score
column2: usually in a theatrical setting. In traditional opera

column4: a speech-inflected style and arias

column1: Opera is a key part of the Western classical music tradition. It started in Italy at the end of the 16th century (with Jacopo Peri's mostly lost Dafne

column7: until Christoph Willibald Gluck reacted against its artificiality with his ""reform"" operas in the 1760s. The most renowned figure of late 18th-century opera is Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

column10: Don Giovanni
column11: and Così fan tutte

column1: 536~5~Ottoman Empire~95036~95050~"The Ottoman Empire (/ˈɒtəmən/; Devlet-i ʿAlīye-i ʿOsmānīye)

column9: which prompted them to initiate a comprehensive process of reform and modernisation known as the Tanzimat. Thus over the course of the nineteenth century the Ottoman state became vastly more powerful and organised
column10: despite suffering further territorial losses
column11: especially in the Balkans

column13: hoping to escape from the diplomatic isolation which had contributed to its recent territorial losses
column14: and thus joined World War I on the side of the Central Powers. While the Empire was able to largely hold its own during the conflict
column15: it was struggling with internal dissent
column16: especially with the Arab Revolt in its Arabian holdings. During this time
column17: major atrocities were committed by the Ottoman government against the Armenians

column1: The Empire's defeat and the occupation of part of its territory by the Allied Powers in the aftermath of World War I resulted in its partitioning and the loss of its Middle Eastern territories
column2: which were divided between the United Kingdom and France. The successful Turkish War of Independence against the occupying Allies led to the emergence of the Republic of Turkey in the Anatolian heartland and the abolition of the Ottoman monarchy."~0.07877691180729504

column1: 539~5~Paleolithic~36063~36074~"The Paleolithic or Palaeolithic  is a period in human prehistory prehistoric distinguished by the original development of stone tools that covers c. 95% of human technological prehistory. It extends from the earliest known use of stone tools by hominins c. 3.3 million years ago
column2: to the end of the Pleistocene c. 11
column3: 650 cal BP.

column1: The Paleolithic is followed in Europe by the Mesolithic
column2: although the date of the transition varies geographically by several thousand years.

column1: During the Paleolithic
column2: hominins grouped together in small societies such as bands
column3: and subsisted by gathering plants and fishing
column4: hunting or scavenging wild animals. The Paleolithic is characterized by the use of knapped stone tools
column5: although at the time humans also used wood and bone tools. Other organic commodities were adapted for use as tools
column6: including leather and vegetable fibers; however
column7: due to their nature
column8: these have not been preserved to any great degree.

column1: About 50
column2: 000 years ago
column3: there was a marked increase in the diversity of artifacts. In Africa
column4: bone artifacts and the first art appear in the archaeological record. The first evidence of human fishing is also noted
column5: from artifacts in places such as Blombos cave in South Africa. Archaeologists classify artifacts of the last 50
column6: 000 years into many different categories
column7: such as projectile points
column8: engraving tools
column9: knife blades
column10: and drilling and piercing tools.

column1: Humankind gradually evolved from early members of the genus Homo—such as Homo habilis
column2: who used simple stone tools—into anatomically modern humans as well as behaviorally modern humans by the Upper Paleolithic. During the end of the Paleolithic
column3: specifically the Middle and or Upper Paleolithic
column4: humans began to produce the earliest works of art and began to engage in religious and spiritual behavior such as burial and ritual. The climate during the Paleolithic consisted of a set of glacial and interglacial periods in which the climate periodically fluctuated between warm and cool temperatures. Archaeological and genetic data suggest that the source populations of Paleolithic humans survived in sparsely wooded areas and dispersed through areas of high primary productivity while avoiding dense forest cover.

column1: By c. 50
column3: 000 BP
column4: the first humans set foot in Australia. By c. 45
column5: 000 BP
column6: humans lived at 61°N latitude in Europe. By c. 30
column7: 000 BP
column8: Japan was reached
column9: and by c. 27
column10: 000 BP humans were present in Siberia
column11: above the Arctic Circle. At the end of the Upper Paleolithic
column12: a group of humans crossed Beringia and quickly expanded throughout the Americas.

column1: The term ""Palaeolithic"" was coined by archaeologist John Lubbock in 1865. It derives from Greek: παλαιός
column2: palaios
column3: ""old""; and λίθος
column4: lithos
column5: ""stone""
column6: meaning ""old age of the stone"" or ""Old Stone Age""."~0.19682571015157374

column1: 540~5~Passacaglia~34086~34097~The passacaglia (; Italian: [pasːaˈkaʎːa]) is a musical form that originated in early seventeenth-century Spain and is still used today by composers. It is usually of a serious character and is often
column2: but not always
column3: based on a bass-ostinato and written in triple metre.~0.4148301673806889

column1: 541~5~Perceive~15326~15335~"Perception (from the Latin perceptio) is the organization
column2: identification
column3: and interpretation of sensory information in order to represent and understand the presented information
column4: or the environment.

column1: All perception involves signals that go through the nervous system
column2: which in turn result from physical or chemical stimulation of the sensory system. For example
column3: vision involves light striking the retina of the eye
column4: smell is mediated by odor molecules
column5: and hearing involves pressure waves.

column1: Perception is not only the passive receipt of these signals
column2: but it's also shaped by the recipient's learning
column3: memory
column4: expectation
column5: and attention.

column1: Perception can be split into two processes
column2: (1) processing the sensory input
column3: which transforms these low-level information to higher-level information (e.g.
column4: extracts shapes for object recognition)
column5: (2) processing which is connected with a person's concepts and expectations (or knowledge)
column6: restorative and selective mechanisms (such as attention) that influence perception.

column1: Perception depends on complex functions of the nervous system
column2: but subjectively seems mostly effortless because this processing happens outside conscious awareness.

column1: Since the rise of experimental psychology in the 19th Century
column2: psychology's understanding of perception has progressed by combining a variety of techniques.  Psychophysics quantitatively describes the relationships between the physical qualities of the sensory input and perception. Sensory neuroscience studies the neural mechanisms underlying perception. Perceptual systems can also be studied computationally
column3: in terms of the information they process. Perceptual issues in philosophy include the extent to which sensory qualities such as sound
column4: smell or color exist in objective reality rather than in the mind of the perceiver.

column1: Although the senses were traditionally viewed as passive receptors
column2: the study of illusions and ambiguous images has demonstrated that the brain's perceptual systems actively and pre-consciously attempt to make sense of their input. There is still active debate about the extent to which perception is an active process of hypothesis testing
column3: analogous to science
column4: or whether realistic sensory information is rich enough to make this process unnecessary.

column1: The perceptual systems of the brain enable individuals to see the world around them as stable
column2: even though the sensory information is typically incomplete and rapidly varying. Human and animal brains are structured in a modular way
column3: with different areas processing different kinds of sensory information. Some of these modules take the form of sensory maps
column4: mapping some aspect of the world across part of the brain's surface. These different modules are interconnected and influence each other. For instance
column5: taste is strongly influenced by smell."~0.18051852640594773

column1: 542~5~Performance~1528~1539~Performance is completion of a task with application of knowledge
column2: skills and abilities. In work place
column3: performance or job performance means good ranking with the hypothesized conception of requirements of a task role
column4: whereas citizenship performance means a set of individual activity/contribution (prosocial organizational behavior) that supports the organizational culture. In the performing arts
column5: a performance generally comprises an event in which a performer or group of performers present one or more works of art to an audience. Usually the performers participate in rehearsals beforehand. A performance may also describe the way in which an actor performs. In a solo capacity
column6: it may also refer to a mime artist
column7: comedian
column8: conjurer
column9: or other entertainer.~0.07283465538386316

column1: 543~5~Performing arts~2783~2797~"Performing arts are a form of art in which artists use their voices or bodies
column2: often in relation to other objects
column3: to convey artistic expression. It is different from visual arts
column4: which is when artists use paint
column5: canvas or various materials to create physical or static art objects. Performing arts include several disciplines
column6: each performed in front of a live audience.

column1: Theatre
column2: music
column3: dance
column4: and other kinds of performances are present in all human cultures. The history of music and dance date to pre-historic times. More refined versions
column5: such as ballet
column6: opera
column7: and Kabuki
column8: are performed professionally.

column1: Live performances before an audience are a form of entertainment. The development of audio and video recording has allowed for private consumption of the performing arts.
The performing arts can help explain our emotions
column2: expressions

column1: 544~5~Phonograph~52027~52038~"The phonograph is a device
column2: invented in 1877
column3: for the mechanical recording and reproduction of sound. In its later forms
column4: it is also called a gramophone (as a trademark since 1887
column5: as a generic name in the UK since 1910)
column6: or
column7: since the 1940s
column8: a record player. The sound vibration waveforms are recorded as corresponding physical deviations of a spiral groove engraved
column9: etched
column10: incised
column11: or impressed into the surface of a rotating cylinder or disc
column12: called a ""record"". To recreate the sound
column13: the surface is similarly rotated while a playback stylus traces the groove and is therefore vibrated by it
column14: very faintly reproducing the recorded sound. In early acoustic phonographs
column15: the stylus vibrated a diaphragm which produced sound waves which were coupled to the open air through a flaring horn
column16: or directly to the listener's ears through stethoscope-type earphones.

column1: The phonograph was invented in 1877 by Thomas Edison. While other inventors had produced devices that could record sounds
column2: Edison's phonograph was the first to be able to reproduce the recorded sound. His phonograph originally recorded sound onto a tinfoil sheet wrapped around a rotating cylinder. A stylus responding to sound vibrations produced an up and down or hill-and-dale groove in the foil. Alexander Graham Bell's Volta Laboratory made several improvements in the 1880s and introduced the graphophone
column3: including the use of wax-coated cardboard cylinders and a cutting stylus that moved from side to side in a zigzag groove around the record. In the 1890s
column4: Emile Berliner initiated the transition from phonograph cylinders to flat discs with a spiral groove running from the periphery to near the center
column5: coining the term gramophone for disc record players
column6: which is predominantly used in many languages. Later improvements through the years included modifications to the turntable and its drive system
column7: the stylus or needle
column8: and the sound and equalization systems.

column1: The disc phonograph record was the dominant audio recording format throughout most of the 20th century. From the mid-1980s on
column2: phonograph use on a standard record player declined sharply because of the rise of the cassette tape
column3: compact disc and other digital recording formats. Records are still a favorite format for some audiophiles and by DJs and turntablists in hip hop music
column4: electronic dance music and other styles. Vinyl records are still used by some DJs and musicians in their concert performances. Some electronic dance music DJs and music producers continue to release their recordings on vinyl records. The original recordings of musicians
column5: which may have been recorded on tape or digital methods
column6: are sometimes re-issued on vinyl."~0.3445401145101617

column1: 545~5~Physics~60696~60703~"Physics (from Ancient Greek: φυσική (ἐπιστήμη)
column2: translit. physikḗ (epistḗmē)
column3: lit. 'knowledge of nature'
column4: from φύσις phýsis ""nature"") is the natural science that studies matter and its motion and behavior through space and time and that studies the related entities of energy and force. Physics is one of the most fundamental scientific disciplines
column5: and its main goal is to understand how the universe behaves.

column1: Physics is one of the oldest academic disciplines and
column2: through its inclusion of astronomy
column3: perhaps the oldest. Over the last two millennia
column4: physics
column5: chemistry
column6: biology
column7: and certain branches of mathematics were a part of natural philosophy
column8: but during the scientific revolution in the 17th century
column9: these natural sciences emerged as unique research endeavors in their own right. Physics intersects with many interdisciplinary areas of research
column10: such as biophysics and quantum chemistry
column11: and the boundaries of physics are not rigidly defined. New ideas in physics often explain the fundamental mechanisms studied by other sciences and suggest new avenues of research in academic disciplines such as mathematics and philosophy.

column1: Theoretical breakthroughs in physics also make significant contributions by enabling advances in new technologies. For example
column2: advances in the understanding of electromagnetism and nuclear physics led directly to the development of new products that have dramatically transformed modern-day society
column3: such as television
column4: computers
column5: domestic appliances
column6: and nuclear weapons; advances in thermodynamics led to the development of industrialization; and advances in mechanics inspired the development of calculus."~0.12429937267270591

column1: 546~5~Physiological~65544~65557~"Physiology (; from Ancient Greek φύσις (physis)
column2: meaning 'nature
column3: origin'
column4: and -λογία (-logia)
column5: meaning 'study of') is the scientific study of normal mechanisms
column6: and their interactions
column7: which works within a living system. A sub-discipline of biology
column8: its focus is in how organisms
column9: organ systems
column10: organs
column11: cells
column12: and biomolecules carry out the chemical or physical functions that exist in a living system. Given the size of the field
column13: it is divided into
column14: among others
column15: animal physiology (including that of humans)
column17: cellular physiology
column19: bacterial physiology

column1: Central to an understanding of physiological functioning is its integrated nature with other disciplines such as chemistry and physics
column2: coordinated homeostatic control mechanisms
column3: and continuous communication between cells.

column1: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded to those who make significant achievements in this discipline by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. In medicine
column2: a physiologic state is one occurring from normal body function
column3: rather than pathologically
column4: which is centered on the abnormalities that occur in animal diseases
column5: including humans."~0.05348500064045196

column1: 547~5~Piccolo~20126~20133~"The piccolo  (Italian pronunciation: [ˈpikkolo]; Italian for ""small""
column2: but named ottavino in Italy) is a half-size flute
column3: and a member of the woodwind family of musical instruments. The modern piccolo has most of the same fingerings as its larger sibling
column4: the standard transverse flute
column5: but the sound it produces is an octave higher than written. This gave rise to the name ottavino (Italian for ""little octave"")
column6: the name by which the instrument is referred to in the scores of Italian composers.

column1: Piccolos are now manufactured in the key of C or D♭. It was for this D♭ piccolo that John Philip Sousa wrote the famous solo in the final repeat of the closing section (trio) of his march ""The Stars and Stripes Forever"".
In the orchestral setting
column2: the piccolo player is often designated as ""piccolo/flute III""
column3: or even ""assistant principal"". The larger orchestras have designated this position as a solo position due to the demands of the literature. Piccolos are often orchestrated to double the violins or the flutes
column4: adding sparkle and brilliance to the overall sound because of the aforementioned one-octave transposition upwards. In concert band settings
column5: the piccolo is almost always used and a piccolo part is almost always available."~0.07666161327626306

column1: 548~5~Pipe organ~44944~44954~"The pipe organ is a musical instrument that produces sound by driving pressurized air (called wind) through organ pipes selected via a keyboard. Because each pipe produces a single pitch
column2: the pipes are provided in sets called ranks
column3: each of which has a common timbre and volume throughout the keyboard compass. Most organs have multiple ranks of pipes of differing timbre
column4: pitch
column5: and volume that the player can employ singly or in combination through the use of controls called stops.

column1: A pipe organ has one or more keyboards (called manuals) played by the hands
column2: and a pedalboard played by the feet; each keyboard has its own group of stops. The keyboard(s)
column3: pedalboard
column4: and stops are housed in the organ's console. The organ's continuous supply of wind allows it to sustain notes for as long as the corresponding keys are pressed
column5: unlike the piano and harpsichord whose sound begins to dissipate immediately after a key is depressed. The smallest portable pipe organs may have only one or two dozen pipes and one manual; the largest may have over 20
column6: 000 pipes and seven manuals. A list of some of the most notable and largest pipe organs in the world can be viewed at List of pipe organs.

column1: The origins of the pipe organ can be traced back to the water organ in Ancient Greece
column2: in the 3rd century BC
column3: in which the wind supply was created with water pressure. By the 6th or 7th century AD
column4: bellows were used to supply organs with wind. Beginning in the 12th century
column5: the organ began to evolve into a complex instrument capable of producing different timbres. A pipe organ with ""great leaden pipes"" was sent to the West by the Byzantine emperor Constantine V as a gift to Pepin the Short
column6: King of the Franks
column7: in 757. Pepin's son Charlemagne requested a similar organ for his chapel in Aachen in 812
column8: beginning the pipe organ's establishment in Western church music. In England
column9: ""The first organ of which any detailed record exists was built in Winchester Cathedral in the 10th century. It was a huge machine with 400 pipes
column10: which needed two men to play it and 70 men to blow it
column11: and its sound could be heard throughout the city.""  By the 17th century
column12: most of the sounds available on the modern classical organ had been developed. From that time
column13: the pipe organ was the most complex man-made device — a distinction it retained until it was displaced by the telephone exchange in the late 19th century.

column1: Pipe organs are installed in churches
column2: synagogues
column3: concert halls
column4: schools
column5: other public buildings and in private properties. They are used in the performance of classical music
column6: sacred music
column7: secular music
column8: and popular music. In the early 20th century
column9: pipe organs were installed in theaters to accompany the screening of films during the silent movie era; in municipal auditoria
column10: where orchestral transcriptions were popular; and in the homes of the wealthy. The beginning of the 21st century has seen a resurgence in installations in concert halls. The organ boasts a substantial repertoire
column11: which spans over 500 years."~0.2869549460713824

column1: 549~5~Plainsong~42631~42640~"Plainsong (also plainchant; Latin: cantus planus) is a body of chants used in the liturgies of the Western Church. Though the Catholic Church (both its Eastern and Western halves) and the Eastern Orthodox churches did not split until long after the origin of plainsong
column2: Byzantine chants are generally not classified as plainsong.

column1: Plainsong is monophonic
column2: consisting of a single
column3: unaccompanied melodic line. Its rhythm is generally freer than the metered rhythm of later Western music."~0.36700924764496806

column1: 550~5~Plaisir~61386~61393~"Plaisir is a commune located in the heart of the Yvelines department in the Île-de-France in north-central France. It is located in the western suburbs of Paris
column2: 29.5 km (18.3 mi) from the center of Paris.

column1: It borders among others on Élancourt (south)
column2: Trappes (southeast) and Les-Clayes-sous-Bois (east).

column1: The inhabitants are called Plaisirois.
Plaisir has managed to preserve its twelfth century church. Its varied territory is characterised by large agricultural plains
column2: many green spaces and a forest area that together occupy half of its surface.

column1: Plaisir is the ninth commune of the Yvelines department in terms of population.
column2: with nearly 31
column3: 000 inhabitants.

column1: It is a member of the Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines.
Between 1968 and 1990
column2: Plaisir has seen explosive growth in its population
column3: but since then
column4: the town's policy has been to contain growth and aim for stabilisation
column5: in order to main the local quality of living as well as the natural spaces (forests and agricultural lands).

column1: It has a major shopping mall that is still expanding. This commercial activity has been a boon for local tax revenues
column2: but also led to congestion of its roads.

column1: Aside from this commercial activity
column2: Plaisir is also home to a number of other activities
column3: for instance it is home to the Zodiaxc corporation and hosts the Lenôtre culinary school which attracts students from across the globe."~0.12643787947790971

column1: 551~5~Plato~62692~62697~"Plato (; Greek: Πλάτων Plátōn
column2: pronounced [plá.tɔːn] in Classical Attic; 428/427 or 424/423 – 348/347 BC) was a philosopher in Classical Greece and the founder of the Academy in Athens
column3: the first institution of higher learning in the Western world. He is widely considered the most pivotal figure in the development of philosophy
column4: especially the Western tradition. Unlike nearly all of his philosophical contemporaries
column5: Plato's entire work is believed to have survived intact for over 2
column6: 400 years. Others believe that the oldest extant manuscript dates to around AD 895
column7: 1100 years after Plato's death. This makes it difficult to know exactly what Plato wrote.

column1: Along with his teacher
column2: Socrates
column3: and his most famous student
column4: Aristotle
column5: Plato laid the foundations of Western philosophy and science. Alfred North Whitehead once noted: ""the safest general characterization of the European philosophical tradition is that it consists of a series of footnotes to Plato."" In addition to being a foundational figure for Western science
column6: philosophy
column7: and mathematics
column8: Plato has also often been cited as one of the founders of Western religion and spirituality.

column1: Plato was the innovator of the written dialogue and dialectic forms in philosophy. Plato appears to have been the founder of Western political philosophy
column2: with his Republic
column3: and Laws among other dialogues
column4: providing some of the earliest extant treatments of political questions from a philosophical perspective. Plato's own most decisive philosophical influences are usually thought to have been Socrates
column5: Parmenides
column6: Heraclitus and Pythagoras
column7: although few of his predecessors' works remain extant and much of what we know about these figures today derives from Plato himself.

column1: The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy describes Plato as ""...one of the most dazzling writers in the Western literary tradition and one of the most penetrating
column2: wide-ranging
column3: and influential authors in the history of philosophy. ... He was not the first thinker or writer to whom the word “philosopher” should be applied. But he was so self-conscious about how philosophy should be conceived
column4: and what its scope and ambitions properly are
column5: and he so transformed the intellectual currents with which he grappled
column6: that the subject of philosophy
column7: as it is often conceived—a rigorous and systematic examination of ethical
column8: political
column9: metaphysical
column10: and epistemological issues
column11: armed with a distinctive method—can be called his invention. Few other authors in the history of Western philosophy approximate him in depth and range: perhaps only Aristotle (who studied with him)
column12: Aquinas and Kant would be generally agreed to be of the same rank."""~0.11880064864031642

column1: 552~5~Playlist~5671~5680~A Playlist is a list of video or audio files that can be played back on a media player sequentially or in random order. In its most general form
column2: an audio playlist is simply a list of songs
column3: but sometimes a loop. They can be played in sequential or shuffled order. The term has several specialized meanings in the realms of television broadcasting
column4: radio broadcasting and personal computers. A playlist can also be a list of recorded titles on a digital video disk. On the Internet
column5: a playlist can be a list of chapters in a movie serial; for example
column6: Flash Gordon in the Planet Mongo is available on YouTube as a playlist of thirteen consecutive video chapters.~0.32535146305997525

column1: 553~5~Polyphony~34272~34282~"In music
column2: polyphony is one type of musical texture
column3: where a texture is
column4: generally speaking
column5: the way that melodic
column6: rhythmic
column7: and harmonic aspects of a musical composition are combined to shape the overall sound and quality of the work. In particular
column8: polyphony consists of two or more simultaneous lines of independent melody
column9: as opposed to a musical texture with just one voice
column10: monophony
column11: or a texture with one dominant melodic voice accompanied by chords
column12: which is called homophony.

column1: Within the context of the Western musical tradition
column2: the term polyphony is usually used to refer to music of the late Middle Ages and Renaissance. Baroque forms such as fugue
column3: which might be called polyphonic
column4: are usually described instead as contrapuntal. Also
column5: as opposed to the species terminology of counterpoint
column6: polyphony was generally either ""pitch-against-pitch"" / ""point-against-point"" or ""sustained-pitch"" in one part with melismas of varying lengths in another. In all cases the conception was probably what Margaret Bent (1999) calls ""dyadic counterpoint""
column7: with each part being written generally against one other part
column8: with all parts modified if needed in the end. This point-against-point conception is opposed to ""successive composition""
column9: where voices were written in an order with each new voice fitting into the whole so far constructed
column10: which was previously assumed.

column1: The term polyphony is also sometimes used more broadly
column2: to describe any musical texture that is not monophonic. Such a perspective considers homophony as a sub-type of polyphony."~0.2858241670152771

column1: 554~5~Positron emission tomography~64496~64524~"Positron-emission tomography (PET) is a nuclear medicine functional imaging technique that is used to observe metabolic processes in the body as an aid to the diagnosis of disease. The system detects pairs of gamma rays emitted indirectly by a positron-emitting radionuclide (tracer)
column2: which is introduced into the body on a biologically active molecule. Three-dimensional images of tracer concentration within the body are then constructed by computer analysis. In modern PET-CT scanners
column3: three-dimensional imaging is often accomplished with the aid of a CT X-ray scan performed on the patient during the same session
column4: in the same machine.

column1: If the biologically active molecule chosen for PET is fludeoxyglucose (FDG)
column2: an analogue of glucose
column3: the concentrations of tracer imaged will indicate tissue metabolic activity as it corresponds to the regional glucose uptake. Use of this tracer to explore the possibility of cancer metastasis (i.e.
column4: spreading to other sites) is the most common type of PET scan in standard medical care (90% of current scans). Less often
column5: other radioactive tracers are used to image the tissue concentration of other types of molecules of interest. One of the disadvantages of PET scanners is their operating cost."~0.028305580520127563

column1: 555~5~Prosumer~78664~78672~"A prosumer is a person who consumes and produces a product. It is derived from ""prosumption""
column2: a dot-com era business term meaning ""production by consumers"". These terms were coined in 1980 by American futurist Alvin Toffler

column1: 556~5~Psychological~17714~17727~"Psychology is the science of behavior and mind

column4: when taken together

column4: attention

column7: phenomenology
column8: motivation (conation)

column14: and other areas. Psychologists of diverse orientations also consider the unconscious mind. Psychologists employ empirical methods to infer causal and correlational relationships between psychosocial variables. In addition
column15: or in opposition
column16: to employing empirical and deductive methods
column17: some—especially clinical and counseling psychologists—at times rely upon symbolic interpretation and other inductive techniques. Psychology has been described as a ""hub science""
column18: with psychological findings linking to research and perspectives from the social sciences
column19: natural sciences
column21: humanities

column2: it is also directed towards understanding and solving problems in several spheres of human activity. By many accounts psychology ultimately aims to benefit society. The majority of psychologists are involved in some kind of therapeutic role

column4: counseling
column5: or school settings. Many do scientific research on a wide range of topics related to mental processes and behavior
column6: and typically work in university psychology departments or teach in other academic settings (e.g.
column7: medical schools

column9: or in other areas such as human development and aging
column10: sports
column11: health
column12: and the media
column13: as well as in forensic investigation and other aspects of law."~0.026422185005329675
