column1: 558~5~Punk rock~55493~55502~"Punk rock (or ""punk"") is a rock music genre that developed in the mid-1970s in the United States
column2: United Kingdom
column3: and Australia. Rooted in 1960s garage rock and other forms of what is now known as ""proto-punk"" music
column4: punk rock bands rejected perceived excesses of mainstream 1970s rock. Punk bands typically produced short or fast-paced songs
column5: with hard-edged melodies and singing styles
column6: stripped-down instrumentation
column7: and often political
column8: anti-establishment lyrics. Punk embraces a DIY ethic; many bands self-produce recordings and distribute them through independent record labels and other informal channels.

column1: The term ""punk rock"" was first used by certain American rock critics in the early 1970s to describe 1960s garage bands and subsequent acts then perceived as stylistic inheritors. Between 1974 and 1976 the movement now bearing the name ""punk rock"" emerged. It produced a new generation of bands such as Television and the Ramones in New York City
column2: the Sex Pistols
column3: the Clash
column4: and the Damned in London
column5: and the Saints in Brisbane—by late-1976 these acts were generally recognized as forming its vanguard. As 1977 approached
column6: punk rock became a major and highly controversial cultural phenomenon in the United Kingdom. It spawned a punk subculture expressing youthful rebellion characterized by distinctive styles of clothing and adornment (ranging from deliberately offensive T-shirts
column7: leather jackets
column8: studded or spiked bands and jewelry
column9: as well as bondage and S&M clothes) and a variety of anti-authoritarian ideologies that have since been associated with the form.

column1: In 1977 the influence of punk rock music and subculture became more pervasive
column2: spreading throughout various countries worldwide. It generally took root in local scenes that tended to reject affiliation with the mainstream. In the late 1970s punk experienced its second wave in which acts that were not active during its formative years adopted the style. By the early 1980s
column3: faster and more aggressive subgenres such as hardcore punk (e.g. Minor Threat)
column4: street punk (e.g. the Exploited)
column5: and anarcho-punk (e.g. Subhumans) became the predominant modes of punk rock. Musicians identifying with or inspired by punk often later pursued other musical directions
column6: resulting in a broad range of spinoffs
column7: giving rise to genres such as post-punk
column8: new wave and later indie pop
column9: alternative rock
column10: and noise rock. By the 1990s punk rock re-emerged in the mainstream
column11: as pop punk bands such as Green Day and the Offspring brought the genre widespread popularity."~0.37033048494062715

column1: 559~5~Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky~50605~50629~"Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky ( IL-yitch chy-KOF-skee; Russian: Пётр Ильи́ч Чайко́вский; 25 April/7 May 1840 – 25 October/6 November 1893)
column2: often anglicized as Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky
column3: was a Russian composer of the romantic period
column4: some of whose works are among the most popular music in the classical repertoire. He was the first Russian composer whose music made a lasting impression internationally
column5: bolstered by his appearances as a guest conductor in Europe and the United States. Tchaikovsky was honored in 1884 by Emperor Alexander III
column6: and awarded a lifetime pension.

column1: Although musically precocious
column2: Tchaikovsky was educated for a career as a civil servant. There was scant opportunity for a musical career in Russia at that time and no system of public music education. When an opportunity for such an education arose
column3: he entered the nascent Saint Petersburg Conservatory
column4: from which he graduated in 1865. The formal Western-oriented teaching he received there set him apart from composers of the contemporary nationalist movement embodied by the Russian composers of The Five
column5: with whom his professional relationship was mixed. Tchaikovsky's training set him on a path to reconcile what he had learned with the native musical practices to which he had been exposed from childhood. From this reconciliation he forged a personal but unmistakably Russian style—a task that did not prove easy. The principles that governed melody
column6: harmony and other fundamentals of Russian music ran completely counter to those that governed Western European music; this seemed to defeat the potential for using Russian music in large-scale Western composition or for forming a composite style
column7: and it caused personal antipathies that dented Tchaikovsky's self-confidence. Russian culture exhibited a split personality
column8: with its native and adopted elements having drifted apart increasingly since the time of Peter the Great. This resulted in uncertainty among the intelligentsia about the country's national identity—an ambiguity mirrored in Tchaikovsky's career.

column1: Despite his many popular successes
column2: Tchaikovsky's life was punctuated by personal crises and depression. Contributory factors included his early separation from his mother for boarding school followed by his mother's early death
column3: the death of his close friend and colleague Nikolai Rubinstein
column4: and the collapse of the one enduring relationship of his adult life
column5: which was his 13-year association with the wealthy widow Nadezhda von Meck. His homosexuality
column6: which he kept private
column7: has traditionally also been considered a major factor
column8: though some musicologists now downplay its importance. Tchaikovsky's sudden death at the age of 53 is generally ascribed to cholera; there is an ongoing debate as to whether cholera was indeed the cause of death
column9: and whether his death was accidental or self-inflicted.

column1: While his music has remained popular among audiences
column2: critical opinions were initially mixed. Some Russians did not feel it was sufficiently representative of native musical values and expressed suspicion that Europeans accepted the music for its Western elements. In an apparent reinforcement of the latter claim
column3: some Europeans lauded Tchaikovsky for offering music more substantive than base exoticism and said he transcended stereotypes of Russian classical music. Others dismissed Tchaikovsky's music as ""lacking in elevated thought
column4: according to longtime New York Times music critic Harold C. Schonberg
column5: and derided its formal workings as deficient because they did not stringently follow Western principles."~0.33406231609830683

column1: 560~5~Raga~38351~38355~"A raga or raaga (IAST: rāga; also raag or ragam ; literally ""coloring
column2: tingeing
column3: dyeing"" is a melodic framework for improvisation akin to a melodic mode in Indian classical music. While the raga is a remarkable and central feature of the classical music tradition
column4: it has no direct translation to concepts in the classical European music tradition. Each raga is an array of melodic structures with musical motifs
column5: considered in the Indian tradition to have the ability to ""color the mind"" and affect the emotions of the audience.

column1: A raga consists of at least five notes
column2: and each raga provides the musician with a musical framework within which to improvise. The specific notes within a raga can be reordered and improvised by the musician. Ragas range from small ragas like Bahar and Shahana that are not much more than songs to big ragas like Malkauns
column3: Darbari and Yaman
column4: which have great scope for improvisation and for which performances can last over an hour. Ragas may change over time
column5: with an example being Marwa
column6: the primary development of which has gone down to the lower octave compared to the traditionally middle octave
column7: mainly due to the influence of Amir Khan. Each raga traditionally has an emotional significance and symbolic associations such as with season
column8: time and mood. The raga is considered a means in Indian musical tradition to evoke certain feelings in an audience. Hundreds of raga are recognized in the classical tradition
column9: of which about 30 are common. Each raga
column10: state Dorothea E. Hast and others
column11: has its ""own unique melodic personality"".

column1: There are two main classical music traditions
column2: Hindustani (North Indian) and Carnatic (South Indian)
column3: and the concept of raga is shared by both. Raga are also found in Sikh traditions such as in Guru Granth Sahib
column4: the primary scripture of Sikhism. Similarly it is a part of the qawwali tradition found in Sufi Islamic communities of South Asia. Some popular Indian film songs and ghazals use rāgas in their compositions."~0.34052099213171183

column1: 561~5~Rapping~561~568~"Rapping (or rhyming
column2: spitting
column3: emceeing
column4: MCing) is a musical form of vocal delivery that incorporates ""rhyme
column5: rhythmic speech

column11: and ""delivery"" (cadence

column1: 562~5~Record label~79087~79099~"A record label or record company is a brand or trademark associated with the marketing of music recordings and music videos. Sometimes

The term ""record label"" derives from the circular label in the center of a vinyl record which prominently displays the manufacturer's name
column9: along with other information."~0.37555086241760327

column1: 563~5~Refrain~30058~30065~"A refrain (from Vulgar Latin refringere
column2: ""to repeat""
column3: and later from Old French refraindre) is the line or lines that are repeated in music or in verse; the ""chorus"" of a song. Poetic fixed forms that feature refrains include the villanelle
column4: the virelay
column5: and the sestina.

column2: rhythmically
column3: and harmonically

column5: often with added instrumentation. Chorus form

column1: 564~5~Remix~78796~78801~"A remix is a piece of media which has been altered from its original state by adding
column2: removing
column3: and/or changing pieces of the item. A song
column4: piece of artwork
column5: book
column6: video
column7: or photograph can all be remixes. The only characteristic of a remix is that it appropriates and changes other materials to create something new.

column1: Most commonly
column2: remixes are a subset of audio mixing in music and song recordings. Songs may be remixed for a variety of reasons:

column1: to adapt or revise a song for radio or nightclub play
to create a stereo or surround sound version of a song where none was previously available
to improve the fidelity of an older song for which the original master has been lost or degraded
to alter a song to suit a specific music genre or radio format
to use some of the same materials
column2: allowing the song to reach a different audience

column1: to alter a song for artistic purposes.
to provide additional versions of a song for use as bonus tracks or for a B-side
column2: for example
column3: in times when a CD single might carry a total of 4 tracks

column1: to create a connection between a smaller artist and a more successful one
column2: as was the case with Fatboy Slim's remix of ""Brimful of Asha"" by Cornershop

column1: to improve the first or demo mix of the song
column2: generally to ensure a professional product.

column1: to provide an alternative version of a song
to improve a song from its original state
Remixes should not be confused with edits
column2: which usually involve shortening a final stereo master for marketing or broadcasting purposes. Another distinction should be made between a remix
column3: which recombines audio pieces from a recording to create an altered version of a song
column4: and a cover: a re-recording of someone else's song like Mike D's remix of Moby's ""Natural Blues"".

column1: While audio mixing is one of the most popular and recognized forms of remixing
column2: this is not the only media form which is remixed in numerous examples. Literature
column3: film
column4: technology
column5: and social systems can all be argued as a form of remix"~0.4288896859773568

column1: 565~5~Remix album~78796~78801~"A remix album is an album consisting mostly of remixes or re-recorded versions of a music artists' earlier released material.

column2: resonance is a phenomenon in which a vibrating system or external force drives another system to oscillate with greater amplitude at specific frequencies.

column1: 568~5~Rhythm section~12878~12892~"A rhythm section (also called a backup band) is a group of musicians within a music ensemble or band who provide the underlying rhythm
column2: harmony and pulse of the accompaniment
column3: providing a rhythmic and harmonic reference and ""beat"" for the rest of the band. Many of the rhythm section instruments
column4: such as keyboard instruments and guitars
column5: are used to play the chord progression upon which the song is based. The bass instrument (either double bass or electric bass
column6: or another low-register instrument
column7: such as synth bass
column8: depending on the group and its style of music) plays the low-pitched bassline that supports the chord progression
column9: typically by emphasizing the roots of the chords (and to a lesser degree the fifths and thirds of the chords).

column1: The term is common in modern small musical ensembles
column2: such as bands that play jazz
column3: country
column4: blues
column5: and rock. In modern rock music
column6: a rhythm guitarist specializes in rhythmic and chordal playing (as opposed to the melodic guitar solos and lead melody lines played by the lead guitar)
column7: often repeating quaver (eighth-note)
column8: half note or whole note chords. In the louder genres
column9: such as hard rock
column10: heavy metal and punk rock
column11: rhythm guitarists often play power chords with distortion. Rhythm guitarists often strum open chords in pop
column12: rock
column13: country and folk music and play barre chords in many pop and rock styles.

column1: A typical rhythm section comprises one or more guitars (either electric guitars
column2: in rock music bands; acoustic guitars
column3: in country music
column4: folk music and blues or both electric and acoustic in some bands); and/or a keyboard instrument (piano
column5: electric piano
column6: Hammond organ
column7: synthesizer
column8: etc.) a double bass or electric bass (depending on the style of music)
column9: and drums (usually acoustic
column10: but in some post-1980s styles
column11: the drums may be electronic drums). In some styles of music
column12: there may be additional percussionists playing instruments such as the djembe or shakers. Some styles of music often have two electric guitarists
column13: such as rock genres like heavy metal music and punk rock. Some styles of music use multiple keyboard instrument performers simultaneously (e.g.
column14: piano and Hammond organ or electric piano and synthesizer) for a fuller sound. A rhythm section could be as small as two or three instruments (e.g.
column15: a guitarist and a bassist or a power trio of bass
column16: drums and guitar) or it may be a fairly large ensemble with several keyboardists
column17: several guitarists
column19: ukulele
column21: a drummer and percussionists. The largest rhythm sections may be led by a bandleader or a conductor who indicates the tempo of each song
column23: leads slow-downs of the music at cadences (sections of songs where the music comes to rest on a chord)

column2: an ostinato [ostiˈnaːto] (derived from Italian: stubborn
column3: compare English
column4: from Latin: 'obstinate') is a motif or phrase that persistently repeats in the same musical voice
column5: frequently at the same pitch. Well-known ostinato-based pieces include both classical compositions such as Ravel's Boléro and popular songs such as Donna Summer and Giorgio Moroder's ""I Feel Love"" (1977)
column6: Henry Mancini's theme from Peter Gunn (1959)
column7: and The Verve's ""Bitter Sweet Symphony"" (1997).

column1: The repeating idea may be a rhythmic pattern
column2: part of a tune
column3: or a complete melody in itself. Both ostinatos and ostinati are accepted English plural forms
column4: the latter reflecting the word's Italian etymology. Strictly speaking
column5: ostinati should have exact repetition

column7: the term covers repetition with variation and development

column1: If the cadence may be regarded as the cradle of tonality
column2: the ostinato patterns can be considered the playground in which it grew strong and self-confident.

column1: Within the context of film music
column2: Claudia Gorbman defines an obstinate as a repeated melodic or rhythmic figure that propels scenes that lack dynamic visual action.

column1: Ostinato plays an important part in improvised music (rock and jazz)

column3: ostinati are often used in modal and Latin jazz and traditional African music including Gnawa music.

column1: 570~5~Rigveda~38152~38159~"The Rigveda (Sanskrit: ऋग्वेद ṛgveda
column2: from ṛc ""praise

column5: 600 verses

column1: The hymns are dedicated to Rigvedic deities. For each deity series the hymns progress from longer to shorter ones; and the number of hymns per book increases. In the eight books that were composed the earliest

column3: which were added last

column1: 574~5~Roman Empire~41692~41704~"The Roman Empire (Latin: Imperium Rōmānum
column2: Classical Latin: [ɪmˈpɛ.ri.ũː roːˈmaː.nũː]; Koine and Medieval Greek: Βασιλεία τῶν Ῥωμαίων
column3: tr. Basileia tōn Rhōmaiōn) was the post-Roman Republic period of the ancient Roman civilization
column4: characterized by government headed by emperors and large territorial holdings around the Mediterranean Sea in Europe
column5: Africa and Asia. The city of Rome was the largest city in the world c. 100 BC –  c. AD 400
column6: with Constantinople (New Rome) becoming the largest around AD 500
column7: and the Empire's populace grew to an estimated 50 to 90 million inhabitants (roughly 20% of the world's population at the time). The 500-year-old republic which preceded it was severely destabilized in a series of civil wars and political conflict
column8: during which Julius Caesar was appointed as perpetual dictator and then assassinated in 44 BC. Civil wars and executions continued
column9: culminating in the victory of Octavian
column10: Caesar's adopted son
column11: over Mark Antony and Cleopatra at the Battle of Actium in 31 BC and the annexation of Egypt. Octavian's power was then unassailable and in 27 BC the Roman Senate formally granted him overarching power and the new title Augustus
column12: effectively marking the end of the Roman Republic.

column1: The imperial period of Rome lasted approximately 1
column2: 500 years compared to the 500 years of the Republican era. The first two centuries of the empire's existence were a period of unprecedented political stability and prosperity known as the Pax Romana
column3: or ""Roman Peace"". Following Octavian's victory

column5: with a bigger loudspeaker diaphragm causing changes to atmospheric pressure to form acoustic sound waves.

column1: Digital recording and reproduction converts the analog sound signal picked up by the microphone to a digital form by the process of sampling. This lets the audio data be stored and transmitted by a wider variety of media. Digital recording stores audio as a series of binary numbers (zeros and ones) representing samples of the amplitude of the audio signal at equal time intervals
column2: at a sample rate high enough to convey all sounds capable of being heard. A digital audio signal must be reconverted to analog form during playback before it is amplified and connected to a loudspeaker to produce sound.

column1: Prior to the development of sound recording
column2: there were mechanical systems
column3: such as wind-up music boxes and
column4: later
column5: player pianos
column6: for encoding and reproducing instrumental music."~0.3226420283484474

column1: 592~5~Spectrum~27519~27527~"A spectrum (plural spectra or spectrums) is a condition that is not limited to a specific set of values but can vary
column2: without steps
column3: across a continuum. The word was first used scientifically in optics to describe the rainbow of colors in visible light after passing through a prism. As scientific understanding of light advanced
column4: it came to apply to the entire electromagnetic spectrum.

column1: Spectrum has since been applied by analogy to topics outside optics. Thus
column2: one might talk about the ""spectrum of political opinion""
column3: or the ""spectrum of activity"" of a drug
column4: or the ""autism spectrum"". In these uses
column5: values within a spectrum may not be associated with precisely quantifiable numbers or definitions. Such uses imply a broad range of conditions or behaviors grouped together and studied under a single title for ease of discussion. Nonscientific uses of the term spectrum are sometimes misleading. For instance
column6: a single left–right spectrum of political opinion does not capture the full range of people's political beliefs. Political scientists use a variety of biaxial and multiaxial systems to more accurately characterize political opinion.

column1: In most modern usages of spectrum there is a unifying theme between the extremes at either end. This was not always true in older usage."~0.2120081738326675
593~5~Speech~65601~65607~"Speech is the vocalized form of communication used by humans and some animals
column2: which is based upon the syntactic combination of items drawn from the lexicon. Each spoken word is created out of the phonetic combination of a limited set of vowel and consonant speech sound units (phonemes). These vocabularies
column3: the syntax that structures them
column4: and their sets of speech sound units differ
column5: creating many thousands of different
column6: and mutually unintelligible
column7: human languages. The vocal abilities that enable humans to produce speech also enable them to sing.

column1: A gestural form of human communication exists for the deaf in the form of sign language. Speech in some cultures has become the basis of written language
column2: often one that differs in its vocabulary
column3: syntax and phonetics from its associated spoken one
column4: a situation called diglossia. In addition to its use in communication
column5: it is suggested by some psychologists such as Lev Vygotsky that speech is internally used in mental processes to enhance and organize cognition in the form of an interior monologue.

column1: Speech is researched in terms of the speech production and speech perception of the sounds used in vocal language. Other research topics concern speech repetition
column2: the ability to map heard spoken words into the vocalizations needed to recreate them
column3: which plays a key role in vocabulary expansion in children and speech errors. Several academic disciplines study these; including acoustics
column4: psychology
column5: speech pathology
column6: linguistics
column7: cognitive science
column8: communication studies
column9: otolaryngology and computer science. Another area of research is how the human brain in its different areas such as the Broca's area and Wernicke's area underlies speech.

column1: It is controversial how far human speech is unique; in that animals also communicate with vocalizations. While none in the wild have comparably large vocabularies
column2: research upon the nonverbal abilities of language trained apes such as Washoe and Kanzi raises the possibility that they might have these capabilities. The evolutionary origins of speech are unknown and subject to much debate and speculation."~0.15664534227655302

column1: 594~5~Streaming video~77267~77282~"Streaming media is multimedia that is constantly received by and presented to an end-user while being delivered by a provider. The verb ""to stream"" refers to the process of delivering or obtaining media in this manner; the term refers to the delivery method of the medium
column2: rather than the medium itself
column3: and is an alternative to file downloading
column4: a process in which the end-user obtains the entire file for the content before watching or listening to it.

column1: A client end-user can use their media player to start playing the data file (such as a digital file of a movie or song) before the entire file has been transmitted. Distinguishing delivery method from the media distributed applies specifically to telecommunications networks
column2: as most of the delivery systems are either inherently streaming (e.g. radio
column3: television
column4: streaming apps) or inherently non-streaming (e.g. books
column5: video cassettes
column6: audio CDs). For example
column7: in the 1930s
column8: elevator music was among the earliest popularly available streaming media; nowadays Internet television is a common form of streamed media. The term ""streaming media"" can apply to media other than video and audio such as live closed captioning
column9: ticker tape
column10: and real-time text
column11: which are all considered ""streaming text"".

column1: The term ""streaming"" was first used for tape drives made by Data Electronics Inc. for drives meant to slowly ramp up and run for the entire track; the slow ramp times resulted in lower drive costs
column2: making a more competitive product. ""Streaming"" was applied in the early 1990s as a better description for video on demand on IP networks; at the time such video was usually referred to as ""store and forward video""
column3: which was misleading nomenclature.

column1: Live streaming is the delivery of Internet content in real-time
column2: as events happen
column3: much as live television broadcasts its contents over the airwaves via a television signal. Live internet streaming requires a form of source media (e.g. a video camera
column4: an audio interface
column5: screen capture software)
column6: an encoder to digitize the content
column7: a media publisher
column8: and a content delivery network to distribute and deliver the content. Live streaming does not need to be recorded at the origination point
column9: although it frequently is.

column1: As of 2017
column2: ""streaming"" generally refers to the situation where a user watches digital video content or listens to digital audio content on a computer screen and speakers (ranging from a smartphone
column3: through a desktop computer to a large-screen home entertainment system) over the Internet. With streaming content
column4: the user does not have to download the entire digital video or digital audio file before they start to play it.

column1: There are challenges with streaming content on the Internet. If the user does not have enough bandwidth in their Internet connection
column2: they may experience stops in the content and some users may not be able to stream certain content due to not having compatible computer or software systems.

column1: Some popular streaming services are the video sharing website YouTube; Twitch and Mixer
column2: which live stream the playing of video games; Netflix
column3: which streams movies and TV shows; and Spotify and Apple Music
column4: which stream music."~0.14621568588011497

column1: 595~5~String quartet~46861~46876~"A string quartet is a musical ensemble of four string players – two violin players
column2: a viola player and a cellist – or a piece written to be performed by such a group. The string quartet is one of the most prominent chamber ensembles in classical music
column3: with most major composers
column4: from the mid 18th century onwards
column5: writing string quartets.

column1: The string quartet was developed into its current form by the Austrian composer Joseph Haydn
column2: with his works in the 1750s establishing the genre. Ever since Haydn's day the string quartet has been considered a prestigious form and represents one of the true tests of the composer's art. With four parts to play with
column3: a composer working in anything like the classical key system has enough lines to fashion a full argument
column4: but none to spare for padding. The closely related characters of the four instruments
column5: moreover
column6: while they cover in combination an ample compass of pitch
column7: do not lend themselves to indulgence in purely colouristic effects. Thus
column8: where the composer of symphonies commands the means for textural enrichment beyond the call of his harmonic discourse
column9: and where the concerto medium offers the further resource of personal characterization and drama in the individual-pitted-against-the-mass vein
column10: the writer of string quartets must perforce concentrate on the bare bones of musical logic. Thus
column11: in many ways the string quartet is pre-eminently the dialectical form of instrumental music
column12: the one most naturally suited to the activity of logical disputation and philosophical enquiry.

column1: Quartet composition flourished in the Classical era
column2: with Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
column3: Ludwig van Beethoven and Franz Schubert following Haydn in each writing a number of quartets. A slight slackening in the pace of quartet composition occurred in the later 19th century
column4: in part due to a movement away from classical forms by composers such as Franz Liszt
column5: Richard Wagner and Richard Strauss. Then it received a resurgence in the 20th Century with the Second Viennese School
column6: Béla Bartók
column7: Dmitri Shostakovich and Elliott Carter producing highly regarded examples of the genre. In the 21st century it remains an important and refined musical form.

column1: The standard structure for a string quartet is four movements
column2: with the first movement in Sonata form
column3: Allegro
column4: in the tonic key; second movement is a slow movement
column5: in a related key; third movement is a Minuet and Trio
column6: in the tonic key; and the fourth movement is often in Rondo form or Sonata rondo form
column7: in the tonic key.

column1: Some quartets play together for many years in ensembles which may be named after the first violinist (e.g. the Takács Quartet)
column2: a composer (e.g. the Borodin Quartet) or a location (e.g. the Budapest Quartet). Well-known string quartets can be found in the list of string quartet ensembles."~0.357742781261157

column1: 596~5~Supplication~39933~39946~"Supplication (also known as petitioning) is a form of prayer
column2: wherein one party humbly or earnestly asks another party to provide something
column3: either for the party who is doing the supplicating (e.g.
column4: ""Please spare my life."") or on behalf of someone else

column1: Supplication is a theme of earliest antiquity
column2: embodied in the Iliad as the prayers of Chryses for the return of his daughter
column3: and of Priam for the dead body of his son
column4: Hector. Richard Martin notes repeated references to suppliants throughout the poem
column5: including warriors begging to be spared by the Greeks on the battlefield.

column1: In Christianity
column2: the prayer of supplication for health by and on behalf of the sick is referenced in early Christian writings in the New Testament
column3: especially James 5:13-16.

column1: One example of supplication is the Catholic ritual of novena (from novem
column2: the Latin word for ""nine"") wherein one repeatedly asks for the same favor over a period of nine days. This ritual began in Spain during the Middle Ages when a nine-day period of hymns and prayers led up to a Christmas feast
column3: a period which ended with gift giving. A contemporary Christian example of supplication is the practice of the Daily Prayer for Peace by the Community of Christ where a member prays for peace each day at a specified time. Philippians 4:6 says
column4: ""Be anxious for nothing
column5: but in everything by prayer and supplication
column6: with thanksgiving
column7: let your requests be made known to God.""

column1: In Islam
column2: the Arabic word duʻā (plural du'aat or ʾadʿiyah) is used to refer to supplications. Adʻiya may be made in any language
column3: although there are many traditional Islamic supplications in Arabic
column4: Persian and Turkish. In Islam
column5: duʻā tends to mean personal prayer. The supplications (Duaas) of Prophets are given in the Quran.

column1: The word Ardâs ( ਅਰਦਾਸ ) is derived from the Persian word 'Arazdashat'
column2: meaning a request
column3: a supplication
column4: a prayer
column5: a petition or an address to a superior authority. It is a Sikh prayer that is done before performing or after undertaking any significant task; after reciting the daily Banis (prayers); or completion of a service like the Paath
column6: kirtan (hymn-singing) program or any other religious program. In Sikhism
column7: these prayers are also said before and after eating. The prayer is a plea to God to support and help the devotee with whatever he or she is about to undertake or has done."~0.32490121469786004

column1: 597~5~Symphonic poem~31193~31207~"A symphonic poem or tone poem is a piece of orchestral music
column2: usually in a single continuous movement
column3: which illustrates or evokes the content of a poem
column4: short story
column5: novel
column6: painting
column7: landscape
column8: or other (non-musical) source. The German term Tondichtung (tone poem) appears to have been first used by the composer Carl Loewe in 1828. The Hungarian composer Franz Liszt first applied the term Symphonische Dichtung to his 13 works in this vein.

column1: While many symphonic poems may compare in size and scale to symphonic movements (or even reach the length of an entire symphony)
column2: they are unlike traditional classical symphonic movements
column3: in that their music is intended to inspire listeners to imagine or consider scenes
column4: images
column5: specific ideas or moods
column6: and not (necessarily) to focus on following traditional patterns of musical form such as sonata form. This intention to inspire listeners was a direct consequence of Romanticism
column7: which encouraged literary
column8: pictorial and dramatic associations in music. According to Hugh Macdonald
column9: the symphonic poem met three 19th-century aesthetic goals: it related music to outside sources; it often combined or compressed multiple movements into a single principal section; and it elevated instrumental program music to an aesthetic level that could be regarded as equivalent to
column10: or higher than opera. The symphonic poem remained a popular composition form from the 1840s until the 1920s
column11: when composers began to abandon the genre.

column1: Some piano and chamber works
column2: such as Arnold Schoenberg's string sextet Verklärte Nacht
column3: have similarities with symphonic poems in their overall intent and effect. However
column4: the term symphonic poem is generally accepted to refer to orchestral works. A symphonic poem may stand on its own (as do those of Richard Strauss)
column5: or it can be part of a series combined into a symphonic suite or cycle. For example
column6: The Swan of Tuonela (1895) is a tone poem from Jean Sibelius's Lemminkäinen Suite
column7: and Vltava (The Moldau) by Bedřich Smetana is part of the six-work cycle Má vlast.

column1: While the terms ""symphonic poem"" and ""tone poem"" have often been used interchangeably
column2: some composers such as Richard Strauss and Jean Sibelius have preferred the latter term for their works."~0.2948176644824794

column1: 598~5~Symphony~980~990~A symphony is an extended musical composition in Western classical music
column2: most often written by composers for orchestra. Although the term has had many meanings from its origins in the ancient Greek era
column3: by the late 18th century the word had taken on the meaning common today: a work usually consisting of multiple distinct sections or movements
column4: often four
column5: with the first movement in sonata form. Symphonies are scored for string (violin
column6: viola
column7: cello
column8: and double bass)
column9: brass
column10: woodwind
column11: and percussion instruments which altogether number about 30–100 musicians. Symphonies are notated in a musical score
column12: which contains all the instrument parts. Orchestral musicians play from parts which contain just the notated music for their instrument. A small number of symphonies also contain vocal parts (e.g.
column13: Beethoven's Ninth Symphony).~0.3335364451769831

column1: 599~5~Syncopation~54381~54392~"In music
column2: syncopation involves a variety of rhythms which are in some way unexpected which make part or all of a tune or piece of music off-beat. More simply
column3: syncopation is a general term for ""a disturbance or interruption of the regular flow of rhythm"": a ""placement of rhythmic stresses or accents where they wouldn't normally occur."" The correlation of at least two sets of time intervals. Also known as an ""Uneven movement from bar to bar"".

column1: Syncopation is used in many musical styles
column2: especially dance music--""All dance music makes use of syncopation and it's often a vital element that helps tie the whole track together"". In the form of a back beat
column3: syncopation is used in virtually all contemporary popular music.

column1: Syncopation can also occur when a strong harmony is placed on a weak beat
column2: for instance when a 7th-chord is placed on the second beat of 34 bar or a dominant is placed at the fourth beat of a 44 bar. The latter frequently occurs in tonal cadences in 18th and early 19th century music and is the usual conclusion of any section.

column1: A hemiola can also be seen as one straight bar in 3 with one long chord and one short chord and a syncope in the bar thereafter
column2: with one short chord and one long chord. Usually
column3: the last chord in a hemiola is a (bi-)dominant
column4: and as such a strong harmony on a weak beat

column1: 600~5~Tape recorder~5578~5592~"An audio tape recorder
column2: tape deck or tape machine is an analog audio storage device that records and plays back sounds
column3: including articulated voices
column4: usually using magnetic tape
column5: either wound on a reel or in a cassette
column6: for storage. In its present-day form
column7: it records a fluctuating signal by moving the tape across a tape head that polarizes the magnetic domains in the tape in proportion to the audio signal. Tape-recording devices include reel-to-reel tape deck and the cassette deck.

column1: The use of magnetic tape for sound recording originated around 1930. Magnetizable tape revolutionized both the radio broadcast and music recording industries. It gave artists and producers the power to record and re-record audio with minimal loss in quality as well as edit and rearrange recordings with ease. The alternative recording technologies of the era
column2: transcription discs and wire recorders
column3: could not provide anywhere near this level of quality and functionality. Since some early refinements improved the fidelity of the reproduced sound
column4: magnetic tape has been the highest quality analog sound recording medium available. As of the first decade of the 21st century
column5: analog magnetic tape has been largely replaced by digital recording technologies for consumer purposes
column6: although some still record audio by analog.

column1: Prior to the development of magnetic tape
column2: magnetic wire recorders had successfully demonstrated the concept of magnetic recording
column3: but they never offered audio quality comparable to the other recording and broadcast standards of the time. Some individuals and organizations developed innovative uses for magnetic wire recorders while others investigated variations of the technology. One particularly important variation was the application of an oxide powder to a long strip of paper. This German invention was the start of a long string of innovations that have led to present day magnetic tape recordings."~0.21766228386495762

column1: 601~5~Techno~51680~51686~"Techno is a form of electronic dance music that emerged in Detroit
column2: Michigan
column3: in the United States during the mid-to-late 1980s. The first recorded use of the word techno in reference to a specific genre of music was in 1988. Many styles of techno now exist
column4: but Detroit techno is seen as the foundation upon which a number of subgenres have been built.

column1: In Detroit
column2: techno resulted from the melding of African American music including Chicago house
column3: funk
column4: electro
column5: and electric jazz with electronic music by artists such as Kraftwerk
column6: Giorgio Moroder
column7: and Yellow Magic Orchestra. Added to this is the influence of futuristic and fictional themes relevant to life in American late capitalist society
column8: with Alvin Toffler's book The Third Wave being a notable point of reference. Pioneering producer Juan Atkins cites Toffler's phrase ""techno rebels"" as inspiring him to use the word techno to describe the musical style he helped to create. This unique blend of influences aligns techno with the aesthetic referred to as afrofuturism. To producers such as Derrick May
column9: the transference of spirit from the body to the machine is often a central preoccupation; essentially an expression of technological spirituality. In this manner: ""techno dance music defeats what Adorno saw as the alienating effect of mechanisation on the modern consciousness"".

column1: Stylistically
column2: techno is generally repetitive instrumental music
column3: often produced for use in a continuous DJ set. The central rhythmic component is most often in common time (4/4)
column4: where time is marked with a bass drum on each quarter note pulse
column5: a backbeat played by snare or clap on the second and fourth pulses of the bar
column6: and an open hi-hat sounding every second eighth note. The tempo tends to vary between approximately 120 to 150 beats per minute (bpm)
column7: depending on the style of techno. The creative use of music production technology
column8: such as drum machines
column9: synthesizers
column10: and digital audio workstations
column11: is viewed as an important aspect of the music's aesthetic. Many producers use retro electronic musical devices to create what they consider to be an authentic techno sound. Drum machines from the 1980s such as Roland's TR-808 and TR-909 are highly prized
column12: and software emulations of such retro technology are popular among techno producers.

column1: Music journalists and fans of techno are generally selective in their use of the term; so a clear distinction can be made between sometimes related but often qualitatively different styles
column2: such as tech house and trance."~0.2530859224936396

column1: 602~5~Tempo~28500~28511~"In musical terminology
column2: tempo [ˈtɛmpo] (""time"" in Italian; plural: tempi [ˈtɛmpi]) is the speed or pace of a given piece.

column1: In classical music
column2: tempo is usually indicated with an instruction at the start of a piece (often using conventional Italian terms). Tempo is usually measured in beats per minute (BPM). In modern classical compositions a ""metronome mark"" in beats per minute may supplement or replace the normal tempo marking
column3: while in modern genres like electronic dance music
column4: tempo will typically simply be stated in BPM.

column1: Tempo may be separated from articulation and metre
column2: or these aspects may be indicated along with tempo
column3: all contributing to the overall texture. While the ability to hold a steady tempo is a vital skill for a musical performer
column4: tempo is changeable. Depending on the genre of a piece of music and the performers' interpretation
column5: a piece may be played with slight tempo rubato or drastic accelerando. In ensembles
column6: the tempo is often indicated by a conductor or by one of the instrumentalists
column7: for instance the drummer."~0.1946483979556319

column1: 603~5~Theatre~8153~8160~"Theatre or theater is a collaborative form of fine art that uses live performers
column2: typically actors or actresses
column3: to present the experience of a real or imagined event before a live audience in a specific place
column4: often a stage. The performers may communicate this experience to the audience through combinations of gesture
column5: speech
column6: song
column7: music
column8: and dance. Elements of art
column9: such as painted scenery and stagecraft such as lighting are used to enhance the physicality
column10: presence and immediacy of the experience. The specific place of the performance is also named by the word ""theatre"" as derived from the Ancient Greek θέατρον (théatron
column11: ""a place for viewing"")
column12: itself from θεάομαι (theáomai
column13: ""to see""
column14: ""to watch""
column15: ""to observe"").

column1: Modern Western theatre comes
column2: in large measure
column3: from ancient Greek drama
column4: from which it borrows technical terminology
column5: classification into genres
column6: and many of its themes
column7: stock characters
column8: and plot elements. Theatre artist Patrice Pavis defines theatricality
column9: theatrical language
column10: stage writing and the specificity of theatre as synonymous expressions that differentiate theatre from the other performing arts
column11: literature and the arts in general.

column1: Modern theatre includes performances of plays and musical theatre. The art forms of ballet and opera are also theatre and use many conventions such as acting
column2: costumes and staging. They were influential to the development of musical theatre; see those articles for more information."~0.2804298346355365

column1: 604~5~Thoth~37066~37071~"Thoth (; from Greek Θώθ thṓth; derived from Egyptian ḏḥw.ty) was one of the deities of the Egyptian pantheon. In art
column2: he was often depicted as a man with the head of an ibis or a baboon
column3: animals sacred to him. His feminine counterpart was Seshat
column4: and his wife was Ma'at.

column1: Thoth's chief temple was located in the city of Khmun

column3: he led the Ogdoad pantheon of eight principal deities. He also had numerous shrines within the cities of Abydos
column4: Hesert
column5: Urit
column6: Per-Ab
column7: Rekhui
column8: Ta-ur
column9: Sep
column10: Hat
column11: Pselket
column12: Talmsis
column13: Antcha-Mutet
column14: Bah
column15: Amen-heri-ab

column1: Thoth played many vital and prominent roles in Egyptian mythology
column2: such as maintaining the universe
column3: and being one of the two deities (the other being Ma'at) who stood on either side of Ra's boat. In the later history of ancient Egypt
column4: Thoth became heavily associated with the arbitration of godly disputes
column5: the arts of magic
column6: the system of writing
column7: the development of science
column8: and the judgment of the dead."~0.16264260267498237

column1: 605~5~Timbre~289~295~"In music
column2: timbre ( TAM-bər
column3: also known as tone color or tone quality from psychoacoustics) is the perceived sound quality of a musical note
column4: sound or tone. Timbre distinguishes different types of sound production
column5: such as choir voices and musical instruments
column6: such as string instruments
column7: wind instruments
column8: and percussion instruments. It also enables listeners to distinguish different instruments in the same category (e.g. an oboe and a clarinet).

column1: The physical characteristics of sound that determine the perception of timbre include spectrum and envelope. Singers and instrumental musicians can change the timbre of the music they are singing/playing by using different singing or playing techniques. For example
column2: a violinist can use different bowing styles or play on different parts of the string to obtain different timbres (e.g.
column3: playing sul tasto produces a light
column4: airy timbre
column5: whereas playing sul ponticello produces a harsh
column6: even and aggressive tone). On electric guitar and electric piano
column7: performers can change the timbre using effects units and graphic equalizers.

column1: In simple terms
column2: timbre is what makes a particular musical sound have a different sound from another
column3: even when they have the same pitch and loudness. For instance
column4: it is the difference in sound between a guitar and a piano playing the same note at the same volume. Both instruments can sound equally tuned in relation to each other as they play the same note
column5: and while playing at the same amplitude level each instrument will still sound distinctively with its own unique tone color. Experienced musicians are able to distinguish between different instruments of the same type based on their varied timbres
column6: even if those instruments are playing notes at the same pitch and loudness."~0.3497281011247419

column1: 606~5~Tin Pan Alley~29708~29721~"Tin Pan Alley is the name given to the collection of New York City music publishers and songwriters who dominated the popular music of the United States in the late 19th century and early 20th century. The name originally referred to a specific place: West 28th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues in the Flower District of Manhattan
column2: and a plaque exists (see below) on the sidewalk on 28th Street between Broadway and Sixth commemorates it.

column1: The start of Tin Pan Alley is usually dated to about 1885
column2: when a number of music publishers set up shop in the same district of Manhattan. The end of Tin Pan Alley is less clear cut. Some date it to the start of the Great Depression in the 1930s when the phonograph
column3: radio
column4: and motion pictures supplanted sheet music as the driving force of American popular music
column5: while others consider Tin Pan Alley to have continued into the 1950s when earlier styles of American popular music were upstaged by the rise of rock & roll
column6: which was centered on the Brill Building.

column1: The origins of the name ""Tin Pan Alley"" are unclear. One account claims that it was a derogatory reference to the sound of many pianos (comparing them to the banging of tin pans). Others claim it arose from songwriters modifying their pianos to produce a more percussive sound. After many years
column2: the term came to refer to the U.S. music industry in general."~0.4446708304296362

column1: 608~5~Transcranial magnetic stimulation~64391~64424~"Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a method in which a changing magnetic field is used to cause electric current to flow in a small region of the brain via electromagnetic induction. During a TMS procedure

A 2015 Cochrane review found that there was not enough evidence to determine its effectiveness in treating schizophrenia. For negative symptoms another review found possible efficacy. As of 2014
column2: all other investigated uses of repetitive TMS have only possible or no clinical efficacy.

column1: 632~6~Amphetamine~75638~75650~"Amphetamine (contracted from alpha-methylphenethylamine) is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that is used in the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)

column1: 638~6~Bach~29463~29467~"Johann Sebastian Bach (31 March [O.S. 21 March] 1685 – 28 July 1750) was a German composer and musician of the Baroque period. He is known for instrumental compositions such as the Brandenburg Concertos and the Goldberg Variations

666~6~Cabaret~39625~39632~Cabaret (English: ) is a form of theatrical entertainment featuring music, song, dance, recitation, or drama. It is mainly distinguished by the performance venue, which might be a pub, a restaurant or a nightclub with a stage for performances. The audience, often dining or drinking, does not typically dance but usually sits at tables. Performances are usually introduced by a master of ceremonies or MC. The entertainment, as done by an ensemble of actors and according to its European origins, is often (but not always) oriented towards adult audiences and of a clearly underground nature. In the United States striptease, burlesque, drag shows, or a solo vocalist with a pianist, as well as the venues which offer this entertainment, are often advertised as cabarets.~0.3149278265821147

column1: 675~6~Classical music~547~556~"Classical music is art music produced or rooted in the traditions of Western culture
column2: including both liturgical (religious) and secular music. While a more precise term is also used to refer to the period from 1750 to 1820 (the Classical period)
column3: this article is about the broad span of time from before the 6th century AD to the present day

column5: which is known as the common-practice period. The major time divisions of Western art music are as follows:

column1: the ancient music period
column2: before 500 AD

column1: the early music period
column2: which includes

column1: the Medieval (500–1400) including
the ars antiqua (1170–1310)
the ars nova (1310–1377)
the ars subtilior (1360–1420)
the Renaissance (1400–1600) eras.
the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
the common-practice period
column2: which includes

column1: the galant music period (1720s–1770s)
Classical (1750–1820)
Romantic eras (c.1780–1910)
the 20th century (1901–2000) which includes
the modern (1890–1930) that overlaps from the late-19th century
the high modern (1930–present)
impressionism (1875–1925) that also overlaps from the late-19th century
neoclassicism (1920–1950)
column2: predominantly in the inter-war period

column1: the postmodern (1930–present) eras
the experimental (1950–present)
contemporary (1945 or 1975–present)
European art music is largely distinguished from many other non-European classical and some popular musical forms by its system of staff notation
column2: in use since about the 11th century. Western staff notation is used by composers to indicate to the performer the pitches (which form the melodies
column3: basslines and chords)
column4: tempo
column5: metre and rhythms for a piece of music. This can leave less room for practices such as improvisation and ad libitum ornamentation
column6: which are frequently heard in non-European art music and in popular-music styles such as jazz and blues. Another difference is that whereas most popular styles adopt the song (strophic) form or a derivation of this form
column7: classical music has been noted for its development of highly sophisticated forms of instrumental music such as the symphony
column8: concerto
column9: fugue
column10: sonata
column11: and mixed vocal and instrumental styles such as opera
column12: cantata
column13: and mass.

column1: The term ""classical music"" did not appear until the early 19th century
column2: in an attempt to distinctly canonize the period from Johann Sebastian Bach to Ludwig van Beethoven as a golden age. The earliest reference to ""classical music"" recorded by the Oxford English Dictionary is from about 1829."~0.4445589816771897

column1: 680~6~Conformity~2748~2758~"Conformity is the act of matching attitudes
column2: beliefs
column3: and behaviors to group norms. Norms are implicit
column4: specific rules
column5: shared by a group of individuals
column6: that guide their interactions with others. This tendency to conform occurs in small groups and/or society as a whole
column7: and may result from subtle unconscious influences
column8: or direct and overt social pressure. Conformity can occur in the presence of others
column9: or when an individual is alone. For example
column10: people tend to follow social norms when eating or watching television
column11: even when alone.

column1: People often conform from a desire for security within a group—typically a group of a similar age
column2: culture
column3: religion
column4: or educational status. This is often referred to as groupthink: a pattern of thought characterized by self-deception
column5: forced manufacture of consent
column6: and conformity to group values and ethics
column7: which ignores realistic appraisal of other courses of action. Unwillingness to conform carries the risk of social rejection. Conformity is often associated with adolescence and youth culture
column8: but strongly affects humans of all ages.

column1: Although peer pressure may manifest negatively
column2: conformity can be regarded as either good or bad. Driving on the correct side of the road could be seen as beneficial conformity. With the right environmental influence
column3: conforming
column4: in early childhood years
column5: allows one to learn and thus
column6: adopt the appropriate behaviours necessary to interact and develop correctly within one's society. Conformity influences formation and maintenance of social norms
column7: and helps societies function smoothly and predictably via the self-elimination of behaviors seen as contrary to unwritten rules. In this sense it can be perceived as a positive force that prevents acts that are perceptually disruptive or dangerous.

column1: As conformity is a group phenomenon
column2: factors such as group size
column3: unanimity
column4: cohesion
column5: status
column6: prior commitment and public opinion help determine the level of conformity an individual displays."~0.2490094059188328

column1: 681~6~Conscription~20454~20459~"Conscription
column2: sometimes called the draft
column3: is the compulsory enlistment of people in a national service
column4: most often a military service. Conscription dates back to antiquity and continues in some countries to the present day under various names. The modern system of near-universal national conscription for young men dates to the French Revolution in the 1790s
column5: where it became the basis of a very large and powerful military. Most European nations later copied the system in peacetime
column6: so that men at a certain age would serve 1–8 years on active duty and then transfer to the reserve force.

column1: Conscription is controversial for a range of reasons
column2: including conscientious objection to military engagements on religious or philosophical grounds; political objection
column3: for example to service for a disliked government or unpopular war; and ideological objection
column4: for example
column5: to a perceived violation of individual rights. Those conscripted may evade service
column6: sometimes by leaving the country
column7: and seeking asylum in another country. Some selection systems accommodate these attitudes by providing alternative service outside combat-operations roles or even outside the military
column8: such as 'Siviilipalvelus' (alternative civil service) in Finland
column9: Zivildienst (compulsory community service) in Austria and Switzerland. Most post-Soviet countries conscript soldiers not only for armed forces but also for paramilitary organizations which are dedicated to police-like domestic only service (Internal Troops) or non-combat rescue duties (Civil defence troops) – none of which is considered alternative to the military conscription.

column1: As of the early 21st century
column2: many states no longer conscript soldiers
column3: relying instead upon professional militaries with volunteers enlisted to meet the demand for troops. The ability to rely on such an arrangement
column4: however
column5: presupposes some degree of predictability with regard to both war-fighting requirements and the scope of hostilities. Many states that have abolished conscription therefore still reserve the power to resume it during wartime or times of crisis. States involved in wars or interstate rivalries are most likely to implement conscription
column6: whereas democracies are less likely than autocracies to implement conscription. Former British colonies are less likely to have conscription
column7: as they are influenced by British anticonscription norms that can be traced back to the English Civil War."~0.14430789438013547

column1: 682~6~Consumerism~2732~2743~"Consumerism is a social and economic order and ideology that encourages the acquisition of goods and services in ever-increasing amounts. With the industrial revolution
column2: but particularly in the 20th century
column3: mass production led to an economic crisis: there was overproduction — the supply of goods would grow beyond consumer demand
column4: and so manufacturers turned to planned obsolescence and advertising to increase consumer spending. An early criticism of consumerism is Thorstein Veblen's best known book
column5: The Theory of the Leisure Class from 1899
column6: which critically examined newly widespread values and economic institutions emerging along with newly widespread ""leisure time
column7: at the turn of the 20th century. In it Veblen ""views the activities and spending habits of this leisure class in terms of conspicuous and vicarious consumption and waste. Both are related to the display of status and not to functionality or usefulness.""

column1: In economics
column2: ""consumerism"" may refer to economic policies which emphasise consumption. In an abstract sense
column3: it is the consideration that the free choice of consumers should strongly orient the choice by manufacturers of what is produced and how
column4: and therefore orient the economic organization of a society (compare producerism
column5: especially in the British sense of the term). In this sense
column6: consumerism expresses the idea not of ""one man
column7: one voice""
column8: but of ""one dollar
column9: one voice""
column10: which may or may not reflect the contribution of people to society."~0.09189080957157414

column1: 684~6~Counterculture~1278~1293~A counterculture (also written counter-culture) is a subculture whose values and norms of behavior differ substantially from those of mainstream society

column1: 685~6~Country music~7076~7095~"Country music ()

688~6~Cultural imperialism~76294~76314~Cultural imperialism comprises the cultural aspects of imperialism. Imperialism here refers to the creation and maintenance of unequal relationships between civilizations, favoring the more powerful civilization. Thus, cultural imperialism is the practice of promoting and imposing a culture, usually that of a politically powerful nation, over a less powerful society; in other words, the cultural hegemony of industrialized or economically influential countries which determine general cultural values and standardize civilizations throughout the world. The term is employed especially in the fields of history, cultural studies, and postcolonial theory. It is usually used in a pejorative sense, often in conjunction with calls to reject such influence. Cultural imperialism can take various forms, such as an attitude, a formal policy, or military action, insofar as it reinforces cultural hegemony.~0.14829175951562606

column1: 695~6~Detroit~67290~67297~"Detroit () is the most populous city in the U.S. state of Michigan

column1: 698~6~Disco~47798~47803~"Disco is a musical style originating in the early 1970s. It began to emerge from America's urban nightlife scene
column2: where it had been curtailed to house parties and makeshift discotheques from the middle of the decade onwards
column3: after which
column4: it began making regular mainstream appearances
column5: gaining popularity and increasing airplay on radio. Its popularity was achieved sometime during the mid-1970s to the early 1980s. Its initial audiences in the U.S. were club-goers
column6: both male and female
column7: from the African American
column8: Italian American
column9: Latino
column10: gay
column11: and psychedelic communities in Philadelphia and New York City during the late 1960s and early 1970s. Disco can be seen as a reaction against both the domination of rock music and the stigmatization of dance music by the counterculture during this period. Several dances styles were also developed during this time including the Bump and the Hustle.

column1: The disco sound often has several components

column3: an eighth note (quaver) or 16th note (semi-quaver) hi-hat pattern with an open hi-hat on the off-beat
column4: and a prominent
column5: syncopated electric bass line. In most disco tracks
column6: string sections
column7: horns
column8: electric piano
column9: and electric rhythm guitars create a lush background sound. Orchestral instruments such as the flute are often used for solo melodies
column10: and lead guitar is less frequently used in disco than in rock. Many disco songs use electronic synthesizers
column11: particularly in the late 1970s.

column1: Well-known disco performers include Donna Summer
column2: the Bee Gees
column3: Gloria Gaynor
column4: KC and the Sunshine Band
column5: the Village People
column6: Thelma Houston
column7: and Chic. While performers and singers garnered much public attention
column8: record producers working behind the scenes played an important role in developing the ""disco sound"". Many non-disco artists recorded disco songs at the height of disco's popularity
column9: and films such as Saturday Night Fever (1977) and Thank God It's Friday (1978) contributed to disco's rise in mainstream popularity.

column2: most major U.S. cities had thriving disco club scenes
column3: where DJs would mix a seamless sequence of dance records. Studio 54
column4: a venue popular among celebrities
column5: was a well-known disco club of that time. Discotheque-goers often wore expensive
column6: extravagant and sexy fashions. There was also a thriving drug subculture in the disco scene
column7: particularly for drugs that would enhance the experience of dancing to the loud music and the flashing lights
column8: such as cocaine and Quaaludes
column9: a drug that was so common in disco subculture that it was nicknamed ""disco biscuits"". Disco clubs were also sometimes associated with promiscuity.

column1: Disco was the last mass popular music movement that was driven by the baby boom generation. Disco was a worldwide phenomenon
column2: but its popularity drastically declined in the United States in 1980
column3: and by 1982 it had lost most of its mainstream popularity in the states. Disco Demolition Night
column4: an anti-disco protest held in Chicago on July 12
column6: remains the most well-known of several ""backlash"" incidents across the country that symbolized disco's declining fortune.

column1: Disco was a key influence in the later development of electronic dance music and house music. Disco has had several revivals
column2: including in 2005 with Madonna's highly successful album Confessions on a Dance Floor
column3: and again in 2013 and 2014
column4: as disco-styled songs by artists like Daft Punk (with Pharrell Williams and Nile Rodgers)
column5: Justin Timberlake

column7: and Bruno Mars—notably Mars' ""Uptown Funk""—filled the pop charts in the UK and the US."~0.39739548918454637

column1: 701~6~Doo Wop~8980~8987~"Doo-wop is a genre of rhythm and blues music that was developed in African-American communities in the East Coast of the United States in the late 1930s
column2: achieving mainstream popularity in the 1950s and early 1960s. Built upon vocal harmony
column3: doo-wop was one of the most mainstream

Singer Bill Kenny is often called the ""Godfather of Doo-wop"" for his introducing the ""top and bottom"" format which featured a high tenor singing the lead and a bass singer reciting the lyrics in the middle of the song. Doo-wop features vocal group harmony
column5: nonsense syllables
column6: a simple beat
column7: sometimes little or no instrumentation
column8: and simple music and lyrics.

column1: The first hit record to use the syllables ""doo-wop"" was probably ""When You Dance"" by The Turbans in 1955. The term ""doo-wop"" first appeared in print in 1961. During the late 1950s many Italian-American groups contributed a significant part in the doo-wop scene. The peak of doo-wop was in 1961. Doo-wop's influence continued in soul
column2: pop
column3: and rock groups of the 1960s. At various times in the 1970s
column5: and 1990s

column1: 705~6~Drug~2657~2661~"A drug is any substance (other than food that provides nutritional support) that
column2: when inhaled
column3: injected
column4: smoked
column5: consumed
column6: absorbed via a patch on the skin
column7: or dissolved under the tongue causes a temporary physiological (and often psychological) change in the body.

column1: In pharmacology
column2: a pharmaceutical drug
column3: also called a medication or medicine
column4: is a chemical substance used to treat
column5: cure
column6: prevent
column7: or diagnose a disease or to promote well-being. Traditionally drugs were obtained through extraction from medicinal plants
column8: but more recently also by organic synthesis. Pharmaceutical drugs may be used for a limited duration
column9: or on a regular basis for chronic disorders.

column1: Pharmaceutical drugs are often classified into drug classes—groups of related drugs that have similar chemical structures
column2: the same mechanism of action (binding to the same biological target)
column3: a related mode of action
column4: and that are used to treat the same disease. The Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical Classification System (ATC)
column5: the most widely used drug classification system
column6: assigns drugs a unique ATC code
column7: which is an alphanumeric code that assigns it to specific drug classes within the ATC system. Another major classification system is the Biopharmaceutics Classification System. This classifies drugs according to their solubility and permeability or absorption properties.

column1: Psychoactive drugs are chemical substances that affect the function of the central nervous system
column2: altering perception
column3: mood or consciousness. They include alcohol
column4: a depressant (and a stimulant in small quantities)
column5: and the stimulants nicotine and caffeine. These three are the most widely consumed psychoactive drugs worldwide and are also considered recreational drugs since they are used for pleasure rather than medicinal purposes. Other recreational drugs include hallucinogens
column6: opiates and amphetamines and some of these are also used in spiritual or religious settings. Some drugs can cause addiction  and all drugs can have side effects. Excessive use of stimulants can promote stimulant psychosis. Many recreational drugs are illicit and international treaties such as the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs exist for the purpose of their prohibition."~0.06946959393634669

column1: 706~6~Drum kit~3189~3197~"A drum kit — also called a drum set
column2: trap set
column3: or simply drums — is a collection of drums and other percussion instruments
column4: typically cymbals
column5: which are set up on stands to be played by a single player
column6: with drumsticks held in both hands
column7: and the feet operating pedals that control the hi-hat cymbal and the beater for the bass drum. A drum kit consists of a mix of drums (categorized classically as membranophones
column8: Hornbostel-Sachs high-level classification 2) and idiophones - most significantly cymbals
column9: but can also include the woodblock and cowbell (classified as Hornbostel-Sachs high-level classification 1). In the 2000s
column10: some kits also include electronic instruments (Hornbostel-Sachs classification 53). Also
column11: both hybrid (mixing acoustic instruments and electronic drums) and entirely electronic kits are used.

column1: A standard modern kit (for a right-handed player)
column2: as used in popular music and taught in music schools
column3: contains:

column1: A snare drum
column2: mounted on a stand
column3: placed between the player's knees and played with drum sticks (which may include rutes or brushes)

column1: A bass drum
column2: played by a pedal operated by the right foot
column3: which moves a felt-covered beater

column1: One or more toms
column2: played with sticks or brushes (usually three toms: rack tom 1 and 2
column3: and floor tom)

column1: A hi-hat (two cymbals mounted on a stand)
column2: played with the sticks
column3: opened and closed with left foot pedal (it can also produce sound with the foot alone)

column1: One or more cymbals
column2: mounted on stands
column3: played with the sticks

column1: All of these are classed as non-pitched percussion
column2: allowing for the music to be scored using percussion notation
column3: for which a loose semi-standardized form exists for the drum kit. If some or all of them are replaced by electronic drums
column4: the scoring and most often positioning remains the same
column5: allowing a standard teaching approach. The drum kit is usually played while seated on a drum stool or throne. The drum kit differs from instruments that can be used to produce pitched melodies or chords
column6: even though drums are often placed musically alongside others that do
column7: such as the guitar or piano. The drum kit is a part of the standard rhythm section used in many types of popular and traditional music styles
column8: ranging from rock and pop to blues and jazz. Other standard instruments used in the rhythm section include the piano
column9: electric guitar
column10: electric bass
column11: and keyboards.

column1: Many drummers extend their kits from this basic pattern
column2: adding more drums
column3: more cymbals
column4: and many other instruments including pitched percussion. In some styles of music particular extensions are normal
column5: for example double bass drums in heavy metal music and the enlarged kits used by some progressive drummers
column6: which may include unusual instruments such as gongs. Some performers
column7: such as some rockabilly drummers
column8: use small kits that omit elements from the basic setup. Some drum kit players may have other roles in the band
column9: such as providing backup vocals
column10: or less commonly

column2: pop

column4: R&B etc. include a drummer for purposes including timekeeping and embellishing the musical timbre. The drummer's equipment includes a drum kit (or ""drum set"" or ""trap set"") which includes various drums

column1: 711~6~Electric guitar~619~634~"An electric guitar is a guitar that uses one or more pickups to convert the vibration of its strings into electrical signals. The vibration occurs when a guitarist strums
column2: plucks
column3: fingerpicks
column4: or taps the strings. The pickup used to sense the vibration generally uses electromagnetic induction to do so
column5: though other technologies exist. In any case
column6: the signal generated by an electric guitar is too weak to drive a loudspeaker

column1: Since the output of an electric guitar is an electric signal

column3: the signal is modified using effects such as reverb and distortion and ""overdrive""
column4: the latter effect is considered a key element of electric blues guitar music and rock guitar playing.

column1: Invented in 1931

column4: tapping
column5: hammering on
column6: using audio feedback
column7: or slide guitar playing. There are several types of electric guitar
column8: including the solid-body guitar
column9: various types of hollow-body guitars
column10: the six-string guitar (the most common type
column11: usually tuned E
column12: A
column13: D
column14: G
column15: B
column17: from lowest to highest strings)
column19: which typically adds a low B string below the low E
column21: which has six pairs of strings.

column1: Popular music and rock groups often use the electric guitar in two roles: as a rhythm guitar
column2: which plays the chord sequence or progression and riffs and sets the beat (as part of a rhythm section)
column3: and as a lead guitar

column5: melodic instrumental fill passages

column1: 736~6~Gospel music~7057~7069~"Gospel music is a genre of Christian music. The creation

column4: with historical distance

column1: 752~6~Hip hop~6637~6644~"Hip hop or hip-hop is a subculture and art movement developed in the Bronx in New York City during the late 1970s. The origins of the word are often disputed. column1: 814~6~Music~5~10~"Music is an art form and cultural activity whose medium is sound organized in time. The common elements of music are pitch (which governs melody and harmony)

column3: meter

column8: solely vocal pieces (such as songs without instrumental accompaniment) and pieces that combine singing and instruments. The word derives from Greek μουσική (mousike; ""art of the Muses""). See glossary of musical terminology.

column8: and the aesthetic examination of music. Ancient Greek and Indian philosophers defined music as tones ordered horizontally as melodies and vertically as harmonies. Common sayings such as ""the harmony of the spheres"" and ""it is music to my ears"" point to the notion that music is often ordered and pleasant to listen to. However
column9: 20th-century composer John Cage thought that any sound can be music

column8: early jazz in the beginning of the 1900s and hardcore punk in the 1980s. There are many types of music

column12: music written for religious ceremonies and work songs such as chanteys. Music ranges from strictly organized compositions–such as Classical music symphonies from the 1700s and 1800s

column2: country music) and genres can be further divided into subgenres (e.g.

column2: in the music industry
column3: is the illegal practice of payment or other inducement by record companies for the broadcast of recordings on commercial radio in which the song is presented as being part of the normal day's broadcast

column1: The term has come to refer to any secret payment made to cast a product in a favorable light (such as obtaining positive reviews).

The term payola is a combination of ""pay"" and ""-ola""
column2: a common suffix of product names in the early 20th century
column3: such as Pianola
column4: Victrola
column5: Amberola
column6: Crayola
column7: Rock-Ola
column8: Shinola
column9: or brands such as the radio equipment manufacturer Motorola. Payola has come to mean the payment of a bribe in commerce and in law to say or do a certain thing against the rules of law
column10: but more specifically a commercial bribe. The FCC defines ""payola"" as a violation of the sponsorship identification rule that in 2005-06 resulted in tens of millions of dollars in fines to cable corporations in New York."~0.28855052347293497
