column1: 836~6~Piano~3358~3363~"The piano is an acoustic
column2: stringed musical instrument invented in Italy by Bartolomeo Cristofori around the year 1700 (the exact year is uncertain)
column3: in which the strings are struck by hammers. It is played using a keyboard
column4: which is a row of keys (small levers) that the performer presses down or strikes with the fingers and thumbs of both hands to cause the hammers to strike the strings. The word piano is a shortened form of pianoforte
column5: the Italian term for the early 1700s versions of the instrument
column6: which in turn derives from gravicembalo col piano e forte and fortepiano. The Italian musical terms piano and forte indicate ""soft"" and ""loud"" respectively
column7: in this context referring to the variations in volume (i.e.
column8: loudness) produced in response to a pianist's touch or pressure on the keys: the greater the velocity of a key press
column9: the greater the force of the hammer hitting the strings
column10: and the louder the sound of the note produced and the stronger the attack. The first fortepianos in the 1700s had a quieter sound and smaller dynamic range.

column1: An acoustic piano usually has a protective wooden case surrounding the soundboard and metal strings
column2: which are strung under great tension on a heavy metal frame. Pressing one or more keys on the piano's keyboard causes a padded hammer (typically padded with firm felt) to strike the strings. The hammer rebounds from the strings
column3: and the strings continue to vibrate at their resonant frequency. These vibrations are transmitted through a bridge to a soundboard that amplifies by more efficiently coupling the acoustic energy to the air. When the key is released
column4: a damper stops the strings' vibration
column5: ending the sound. Notes can be sustained
column6: even when the keys are released by the fingers and thumbs
column7: by the use of pedals at the base of the instrument. The sustain pedal enables pianists to play musical passages that would otherwise be impossible
column8: such as sounding a 10-note chord in the lower register and then
column9: while this chord is being continued with the sustain pedal
column10: shifting both hands to the treble range to play a melody and arpeggios over the top of this sustained chord. Unlike the pipe organ and harpsichord
column11: two major keyboard instruments widely used before the piano
column12: the piano allows gradations of volume and tone according to how forcefully a performer presses or strikes the keys.

column1: Most modern pianos have a row of 88 black and white keys
column2: 52 white keys for the notes of the C major scale (C
column3: D
column4: E
column5: F
column6: G
column7: A and B) and 36 shorter black keys
column8: which are raised above the white keys
column9: and set further back on the keyboard. This means that the piano can play 88 different pitches (or ""notes"")
column10: going from the deepest bass range to the highest treble. The black keys are for the ""accidentals"" (F♯/G♭
column11: G♯/A♭
column12: A♯/B♭
column13: C♯/D♭

column1: 903~6~Surfaris~14606~14614~"A surface
column2: as the term is most generally used
column3: is the outermost or uppermost layer of a physical object or space. It is the portion or region of the object that can first be perceived by an observer using the senses of sight and touch
column4: and is the portion with which other materials first interact. The surface of an object is more than ""a mere geometric solid""
column5: but is ""filled with
column6: spread over by
column7: or suffused with perceivable qualities such as color and warmth"".

column1: The concept of surface has been abstracted and formalized in mathematics
column2: specifically in geometry. Depending on the properties on which the emphasis is given
column3: there are several non equivalent such formalizations
column4: that are all called surface
column5: sometimes with some qualifier
column6: such as algebraic surface
column7: smooth surface or fractal surface.

column1: The concept of surface and its mathematical abstraction are both widely used in physics
column2: engineering
column3: computer graphics
column4: and many other disciplines
column5: primarily in representing the surfaces of physical objects. For example
column6: in analyzing the aerodynamic properties of an airplane
column7: the central consideration is the flow of air along its surface. The concept also raises certain philosophical questions—for example
column8: how thick is the layer of atoms or molecules that can be considered part of the surface of an object (i.e.
column9: where does the ""surface"" end and the ""interior"" begin)
column10: and do objects really have a surface at all if
column11: at the subatomic level
column12: they never actually come in contact with other objects."~0.4344388252086665

column1: 915~6~Tin Pan Alley~5085~5098~"Tin Pan Alley is the name given to the collection of New York City music publishers and songwriters who dominated the popular music of the United States in the late 19th century and early 20th century. column1: The origins of the name ""Tin Pan Alley"" are unclear. One account claims that it was a derogatory reference to the sound of many pianos (comparing them to the banging of tin pans). Others claim it arose from songwriters modifying their pianos to produce a more percussive sound. After many years
column2: the term came to refer to the U.S. music industry in general."~0.4446708304296362

column1: 921~6~United Kingdom~212~226~"The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

column1: Prior to the creation of the UK

column9: but now ""DJ"" is used as an all-encompassing term to describe someone who mixes recorded music from any source
column10: including cassettes
column11: CDs
column12: or digital audio files on a CDJ or laptop. The title ""DJ"" is commonly used by DJs in front of their real names or adopted pseudonyms or stage names.

column1: DJs use equipment that can play at least two sources of recorded music simultaneously and mix them together to create seamless transitions between recordings and develop unique mixes of songs. Often
column2: this involves aligning the beats of the music sources so their rhythms do not clash when played together

column1: 953~7~Dischord Records~11126~11134~"Dischord Records is a Washington

column1: 954~7~Disco~3910~3915~"Disco is a musical style originating in the early 1970s. It began to emerge from America's urban nightlife scene

column3: after which
column4: it began making regular mainstream appearances

column6: both male and female
column7: from the African American
column8: Italian American
column9: Latino
column10: gay
column11: and psychedelic communities in Philadelphia and New York City during the late 1960s and early 1970s. Several dances styles were also developed during this time including the Bump and the Hustle.

column1: The disco sound often has several components

column4: and a prominent
column5: syncopated electric bass line. In most disco tracks

column7: horns

column9: and electric rhythm guitars create a lush background sound. Orchestral instruments such as the flute are often used for solo melodies
column10: and lead guitar is less frequently used in disco than in rock. Many disco songs use electronic synthesizers
column11: particularly in the late 1970s.

column1: Well-known disco performers include Donna Summer
column2: the Bee Gees
column3: Gloria Gaynor
column4: KC and the Sunshine Band
column5: the Village People
column6: Thelma Houston
column7: and Chic. While performers and singers garnered much public attention
column8: record producers working behind the scenes played an important role in developing the ""disco sound"". Many non-disco artists recorded disco songs at the height of disco's popularity

column4: a venue popular among celebrities
column5: was a well-known disco club of that time. Discotheque-goers often wore expensive
column6: extravagant and sexy fashions. There was also a thriving drug subculture in the disco scene
column7: particularly for drugs that would enhance the experience of dancing to the loud music and the flashing lights
column8: such as cocaine and Quaaludes

column1: Disco was the last mass popular music movement that was driven by the baby boom generation. Disco was a worldwide phenomenon

column1: 955~7~Effects pedal~16695~16709~"An effects unit or pedal is an electronic or digital device that alters how a musical instrument or other audio source sounds. In the 2010s
column2: most effects use solid-state electronics and/or computer chips. Some vintage effects units from the 1930s to the 1970s and modern reissues of these effects use mechanical components as well (e.g.
column3: Leslie rotating speaker
column4: spring reverb
column5: and tape recorder-based echo effects) or vacuum tubes. Some effects subtly ""color"" a sound
column6: such as a reverb unit used on a low setting
column7: while others transform it dramatically
column8: such as a distortion pedal used with electric guitar
column9: with the overdrive set to its maximum level. Musicians
column10: audio engineers and record producers use effects units during live performances or in the studio
column11: typically with electric guitar
column12: electronic keyboard
column13: electric piano or electric bass. While guitar effects are most frequently used with electric or electronic instruments
column14: effects can also be used with acoustic instruments
column15: drums and vocals. Rackmounted or audio console-integrated reverb effects are commonly used with vocals in live sound and sound recording. Examples of common effects units include wah-wah pedals

column1: Effects are built into amplifiers (reverb and distortion are the most common in 2010s-era amps
column2: but vintage amps and modern reissued amps may also have tremolo and vibrato); housed in table top units designed for DJs and record producers
column3: a format which typically contains multiple effects; ""stompboxes"" and ""rackmount units""
column4: or they are built into the instruments themselves
column5: as in the case of the Hammond organ
column6: which includes chorus and vibrato effects inside the instrument chassis. A stompbox or ""pedal"" is a small metal or plastic box placed on the floor in front of the musician and connected to the instrument and the instrument amplifier with patch cords. Pedals are usually the least expensive format. Typically
column7: one or more on-off foot-operated switches control a device that provides only one or two effects
column8: with many pedals having knobs for controlling the volume
column9: tone and intensity of the effect. A rackmount device mounts on a standard 19-inch equipment rack and usually contains several types of effects. Rackmount effects typically have buttons and/or knobs on the face of the chassis for controlling the effects and a patch bay at the rear of the unit.

column1: While there is currently no firm consensus on how to categorize effects
column2: the following are seven common classifications: distortion/overdrive
column3: also called ""fuzz""
column4: which produce the ""growling"" audio clipping sounds that are a key part of electric guitar playing in electric blues
column5: hard rock and heavy metal music; dynamics effects which affect loudness
column6: such as volume pedals and audio compressors; filters which modify the frequency range of the instrument
column7: such as the wah-wah pedal and the graphic equalizer; modulation effects
column8: such as the chorus
column9: flanger and phaser; pitch/frequency effects such as a pitch shifter
column10: a common example of which is an octave pedal
column11: which can shift a note down an octave (or up an octave); time-based effects
column12: such as reverb
column13: echo effect and looper pedals (the latter can be used by a one person band to record a riff and then solo over it); and feedback/sustain effects
column14: such as electric guitar feedback and the EBow
column15: which are two different techniques for producing pipe organ-like sustain on the electric guitar. Guitarists derive their signature sound or ""tone"" from their choice of instrument
column17: effects units
column18: and guitar amp and from the different settings they use with their pickups
column19: effects units and amp."~0.25958014201492874

column1: 958~7~Fanzine~8622~8630~"A fanzine (blend of fan and magazine or -zine) is a non-professional and non-official publication produced by enthusiasts of a particular cultural phenomenon (such as a literary or musical genre) for the pleasure of others who share their interest. column1: 959~7~Folk music~10573~10583~"Folk music includes both traditional music and the genre that evolved from it during the 20th century folk revival. The term originated in the 19th century

column1: 961~7~Grunge~1281~1287~"Grunge (sometimes referred to as the Seattle sound) is a subgenre of alternative rock and a subculture that emerged during the mid-1980s in the Pacific Northwest U.S. state of Washington

column1: 962~7~Guitar~5395~5401~"The guitar is a fretted musical instrument that usually has six strings. The sound is projected either acoustically

column1: 1024~7~Techno~16442~16448~"Techno is a form of electronic dance music that emerged in Detroit
column2: Michigan
column3: in the United States during the mid-to-late 1980s. The first recorded use of the word techno in reference to a specific genre of music was in 1988. Many styles of techno now exist

column1: In Detroit
column2: techno resulted from the melding of African American music including Chicago house
column3: funk
column4: electro
column5: and electric jazz with electronic music by artists such as Kraftwerk
column6: Giorgio Moroder
column7: and Yellow Magic Orchestra. Added to this is the influence of futuristic and fictional themes relevant to life in American late capitalist society
column8: with Alvin Toffler's book The Third Wave being a notable point of reference. Pioneering producer Juan Atkins cites Toffler's phrase ""techno rebels"" as inspiring him to use the word techno to describe the musical style he helped to create. This unique blend of influences aligns techno with the aesthetic referred to as afrofuturism. To producers such as Derrick May
column9: the transference of spirit from the body to the machine is often a central preoccupation; essentially an expression of technological spirituality. In this manner: ""techno dance music defeats what Adorno saw as the alienating effect of mechanisation on the modern consciousness"".

column1: Stylistically
column2: techno is generally repetitive instrumental music
column3: often produced for use in a continuous DJ set. The central rhythmic component is most often in common time (4/4)
column4: where time is marked with a bass drum on each quarter note pulse
column5: a backbeat played by snare or clap on the second and fourth pulses of the bar
column6: and an open hi-hat sounding every second eighth note. The tempo tends to vary between approximately 120 to 150 beats per minute (bpm)
column7: depending on the style of techno. The creative use of music production technology
column8: such as drum machines
column9: synthesizers
column10: and digital audio workstations
column11: is viewed as an important aspect of the music's aesthetic. Many producers use retro electronic musical devices to create what they consider to be an authentic techno sound. Drum machines from the 1980s such as Roland's TR-808 and TR-909 are highly prized
column12: and software emulations of such retro technology are popular among techno producers.

column1: Music journalists and fans of techno are generally selective in their use of the term; so a clear distinction can be made between sometimes related but often qualitatively different styles
column2: such as tech house and trance."~0.2530859224936396

column1: 1027~7~United Kingdom~2655~2669~"The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

column1: 1028~7~United States~2513~2526~"The United States of America (USA)

1033~7~Zine~1047~1052~A zine ( ZEEN; short for magazine or fanzine) is most commonly a small-circulation self-published work of original or appropriated texts and images
column2: usually reproduced via photocopier. Usually zines are the product of a single person

column1: Popularly defined as having a circulation of 1

column3: in practice many zines are produced in editions of fewer than 100. The primary intent of publication is to advance the views of the editor rather than profit

column1: Zines are written in a variety of formats
column2: from desktop-published text to comics to handwritten text (an example being the hardcore punk zine Cometbus). Print remains the most popular zine format
column3: usually photocopied with a small circulation. Topics covered are broad
column4: including fanfiction
column5: politics
column6: poetry
column7: art and design
column8: ephemera
column9: personal journals
column10: social theory
column11: riot grrrl and intersectional feminism
column12: single-topic obsession
column13: or sexual content far outside the mainstream enough to be prohibitive of inclusion in more traditional media. (An example of the latter is Boyd McDonald's Straight to Hell
column14: which reached a circulation of 20

column1: Zines are typically experimental cultural fragments defined by being created and distributed outside mainstream publication centers. They have the opportunity to reach selected
column2: specific audiences
column3: and often create pockets of intimate
column4: subcultural communities.

column1: In recent years a number of photocopied zines have risen to prominence or professional status and have found wide bookstore and online distribution. Notable among these are Giant Robot

column3: Bust
column4: Bitch

column1: 1~1~5K run~10973~10977~"The 5K run is a long-distance road running competition over a distance of five kilometres (3.1 miles). Also referred to as the 5K road race
column2: 5 km
column3: or simply 5K
column4: it is the shortest of the most common road running distances. It is usually distinguished from the 5000 metres track running event by stating the distance in kilometres
column5: rather than metres.

column1: Among road running events
column2: the 5K distance is mostly popular with novice or infrequent runners or joggers
column3: as it is comparatively easier to complete the distance without endurance training. This also makes the distance suitable for people looking to improve or maintain their general physical fitness
column4: rather than develop long-distance running abilities. The brevity of the distance means that less time is required to take part in the activity and that people from a wide range of ages and abilities may participate. From a physiological perspective
column5: five kilometres is towards the low end of endurance running.

column1: The combination of the activity's simplicity
column2: its low cost
column3: and medium exercise intensity mean that it is often recommended by medical organisations and healthcare professionals. Like all physical activity
column4: regular 5K runs can improve cardiovascular function and reduce body fat
column5: as well as having mental health benefits (see runner's high)."~0.18361895779097726

3~1~Amputation~6942~6952~Amputation is the removal of a limb by trauma
column2: medical illness
column3: or surgery. As a surgical measure
column4: it is used to control pain or a disease process in the affected limb

column6: it is carried out on individuals as a preventative surgery for such problems. A special case is that of congenital amputation
column7: a congenital disorder
column8: where fetal limbs have been cut off by constrictive bands. In some countries
column9: amputation of the hands
column10: feet or other body parts is or was used as a form of punishment for people who committed crimes. Amputation has also been used as a tactic in war and acts of terrorism; it may also occur as a war injury. In some cultures and religions
column11: minor amputations or mutilations are considered a ritual accomplishment.

column1: In the US
column2: the majority of new amputations occur due to complications of the vascular system (the blood vessels)
column3: especially from diabetes. Between 1988 and 1996

column5: 735 hospital discharges for amputation per year in the US."~0.09869885634525431

column1: 4~1~Ancient Greek~1697~1710~"The Ancient Greek language includes the forms of Greek used in ancient Greece and the ancient world from around the 9th century BC to the 6th century AD. It is often roughly divided into the Archaic period (9th to 6th centuries BC)

column3: Greek of the classic and earlier periods included several regional dialects.

column1: Ancient Greek was the language of Homer and of fifth-century Athenian historians
column2: playwrights
column3: and philosophers. It has contributed many words to English vocabulary and has been a standard subject of study in educational institutions of the Western world since the Renaissance. This article primarily contains information about the Epic and Classical phases of the language."~0.20112284908741263

column1: 5~1~Aristotle~30078~30087~"Aristotle (; Greek: Ἀριστοτέλης Aristotélēs
column2: pronounced [aristotélɛːs]; 384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in the city of Stagira
column3: Chalkidiki
column4: in the north of Classical Greece. Along with Plato
column5: Aristotle is considered the ""Father of Western Philosophy""
column6: which inherited almost its entire lexicon from his teachings
column7: including problems and methods of inquiry
column8: so influencing almost all forms of knowledge.

column1: His father
column2: Nicomachus
column3: died when Aristotle was a child
column4: and he was brought up by a guardian. At seventeen or eighteen years of age
column5: he joined Plato's Academy in Athens and remained there until the age of thirty-seven (c. 347 BC). His writings cover many subjects – including physics
column6: biology
column7: zoology
column8: metaphysics
column9: logic
column10: ethics
column11: aesthetics
column12: poetry
column13: theater
column14: music
column15: rhetoric
column17: linguistics
column18: politics and government – and constitute the first comprehensive system of Western philosophy. Shortly after Plato died
column19: Aristotle left Athens and
column20: at the request of Philip II of Macedon
column21: tutored Alexander the Great beginning in 343 BC. Teaching Alexander the Great gave Aristotle many opportunities. He established a library in the Lyceum which helped him to produce many of his hundreds of books
column22: which were papyrus scrolls. The fact that Aristotle was a pupil of Plato contributed to his former views of Platonism
column24: following Plato's death
column25: Aristotle immersed himself in empirical studies and shifted from Platonism to empiricism. He believed all peoples' concepts and all of their knowledge was ultimately based on perception. Aristotle's views on natural sciences represent the groundwork underlying many of his works.

column1: Aristotle's views on physical science profoundly shaped medieval scholarship. Their influence extended from Late Antiquity and the Early Middle Ages into the Renaissance
column2: and were not replaced systematically until the Enlightenment and theories such as classical mechanics. Some of Aristotle's zoological observations
column3: such as on the hectocotyl (reproductive) arm of the octopus
column4: were disbelieved until the 19th century. His works contain the earliest known formal study of logic
column5: studied by medieval scholars such as Peter Abelard and John Buridan. Aristotelianism profoundly influenced Islamic thought during the Middle Ages
column6: as well as Christian theology
column7: especially the Neoplatonism of the Early Church and the scholastic tradition of the Catholic Church. Aristotle was revered among medieval Muslim scholars as ""The First Teacher"". His ethics
column8: though always influential
column9: gained renewed interest with the modern advent of virtue ethics.

column1: All aspects of Aristotle's philosophy continue to be the object of active academic study today. Though Aristotle wrote many elegant treatises and dialogues for publication
column2: only around a third of his original output has survived
column3: none of it intended for publication. Aristotle has been depicted by major artists including Raphael and Rembrandt. Early Modern theories including William Harvey's circulation of the blood and Galileo Galilei's kinematics were developed in reaction to Aristotle's. In the 19th century
column4: Martin Heidegger created a new interpretation of Aristotle's political philosophy
column5: while George Boole gave Aristotle's logic a mathematical foundation with his system of algebraic logic. In the 20th century
column6: Aristotle was widely criticised
column7: even ridiculed by thinkers such as the philosopher Bertrand Russell and the biologist Peter Medawar. More recently
column8: Aristotle has again been taken seriously
column9: such as in the thinking of Ayn Rand and Alasdair MacIntyre
column10: while Armand Marie Leroi has reconstructed Aristotle's biology. The image of Aristotle tutoring the young Alexander the Great remains current
column11: as in the 2004 film Alexander
column12: and the Poetics continues to play a role in the cinema of the United States."~0.12778802362167405

column1: 6~1~Athlete~367~374~"An athlete (American and British English) or sportsman or sportswoman (British English) is a person who is good at a sport and competes in one or more sports that involve physical strength
column2: speed or endurance. The term's applies to those who participate in other activities
column3: such as horse riding or driving
column4: is somewhat controversial.

column1: Athletes may be professionals or amateurs. Most professional athletes have particularly well-developed physiques obtained by extensive physical training and strict exercise accompanied by a strict dietary regimen."~0.2918075095614494
7~1~Biopic~30881~30888~"A biographical film
column2: or biopic (; abbreviation for biographical motion picture)
column3: is a film that dramatizes the life of a non-fictional or historically-based person or people. Such films show the life of a historical person and the central character's real name is used. They differ from films ""based on a true story"" or ""historical drama films"" in that they attempt to comprehensively tell a single person's life story or at least the most historically important years of their lives.

column1: Because the figures portrayed are actual people
column2: whose actions and characteristics are known to the public (or at least historically documented)
column3: biopic roles are considered some of the most demanding of actors and actresses. Ben Kingsley
column4: Johnny Depp
column5: Jim Carrey
column6: and Jamie Foxx all gained new-found respect as dramatic actors after starring in biopics: Ben Kingsley as Mahatma Gandhi in Gandhi (1982)
column7: Depp as Ed Wood in Ed Wood (1994)
column8: Carrey as Andy Kaufman in Man on the Moon (1999)
column9: and Foxx as Ray Charles in Ray (2004).

column1: In rare cases
column2: sometimes called auto biopics
column3: the subject of the film plays himself or herself: Jackie Robinson in The Jackie Robinson Story; Muhammad Ali in The Greatest; Audie Murphy in To Hell and Back; Patty Duke in Call Me Anna; Bob Mathias in The Bob Mathias Story
column4: Arlo Guthrie in Alice's Restaurant; and Howard Stern in Private Parts.

column1: Biopic scholars include George F. Custen of the College of Staten Island and Dennis P. Bingham of Indiana University – Purdue University Indianapolis. Custen
column2: in Bio/Pics: How Hollywood Constructed Public History (1992)
column3: regards the genre as having died with the Hollywood studio era
column4: and in particular
column5: Darryl F. Zanuck. On the other hand
column6: Bingham's 2010 study Whose Lives Are They Anyway? The Biopic as Contemporary Film Genre shows how it perpetuates as a codified genre using many of the same tropes used in the studio era that has followed a similar trajectory as that shown by Rick Altman in his study
column7: Film/Genre. Bingham also addresses the male biopic and the female biopic as distinct genres from each other
column8: the former generally dealing with great accomplishments
column9: the latter generally dealing with female victimization. Ellen Cheshire's Bio-Pics: a life in pictures (2014) examines UK/US films from the 1990s and 2000s. Each chapter reviews key films linked by profession and concludes with further viewing list. Christopher Robé has also written on the gender norms that underlie the biopic in his article
column10: ""Taking Hollywood Back"" in the 2009 issue of Cinema Journal.  Roger Ebert defended The Hurricane and distortions in biographical films in general
column11: stating ""those who seek the truth about a man from the film of his life might as well seek it from his loving grandmother. ... The Hurricane is not a documentary but a parable.""

column1: Some biopics purposely stretch the truth. Confessions of a Dangerous Mind was based on game show host Chuck Barris' widely debunked yet popular memoir of the same name
column2: in which he claimed to be a CIA agent. Kafka incorporated both the life of author Franz Kafka and the surreal aspects of his fiction. The Errol Flynn film They Died with Their Boots On tells the story of Custer but is highly romanticized. The Oliver Stone film The Doors
column3: mainly about Jim Morrison
column4: was highly praised for the similarities between Jim Morrison and actor Val Kilmer
column5: look-wise and singing-wise
column6: but fans and band members did not like the way Oliver Stone portrayed Jim Morrison
column7: and a few of the scenes were even completely made up.

column1: Casting can be controversial for biographical films. Casting is often a balance between similarity in looks and ability to portray the characteristics of the person. Anthony Hopkins felt that he should not have played Richard Nixon in Nixon because of a lack of resemblance between the two. The casting of John Wayne as Genghis Khan in The Conqueror was objected to because of the American Wayne being cast as the Mongol warlord. Egyptian critics criticized the casting of Louis Gossett
column2: Jr.
column3: an African American actor
column4: as Egyptian president Anwar Sadat in the 1982 TV miniseries Sadat. Also
column5: some objected to the casting of Jennifer Lopez in Selena because she is a New York City native of Puerto Rican descent while Selena was Mexican-American."~0.05582862988932362

column1: 8~1~Boston Marathon~11425~11431~"The Boston Marathon is an annual marathon hosted by several cities in greater Boston in eastern Massachusetts
column2: United States. It is always held on Patriots' Day
column3: the third Monday of April. Begun in 1897

column5: the Boston Marathon is the world's oldest annual marathon and ranks as one of the world's best-known road racing events. It is one of six World Marathon Majors
column6: and is one of five major events held in the United States through the years of both World Wars (the Kentucky Derby
column7: Penn Relays
column8: Rose Parade
column9: and Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show are the others).

column1: Since 1897
column2: the Boston Athletic Association (B.A.A.) has organized this event
column3: and it has been managed by DMSE Sports
column4: Inc. since 1988. Amateur and professional runners from all over the world compete in the Boston Marathon each year
column5: braving the hilly Massachusetts terrain and varying weather to take part in the race.

column1: The event attracts 500
column2: 000 spectators each year
column3: making it New England's most widely viewed sporting event. Though starting with 15 participants in 1897
column4: the event now attracts an average of about 30
column5: 000 registered participants each year
column6: with 30
column7: 251 people entering in 2015. The Centennial Boston Marathon in 1996 established a record as the world's largest marathon with 38
column8: 708 entrants
column10: 748 starters
column11: and 35

column1: 10~1~Celts~3230~3236~"The Celts (
column2: see pronunciation of Celt for different usages) were an Indo-European people in Iron Age and Medieval Europe who spoke Celtic languages and had cultural similarities
column3: although the relationship between ethnic
column4: linguistic and cultural factors in the Celtic world remains uncertain and controversial. The exact geographic spread of the ancient Celts is also disputed; in particular
column5: the ways in which the Iron Age inhabitants of Great Britain and Ireland should be regarded as Celts have become a subject of controversy.

column1: The history of pre-Celtic Europe remains very uncertain. According to one theory
column2: the common root of the Celtic languages
column3: the Proto-Celtic language
column4: arose in the Late Bronze Age Urnfield culture of Central Europe
column5: which flourished from around 1200 BC. In addition
column6: according to a theory proposed in the 19th century
column7: the first people to adopt cultural characteristics regarded as Celtic were the people of the Iron Age Hallstatt culture in central Europe (c. 800–450 BC)
column8: named for the rich grave finds in Hallstatt
column9: Austria. Thus this area is sometimes called the ""Celtic homeland"". By or during the later La Tène period (c. 450 BC up to the Roman conquest)
column10: this Celtic culture was supposed to have expanded by trans-cultural diffusion or migration to the British Isles (Insular Celts)
column11: France and the Low Countries (Gauls)
column12: Bohemia
column13: Poland and much of Central Europe
column14: the Iberian Peninsula (Celtiberians
column15: Celtici
column16: Lusitanians and Gallaeci) and northern Italy (Golasecca culture and Cisalpine Gauls) and
column17: following the Celtic settlement of Eastern Europe beginning in 279 BC
column18: as far east as central Anatolia (Galatians) in modern-day Turkey.

column1: The earliest undisputed direct examples of a Celtic language are the Lepontic inscriptions beginning in the 6th century BC. Continental Celtic languages are attested almost exclusively through inscriptions and place-names. Insular Celtic languages are attested beginning around the 4th century in Ogham inscriptions
column2: although it was clearly being spoken much earlier. Celtic literary tradition begins with Old Irish texts around the 8th century. Coherent texts of Early Irish literature
column3: such as the Táin Bó Cúailnge (""Cattle Raid of Cooley"")
column4: survive in 12th century recensions.

column1: By the mid-1st millennium
column2: with the expansion of the Roman Empire and the Migration Period of Germanic peoples
column3: Celtic culture and Insular Celtic languages had become restricted to Ireland
column4: the western and northern parts of Great Britain (Wales
column5: Scotland
column6: and Cornwall)
column7: the Isle of Man
column8: and Brittany. Between the 5th and 8th centuries
column9: the Celtic-speaking communities in these Atlantic regions emerged as a reasonably cohesive cultural entity. They had a common linguistic
column10: religious and artistic heritage that distinguished them from the culture of the surrounding polities. By the 6th century
column11: however
column12: the Continental Celtic languages were no longer in wide use.

column1: Insular Celtic culture diversified into that of the Gaels (Irish
column2: Scottish and Manx) and the Celtic Britons (Welsh
column3: Cornish
column4: and Bretons) of the medieval and modern periods. A modern ""Celtic identity"" was constructed as part of the Romanticist Celtic Revival in Great Britain
column5: Ireland
column6: and other European territories
column7: such as Portugal and Spanish Galicia. Today
column8: Irish
column9: Scottish Gaelic
column10: Welsh
column11: and Breton are still spoken in parts of their historical territories
column12: and Cornish and Manx are undergoing a revival."~0.19286242307901108

column1: 11~1~Cerebral palsy~6955~6969~"Cerebral palsy (CP) is a group of permanent movement disorders that appear in early childhood. Signs and symptoms vary among people. Often
column2: symptoms include poor coordination
column3: stiff muscles
column4: weak muscles
column5: and tremors. There may be problems with sensation
column6: vision
column7: hearing
column8: swallowing
column9: and speaking. Often babies with cerebral palsy do not roll over
column10: sit
column11: crawl
column12: or walk as early as other children of their age. Other symptoms may include seizures and problems with thinking or reasoning
column13: either of which occurs in about one third of people with CP. While the symptoms may get more noticeable over the first few years of life
column14: the underlying problems do not worsen over time.

column1: Cerebral palsy is caused by abnormal development or damage to the parts of the brain that control movement
column2: balance and posture. Most often the problems occur during pregnancy; however
column3: they may also occur during childbirth
column4: or shortly after birth. Often the cause is unknown. Risk factors include preterm birth
column5: being a twin
column6: certain infections during pregnancy such as toxoplasmosis or rubella
column7: exposure to methylmercury during pregnancy
column8: a difficult delivery
column9: and head trauma during the first few years of life
column10: among others. About 2% of cases are believed to be due to an inherited genetic cause. A number of sub-types are classified based on the specific problems present. For example
column11: those with stiff muscles have spastic cerebral palsy
column12: those with poor coordination have ataxic cerebral palsy
column13: and those with writhing movements have athetoid cerebral palsy. Diagnosis is based on the child's development over time. Blood tests and medical imaging may be used to rule out other possible causes.

column1: CP is partly preventable through immunization of the mother and efforts to prevent head injuries in children such as through improved safety. There is no cure for CP; however
column2: supportive treatments
column3: medications
column4: and surgery may help many individuals. This may include physical therapy
column5: occupational therapy
column6: and speech therapy. Medications such as diazepam
column7: baclofen
column8: and botulinum toxin may help relax stiff muscles. Surgery may include lengthening muscles and cutting overly active nerves. Often external braces and other assistive technology are helpful. Some affected children can achieve near normal adult lives with appropriate treatment. While alternative medicines are frequently used there is no evidence to support their use.

column1: CP is the most common movement disorder in children. It occurs in about 2.1 per 1
column2: 000 live births. Cerebral palsy has been documented throughout history with the first known descriptions occurring in the work of Hippocrates in the 5th century BCE. Extensive study of the condition began in the 19th century by William John Little
column3: after whom spastic diplegia was called ""Little disease"". William Osler first named it ""cerebral palsy"" from the German ""zerebrale Kinderlähmung"" (cerebral child-paralysis). A number of potential treatments are being examined
column4: including stem cell therapy. However
column5: more research is required to determine if it is effective and safe."~0.19807880156751237

column1: 12~1~Cinder~20118~20124~"A cinder is a pyroclastic material. Cinders are extrusive igneous rocks. Cinders are similar to pumice
column2: which has so many cavities
column3: causing its low-density of 0.641g/cm^3 that allows it to even float on water. Cinder is typically brown

13~1~Commonwealth Games~29073~29091~The Commonwealth Games is an international multi-sport event involving athletes from the Commonwealth of Nations. The event was first held in 1930
column2: and has taken place every four years since then (with the exception of 1942 and 1946
column3: which were cancelled due to World War II). The most recent Commonwealth Games were held in Glasgow
column4: Scotland in 2014. The Commonwealth Games were known as the British Empire Games from 1930–1950
column5: the British Empire and Commonwealth Games from 1954–1966
column6: and British Commonwealth Games from 1970–1974.

column1: The games are overseen by the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF)
column2: which also controls the sporting programme and selects the host cities. The games movement consists of international sports federations (IFs)
column3: Commonwealth Games Associations (CGAs)
column4: and organising committees for each specific Commonwealth Games. There are several rituals and symbols
column5: such as the Commonwealth Games flag and Queen's Baton
column6: as well as the opening and closing ceremonies. Over 5
column7: 000 athletes compete at the Commonwealth Games in more than 15 different sports and more than 250 events. The first
column8: second
column9: and third-place finishers in each event receive Commonwealth Games medals: gold
column10: silver
column11: and bronze
column12: respectively. Apart from many Olympic sports
column13: the games also include some sports that are played predominantly in Commonwealth countries
column14: such as lawn bowls and netball.

column1: Although there are 53 members of the Commonwealth of Nations
column2: 71 teams participate in the Commonwealth Games
column3: as a number of dependent territories compete under their own flags. The four Home Nations of the United Kingdom—England
column4: Scotland
column5: Wales
column6: and Northern Ireland—also send separate teams.

column1: Nine nations have hosted the Commonwealth Games. 18 cities in seven countries have hosted the event. Australia has hosted four Commonwealth Games (1938
column4: 2006) and will host for the fifth time in 2018. Canada has hosted four Commonwealth Games (1930
column7: 1994). Two cities have hosted Commonwealth Games more than one time: Auckland (1950
column8: 1990) and Edinburgh (1970

column1: Only six countries have attended every Commonwealth Games: Australia
column2: Canada
column3: England
column4: New Zealand
column5: Scotland
column6: and Wales. Australia has been the highest achieving team for twelve games
column7: England for seven
column8: and Canada for one."~0.393834227470852

column1: 14~1~Decathlon~9257~9266~"The decathlon is a combined event in athletics consisting of ten track and field events. The word decathlon is of Greek origin
column2: from δέκα (déka
column3: meaning ""ten"") and ἄθλος (áthlos
column4: or ἄθλον
column5: áthlon
column6: meaning ""feat""). Events are held over two consecutive days and the winners are determined by the combined performance in all. Performance is judged on a points system in each event
column7: not by the position achieved. The decathlon is contested mainly by male athletes
column8: while female athletes typically compete in the heptathlon.

column1: Traditionally
column2: the title of ""World's Greatest Athlete"" has been given to the person who wins the Olympic decathlon. This began when King Gustav V of Sweden told Jim Thorpe
column3: ""You
column4: sir
column5: are the world's greatest athlete"" after Thorpe won the decathlon at the Stockholm Olympics in 1912. The current decathlon world record holder is American Ashton Eaton
column6: who scored 9
column7: 045 points at the 2015 IAAF World Championships.

column1: The event developed from the ancient pentathlon. Pentathlon competitions were held at the ancient Greek Olympics. Pentathlons involved five disciplines – long jump
column2: discus throw
column3: javelin throw
column4: sprint and a wrestling match. Introduced in Olympia during 708 BC
column5: the competition was extremely popular for many centuries. By the sixth century BC
column6: pentathlons had become part of religious games. A ten-event competition known as the ""all-around"" or ""all-round"" championship
column7: similar to the modern decathlon
column8: was first contested at the United States amateur championships in 1884 and reached a consistent form by 1890; an all-around was held at the 1904 Summer Olympics
column9: though whether it was an official Olympic event has been disputed. The modern decathlon first appeared on the Olympic athletics program at the 1912 Games in Stockholm."~0.3107214487345996

column1: 15~1~Discus throw~8980~8986~The discus throw ( pronunciation) is a track and field event in which an athlete throws a heavy disc—called a discus—in an attempt to mark a farther distance than their competitors. It is an ancient sport

column1: 16~1~Dwarfism~17792~17800~"Dwarfism
column2: also known as short stature
column3: occurs when an organism is extremely small. In humans
column4: it is sometimes defined as an adult height of less than 4 feet 10 inches (58 in; 147 cm)
column5: regardless of sex
column6: although some individuals with dwarfism are slightly taller. Disproportionate dwarfism is characterized by either short limbs or a short torso. In cases of proportionate dwarfism

column1: Treatment depends on the underlying cause. Those with bone growth disorders can sometimes be treated with surgery
column2: or physical therapy. Hormone disorders can be treated with hormone replacement therapy as well before the child's growth plates fuse. Individual accommodations
column3: such as specialized furniture
column4: are often used by people with dwarfism. Many support groups provide services to aid individuals and the discrimination they may face.

column4: United States
column5: Canada
column6: Australia

column10: or persons of short stature. Historically

column1: 17~1~Educational institution~7862~7886~An educational institution is a place where people of different ages gain an education. Examples of some institutions are preschools
column2: primary schools
column3: secondary schools
column4: and further and higher education. They provide a large variety of learning environments and learning spaces. The American Educational System typically divides learning facilities by an age grade system. The student is designated to a grade level based on their age
column5: and advances one grade each year. This determines what educational institution would be an appropriate setting for the individual. The institution can be public
column6: private or unconventional.~0.15248510132332396

column1: 19~1~England~3783~3790~"England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It shares land borders with Scotland to the north and Wales to the west. The Irish Sea lies northwest of England and the Celtic Sea lies to the southwest. England is separated from continental Europe by the North Sea to the east and the English Channel to the south. The country covers five-eighths of the island of Great Britain (which lies in the North Atlantic) in its centre and south
column2: and includes over 100 smaller named islands such as the Isles of Scilly and the Isle of Wight.

column1: The area now called England was first inhabited by modern humans during the Upper Palaeolithic period
column2: but takes its name from the Angles
column3: a Germanic tribe deriving its name from the Anglia peninsula
column4: who settled during the 5th and 6th centuries. England became a unified state in the 10th century
column5: and since the Age of Discovery
column6: which began during the 15th century
column7: has had a significant cultural and legal impact on the wider world. The English language
column8: the Anglican Church
column9: and English law – the basis for the common law legal systems of many other countries around the world – developed in England
column10: and the country's parliamentary system of government has been widely adopted by other nations. The Industrial Revolution began in 18th-century England
column11: transforming its society into the world's first industrialised nation.

column1: England's terrain mostly comprises low hills and plains
column2: especially in central and southern England. However
column3: there are uplands in the north (for example
column4: the mountainous Lake District
column5: and the Pennines) and in the west (for example
column6: Dartmoor and the Shropshire Hills). The capital is London
column7: which has the largest metropolitan area in both the United Kingdom and the European Union. England's population of over 53 million comprises 84% of the population of the United Kingdom
column8: largely concentrated around London
column9: the South East
column10: and conurbations in the Midlands
column11: the North West
column12: the North East
column13: and Yorkshire
column14: which each developed as major industrial regions during the 19th century.

column1: The Kingdom of England – which after 1535 included Wales – ceased being a separate sovereign state on 1 May 1707
column2: when the Acts of Union put into effect the terms agreed in the Treaty of Union the previous year
column3: resulting in a political union with the Kingdom of Scotland to create the Kingdom of Great Britain. In 1801
column4: Great Britain was united with the Kingdom of Ireland through another Act of Union to become the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. In 1922 the Irish Free State seceded from the United Kingdom
column5: leading to the latter being renamed the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland."~0.34733604692014397

column2: Fukuoka Kokusai Marason)
column3: held in Fukuoka

column1: 21~1~Gambling~11735~11741~"Gambling is the wagering of money or something of value (referred to as ""the stakes"") on an event with an uncertain outcome with the primary intent of winning money or material goods. Gambling thus requires three elements be present: consideration
column2: chance and prize. The outcome of the wager is often immediate
column3: such as a single roll of dice
column4: a spin of a roulette wheel
column5: or a horse crossing the finish line
column6: but longer time frames are also common
column7: allowing wagers on the outcome of a future sports contest or even an entire sports season.

column1: The term ""gaming"" in this context typically refers to instances in which the activity has been specifically permitted by law. The two words are not mutually exclusive; i.e.
column2: a ""gaming"" company offers (legal) ""gambling"" activities to the public and may be regulated by one of many gaming control boards
column3: for example
column4: the Nevada Gaming Control Board. However
column5: this distinction is not universally observed in the English-speaking world. For instance
column6: in the United Kingdom
column7: the regulator of gambling activities is called the Gambling Commission (not the Gaming Commission). The word gaming is used more frequently since the rise of computer and video games to describe activities that do not necessarily involve wagering
column8: especially online gaming
column9: with the new usage still not having displaced the old usage as the primary definition in common dictionaries.

column1: Gambling is also a major international commercial activity
column2: with the legal gambling market totaling an estimated $335 billion in 2009. In other forms
column3: gambling can be conducted with materials which have a value
column4: but are not real money. For example
column5: players of marbles games might wager marbles
column6: and likewise games of Pogs or Magic: The Gathering can be played with the collectible game pieces (respectively
column7: small discs and trading cards) as stakes

column1: 22~1~Germanic languages~2299~2307~"The Germanic languages are a branch of the Indo-European language family spoken natively by a population of about 515 million people mainly in Europe
column2: North America
column3: Oceania
column4: and Southern Africa.

column1: 23~1~Gold medal~30733~30744~"A gold medal is a medal awarded for highest achievement in a non-military field. Its name derives from the use of at least a fraction of gold in form of plating or alloying in its manufacture.

column2: gold medals have been awarded in the arts
column3: for example

column5: the United States Congressional Gold Medal and the Nobel Prize medal. Nobel Prize medals consist of 18 karat green gold plated with 24 karat gold. Before 1980 they were struck in 23 karat gold."~0.13400785879860685

column1: 24~1~Grass~10348~10353~"Poaceae (Poe-ay-see-ay) or Gramineae (Grammy-nee-ay) is a large and nearly ubiquitous family of monocotyledonous flowering plants known as grasses. Poaceae includes the cereal grasses
column2: bamboos and the grasses of natural grassland and cultivated lawns and pasture. Grasses have stems that are hollow except at the nodes and narrow alternate leaves borne in two ranks. The lower part of each leaf encloses the stem
column3: forming a leaf-sheath. With around 780 genera and around 12
column4: 000 species
column5: Poaceae are the fifth-largest plant family
column6: following the Asteraceae
column7: Orchidaceae
column8: Fabaceae and Rubiaceae.

column1: Grasslands such as savannah and prairie where grasses are dominant are estimated to constitute 40.5% of the land area of the Earth
column2: excluding Greenland and Antarctica. Grasses are also an important part of the vegetation in many other habitats
column3: including wetlands
column4: forests and tundra. The Poaceae are the most economically important plant family

column6: wheat
column7: rice
column8: barley
column9: and millet as well as forage
column10: building materials (bamboo
column11: thatch
column12: straw) and fuel (ethanol).

column1: Though they are commonly called ""grasses""

column5: being members of the order Poales
column6: but the seagrasses are members of order Alismatales."~0.09785241741432282

column1: 25~1~Half marathon~1515~1528~"A half marathon is a road running event of 21.0975 km (13 mi 192½ yd)—half the distance of a marathon. It is common for a half marathon event to be held concurrently with a marathon
column2: using almost the same course with a late start

column5: 21.1K or 13.1 miles
column6: although these values are rounded and not formally correct.

column4: and for women is 1:04:51

column7: in Valencia
column8: Spain.

column1: 29~1~Hurdling~8639~8647~"Hurdling is the act of running and jumping over an obstacle at speed. In the early 19th century
column2: hurdlers ran at and jumped over each hurdle
column3: landing on both feet and checking their forward motion. After experimenting with different step patterns the 3-step for high hurdles
column4: 7-step for low hurdles
column5: and 15-step for intermediate hurdles was decided on. In the sport of athletics
column6: hurdling forms the basis of a number track and field events which are a highly specialized form of obstacle racing. In these events
column7: a series of barriers known as hurdles are set at precisely measured heights and distances which each athlete must pass by running over. Failure to pass over
column8: by passing under
column9: or intentionally knocking over hurdles will result in disqualification. Accidental knocking over of hurdles is not cause for disqualification

column12: the athlete could hit the hurdle and it will tip down

column1: The most prominent hurdles events are 110 meters hurdles for men

column6: including the decathlon and heptathlon.

column1: In track races
column2: hurdles are normally between 68–107 cm in height (or 27-42 inches)
column3: and vary depending on the age and gender of the hurdler. Events from 50 to 110 meters are technically known as high hurdles races
column4: while longer competitions are low hurdles races. The track hurdles events are forms of sprinting competitions
column5: although the 400 m version is less anaerobic in nature and demands athletic qualities similar to the 800 meters flat race.

column1: A hurdling technique can also be found in the steeplechase
column2: although in this event athletes are also permitted to step on the barrier to clear it. Similarly
column3: in cross country running athletes may hurdle over various natural obstacles
column4: such as logs
column5: mounds of earth and small streams – this represents the sporting origin of the modern events. Horse racing has its own variant of hurdle racing
column6: with similar principles."~0.3363641719279288

column1: 30~1~Ireland~3249~3256~"Ireland ( ( listen); Irish: Éire [ˈeːɾʲə] ( listen); Ulster-Scots: Airlann [ˈɑːrlən]) is an island in the North Atlantic. It is separated from Great Britain to its east by the North Channel
column2: the Irish Sea
column3: and St George's Channel. Ireland is the third-largest island in Europe.

column1: Politically

column3: which covers five-sixths of the island

column5: which is part of the United Kingdom. In 2011
column6: the population of Ireland was about 6.6 million
column7: ranking it the second-most populous island in Europe after Great Britain. Just under 4.8 million live in the Republic of Ireland and just over 1.8 million live in Northern Ireland.

column1: The island's geography comprises relatively low-lying mountains surrounding a central plain
column2: with several navigable rivers extending inland. Its lush vegetation is a product of its mild but changeable climate which is free of extremes in temperature. It was covered by thick woodlands until the Middle Ages. As of 2013

column4: compared with a European average of 35%. There are twenty-six extant mammal species native to Ireland. The Irish climate is influenced by the Atlantic Ocean and thus very moderate
column5: and winters are milder than expected for such a northerly area
column6: although summers are cooler than those in Continental Europe. Rainfall and cloud cover are abundant.

column1: The earliest evidence of human presence in Ireland is dated at 10
column2: 500 BC. Gaelic Ireland had emerged by the 1st century AD. The island was Christianised from the 5th century onward. Following the 12th century Norman invasion
column3: the England claimed sovereignty. However
column4: English rule did not extend over the whole island until the 16th–17th century Tudor conquest
column5: which led to colonisation by settlers from Britain. In the 1690s
column6: a system of Protestant English rule was designed to materially disadvantage the Catholic majority and Protestant dissenters
column7: and was extended during the 18th century. With the Acts of Union in 1801
column8: Ireland became a part of the United Kingdom. A war of independence in the early 20th century was followed by the partition of the island
column9: creating the Irish Free State
column10: which became increasingly sovereign over the following decades
column11: and Northern Ireland
column12: which remained a part of the United Kingdom. Northern Ireland saw much civil unrest from the late 1960s until the 1990s. This subsided following a political agreement in 1998. In 1973 the Republic of Ireland joined the European Economic Community while the United Kingdom
column13: and Northern Ireland
column14: as part of it
column15: did the same.

column1: Irish culture has had a significant influence on other cultures
column2: especially in the fields of literature. Alongside mainstream Western culture
column3: a strong indigenous culture exists
column4: as expressed through Gaelic games

column9: horse racing

column1: 31~1~Japan~12593~12598~"Japan (Japanese: 日本 Nippon [ɲippoɴ] or Nihon [ɲihoɴ]; formally 日本国  Nippon-koku or Nihon-koku

column1: The kanji
column2: or Sino-Japanese characters

column5: 852 islands. The four largest are Honshu

column7: Kyushu

column10: with Hokkaido being the northernmost prefecture and Okinawa being the southernmost one. The population of 127 million is the world's tenth largest. Japanese people make up 98.5% of Japan's total population. About 9.1 million people live in Tokyo

column1: Archaeological research indicates that Japan was inhabited as early as the Upper Paleolithic period. The first written mention of Japan is in Chinese history texts from the 1st century AD. Influence from other regions

column3: followed by periods of isolation
column4: particularly from Western Europe

column1: From the 12th century until 1868

column6: the Russo-Japanese War and World War I allowed Japan to expand its empire during a period of increasing militarism. The Second Sino-Japanese War of 1937 expanded into part of World War II in 1941
column7: which came to an end in 1945 following the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki and the Japanese surrender. Since adopting its revised constitution on May 3

column1: The country benefits from a highly skilled workforce and is among the most highly educated countries in the world

Its population enjoys the highest life expectancy and the third lowest infant mortality rate in the world. Japan is renowned for its historical and extensive cinema

column1: 33~1~Journalism~31510~31520~"Journalism is the production and the distribution of reports on recent events. The word journalism applies to the occupation (professional or not)
column2: the methods of gathering information
column3: and the organizing literary styles. Journalistic media include: print
column4: television
column5: radio
column6: Internet
column7: and
column8: in the past
column9: newsreels.

column1: Concepts of the appropriate role for journalism vary between countries. In some nations
column2: the news media is controlled by a government intervention
column3: and is not a fully independent body. In others
column4: the news media is independent from the government but the profit motive is in tension with constitutional protections of freedom of the press. Access to freely available information gathered by independent and competing journalistic enterprises with transparent editorial standards can enable citizens to effectively participate in the political process. In the United States
column5: journalism is protected by the freedom of the press clause in the First Amendment.

column1: The role and status of journalism
column2: along with that of the mass media
column3: has undergone changes over the last two decades
column4: together with the advancement of digital technology and publication of news on the Internet. This has created a shift in the consumption of print media channels
column5: as people increasingly consume news through e-readers
column6: smartphones
column7: and other electronic devices. News organizations are challenged to fully monetize their digital wing
column8: as well as improvise on the context in which they publish news in print. Notably
column9: in the American media landscape
column10: newsrooms have reduced their staff and coverage as traditional media channels
column11: such as television
column12: grapple with declining audiences. For example
column13: between 2007 and 2012
column14: CNN edited its story packages into nearly half of their original time length.

column1: This compactness in coverage has been linked to broad audience attrition
column2: as a large majority of respondents in recent studies show changing preferences in news consumption. The digital era has also ushered in a new kind of journalism in which ordinary citizens play a greater role in the process of news making
column3: with the rise of citizen journalism being possible through the Internet. Using video camera equipped smartphones
column4: active citizens are now enabled to record footage of news events and upload them onto channels like YouTube

column6: easy access to news from a variety of online sources
column7: like blogs and other social media
column8: has resulted in readers being able to pick from a wider choice of official and unofficial sources
column9: instead of only from traditional media organizations."~0.25306588780239236

column3: and 400 meter races. She also competed in cycling at those games. She attempted to qualify for the ""Able Bodied"" Olympics at the 1996 U. S. Olympic Trials
column4: finishing 10th in the Heptathlon. While failing to qualify
column5: she ran the 800 meters in 2:04.60
column6: a heptathlon-800m American record. This success convinced her to try distance running. At the 1996 Paralympics in Atlanta
column7: she took silver in the shot put and gold in the pentathlon.

column1: Her career as a world-class runner in able-bodied events began in 1999 at the Pan American Games in Winnipeg
column2: where she won Gold in the 1
column3: 500-meter race and was ranked second in the United States in that event in 1999 by Track and Field News. . The next year
column4: she placed eighth in the 1
column5: 500-meter in the 2000 Sydney Olympics
column6: making Runyan the first legally blind athlete to compete in the Olympics and the highest finish by an American woman in that event.

column1: She finished as the top American at the 2002 New York Marathon with a time of 2 hours
column2: 27 minutes and 10 seconds to post the second-fastest debut time ever by an American woman.

column1: I just think it's pretty brave
column2: Marla's very tough
column3: really gutsy. She's been fighting all of her life
column4: and it comes out in her running.""

column1: Being an international medalist at 1500 metres and a top major marathon runner is an accomplishment over a wide variety of distances rivaled only by Rod Dixon on the men's side. Medaling at distances as short as 100 metres and diversely explosive events like Shot Put and Long Jump is remarkable versatility.

She won the road 5K again in 2003 and qualified for the 2004 Summer Olympic Games by finishing second in the United States Olympic Trials (track and field). She took 2005 off to give birth to her first child
