column1: 42~1~Millrose Games~20577~20591~The Millrose Games is an annual indoor athletics meet (track and field) held each February in New York City. They started taking place at the Armory in Washington Heights in 2012
column2: after having taken place in Madison Square Garden from 1914 to 2011. The games were started when employees of the New York City branch of Wanamaker's department store formed the Millrose Track Club to hold a meet. The featured event is the Wanamaker Mile.~0.3434213403549749

column1: 43~1~Modern pentathlon~14286~14303~"The modern pentathlon is an Olympic sport that comprises five different events; fencing (one-touch épée)
column2: freestyle swimming (200m)
column3: equestrian show jumping (15 jumps)
column4: and a final combined event of pistol shooting and cross country running (3200m). This last event is now referred to as the laser-run
column5: since it alternates four legs of laser pistol shooting followed by an 800m run (for 3200m in total). The event is inspired by the traditional pentathlon held during the ancient Olympics; as the original events were patterned on the skills needed by an ideal Greek soldier of the era
column6: the modern pentathlon is similarly patterned on events representing the skills needed by cavalry behind enemy lines.

column1: The sport has been a core sport of the Olympic Games since 1912 despite attempts to remove it. A world championships for modern pentathlon has been held annually since 1949.
Originally the competition took place over four or five days; in 1996 a one-day format was adopted in an effort to be more audience-friendly. Modern pentathlon
column2: despite its long Olympic history
column3: has had to justify its inclusion in the modern Olympic Games several times. On February 11
column4: 2013 in Lausanne
column5: the IOC confirmed modern pentathlon once again as one of the 25 core sports of the Olympic program through to 2020. The governing body
column6: Union Internationale de Pentathlon Moderne (UIPM)
column7: administers the international sport in more than 90 countries in all the continents of the world.

column1:
~0.36000378637632124
44~1~Navigation~14638~14648~Navigation is a field of study that focuses on the process of monitoring and controlling the movement of a craft or vehicle from one place to another. The field of navigation includes four general categories: land navigation
column2: marine navigation
column3: aeronautic navigation
column4: and space navigation.

column1: It is also the term of art used for the specialized knowledge used by navigators to perform navigation tasks. All navigational techniques involve locating the navigator's position compared to known locations or patterns.
Navigation
column2: in a broader sense
column3: can refer to any skill or study that involves the determination of position and direction. In this sense
column4: navigation includes orienteering and pedestrian navigation."~0.06326692228492212

column1: 45~1~Olympic Games~828~841~"The modern Olympic Games or Olympics (French: Jeux olympiques) are leading international sporting events featuring summer and winter sports competitions in which thousands of athletes from around the world participate in a variety of competitions. The Olympic Games are considered the world's foremost sports competition with more than 200 nations participating. The Olympic Games are held every four years
column2: with the Summer and Winter Games alternating by occurring every four years but two years apart.

column1: Their creation was inspired by the ancient Olympic Games
column2: which were held in Olympia
column3: Greece
column4: from the 8th century BC to the 4th century AD. Baron Pierre de Coubertin founded the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in 1894
column5: leading to the first modern Games in Athens in 1896. The IOC is the governing body of the Olympic Movement
column6: with the Olympic Charter defining its structure and authority.

column1: The evolution of the Olympic Movement during the 20th and 21st centuries has resulted in several changes to the Olympic Games. Some of these adjustments include the creation of the Winter Olympic Games for ice and winter sports
column2: the Paralympic Games for athletes with a disability
column3: and the Youth Olympic Games for teenage athletes. The Deaflympics and Special Olympics are also endorsed by the IOC. The IOC has had to adapt to a variety of economic
column4: political
column5: and technological advancements.

column1: The advent of the state-sponsored ""full-time amateur athlete"" of the Eastern Bloc countries further eroded the ideology of the pure amateur
column2: as it put the self-financed amateurs of the Western countries at a disadvantage. The Soviet Union entered teams of athletes who were all nominally students
column3: soldiers
column4: or working in a profession
column5: but many of whom were in reality paid by the state to train on a full-time basis. As a result
column6: the Olympics has shifted away from pure amateurism
column7: as envisioned by Coubertin
column8: to allowing participation of professional athletes. The growing importance of mass media created the issue of corporate sponsorship and commercialisation of the Games. World wars led to the cancellation of the 1916
column10: and 1944 Games. Large boycotts during the Cold War limited participation in the 1980 and 1984 Games. The latter
column11: however
column12: attracted 140 National Olympic Committees
column13: which was a record at the time.

column1: The Olympic Movement consists of international sports federations (IFs)
column2: National Olympic Committees (NOCs)
column3: and organising committees for each specific Olympic Games. As the decision-making body
column4: the IOC is responsible for choosing the host city for each Games
column5: and organises and funds the Games according to the Olympic Charter. The IOC also determines the Olympic programme
column6: consisting of the sports to be contested at the Games. There are several Olympic rituals and symbols
column7: such as the Olympic flag and torch
column8: as well as the opening and closing ceremonies. Over 13
column9: 000 athletes compete at the Summer and Winter Olympic Games in 33 different sports and nearly 400 events. The first
column10: second
column11: and third-place finishers in each event receive Olympic medals: gold
column12: silver
column13: and bronze
column14: respectively.

column1: The Games have grown so much that nearly every nation is now represented. This growth has created numerous challenges and controversies
column2: including boycotts
column3: doping
column4: bribery
column5: and a terrorist attack in 1972. Every two years the Olympics and its media exposure provide unknown athletes with the chance to attain national and sometimes international fame. The Games also constitute an opportunity for the host city and country to showcase themselves to the world."~0.37767067117916475

column1: 46~1~Orienteering~14534~14546~"Orienteering is a group of sports that requires navigational skills using a map and compass to navigate from point to point in diverse and usually unfamiliar terrain whilst moving at speed. Participants are given a topographical map
column2: usually a specially prepared orienteering map
column3: which they use to find control points. Originally a training exercise in land navigation for military officers
column4: orienteering has developed many variations. Among these
column5: the oldest and the most popular is foot orienteering. For the purposes of this article
column6: foot orienteering serves as a point of departure for discussion of all other variations
column7: but almost any sport that involves racing against a clock and requires navigation with a map is a type of orienteering.

column1: Orienteering is included in the programs of world sporting events including the World Games (see Orienteering at the World Games) and World Police and Fire Games."~0.34630487836809254

47~1~Oscar Pistorius~18524~18539~"Oscar Leonard Carl Pistorius OIB (; Afrikaans pronunciation: [pisˈtɔrjus]; born 22 November 1986) is a South African former sprint runner and convicted murderer. Both of Pistorius's legs were amputated below the knee when he was 11 months old. He was the tenth athlete to compete at both the Paralympic Games and Olympic Games
column2: competing in sprint events for below-knee amputees in Paralympic events
column3: and in non-disabled sprint events.

column1: After becoming a Paralympic champion
column2: Pistorius attempted to enter non-disabled international competition
column3: over persistent objections of the IAAF and charges that his artificial limbs gave an unfair advantage. Pistorius eventually prevailed in this legal dispute. At the 2011 World Championships in Athletics
column4: Pistorius became the first amputee to win a non-disabled world track medal. At the 2012 Summer Olympics
column5: Pistorius became the first double-leg amputee to participate in the Olympics.

column1: On Valentine's Day in 2013
column2: Pistorius fatally shot his girlfriend
column3: model Reeva Steenkamp
column4: in his Pretoria home. He claimed he had mistaken Steenkamp for an intruder hiding in the bathroom
column5: but he was arrested and charged with murder. At his trial the following year
column6: Pistorius was found guilty of culpable homicide. He received a five-year prison sentence for culpable homicide and a concurrent three-year suspended prison sentence for a separate reckless endangerment conviction.

column1: In November 2014
column2: prosecutors asked the sentencing judge for permission to appeal the verdict. Permission was granted in December
column3: and the case was presented to a five-person panel at the Supreme Court of Appeal. He was released on house arrest
column4: and on 3 December 2015 the Appeal Court overturned the culpable homicide verdict and convicted him of murder. Pistorius appeared in court on 13 June 2016 to start the sentence hearing for the murder conviction which concluded on 15 June 2016 after Judge Thokozile Masipa adjourned the sentencing until 6 July 2016 when she extended Pistorius's sentence to six years. On Appeal by the state for a longer prison sentence
column5: the Supreme Court of Appeal more than doubled Pistorius's prison term to 13 years and five months."~0.28024877215994914

column1: 48~1~Paralympic Games~5873~5889~"The Paralympic Games is a major international multi-sport event involving athletes with a range of disabilities
column2: including impaired muscle power (e.g. paraplegia and quadriplegia
column3: muscular dystrophy
column4: post-polio syndrome
column5: spina bifida)
column6: impaired passive range of movement
column7: limb deficiency (e.g. amputation or dysmelia)
column8: leg length difference
column9: short stature
column10: hypertonia
column11: ataxia
column12: athetosis
column13: vision impairment and intellectual impairment. There are Winter and Summer Paralympic Games
column14: which since the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul
column15: South Korea
column16: are held almost immediately following the respective Olympic Games. All Paralympic Games are governed by the International Paralympic Committee (IPC).

column1: The Paralympics has grown from a small gathering of British World War II veterans in 1948 to become one of the largest international sporting events by the early 21st century. The Paralympics has grown from 400 athletes with a disability from 23 countries in 1960 to thousands of competitors from over 100 countries in the London 2012 Games. Paralympians strive for equal treatment with non-disabled Olympic athletes
column2: but there is a large funding gap between Olympic and Paralympic athletes.

column1: The Paralympic Games are organized in parallel with the Olympic Games
column2: while the IOC-recognized Special Olympics World Games include athletes with intellectual disabilities
column3: and the Deaflympics include deaf athletes.

column1: Given the wide variety of disabilities that Paralympic athletes have
column2: there are several categories in which the athletes compete. The allowable disabilities are broken down into ten eligible impairment types. The categories are impaired muscle power
column3: impaired passive range of movement
column4: limb deficiency
column5: leg length difference
column6: short stature
column7: hypertonia
column8: ataxia
column9: athetosis
column10: vision impairment and intellectual impairment. These categories are further broken down into classifications
column11: which vary from sport to sport."~0.3561905087344855

column1: 49~1~Paralympic Winter Games~27280~27303~"The Winter Paralympic Games is an international multi-sport event where athletes with physical disabilities compete in snow & ice sports. This includes athletes with mobility disabilities
column2: amputations
column3: blindness
column4: and cerebral palsy. The Winter Paralympic Games are held every four years directly following the Winter Olympic Games. The Winter Paralympics are also hosted by the city that hosted the Winter Olympics. The International Paralympic Committee (IPC) oversees the Winter Paralympics. Medals are awarded in each event: with gold medals for first place
column5: silver for second and bronze for third
column6: following the tradition that the Olympic Games started in 1904.

column1: The Winter Paralympics began in 1976 in Örnsköldsvik
column2: Sweden. Those Games were the first Paralympics (Summer or Winter) that featured athletes other than wheelchair athletes. The Games have expanded and grown to be (along with the Summer Games) part of the largest international sporting event after the Olympic Games. Given their expansion
column3: the need for a very specific classification system has arisen. This system has also given rise to controversy and opened the door for cheating. Winter Paralympians have also been convicted of steroid use and other forms of cheating unique to Paralympic athletes
column4: which has tainted the integrity of the Games."~0.22926304541403258

column1: 50~1~Park~21214~21218~"A park is an area of natural
column2: semi-natural or planted space set aside for human enjoyment and recreation or for the protection of wildlife or natural habitats. It may consist of grassy areas
column3: rocks
column4: soil and trees
column5: but may also contain buildings and other artifacts such as monuments
column6: fountains or playground structures. In North America
column7: many parks have fields for playing sports such as association football
column8: baseball and football
column9: and paved areas for games such as basketball. Many parks have trails for walking
column10: biking and other activities. Some parks are built adjacent to bodies of water or watercourses and may comprise a beach or boat dock area. Often
column11: the smallest parks are in urban areas
column12: where a park may take up only a city block or less and is ideally within a 10-Minute Walk of its residents. Urban parks often have benches for sitting and may contain picnic tables and barbecue grills. Parks have differing rules regarding whether dogs can be brought into the park: some parks prohibit dogs; some parks allow them with restrictions (e.g.
column13: use of a leash); and some parks
column14: which may be called ""dog parks""
column15: permit dogs to run off-leash.

column1: The largest parks can be vast natural areas of hundreds of thousands of square kilometers (thousands of square miles)
column2: with abundant wildlife and natural features such as mountains and rivers. There are also amusement parks which have live shows
column3: fairground rides
column4: refreshments
column5: and games of chance/skill. Amusement parks are the largest types of park in the world. In many large parks
column6: camping in tents is allowed with a permit. Many natural parks are protected by law
column7: and users may have to follow restrictions (e.g.
column8: rules against open fires or bringing in glass bottles). Large national and sub-national parks are typically overseen by a park ranger or a park warden. Large parks may have areas for canoeing and hiking in the warmer months and
column9: in some northern hemisphere countries
column10: cross-country skiing and snowshoeing in colder months."~0.12265788834802238

column1: 51~1~Periodical~31555~31566~Periodical literature (also called a periodical publication or simply a periodical) is a published work that appears in a new edition on a regular schedule. The most familiar example is the magazine
column2: typically published weekly
column3: monthly
column4: or quarterly. Newspapers
column5: often published daily or weekly
column6: are
column7: strictly speaking
column8: serials
column9: not periodicals. Other examples of periodicals are newsletters
column10: literary magazines (literary journals)
column11: academic journals (including scientific journals)
column12: science magazines

column1: 52~1~Physical disability~1560~1579~A physical disability is a limitation on a person's physical functioning

column4: such as respiratory disorders
column5: blindness
column6: epilepsy and sleep disorders.~0.12816482696364434

column1: 53~1~Pole vault~9175~9185~"Pole vaulting is a track and field event in which a person uses a long
column2: flexible pole (which today is usually made either of fiberglass or carbon fiber) as an aid to jump over a bar. Pole jumping competitions were known to the ancient Greeks
column3: Cretans and Celts. It has been a full medal event at the Olympic Games since 1896 for men and 2000 for women.

column1: It is typically classified as one of the four major jumping events in athletics
column2: alongside the high jump
column3: long jump and triple jump. It is unusual among track and field sports in that it requires a significant amount of specialised equipment in order to participate
column4: even at a basic level. A number of elite pole vaulters have had backgrounds in gymnastics
column5: including world record breakers Yelena Isinbayeva and Brian Sternberg
column6: reflecting the similar physical attributes required for the sports. Running speed
column7: however
column8: may be the most dominant factor."~0.28548850078406546

column1: 54~1~Pottery~30063~30070~"Pottery is the ceramic material which makes up pottery wares
column2: of which major types include earthenware
column3: stoneware and porcelain. The place where such wares are made by a potter is also called a pottery (plural ""potteries""). The definition of pottery used by the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) is ""all fired ceramic wares that contain clay when formed
column4: except technical
column5: structural
column6: and refractory products.""

column1: Pottery is one of the oldest human inventions
column2: originating before the Neolithic period
column3: with ceramic objects like the Gravettian culture Venus of Dolní Věstonice figurine discovered in the Czech Republic date back to 29
column5: 000 BC
column6: and pottery vessels that were discovered in Jiangxi
column7: China
column8: which date back to 18
column9: 000 BC. Early Neolithic pottery have been found in places such as Jōmon Japan (10
column11: the Russian Far East (14
column13: Sub-Saharan Africa and South America.

column1: Pottery is made by forming a ceramic (often clay) body into objects of a required shape and heating them to high temperatures in a kiln which removes all the water from the clay
column2: which induces reactions that lead to permanent changes including increasing their strength and hardening and setting their shape. A clay body can be decorated before or after firing; however
column3: prior to some shaping processes
column4: clay must be prepared. Kneading helps to ensure an even moisture content throughout the body. Air trapped within the clay body needs to be removed. This is called de-airing and can be accomplished either by a machine called a vacuum pug or manually by wedging. Wedging can also help produce an even moisture content. Once a clay body has been kneaded and de-aired or wedged
column5: it is shaped by a variety of techniques. After shaping
column6: it is dried and then fired."~0.0847972215670918

column1: 55~1~Prehistoric~2989~3000~"Prehistory is the period of human activity between the use of the first stone tools c. 3.3 million years ago and the invention of writing systems
column2: the earliest of which appeared c. 5
column3: 300 years ago.

column1: Sumer in Mesopotamia
column2: the Indus valley civilisation and ancient Egypt were the first civilisations to develop their own scripts
column3: and to keep historical records; this took place already during the early Bronze Age. Neighbouring civilizations were the first to follow. Most other civilizations reached the end of prehistory during the Iron Age. The three-age system of division of prehistory into the Stone Age
column4: followed by the Bronze Age and Iron Age
column5: remains in use for much of Eurasia and North Africa
column6: but is not generally used in those parts of the world where the working of hard metals arrived abruptly with contact with Eurasian cultures
column7: such as the Americas
column8: Oceania
column9: Australasia and much of Sub-Saharan Africa. These areas also
column10: with some exceptions in Pre-Columbian civilizations in the Americas
column11: did not develop complex writing systems before the arrival of Eurasians
column12: and their prehistory reaches into relatively recent periods.

column1: The period when a culture is written about by others
column2: but has not developed its own writing is often known as the protohistory of the culture. By definition
column3: there are no written records from human prehistory
column4: so dating of prehistoric materials is crucial. Clear techniques for dating were not well-developed until the 19th century."~0.09793755593617831

column1: 56~1~Racewalking~2726~2737~"Racewalking
column2: or race walking
column3: is a long-distance discipline within the sport of athletics. Although it is a foot race
column4: it is different from running in that one foot must appear to be in contact with the ground at all times. This is assessed by race judges. Typically held on either roads or on running tracks
column5: common distances vary from 3000 metres (1.8 mi) up to 100 kilometres (62.1 mi).

column1: There are two racewalking distances contested at the Summer Olympics: the 20 kilometres race walk (men and women) and 50 kilometres race walk (men only). Both are held as road events. The biennial IAAF World Championships in Athletics also features these three events
column2: in addition to a 50 km walk for women. The IAAF World Race Walking Cup
column3: first held in 1961
column4: is a stand-alone global competition for the discipline and it has 10 kilometres race walks for junior athletes
column5: in addition to the Olympic-standard events. The IAAF World Indoor Championships featured 5000 m and 3000 m race walk variations
column6: but these were discontinued after 1993. Top level athletics championships and games typically feature 20 km racewalking events.

column1: The sport emerged from a British culture of long-distance competitive walking known as pedestrianism
column2: which began to develop the ruleset that is the basis of the modern discipline around the mid-19th century. Since the mid-20th century onwards
column3: Russian and Chinese athletes have been among the most successful on the global stage
column4: with Europe and parts of Latin America producing most of the remaining top level walkers.

column1: Compared to other forms of foot racing
column2: stride length is reduced; to achieve competitive speeds racewalkers must attain cadence rates comparable to those achieved by world-class 800 metres runners."~0.3778079688082411

column1: 57~1~Racing~250~256~"In sport
column2: racing is a competition of speed
column3: against an objective criterion
column4: usually a clock or to a specific point. The competitors in a race try to complete a given task in the shortest amount of time. Typically this involves traversing some distance
column5: but it can be any other task involving speed to reach a specific goal.

column1: A race may be run continuously to finish or may be made of several segments called heats
column2: stages or legs. A heat is usually run over the same course at different times. A stage is a shorter section of a much longer course or a time trial.

column1: Early records of races are evident on pottery from ancient Greece
column2: which depicted running men vying for first place. A chariot race is described in Homer's Iliad."~0.32218177172173723

column1: 58~1~Rain~11986~11990~"Rain is liquid water in the form of droplets that have condensed from atmospheric water vapor and then becomes heavy enough to fall under gravity. Rain is a major component of the water cycle and is responsible for depositing most of the fresh water on the Earth. It provides suitable conditions for many types of ecosystems
column2: as well as water for hydroelectric power plants and crop irrigation.

column1: The major cause of rain production is moisture moving along three-dimensional zones of temperature and moisture contrasts known as weather fronts. If enough moisture and upward motion is present
column2: precipitation falls from convective clouds (those with strong upward vertical motion) such as cumulonimbus (thunder clouds) which can organize into narrow rainbands. In mountainous areas
column3: heavy precipitation is possible where upslope flow is maximized within windward sides of the terrain at elevation which forces moist air to condense and fall out as rainfall along the sides of mountains. On the leeward side of mountains
column4: desert climates can exist due to the dry air caused by downslope flow which causes heating and drying of the air mass. The movement of the monsoon trough
column5: or intertropical convergence zone
column6: brings rainy seasons to savannah climes.

column1: The urban heat island effect leads to increased rainfall
column2: both in amounts and intensity
column3: downwind of cities. Global warming is also causing changes in the precipitation pattern globally
column4: including wetter conditions across eastern North America and drier conditions in the tropics. Antarctica is the driest continent. The globally averaged annual precipitation over land is 715 mm (28.1 in)
column5: but over the whole Earth it is much higher at 990 mm (39 in). Climate classification systems such as the Köppen classification system use average annual rainfall to help differentiate between differing climate regimes. Rainfall is measured using rain gauges. Rainfall amounts can be estimated by weather radar.

column1: Rain is also known or suspected on other planets
column2: where it may be composed of methane
column3: neon
column4: sulfuric acid
column5: or even iron rather than water."~0.08315642580938842

column1: 59~1~Road~10607~10612~"A road is a thoroughfare
column2: route
column3: or way on land between two places that has been paved or otherwise improved to allow travel by foot or some form of conveyance
column4: including a motor vehicle
column5: cart
column6: bicycle
column7: or horse.

column1: Roads consist of one or two roadways (British English: carriageways)
column2: each with one or more lanes and any associated sidewalks (British English: pavement) and road verges. In countries like the Netherlands and Denmark there is often a bike path provided for cycling.

column1: Roads available for use by the public may be referred to as parkways
column2: avenues
column3: freeways
column4: interstates
column5: highways
column6: or primary
column7: secondary
column8: and tertiary local roads."~0.0879749241889487

column1: 60~1~Romance languages~2312~2329~"The Romance languages (sometimes called the Romanic languages
column2: Latin languages
column3: or Neo-Latin languages) are the modern languages that evolved from Vulgar Latin between the sixth and ninth centuries and that thus form a branch of the Italic languages within the Indo-European language family.

column3: French (150 million)

column5: and Romanian (25 million).

column1: 61~1~Running~70~77~"Running is a method of terrestrial locomotion allowing humans and other animals to move rapidly on foot. Running is a type of gait characterized by an aerial phase in which all feet are above the ground (though there are exceptions). This is in contrast to walking
column2: where one foot is always in contact with the ground
column3: the legs are kept mostly straight and the center of gravity vaults over the stance leg or legs in an inverted pendulum fashion. A characteristic feature of a running body from the viewpoint of spring-mass mechanics is that changes in kinetic and potential energy within a stride occur simultaneously
column4: with energy storage accomplished by springy tendons and passive muscle elasticity. The term running can refer to any of a variety of speeds ranging from jogging to sprinting.

column1: It is assumed that the ancestors of humankind developed the ability to run for long distances about 2.6 million years ago
column2: probably in order to hunt animals. Competitive running grew out of religious festivals in various areas. Records of competitive racing date back to the Tailteann Games in Ireland in 1829 BCE
column3: while the first recorded Olympic Games took place in 776 BCE. Running has been described as the world's most accessible sport."~0.6978581463051312

column5: 000 years

66~1~Sledgehammer~3826~3838~A sledgehammer is a tool with a large
column2: flat

column1: 67~1~Snow~21887~21891~"Snow refers to forms of ice crystals that precipitate from the atmosphere (usually from clouds) and undergo changes on the Earth's surface. It pertains to frozen crystalline water throughout its life cycle
column2: starting when
column3: under suitable conditions
column4: the ice crystals form in the atmosphere
column5: increase to millimeter size
column6: precipitate and accumulate on surfaces
column7: then metamorphose in place
column8: and ultimately melt
column9: slide or sublimate away. Snowstorms organize and develop by feeding on sources of atmospheric moisture and cold air. Snowflakes nucleate around particles in the atmosphere by attracting supercooled water droplets
column10: which freeze in hexagonal-shaped crystals. Snowflakes take on a variety of shapes
column11: basic among these are platelets
column12: needles
column13: columns and rime. As snow accumulates into a snowpack
column14: it may blow into drifts. Over time
column15: accumulated snow metamorphoses
column17: sublimation and freeze-thaw. Where the climate is cold enough for year-to-year accumulation
column19: snow typically melts seasonally
column20: causing runoff into streams and rivers and recharging groundwater.

column1: Major snow-prone areas include the polar regions
column2: the upper half of the Northern Hemisphere and mountainous regions worldwide with sufficient moisture and cold temperatures. In the Southern Hemisphere
column3: snow is confined primarily to mountainous areas
column4: apart from Antarctica.

column1: Snow affects such human activities as transportation: creating the need for keeping roadways
column2: wings
column3: and windows clear; agriculture: providing water to crops and safeguarding livestock; sports such as skiing
column4: snowboarding
column5: and snowmachine travel; and warfare. Snow affects ecosystems
column6: as well
column7: by providing an insulating layer during winter under which plants and animals are able to survive the cold."~0.13936664243340827

column1: 68~1~Soil~12948~12953~"Soil is a mixture of organic matter
column2: minerals
column3: gases
column4: liquids
column5: and organisms that together support life. The Earth's body of soil is the pedosphere
column6: which has four important functions: it is a medium for plant growth; it is a means of water storage
column7: supply and purification; it is a modifier of Earth's atmosphere; it is a habitat for organisms; all of which
column8: in turn
column9: modify the soil.

column1: Soil interfaces with the lithosphere
column2: the hydrosphere
column3: the atmosphere
column4: and the biosphere. The term pedolith
column5: used commonly to refer to the soil
column6: literally translates ground stone. Soil consists of a solid phase of minerals and organic matter (the soil matrix)
column7: as well as a porous phase that holds gases (the soil atmosphere) and water (the soil solution). Accordingly
column8: soils are often treated as a three-state system of solids
column9: liquids
column10: and gases.

column1: Soil is a product of the influence of climate
column2: relief (elevation
column3: orientation
column4: and slope of terrain)
column5: organisms
column6: and its parent materials (original minerals) interacting over time. It continually undergoes development by way of numerous physical
column7: chemical and biological processes
column8: which include weathering with associated erosion. Given its complexity and strong internal connectedness
column9: it is considered an ecosystem by soil ecologists.

column1: Most soils have a dry bulk density (density of soil taking into account voids when dry) between 1.1 and 1.6 g/cm3
column2: while the soil particle density is much higher
column3: in the range of 2.6 to 2.7 g/cm3. Little of the soil of planet Earth is older than the Pleistocene and none is older than the Cenozoic
column4: although fossilized soils are preserved from as far back as the Archean.

column1: Soil science has two basic branches of study: edaphology and pedology. Edaphology is concerned with the influence of soils on living things. Pedology is focused on the formation
column2: description (morphology)
column3: and classification of soils in their natural environment. In engineering terms
column4: soil is included in the broader concept of regolith
column5: which also includes other loose material that lies above the bedrock. Soil is commonly referred to as earth or dirt; technically
column6: the term dirt should be restricted to displaced soil."~0.11501277978238374

column1: 69~1~Sport~29~37~"Sport (British English) or sports (American English) includes all forms of competitive physical activity or games which
column2: through casual or organised participation
column3: aim to use
column4: maintain or improve physical ability and skills while providing enjoyment to participants
column5: and in some cases
column6: entertainment for spectators. Usually the contest or game is between two sides
column7: each attempting to exceed the other. Some sports allow a tie game; others provide tie-breaking methods
column8: to ensure one winner and one loser. A number of such two-sided contests may be arranged in a tournament producing a champion. Many sports leagues make an annual champion by arranging games in a regular sports season
column9: followed in some cases by playoffs. Hundreds of sports exist
column10: from those between single contestants
column11: through to those with hundreds of simultaneous participants
column12: either in teams or competing as individuals. In certain sports such as racing
column13: many contestants may compete
column14: each against each other
column15: with one winner.

column1: Sport is generally recognised as system of activities which are based in physical athleticism or physical dexterity
column2: with the largest major competitions such as the Olympic Games admitting only sports meeting this definition
column3: and other organisations such as the Council of Europe using definitions precluding activities without a physical element from classification as sports. However
column4: a number of competitive
column5: but non-physical
column6: activities claim recognition as mind sports. The International Olympic Committee (through ARISF) recognises both chess and bridge as bona fide sports

column9: recognises five non-physical sports: bridge
column10: chess
column11: draughts (checkers)
column12: Go and xiangqi
column13: and limits the number of mind games which can be admitted as sports.

column1: Sports are usually governed by a set of rules or customs
column2: which serve to ensure fair competition
column3: and allow consistent adjudication of the winner. Winning can be determined by physical events such as scoring goals or crossing a line first. It can also be determined by judges who are scoring elements of the sporting performance
column4: including objective or subjective measures such as technical performance or artistic impression.

column4: with spectator sport drawing large crowds to sport venues
column5: and reaching wider audiences through broadcasting. Sports betting is in some cases severely regulated

column4: while association football is its most popular spectator sport."~0.521638118992487

column1: 73~1~Summer Olympics~1224~1239~"The Summer Olympic Games (French: Jeux olympiques d'été) or the Games of the Olympiad

column2: 238 competitors (6

column14: Italy (1960)
column15: Japan (1964)
column17: Canada (1976)

column5: interchanges

column1: 78~1~United States~2656~2669~"The United States of America (USA)
column2: commonly known as the United States (U.S.) or America
column3: is a federal republic composed of 50 states
column4: a federal district

column6: and various possessions. At 3.8 million square miles (9.8 million km2) and with over 325 million people

column8: D.C.
column9: and the largest city by population is New York City. Forty-eight states and the capital's federal district are contiguous and located in North America between Canada and Mexico. The state of Alaska is in the northwest corner of North America
column10: bordered by Canada to the east and across the Bering Strait from Russia to the west. The state of Hawaii is an archipelago in the mid-Pacific Ocean. The U.S. territories are scattered about the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea

column1: Paleo-Indians migrated from Siberia to the North American mainland at least 15
column2: 000 years ago. European colonization began in the 16th century. The United States emerged from the thirteen British colonies established along the East Coast. Numerous disputes between Great Britain and the colonies following the French and Indian War led to the American Revolution
column3: which began in 1775
column4: and the subsequent Declaration of Independence in 1776. The war ended in 1783 with the United States becoming the first country to gain independence from a European power. The current constitution was adopted in 1788

column18: and a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council. During the Cold War

column1: The United States is a founding member of the United Nations

column3: International Monetary Fund
column4: Organization of American States (OAS)
column5: and other international organizations. The United States is a highly developed country

column16: making up a third of global military spending

column19: and scientific force internationally."~0.1564843640471021

column1: 80~1~Visual impairment~6974~6991~"Visual impairment

Visual impairment may cause people difficulties with normal daily activities such as driving

column2: cataracts (33%)

column1: 83~1~Winter~8155~8161~Winter is the coldest season of the year in polar and temperate zones (winter does not occur in the tropical zone). column6: the sun is at its farthest below the horizon as measured from the pole). The day on which this occurs has the shortest day and the longest night

column1: 84~1~Woodland~12927~12935~"Woodland  ( listen) is a low-density forest forming open habitats with plenty of sunlight and limited shade. column1: 87~2~Baseball~4392~4400~"Baseball is a bat-and-ball game played between two opposing teams who take turns batting and fielding. The game proceeds when a player on the fielding team

column1: 88~2~Bowled~1759~1765~"Bowled is a method of dismissing a batsman in the sport of cricket. This method of dismissal is covered by Law 32 of the Laws of cricket.

column1: The Britannica is the oldest English-language encyclopaedia still in production. It was first published between 1768 and 1771 in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh
column2: as three volumes. The encyclopaedia grew in size: the second edition was 10 volumes
column3: and by its fourth edition (1801–1810) it had expanded to 20 volumes. Its rising stature as a scholarly work helped recruit eminent contributors

column6: the Britannica became the first encyclopaedia to adopt ""continuous revision""
column7: in which the encyclopaedia is continually reprinted
column8: with every article updated on a schedule. In March 2012
column9: Encyclopædia Britannica
column10: Inc. announced it would no longer publish printed editions
column11: and would focus instead on Encyclopædia Britannica Online.

column1: The 15th edition has a three-part structure: a 12-volume Micropædia of short articles (generally fewer than 750 words)
column2: a 17-volume Macropædia of long articles (two to 310 pages)
column3: and a single Propædia volume to give a hierarchical outline of knowledge. The Micropædia is meant for quick fact-checking and as a guide to the Macropædia; readers are advised to study the Propædia outline to understand a subject's context and to find more detailed articles. Over 70 years
column4: the size of the Britannica has remained steady
column5: with about 40 million words on half a million topics. Though published in the United States since 1901
column6: the Britannica has for the most part maintained British English spelling."~0.15962294093545776

column1: 102~2~Gambling~8721~8729~"Gambling is the wagering of money or something of value (referred to as ""the stakes"") on an event with an uncertain outcome with the primary intent of winning money or material goods. Gambling thus requires three elements be present: consideration
column2: chance and prize. The outcome of the wager is often immediate

column5: or a horse crossing the finish line

column7: allowing wagers on the outcome of a future sports contest or even an entire sports season.

column1: The term ""gaming"" in this context typically refers to instances in which the activity has been specifically permitted by law. The two words are not mutually exclusive; i.e.
column2: a ""gaming"" company offers (legal) ""gambling"" activities to the public and may be regulated by one of many gaming control boards
column3: for example
column4: the Nevada Gaming Control Board. However
column5: this distinction is not universally observed in the English-speaking world. For instance
column6: in the United Kingdom

column8: especially online gaming
column9: with the new usage still not having displaced the old usage as the primary definition in common dictionaries.

column1: Gambling is also a major international commercial activity
column2: with the legal gambling market totaling an estimated $335 billion in 2009. In other forms
column3: gambling can be conducted with materials which have a value
column4: but are not real money. For example
column5: players of marbles games might wager marbles

column1: 105~2~Gregorian calendar~5398~5416~"The Gregorian calendar is internationally the most widely used civil calendar. It is named after Pope Gregory XIII
column2: who introduced it in October 1582.

column1: It was a refinement to the Julian calendar involving an approximately 0.002% correction in the length of the calendar year. The motivation for the reform was to stop the drift of the calendar with respect to the equinoxes and solstices—particularly the northern vernal equinox
column2: which helps set the date for Easter. Transition to the Gregorian calendar would restore the holiday to the time of the year in which it was celebrated when introduced by the early Church. The reform was adopted initially by the Catholic countries of Europe. Protestants and Eastern Orthodox countries continued to use the traditional Julian calendar and adopted the Gregorian reform
column3: one by one
column4: after a time
column5: at least for civil purposes and for the sake of convenience in international trade. The last European country to adopt the reform was Greece
column6: in 1923. Many (but not all) countries that have traditionally used the Julian calendar
column7: or the Islamic or other religious calendars
column8: have come to adopt the Gregorian calendar for civil purposes.

column1: The Gregorian reform contained two parts: a reform of the Julian calendar as used prior to Pope Gregory XIII's time
column2: and a reform of the lunar cycle used by the Church with the Julian calendar to calculate the date of Easter. The reform was a modification of a proposal made by Aloysius Lilius
column3: who proposed to reduce the number of leap years that occur in every four centuries from 100 to 97
column4: by making 3 out of 4 centurial years common years instead of leap years. Lilius also produced an original and practical scheme for adjusting the epacts of the moon when calculating the annual date of Easter
column5: solving a long-standing obstacle to calendar reform.

column1: The Gregorian reform modified the Julian calendar's scheme of leap years as follows:
Every year that is exactly divisible by four is a leap year
column2: except for years that are exactly divisible by 100
column3: but these centurial years are leap years if they are exactly divisible by 400. For example
column4: the years 1700
column6: and 1900 are not leap years
column7: but the year 2000 is.

column1: In addition to the change in the mean length of the calendar year from 365.25 days (365 days 6 hours) to 365.2425 days (365 days 5 hours 49 minutes 12 seconds)
column2: a reduction of 10 minutes 48 seconds per year
column3: the Gregorian calendar reform also dealt with the accumulated difference between these lengths. The canonical Easter tables were devised at the end of the third century
column4: when the vernal equinox fell either on 20 March or 21 March depending on the year's position in the leap year cycle. As the rule was that the full moon preceding Easter was not to precede the equinox
column5: the date was fixed at 21 March for computational purposes and the earliest date for Easter was fixed at 22 March. The Gregorian calendar reproduced these conditions by removing ten days.

column1: To unambiguously specify a date
column2: dual dating or Old Style and New Style dates are sometimes used. Dual dating gives two consecutive years for a given date because of differences in the starting date of the year or to give both the Julian and the Gregorian dates. The ""Old Style"" (O.S.) and ""New Style"" (N.S.) notations indicate either that the start of the Julian year has (or has not) been adjusted to start on 1 January (even though documents written at the time use a different start of year)
column3: or that a date conforms to the (old) Julian calendar rather than the (new) Gregorian.

column1: The Gregorian calendar continued to use the previous calendar era (year-numbering system)
column2: which counts years from the traditional date of the nativity (Anno Domini)
column3: originally calculated in the 6th century by Dionysius Exiguus. This year-numbering system
column4: also known as Dionysian era or Common Era
column5: is the predominant international standard today."~0.1661543215886409

column1: 119~2~Match referee~2434~2447~"A match referee is an official appointed to oversee professional cricket matches. column1: 121~2~Metaphor~47127~47135~"A metaphor is a figure of speech that directly refers to one thing by mentioning another for rhetorical effect. It may provide clarity or identify hidden similarities between two ideas. Antithesis
column2: hyperbole
column3: metonymy and simile are all types of metaphor. One of the most commonly cited examples of a metaphor in English literature is the ""All the world's a stage"" monologue from As You Like It:

column1: This quotation expresses a metaphor because the world is not literally a stage. By asserting that the world is a stage
column2: Shakespeare uses points of comparison between the world and a stage to convey an understanding about the mechanics of the world and the behavior of the people within it.

column1: The Philosophy of Rhetoric (1937) by rhetorician I. A. Richards describes a metaphor as having two parts: the tenor and the vehicle. The tenor is the subject to which attributes are ascribed. The vehicle is the object whose attributes are borrowed. In the previous example
column2: ""the world"" is compared to a stage
column3: describing it with the attributes of ""the stage""; ""the world"" is the tenor
column4: and ""a stage"" is the vehicle; ""men and women"" is the secondary tenor
column5: and ""players"" is the secondary vehicle.

column1: Other writers employ the general terms ground and figure to denote the tenor and the vehicle. Cognitive linguistics uses the terms target and source
column2: respectively."~0

151~3~Cardiovascular disease~17388~17410~Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a class of diseases that involve the heart or blood vessels. Cardiovascular disease includes coronary artery diseases (CAD) such as angina and myocardial infarction (commonly known as a heart attack). Other CVDs include stroke

column4: smoking
column5: diabetes
column6: lack of exercise
column7: obesity
column8: high blood cholesterol
column9: poor diet
column10: and excessive alcohol consumption
column11: among others. High blood pressure results in 13% of CVD deaths
column12: while tobacco results in 9%
column13: diabetes 6%
column14: lack of exercise 6% and obesity 5%. Rheumatic heart disease may follow untreated strep throat.

column2: exercise
column3: avoidance of tobacco smoke and limiting alcohol intake. Treating risk factors
column4: such as high blood pressure
column5: blood lipids and diabetes is also beneficial. Treating people who have strep throat with antibiotics can decrease the risk of rheumatic heart disease. The effect of the use of aspirin in people who are otherwise healthy is of unclear benefit.

column5: while rates have declined in most of the developed world since the 1970s. Coronary artery disease and stroke account for 80% of CVD deaths in males and 75% of CVD deaths in females. Most cardiovascular disease affects older adults. In the United States 11% of people between 20 and 40 have CVD

column7: 71% of people between 60 and 80
column8: and 85% of people over 80 have CVD. The average age of death from coronary artery disease in the developed world is around 80 while it is around 68 in the developing world. Disease onset is typically seven to ten years earlier in men as compared to women."~0.09864697461727452

column1: 152~3~Cell Metabolism~19159~19174~"Metabolism (from Greek: μεταβολή metabolē

column3: the conversion of food/fuel to building blocks for proteins

column1: A striking feature of metabolism is the similarity of the basic metabolic pathways and components between even vastly different species. For example
column2: the set of carboxylic acids that are best known as the intermediates in the citric acid cycle are present in all known organisms
column3: being found in species as diverse as the unicellular bacterium Escherichia coli and huge multicellular organisms like elephants. These striking similarities in metabolic pathways are likely due to their early appearance in evolutionary history

column1: 153~3~Cholesterol~17008~17019~"Cholesterol (from the Ancient Greek chole- (bile) and stereos (solid)

column1: 156~3~Ecopsychology~18897~18931~"Ecopsychology studies the relationship between human beings and the natural world through ecological and psychological principles. The field seeks to develop and understand ways of expanding the emotional connection between individuals and the natural world
column2: thereby assisting individuals with developing sustainable lifestyles and remedying alienation from nature. Theodore Roszak is credited with coining the term in his 1992 book

column1: A central premise of ecopsychology is that while today the human mind is affected and shaped by the modern social world

column1: The field of ecopsychology extends beyond the conventional purview of psychology
column2: which had traditionally considered the psyche to be a matter of relevance to humans alone. Ecopsychology examines why people continue environmentally damaging behaviour
column3: and to develop methods of positive motivation for adopting sustainable practices. Evidence suggests that many environmentally damaging behaviours are addictive at some level
column4: and thus are more effectively addressed through positive emotional fulfillment rather than by inflicting shame. Other names used to refer to ecopsychology include depth ecology

column7: ecotherapy

157~3~Encyclopædia Britannica~27217~27240~The Encyclopædia Britannica (Latin for ""British Encyclopaedia"")
column2: published by Encyclopædia Britannica
column3: Inc.
column4: is a general knowledge English-language encyclopaedia. It is written by about 100 full-time editors and more than 4
column5: 000 contributors

column8: 640 pages

column1: The Britannica is the oldest English-language encyclopaedia still in production. It was first published between 1768 and 1771 in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh
column2: as three volumes. The encyclopaedia grew in size: the second edition was 10 volumes
column3: and by its fourth edition (1801–1810) it had expanded to 20 volumes. Its rising stature as a scholarly work helped recruit eminent contributors
column4: and the 9th (1875–1889) and 11th editions (1911) are landmark encyclopaedias for scholarship and literary style. Beginning with the 11th edition and following its acquisition by an American firm
column5: the Britannica shortened and simplified articles to broaden its appeal to the North American market. In 1933
column6: the Britannica became the first encyclopaedia to adopt ""continuous revision""
column7: in which the encyclopaedia is continually reprinted
column8: with every article updated on a schedule. In March 2012
column9: Encyclopædia Britannica
column10: Inc. announced it would no longer publish printed editions
column11: and would focus instead on Encyclopædia Britannica Online.

column1: The 15th edition has a three-part structure: a 12-volume Micropædia of short articles (generally fewer than 750 words)
column2: a 17-volume Macropædia of long articles (two to 310 pages)
column3: and a single Propædia volume to give a hierarchical outline of knowledge. The Micropædia is meant for quick fact-checking and as a guide to the Macropædia; readers are advised to study the Propædia outline to understand a subject's context and to find more detailed articles. Over 70 years
column4: the size of the Britannica has remained steady
column5: with about 40 million words on half a million topics. Though published in the United States since 1901
column6: the Britannica has for the most part maintained British English spelling."~0.15962294093545776

column1: 158~3~Endurance~1557~1566~"Endurance (also related to sufferance

column11: or fatigue. It is usually used in aerobic or anaerobic exercise. The definition of 'long' varies according to the type of exertion – minutes for high intensity anaerobic exercise
column12: hours or days for low intensity aerobic exercise. Training for endurance can have a negative impact on the ability to exert endurance strength unless an individual also undertakes resistance training to counteract this effect.

column1: When a person is able to accomplish or withstand a higher amount of effort than their original capabilities their endurance is increasing which to many personnel indicates progress. In looking to improve ones endurance they may slowly increase the amount of repetitions or time spent
column2: if higher repetitions are taken rapidly muscle strength improves while less endurance is gained. Increasing endurance has been proven to release endorphins resulting in a positive mind. The act of gaining endurance through physical activity has been shown to decrease anxiety
column3: depression
column4: and stress
column5: or any chronic disease in total. Although a greater endurance can assist the cardiovascular system it does not imply that any cardiovascular disease can be guaranteed to improve. ""The major metabolic consequences of the adaptations of muscle to endurance exercise are a slower utilization of muscle glycogen and blood glucose
column6: a greater reliance on fat oxidation
column7: and less lactate production during exercise of a given intensity.""

column1: The term stamina is sometimes used synonymously and interchangeably with endurance. In military settings
column2: endurance is considered the ability of a force to sustain high levels of combat potential relative to its opponent over the duration of a campaign.

column1: Endurance may also refer to an ability to keep going through a tough situation involving hardship
column2: stress

column1: 159~3~Furlong~25053~25060~"A furlong is a measure of distance in imperial units and U.S. customary units equal to one-eighth of a mile
column2: equivalent to 660 feet
column3: 220 yards
column4: 40 rods
column5: or 10 chains.

column1: Using the international definition of the inch as exactly 25.4 millimetres
column2: one furlong is 201.168 metres. However
column3: the United States does not uniformly use this conversion ratio. Older ratios are in use for surveying purposes in some states
column4: leading to variations in the length of the furlong of about two parts per million
column5: or 0.4 millimetres (​1⁄64 inch). This variation is too small to have many practical consequences. Five furlongs are about 1.0 kilometre (1.00584 km is the exact value
column6: according to the international conversion)."~0.1701608700639365

column1: 160~3~Gait~126~130~"Gait is the pattern of movement of the limbs of animals
column2: including humans
column3: during locomotion over a solid substrate. Most animals use a variety of gaits
column4: selecting gait based on speed
column5: terrain
column6: the need to maneuver
column7: and energetic efficiency. Different animal species may use different gaits due to differences in anatomy that prevent use of certain gaits
column8: or simply due to evolved innate preferences as a result of habitat differences. While various gaits are given specific names
column9: the complexity of biological systems and interacting with the environment make these distinctions 'fuzzy' at best. Gaits are typically classified according to footfall patterns
column10: but recent studies often prefer definitions based on mechanics. The term typically does not refer to limb-based propulsion through fluid mediums such as water or air
column11: but rather to propulsion across a solid substrate by generating reactive forces against it (which can apply to walking while underwater as well as on land).

column1: Due to the rapidity of animal movement
column2: simple direct observation is rarely sufficient to give any insight into the pattern of limb movement. In spite of early attempts to classify gaits based on footprints or the sound of footfalls
column3: it was not until Eadweard Muybridge and Étienne-Jules Marey began taking rapid series of photographs that proper scientific examination of gaits could begin."~0.15633084123866237

column1: 161~3~Half marathon~23918~23931~"A half marathon is a road running event of 21.0975 km (13 mi 192½ yd)—half the distance of a marathon. It is common for a half marathon event to be held concurrently with a marathon
column2: using almost the same course with a late start
column3: an early finish or shortcuts. If finisher medals are awarded
column4: the medal or ribbon may differ from those for the full marathon. The half marathon is also known as a 21K
column5: 21.1K or 13.1 miles
column6: although these values are rounded and not formally correct.

column1: A half marathon world record is officially recognised by the International Association of Athletics Federations. The official IAAF world record for men is 58:23
column2: set by Zersenay Tadese of Eritrea on March 21
column3: 2010 at the Lisbon Half Marathon in Portugal
column4: and for women is 1:04:51
column5: set by Joyciline Jepkosgei of Kenya on October 22
column7: in Valencia
column8: Spain.

column1: Participation in half marathons has grown steadily since 2003
column2: partly because it is a challenging distance
column3: but does not require the same level of training that a marathon does. In 2008
column4: Running USA reported that the half marathon is the fastest-growing type of race."~0.22670391381184668

column1: 162~3~Hurdles~21954~21961~"Hurdling is the act of running and jumping over an obstacle at speed. In the early 19th century
column2: hurdlers ran at and jumped over each hurdle
column3: landing on both feet and checking their forward motion. After experimenting with different step patterns the 3-step for high hurdles
column4: 7-step for low hurdles
column5: and 15-step for intermediate hurdles was decided on. In the sport of athletics
column6: hurdling forms the basis of a number track and field events which are a highly specialized form of obstacle racing. In these events
column7: a series of barriers known as hurdles are set at precisely measured heights and distances which each athlete must pass by running over. Failure to pass over
column8: by passing under
column9: or intentionally knocking over hurdles will result in disqualification. Accidental knocking over of hurdles is not cause for disqualification
column10: but the hurdles are weighted to make doing so disadvantageous. Hurdle design improvements were made in 1935
column11: when they developed the L-shaped hurdle. With this shape
column12: the athlete could hit the hurdle and it will tip down
column13: clearing the athlete's path.

column1: The most prominent hurdles events are 110 meters hurdles for men
column2: 100 meters hurdles for women
column3: and 400 meters hurdles (both sexes) – these three distances are all contested at the Summer Olympics and the World Championships in Athletics. The two shorter distances take place on the straight of a running track
column4: while the 400 m version covers one whole lap of a standard oval track. Events over shorter distances are also commonly held at indoor track and field events
column5: ranging from 50 meters hurdles upwards. Women historically competed in the 80 meters hurdles at the Olympics in the mid-20th century. Hurdles race are also part of combined events contests
column6: including the decathlon and heptathlon.

column1: In track races
column2: hurdles are normally between 68–107 cm in height (or 27-42 inches)
column3: and vary depending on the age and gender of the hurdler. Events from 50 to 110 meters are technically known as high hurdles races
column4: while longer competitions are low hurdles races. The track hurdles events are forms of sprinting competitions
column5: although the 400 m version is less anaerobic in nature and demands athletic qualities similar to the 800 meters flat race.

column1: A hurdling technique can also be found in the steeplechase
column2: although in this event athletes are also permitted to step on the barrier to clear it. Similarly
column3: in cross country running athletes may hurdle over various natural obstacles
column4: such as logs
column5: mounds of earth and small streams – this represents the sporting origin of the modern events. Horse racing has its own variant of hurdle racing
column6: with similar principles."~0.12702624578063493

column1: 164~3~Immune system~17116~17129~"The immune system is a host defense system comprising many biological structures and processes within an organism that protects against disease. To function properly
column2: an immune system must detect a wide variety of agents
column3: known as pathogens
column4: from viruses to parasitic worms
column5: and distinguish them from the organism's own healthy tissue. In many species
column6: the immune system can be classified into subsystems
column7: such as the innate immune system versus the adaptive immune system
column8: or humoral immunity versus cell-mediated immunity. In humans
column9: the blood–brain barrier
column10: blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier
column11: and similar fluid–brain barriers separate the peripheral immune system from the neuroimmune system
column12: which protects the brain.

column1: Pathogens can rapidly evolve and adapt
column2: and thereby avoid detection and neutralization by the immune system; however
column3: multiple defense mechanisms have also evolved to recognize and neutralize pathogens. Even simple unicellular organisms such as bacteria possess a rudimentary immune system in the form of enzymes that protect against bacteriophage infections. Other basic immune mechanisms evolved in ancient eukaryotes and remain in their modern descendants
column4: such as plants and invertebrates. These mechanisms include phagocytosis
column5: antimicrobial peptides called defensins
column6: and the complement system. Jawed vertebrates
column7: including humans
column8: have even more sophisticated defense mechanisms
column9: including the ability to adapt over time to recognize specific pathogens more efficiently. Adaptive (or acquired) immunity creates immunological memory after an initial response to a specific pathogen
column10: leading to an enhanced response to subsequent encounters with that same pathogen. This process of acquired immunity is the basis of vaccination.

column1: Disorders of the immune system can result in autoimmune diseases
column2: inflammatory diseases and cancer. Immunodeficiency occurs when the immune system is less active than normal
column3: resulting in recurring and life-threatening infections. In humans
column4: immunodeficiency can either be the result of a genetic disease such as severe combined immunodeficiency
column5: acquired conditions such as HIV/AIDS
column6: or the use of immunosuppressive medication. In contrast
column7: autoimmunity results from a hyperactive immune system attacking normal tissues as if they were foreign organisms. Common autoimmune diseases include Hashimoto's thyroiditis
column8: rheumatoid arthritis
column9: diabetes mellitus type 1
column10: and systemic lupus erythematosus. Immunology covers the study of all aspects of the immune system."~0.002561066396091785

column1: 165~3~Injury~5307~5313~"Injury is damage to the body caused by external force. This may be caused by accidents
column2: falls
column3: hits
column4: weapons
column5: and other causes. Major trauma is injury that has the potential to cause prolonged disability or death.

column2: 4.8 million people died from injuries
column3: up from 4.3 million in 1990. More than 30% of these deaths were transport-related injuries. In 2013
column5: 000 children under the age of five died from injuries
column6: down from 766
column7: 000 in 1990. Injuries are the cause of 9% of all deaths
column8: and are the sixth-leading cause of death in the world."~0.16413121309841486

column1: 166~3~Jogging~773~780~Jogging is a form of trotting or running at a slow or leisurely pace. The main intention is to increase physical fitness with less stress on the body than from faster running
column2: or to maintain a steady speed for longer periods of time. Performed over long distances
column3: it is a form of aerobic endurance training.~0.283732705032277

column1: 167~3~Lactic acid~25802~25813~"Lactic acid is an organic compound with the formula CH3CH(OH)COOH. In its solid state
column2: it is white and water-soluble. In its liquid state
column3: it is colorless. It is produced both naturally and synthetically. With a hydroxyl group adjacent to the carboxyl group
column4: lactic acid is classified as an alpha-hydroxy acid (AHA). In the form of its conjugate base called lactate
column5: it plays a role in several biochemical processes.

column1: In solution
column2: it can ionize a proton from the carboxyl group
column3: producing the lactate ion CH3CH(OH)CO−2. Compared to acetic acid
column4: its pKa is 1 unit less
column5: meaning lactic acid deprotonates ten times more easily than acetic acid does. This higher acidity is the consequence of the intramolecular hydrogen bonding between the α-hydroxyl and the carboxylate group.

column1: Lactic acid is chiral
column2: consisting of two optical isomers. One is known as L-(+)-lactic acid or (S)-lactic acid and the other
column3: its mirror image
column4: is D-(−)-lactic acid or (R)-lactic acid. A mixture of the two in equal amounts is called DL-lactic acid
column5: or racemic lactic acid.

column1: Lactic acid is hygroscopic. DL-lactic acid is miscible with water and with ethanol above its melting point which is around 17 or 18 °C. D-lactic acid and L-lactic acid have a higher melting point.
In animals
column2: L-lactate is constantly produced from pyruvate via the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in a process of fermentation during normal metabolism and exercise. It does not increase in concentration until the rate of lactate production exceeds the rate of lactate removal
column3: which is governed by a number of factors
column4: including monocarboxylate transporters
column5: concentration and isoform of LDH
column6: and oxidative capacity of tissues. The concentration of blood lactate is usually 1–2 mmol/L at rest
column7: but can rise to over 20 mmol/L during intense exertion and as high as 25 mmol/L afterward.

column1: In industry
column2: lactic acid fermentation is performed by lactic acid bacteria
column3: which convert simple carbohydrates such as glucose
column4: sucrose
column5: or galactose to lactic acid. These bacteria can also grow in the mouth; the acid they produce is responsible for the tooth decay known as caries.

column1: In medicine
column2: lactate is one of the main components of lactated Ringer's solution and Hartmann's solution. These intravenous fluids consist of sodium and potassium cations along with lactate and chloride anions in solution with distilled water
column3: generally in concentrations isotonic with human blood. It is most commonly used for fluid resuscitation after blood loss due to trauma
column4: surgery

column1: 168~3~Marathon~2769~2777~"The marathon is a long-distance race
column2: completed by running
column3: walking
column4: or a run/walk strategy. There are also wheelchair divisions. The marathon has an official distance of 42.195 kilometres (26.219 miles
column5: or 26 miles 385 yards)
column6: usually run as a road race. The event was instituted in commemoration of the fabled run of the Greek soldier Pheidippides
column7: a messenger from the Battle of Marathon to Athens
column8: who reported the victory.

column1: The marathon was one of the original modern Olympic events in 1896
column2: though the distance did not become standardized until 1921. More than 800 marathons are held throughout the world each year
column3: with the vast majority of competitors being recreational athletes as larger marathons can have tens of thousands of participants."~0.20711092007695386

column1: 169~3~Marathons~17456~17465~"The marathon is a long-distance race
column2: completed by running
column3: walking
column4: or a run/walk strategy. There are also wheelchair divisions. The marathon has an official distance of 42.195 kilometres (26.219 miles
column5: or 26 miles 385 yards)
column6: usually run as a road race. The event was instituted in commemoration of the fabled run of the Greek soldier Pheidippides
column7: a messenger from the Battle of Marathon to Athens
column8: who reported the victory.

column1: The marathon was one of the original modern Olympic events in 1896
