column3: with the vast majority of competitors being recreational athletes as larger marathons can have tens of thousands of participants."~0.23707580310307574

column1: 170~3~Metabolism~17794~17804~"Metabolism (from Greek: μεταβολή metabolē
column2: ""change"") is the set of life-sustaining chemical transformations within the cells of organisms. The three main purposes of metabolism are the conversion of food/fuel to energy to run cellular processes
column3: the conversion of food/fuel to building blocks for proteins
column4: lipids
column5: nucleic acids
column6: and some carbohydrates
column7: and the elimination of nitrogenous wastes. These enzyme-catalyzed reactions allow organisms to grow and reproduce
column8: maintain their structures
column9: and respond to their environments. The word metabolism can also refer to the sum of all chemical reactions that occur in living organisms
column10: including digestion and the transport of substances into and between different cells
column11: in which case the set of reactions within the cells is called intermediary metabolism or intermediate metabolism.

column1: Metabolism is usually divided into two categories: catabolism
column2: the breaking down of organic matter for example
column3: the breaking down of glucose to pyruvate
column4: by cellular respiration
column5: and anabolism
column6: the building up of components of cells such as proteins and nucleic acids. Usually
column7: breaking down releases energy and building up consumes energy.

column1: The chemical reactions of metabolism are organized into metabolic pathways
column2: in which one chemical is transformed through a series of steps into another chemical
column3: by a sequence of enzymes. Enzymes are crucial to metabolism because they allow organisms to drive desirable reactions that require energy that will not occur by themselves
column4: by coupling them to spontaneous reactions that release energy. Enzymes act as catalysts that allow the reactions to proceed more rapidly. Enzymes also allow the regulation of metabolic pathways in response to changes in the cell's environment or to signals from other cells.

column1: The metabolic system of a particular organism determines which substances it will find nutritious and which poisonous. For example
column2: some prokaryotes use hydrogen sulfide as a nutrient
column3: yet this gas is poisonous to animals. The speed of metabolism
column4: the metabolic rate
column5: influences how much food an organism will require
column6: and also affects how it is able to obtain that food.

column1: A striking feature of metabolism is the similarity of the basic metabolic pathways and components between even vastly different species. For example
column2: the set of carboxylic acids that are best known as the intermediates in the citric acid cycle are present in all known organisms
column3: being found in species as diverse as the unicellular bacterium Escherichia coli and huge multicellular organisms like elephants. These striking similarities in metabolic pathways are likely due to their early appearance in evolutionary history
column4: and their retention because of their efficacy."~0.11134048066717767

column1: 171~3~Mud~24153~24156~"A MUD (; originally Multi-User Dungeon
column2: with later variants Multi-User Dimension and Multi-User Domain)
column3: is a multiplayer real-time virtual world
column4: usually text-based. MUDs combine elements of role-playing games
column5: hack and slash
column6: player versus player
column7: interactive fiction
column8: and online chat. Players can read or view descriptions of rooms
column9: objects
column10: other players
column11: non-player characters
column12: and actions performed in the virtual world. Players typically interact with each other and the world by typing commands that resemble a natural language.

column1: Traditional MUDs implement a role-playing video game set in a fantasy world populated by fictional races and monsters
column2: with players choosing classes in order to gain specific skills or powers. The objective of this sort of game is to slay monsters
column3: explore a fantasy world
column4: complete quests
column5: go on adventures
column6: create a story by roleplaying
column7: and advance the created character. Many MUDs were fashioned around the dice-rolling rules of the Dungeons & Dragons series of games.

column1: Such fantasy settings for MUDs are common
column2: while many others have science fiction settings or are based on popular books
column3: movies
column4: animations
column5: periods of history
column6: worlds populated by anthropomorphic animals
column7: and so on. Not all MUDs are games; some are designed for educational purposes
column8: while others are purely chat environments
column9: and the flexible nature of many MUD servers leads to their occasional use in areas ranging from computer science research to geoinformatics to medical informatics to analytical chemistry. MUDs have attracted the interest of academic scholars from many fields
column10: including communications
column11: sociology
column12: law
column13: and economics. At one time
column14: there was interest from the United States military in using them for teleconferencing.

column1: Most MUDs are run as hobbies and are free to players; some may accept donations or allow players to purchase virtual items
column2: while others charge a monthly subscription fee. MUDs can be accessed via standard telnet clients
column3: or specialized MUD clients which are designed to improve the user experience. Numerous games are listed at various web portals
column4: such as The Mud Connector.

column1: The history of modern massively multiplayer online role-playing games (MMORPGs) like EverQuest and Ultima Online
column2: and related virtual world genres such as the social virtual worlds exemplified by Second Life
column3: can be traced directly back to the MUD genre. Indeed
column4: before the invention of the term MMORPG
column5: games of this style were simply called graphical MUDs. A number of influential MMORPG designers began as MUD developers and/or players (such as Raph Koster
column6: Brad McQuaid
column7: Matt Firor
column8: and Brian Green) or were involved with early MUDs (like Mark Jacobs and J. Todd Coleman)."~0.1405404841325464

column1: 172~3~Myopathy~1726~1734~"Myopathy is a disease of the muscle in which the muscle fibers do not function properly. This results in muscular weakness. ""Myopathy"" simply means muscle disease (Greek myo- ""muscle"" + patheia < -pathy ""suffering""). This meaning implies that the primary defect is within the muscle
column2: as opposed to the nerves (""neuropathies"" or ""neurogenic"" disorders) or elsewhere (e.g.
column3: the brain). Muscle cramps
column4: stiffness
column5: and spasm can also be associated with myopathy.

column1: Muscular disease can be classified as neuromuscular or musculoskeletal in nature. Some conditions
column2: such as myositis
column3: can be considered both neuromuscular and musculoskeletal."~0.14105588873525873

column1: 173~3~Neurogenesis~19001~19022~"Neurogenesis is the process by which nervous system cells
column2: known as neurons
column3: are produced by neural stem cells. Neural stem cells have the potential to produce many different types of neuron. They include neuroepithelial cells (NEPs)
column4: stem cells
column5: radial glial cells (RGCs)
column6: basal progenitors (BPs)
column7: subventricular zone astrocytes
column8: and subgranular zone radial astrocytes
column9: among others. Neurogenesis is most active during embryonic development
column10: but continues throughout adult life.

column1: Neurogenesis begins during embryogenesis in all animals and is responsible for producing all the neurons of the organism. Prior to the period of neurogenesis
column2: neural stem cells first multiply. The primary neural stem cell of the mammalian brain
column3: called a radial glial cell
column4: resides in the embryonic ventricular zone
column5: which lies adjacent to the developing brain ventricles. The process of neurogenesis then involves a final cell division of the parent neural stem cell
column6: which produces daughter neurons that will never divide again. Most neurons of the human central nervous system live the lifetime of the individual. The molecular and genetic factors influencing neurogenesis notably include the Notch signaling pathway
column7: and many genes have been linked to Notch pathway regulation. In mammals
column8: adult neurogenesis has been shown to occur in two primary regions in the brain: the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus and the subventricular zone (SVZ). In some mammals
column9: such as rodents
column10: the olfactory bulb is a zone which features integration of adult-born neurons
column11: which migrate from the SVZ through the rostral migratory stream (RMS). In some vertebrates
column12: regenerative neurogenesis has also been shown to occur. Many environmental factors
column13: such as exercise
column14: stress
column15: and antidepressants
column16: have been shown to change the rate of neurogenesis within the hippocampus."~0.02945842237780664

column1: 174~3~Oxygen~25865~25871~"Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8. It is a member of the chalcogen group on the periodic table
column2: a highly reactive nonmetal
column3: and an oxidizing agent that readily forms oxides with most elements as well as with other compounds. By mass
column4: oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe
column5: after hydrogen and helium. At standard temperature and pressure
column6: two atoms of the element bind to form dioxygen
column7: a colorless and odorless diatomic gas with the formula O2. Diatomic oxygen gas constitutes 20.8% of the Earth's atmosphere. As compounds including oxides
column8: the element makes up almost half of the Earth's crust.

column1: Dioxygen is used in cellular respiration and many major classes of organic molecules in living organisms contain oxygen
column2: such as proteins
column3: nucleic acids
column4: carbohydrates
column5: and fats
column6: as do the major constituent inorganic compounds of animal shells
column7: teeth
column8: and bone. Most of the mass of living organisms is oxygen as a component of water
column9: the major constituent of lifeforms. Oxygen is continuously replenished in Earth's atmosphere by photosynthesis
column10: which uses the energy of sunlight to produce oxygen from water and carbon dioxide. Oxygen is too chemically reactive to remain a free element in air without being continuously replenished by the photosynthetic action of living organisms. Another form (allotrope) of oxygen
column11: ozone (O3)
column12: strongly absorbs ultraviolet UVB radiation and the high-altitude ozone layer helps protect the biosphere from ultraviolet radiation. However
column13: ozone present at the surface is a byproduct of smog and thus a pollutant.

column1: Oxygen was discovered independently by Carl Wilhelm Scheele
column2: in Uppsala
column3: in 1773 or earlier
column4: and Joseph Priestley in Wiltshire
column6: but Priestley is often given priority because his work was published first. The name oxygen was coined in 1777 by Antoine Lavoisier.

column1: Common uses of oxygen include production of steel
column2: plastics and textiles
column3: brazing
column4: welding and cutting of steels and other metals
column5: rocket propellant
column6: oxygen therapy
column7: and life support systems in aircraft
column8: submarines
column9: spaceflight and diving."~0.1002461126290753

column1: 175~3~Pietro Mennea~26154~26167~Pietro Paolo Mennea (Italian pronunciation: [ˈpjɛtro menˈnɛa]; 28 June 1952 – 21 March 2013) was an Italian sprinter and politician. He was most successful in the 200 m event
column2: in which he won a gold medal at the 1980 Moscow Olympics and set a world record at 19.72 seconds in September 1979. This record stood for almost 17 years – the longest duration in the event history – and is still listed as the European record.~0.18013691013591512

column1: 176~3~Plantar fasciitis~19629~19646~"Plantar fasciitis is a disorder that results in pain in the heel and bottom of the foot. The pain is usually most severe with the first steps of the day or following a period of rest. Pain is also frequently brought on by bending the foot and toes up towards the shin and may be worsened by a tight Achilles tendon. The condition typically comes on slowly. In about a third of people both legs are affected.
The causes of plantar fasciitis are not entirely clear. Risk factors include overuse such as from long periods of standing
column2: an increase in exercise
column3: and obesity. It is also associated with inward rolling of the foot and a lifestyle that involves little exercise. While heel spurs are frequently found it is unclear if they have a role in causing the condition. Plantar fasciitis is a disorder of the insertion site of the ligament on the bone characterized by micro tears
column4: breakdown of collagen
column5: and scarring. As inflammation plays a lesser role
column6: a review proposed it be renamed plantar fasciosis. The diagnosis is typically based on signs and symptoms
column7: and ultrasound is sometimes used to help. Other conditions with similar symptoms include osteoarthritis
column8: ankylosing spondylitis
column9: heel pad syndrome
column10: and reactive arthritis.

column1: Most cases of plantar fasciitis resolve with time and conservative methods of treatment. Usually for the first few weeks
column2: people are advised to rest
column3: change their activities
column4: take pain medications
column5: and stretch. If this is not sufficient
column6: physiotherapy
column7: orthotics
column8: splinting
column9: or steroid injections may be options. If other measures do not work
column10: extracorporeal shockwave therapy or surgery may be tried.

column1: Between 4% and 7% of people have heel pain at any given time
column2: and about 80% of these cases are due to plantar fasciitis. Approximately 10% of people have the disorder at some point during their life. It becomes more common with age. It is unclear if one sex is more affected than the other."~0.1282414584770295

column1: 180~3~Speed~753~758~"In everyday use and in kinematics
column2: the speed of an object is the magnitude of its velocity (the rate of change of its position); it is thus a scalar quantity. The average speed of an object in an interval of time is the distance travelled by the object divided by the duration of the interval; the instantaneous speed is the limit of the average speed as the duration of the time interval approaches zero.

column1: Speed has the dimensions of distance divided by time. The SI unit of speed is the metre per second
column2: but the most common unit of speed in everyday usage is the kilometre per hour or
column3: in the US and the UK
column4: miles per hour. For air and marine travel the knot is commonly used.

column5: the concept of rapidity replaces the classical idea of speed."~0.23271573491580666

column1: 181~3~Starting blocks~25248~25263~"Starting blocks are a device used in the sport of track and field by sprint athletes to hold their feet at the start of a race so they do not slip as they push out at the sound of the gun. For most levels of competition
column2: including the whole of high level international competition
column3: starting blocks are mandatory equipment for the start of sprint races.

column1: The invention of starting blocks is credited to Australian Charlie Booth and his father in 1929.
Prior to their invention
column2: runners would dig holes in the dirt track. Trowels were provided at the start of races. This was not the most consistent or stable system. It also was destructive to the track surface with the holes having to be filled for subsequent runners. When George Simpson became the first person to run 10.4 seconds for the 100-yard dash in 1930
column3: his record was disallowed because he used starting blocks.

column1: Wood was the first material used
column2: with some tracks having permanently placed wooden starting blocks with golden structures at the start line. Portable blocks were held by long metal spikes that needed to be pounded into the ground. These devices evolved to metal blocks. The common blocks of the 1960s were heavy and adjusted by screws that were frequently broken or became rusted over the years. Lighter weight blocks were made of sheet metal. Nick Newton's innovative design uses cast aluminum.

column1: The rubberized surfaces of new all-weather running tracks that became common starting in the 1970s
column2: made the old blocks even less secure. Original Tartan tracks left long holes to secure the blocks but most tracks today require blocks to be held by small spikes similar to the ones used in shoes. Block slippage was common enough that it is an allowable loophole in the rules to recall the start of a race without calling a false start against an athlete whose blocks slip. In some amateur settings
column3: such as high school track
column4: since block slippage is much more common due to lower quality track surface material and/or starting blocks' spike quality
column5: it is a commonly accepted practice to allow another person (usually a teammate) to sit on the ground behind the starting block and place their feet behind each block
column6: using their leg power to further reduce the chance for the blocks to slip back upon the runner launching out of them.

column1: Generally most races of 400 meters or shorter allow athletes to use starting blocks. Most runners in the 800 meters at the 1956 Olympics used starting blocks from a waterfall start.

Modern blocks used for world records now must have sensors that detect the pressure from the athlete and can be used to time their reaction to the starting gun. Athletes who react faster than 1/10th of a second can be charged with a false start and the race recalled. Many also carry electronic speakers so the sound of the gun arrives at the ears of the athletes at exactly the same time."~0.2751852206713014

column1: 190~4~Apartheid~18236~18245~"Apartheid (South African English pronunciation: ; Afrikaans: [aˈpartɦəit]

column7: socioeconomic status
column8: and cultural lifestyle: ""black""
column9: ""white""
column10: ""coloured""

Those among these officials who were also indicted in the U.S. are expected to be extradited to face charges there as well. Many officials were suspended by FIFA's ethics committee including Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini. In early 2017 reports became public about FIFA president Gianni Infantino attempting to prevent the re-elections of both chairmen of the ethics committee

column1: 213~4~FINA~13579~13583~"FINA or Fédération internationale de natation (English: International Swimming Federation) is the international federation recognised by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) for administering international competition in water sports. It is one of several international federations which administer a given sport or discipline for the IOC and international community. It is based in Lausanne

column1: 214~4~Gambling~3119~3127~"Gambling is the wagering of money or something of value (referred to as ""the stakes"") on an event with an uncertain outcome with the primary intent of winning money or material goods. Gambling thus requires three elements be present: consideration
column2: chance and prize. The outcome of the wager is often immediate
column3: such as a single roll of dice
column4: a spin of a roulette wheel
column5: or a horse crossing the finish line
column6: but longer time frames are also common
column7: allowing wagers on the outcome of a future sports contest or even an entire sports season.

column1: The term ""gaming"" in this context typically refers to instances in which the activity has been specifically permitted by law. The two words are not mutually exclusive; i.e.
column2: a ""gaming"" company offers (legal) ""gambling"" activities to the public and may be regulated by one of many gaming control boards
column3: for example
column4: the Nevada Gaming Control Board. However
column5: this distinction is not universally observed in the English-speaking world. For instance
column6: in the United Kingdom
column7: the regulator of gambling activities is called the Gambling Commission (not the Gaming Commission). The word gaming is used more frequently since the rise of computer and video games to describe activities that do not necessarily involve wagering
column8: especially online gaming
column9: with the new usage still not having displaced the old usage as the primary definition in common dictionaries.

column1: Gambling is also a major international commercial activity
column2: with the legal gambling market totaling an estimated $335 billion in 2009. In other forms
column3: gambling can be conducted with materials which have a value
column4: but are not real money. For example
column5: players of marbles games might wager marbles
column6: and likewise games of Pogs or Magic: The Gathering can be played with the collectible game pieces (respectively
column7: small discs and trading cards) as stakes
column8: resulting in a meta-game regarding the value of a player's collection of pieces."~0.27480751170862394

column1: 215~4~Game~108~113~"A game is a structured form of play
column2: usually undertaken for enjoyment and sometimes used as an educational tool. Games are distinct from work
column3: which is usually carried out for remuneration
column4: and from art
column5: which is more often an expression of aesthetic or ideological elements. However
column6: the distinction is not clear-cut
column7: and many games are also considered to be work (such as professional players of spectator sports or games) or art (such as jigsaw puzzles or games involving an artistic layout such as Mahjong
column8: solitaire
column9: or some video games).

column1: Games are sometimes played purely for entertainment
column2: sometimes for achievement or reward as well. They can be played alone
column3: in teams
column4: or online; by amateurs or by professionals. The players may have an audience of non-players
column5: such as when people are entertained by watching a chess championship. On the other hand
column6: players in a game may constitute their own audience as they take their turn to play. Often
column7: part of the entertainment for children playing a game is deciding who is part of their audience and who is a player.

column1: Key components of games are goals
column2: rules
column3: challenge
column4: and interaction. Games generally involve mental or physical stimulation
column5: and often both. Many games help develop practical skills
column6: serve as a form of exercise
column7: or otherwise perform an educational
column8: simulational
column9: or psychological role.

column1: Attested as early as 2600 BC
column2: games are a universal part of human experience and present in all cultures. The Royal Game of Ur
column3: Senet
column4: and Mancala are some of the oldest known games."~0.10208609643797191

column1: 216~4~Gender identity~8882~8897~"Gender identity is one's personal experience of one's own gender. Gender identity can correlate with assigned sex at birth
column2: or can differ from it. All societies have a set of gender categories that can serve as the basis of the formation of a person's social identity in relation to other members of society. In most societies
column3: there is a basic division between gender attributes assigned to males and females
column4: a gender binary to which most people adhere and which includes expectations of masculinity and femininity in all aspects of sex and gender: biological sex
column5: gender identity
column6: and gender expression. In all societies
column7: some individuals do not identify with some (or all) of the aspects of gender that are assigned to their biological sex; some of those individuals are transgender
column8: genderqueer or non-binary. There are some societies that have third gender categories.

column1: Core gender identity is usually formed by age three. After age three
column2: it is extremely difficult to change
column3: and attempts to reassign it can result in gender dysphoria. Both biological and social factors have been suggested to influence its formation."~0.08933059893226672

column1: 219~4~Gymnastics~6856~6866~"Gymnastics is a sport practiced by men and women that requires balance

column14: and from circus performance skills.

column1: 221~4~Hurling~18773~18780~"Hurling (Irish: iománaíocht
column2: iomáint) is an outdoor team game of ancient Gaelic and Irish origin. It is administered by the Gaelic Athletic Association (GAA). The game has prehistoric origins
column3: and has been played for 3
column4: 000 years. One of Ireland's native Gaelic games

column6: such as the field and goals

column9: which is played predominantly in Scotland.

column1: The objective of the game is for players to use a wooden (ash) stick called a hurley (in Irish a camán

column3: or under the crossbar into a net guarded by a goalkeeper for one goal
column4: which is equivalent to three points. The sliotar can be caught in the hand and carried for not more than four steps
column5: struck in the air
column6: or struck on the ground with the hurley. It can be kicked
column7: or slapped with an open hand (the hand pass) for short-range passing. A player who wants to carry the ball for more than four steps has to bounce or balance the sliotar on the end of the stick
column8: and the ball can only be handled twice while in his possession.

column1: Provided that a player has at least one foot on the ground
column2: a player may make a shoulder to shoulder charge on an opponent:

column1: who is in possession of the ball
column2: or

column1: who is playing the ball
column2: or

column1: when both players are moving in the direction of the ball to play it
No protective padding is worn by players. A plastic protective helmet with a faceguard is mandatory for all age groups
column2: including senior level
column3: as of 2010. The game has been described as ""a bastion of humility""
column4: with player names absent from jerseys and a player's number decided by his position on the field.

column3: Europe
column4: Australia
column5: New Zealand
column6: South Africa
column7: Argentina
column8: and South Korea. In many parts of Ireland
column9: however

column11: music and literature. The final of the All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship was listed in second place by CNN in its ""10 sporting events you have to see live""
column12: after the Olympic Games and ahead of both the FIFA World Cup and UEFA European Football Championship. After covering the 1959 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship Final between Kilkenny and Waterford for BBC Television

column1: 222~4~Idolatry~22083~22091~"Idolatry literally means the worship of an ""idol""
column2: also known as a cult image
column3: in the form of a physical image
column4: such as a statue or icon. In Abrahamic religions
column5: namely Christianity
column6: Islam and Judaism
column7: idolatry connotes the worship of something or someone other than God as if it were God. In these and several other monotheistic religions
column8: idolatry has been considered as the ""worship of false gods"" and is forbidden. In many Indian religions
column9: such as theistic and non-theistic forms of Hinduism
column10: Buddhism and Jainism
column11: idols (murti) are considered as symbolism for the absolute but not the absolute
column12: or icons of spiritual ideas
column13: or the embodiment of the divine. They are a means to focus one's religious pursuits and worship (bhakti). In the traditional religions of ancient Egypt
column14: Greece
column15: Rome
column17: Asia
column19: the reverence of an image or statue has been a common practice
column20: and cult images have carried different meanings and significance.

column1: The opposition to the use of any icon or image to represent ideas of reverence or worship is called aniconism. The destruction of idols and images as icons of veneration is called iconoclasm
column2: and this has long been accompanied with violence between religious groups that forbid idol worship and those who have accepted icons
column3: images and idols for worship. The definition of idolatry has been a contested topic within Abrahamic religions
column4: with some Muslims considering the Christian use of the cross as a symbol of Christ
column5: and of Madonna (Mary) in some churches
column6: as a form of idolatry.

column1: The history of religions has been marked with accusations and denials of idolatry. These accusations have considered statues and images to be devoid of symbolism. Alternatively
column2: the topic of idolatry has been a source of disagreements between many religions
column3: or within denominations of various religions
column4: with the presumption that icons of one's own religious practices have meaningful symbolism
column5: while another person's different religious practices do not."~0.062513042236254

column1: 223~4~Intellectual disabilities~12391~12416~"Intellectual disability (ID)
column2: also known as general learning disability
column3: and mental retardation (MR)
column4: is a generalized neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by significantly impaired intellectual and adaptive functioning. It is defined by an IQ under 70 in addition to deficits in two or more adaptive behaviors that affect everyday
column5: general living.

column1: Once focused almost entirely on cognition
column2: the definition now includes both a component relating to mental functioning and one relating to individuals' functional skills in their environments. As a result of this focus on the person's abilities in practice
column3: a person with an unusually low IQ may not be considered to have intellectually disability.

column1: Intellectual disability is subdivided into syndromic intellectual disability
column2: in which intellectual deficits associated with other medical and behavioral signs and symptoms are present
column3: and non-syndromic intellectual disability
column4: in which intellectual deficits appear without other abnormalities. Down syndrome and fragile X syndrome are examples of syndromic intellectual disabilities.

column1: Intellectual disability affects about 2–3% of the general population. Seventy-five to ninety percent of the affected people have mild intellectual disability. Non-syndromic or idiopathic cases account for 30–50% of cases. About a quarter of cases are caused by a genetic disorder
column2: and about 5% of cases are inherited from a person's parents. Cases of unknown cause affect about 95 million people as of 2013.

~0.14310206734698422
224~4~Internet~13137~13145~The Internet is the global system of interconnected computer networks that use the Internet protocol suite (TCP/IP) to link devices worldwide. It is a network of networks that consists of private
column2: public
column3: academic
column4: business
column5: and government networks of local to global scope
column6: linked by a broad array of electronic
column7: wireless
column8: and optical networking technologies. The Internet carries a vast range of information resources and services
column9: such as the inter-linked hypertext documents and applications of the World Wide Web (WWW)
column10: electronic mail
column11: telephony
column12: and file sharing.

column1: The origins of the Internet date back to research commissioned by the federal government of the United States in the 1960s to build robust
column2: fault-tolerant communication with computer networks. The primary precursor network
column3: the ARPANET
column4: initially served as a backbone for interconnection of regional academic and military networks in the 1980s. The funding of the National Science Foundation Network as a new backbone in the 1980s
column5: as well as private funding for other commercial extensions
column6: led to worldwide participation in the development of new networking technologies
column7: and the merger of many networks. The linking of commercial networks and enterprises by the early 1990s marks the beginning of the transition to the modern Internet
column8: and generated a sustained exponential growth as generations of institutional
column9: personal
column10: and mobile computers were connected to the network. Although the Internet was widely used by academia since the 1980s
column11: the commercialization incorporated its services and technologies into virtually every aspect of modern life.

column1: Most traditional communications media
column2: including telephony
column3: radio
column4: television
column5: paper mail and newspapers are reshaped
column6: redefined
column7: or even bypassed by the Internet
column8: giving birth to new services such as email
column9: Internet telephony
column10: Internet television
column11: online music
column12: digital newspapers
column13: and video streaming websites. Newspaper
column14: book
column15: and other print publishing are adapting to website technology
column17: web feeds and online news aggregators. The Internet has enabled and accelerated new forms of personal interactions through instant messaging
column19: and social networking. Online shopping has grown exponentially both for major retailers and small businesses and entrepreneurs
column20: as it enables firms to extend their ""brick and mortar"" presence to serve a larger market or even sell goods and services entirely online. Business-to-business and financial services on the Internet affect supply chains across entire industries.

column1: The Internet has no centralized governance in either technological implementation or policies for access and usage; each constituent network sets its own policies. Only the overreaching definitions of the two principal name spaces in the Internet
column2: the Internet Protocol address (IP address) space and the Domain Name System (DNS)
column3: are directed by a maintainer organization
column4: the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN). The technical underpinning and standardization of the core protocols is an activity of the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF)
column5: a non-profit organization of loosely affiliated international participants that anyone may associate with by contributing technical expertise."~0.12884857425763355

column1: 225~4~Iran~7564~7571~"Iran (Persian: ایران‎ Irān [ʔiːˈɾɒːn] ( listen))
column2: also known as Persia ()
column3: officially the Islamic Republic of Iran (Persian: جمهوری اسلامی ایران‎‎ Jomhuri-ye Eslāmi-ye Irān ( listen))
column4: is a sovereign state in Western Asia. With over 81 million inhabitants
column5: Iran is the world's 18th-most-populous country. Comprising a land area of 1
column8: 372 sq mi)
column9: it is the second-largest country in the Middle East and the 17th-largest in the world. Iran is bordered to the northwest by Armenia and the Republic of Azerbaijan
column10: to the north by the Caspian Sea
column11: to the northeast by Turkmenistan
column12: to the east by Afghanistan and Pakistan
column13: to the south by the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman
column14: and to the west by Turkey and Iraq. The country's central location in Eurasia and Western Asia
column15: and its proximity to the Strait of Hormuz
column16: give it geostrategic importance. Tehran is the country's capital and largest city
column17: as well as its leading economic and cultural center.

column1: Iran is home to one of the world's oldest civilizations
column2: beginning with the formation of the Elamite kingdoms in the fourth millennium BC. It was first unified by the Iranian Medes in the seventh century BC
column3: and reached its greatest extent during the Achaemenid Empire founded by Cyrus the Great in the sixth century BC
column4: stretching from Eastern Europe to the Indus Valley
column5: becoming a larger empire than previously ever existed in the world. The Iranian realm fell to Alexander the Great in the fourth century BC
column6: but reemerged shortly after as the Parthian Empire
column7: followed by the Sasanian Empire
column8: which became a leading world power for the next four centuries.

column1: Arab Muslims conquered the empire in the seventh century AD
column2: ultimately leading to the displacement of the indigenous faiths of Zoroastrianism and Manichaeism with Islam. Iran made major contributions to the Islamic Golden Age that followed
column3: producing many influential figures in art and science. After two centuries
column4: a period of various native Muslim dynasties began
column5: which were later conquered by the Turks and the Mongols. The rise of the Safavids in the 15th century led to the reestablishment of a unified Iranian state and national identity
column6: which followed the country's conversion to Shia Islam
column7: marking a turning point in Iranian and Muslim history. By the 18th century
column8: under Nader Shah
column9: Iran briefly possessed what was arguably the most powerful empire at the time. The 19th-century conflicts with the Russian Empire led to significant territorial losses. Popular unrest culminated in the Constitutional Revolution of 1906
column10: which established a constitutional monarchy and the country's first legislature. Following the coup of 1953 instigated by the United Kingdom and the United States
column11: Iran gradually became closely aligned with the West
column12: and grew increasingly autocratic. Growing dissent against foreign influence and political repression led to the 1979 Revolution
column13: which followed the establishment of an Islamic republic
column14: a political system which includes elements of a parliamentary democracy vetted and supervised by a theocracy governed by an autocratic ""Supreme Leader"". During the 1980s
column15: the country was engaged in a war with Iraq
column16: which lasted for almost nine years and resulted in a high number of casualties and financial loss for both sides.

column1: According to international reports
column2: Iran's human rights record is exceptionally poor. The regime in Iran has frequently persecuted and arrested critics of the government and its Supreme Leader. Women's rights in Iran are described as seriously inadequate
column3: and children's rights have been severely violated
column4: with more child offenders being executed in Iran than in any other country in the world.  Since the 2000s
column5: Iran's controversial nuclear program has raised concerns
column6: which is part of the basis of the international sanctions against the country. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action
column7: an agreement reached between Iran and the P5+1
column8: was created on 14 July 2015
column9: aimed to loosen the nuclear sanctions in exchange for Iran's restriction in producing enriched uranium.

column1: Iran is a founding member of the UN
column2: ECO
column3: NAM
column4: OIC
column5: and OPEC. It is a major regional and middle power
column6: and its large reserves of fossil fuels – which include the world's largest natural gas supply and the fourth-largest proven oil reserves – exert considerable influence in international energy security and the world economy.

column1: The country's rich cultural legacy is reflected in part by its 22 UNESCO World Heritage Sites
column2: the third-largest number in Asia and eleventh-largest in the world. Iran is a multicultural country comprising numerous ethnic and linguistic groups
column3: the largest being Persians (61%)
column4: Azeris (16%)
column5: Kurds (10%)

column1: 226~4~Ireland~18619~18626~"Ireland ( ( listen); Irish: Éire [ˈeːɾʲə] ( listen); Ulster-Scots: Airlann [ˈɑːrlən]) is an island in the North Atlantic. It is separated from Great Britain to its east by the North Channel
column2: the Irish Sea
column3: and St George's Channel. Ireland is the third-largest island in Europe.

column1: Politically
column2: Ireland is divided between the Republic of Ireland (officially named Ireland)
column3: which covers five-sixths of the island
column4: and Northern Ireland
column5: which is part of the United Kingdom. In 2011
column6: the population of Ireland was about 6.6 million
column7: ranking it the second-most populous island in Europe after Great Britain. Just under 4.8 million live in the Republic of Ireland and just over 1.8 million live in Northern Ireland.

column1: The island's geography comprises relatively low-lying mountains surrounding a central plain
column2: with several navigable rivers extending inland. Its lush vegetation is a product of its mild but changeable climate which is free of extremes in temperature. It was covered by thick woodlands until the Middle Ages. As of 2013
column3: the amount of land that is wooded in Ireland is about 11% of the total

column5: and winters are milder than expected for such a northerly area
column6: although summers are cooler than those in Continental Europe. Rainfall and cloud cover are abundant.

column1: The earliest evidence of human presence in Ireland is dated at 10
column2: 500 BC. Gaelic Ireland had emerged by the 1st century AD. The island was Christianised from the 5th century onward. Following the 12th century Norman invasion
column3: the England claimed sovereignty. However
column4: English rule did not extend over the whole island until the 16th–17th century Tudor conquest
column5: which led to colonisation by settlers from Britain. In the 1690s

column7: and was extended during the 18th century. With the Acts of Union in 1801
column8: Ireland became a part of the United Kingdom. A war of independence in the early 20th century was followed by the partition of the island
column9: creating the Irish Free State
column10: which became increasingly sovereign over the following decades
column11: and Northern Ireland
column12: which remained a part of the United Kingdom. Northern Ireland saw much civil unrest from the late 1960s until the 1990s. This subsided following a political agreement in 1998. In 1973 the Republic of Ireland joined the European Economic Community while the United Kingdom
column13: and Northern Ireland
column14: as part of it
column15: did the same.

column1: Irish culture has had a significant influence on other cultures
column2: especially in the fields of literature. Alongside mainstream Western culture
column3: a strong indigenous culture exists
column4: as expressed through Gaelic games
column5: Irish music and the Irish language. The island's culture shares many features with that of Great Britain
column6: including the English language
column7: and sports such as association football
column8: rugby
column9: horse racing

column1: 227~4~Italy~17844~17849~"Italy (Italian: Italia [iˈtaːlja] ( listen))

column10: 347 sq mi) and has a largely temperate seasonal and Mediterranean climate. With around 61 million inhabitants it is the fourth most populous EU member state.

column3: science

column5: producing famous scholars

column9: Raphael

column7: and acquired a colonial empire
column8: while the south remained largely impoverished and excluded from industrialisation
column9: fuelling a large and influential diaspora. Despite being one of the main victors in World War I
column10: Italy entered a period of economic crisis and social turmoil
column11: leading to the rise of a fascist dictatorship in 1922. Participation in World War II on the Axis side ended in military defeat
column12: economic destruction
column13: and an Italian civil war. Following the liberation of Italy and the rise of the resistance
column14: the country abolished the monarchy
column15: reinstated democracy
column16: enjoyed a prolonged economic boom and
column17: despite periods of sociopolitical turmoils

column1: Today
column2: Italy has the third largest nominal GDP in the Eurozone and the eighth largest in the world. As advanced economy the country has the sixth-largest worldwide national wealth and it is ranked third for its central bank gold reserve. Italy has a very high level of human development and it is sixth in the world for life expectancy. The country plays a prominent role in regional and global economic
column3: military
column4: cultural
column5: and diplomatic affairs

column1: 228~4~Jousting~7705~7713~"Jousting is a martial game or hastilude between two horsemen wielding lances with blunted tips
column2: often as part of a tournament. The primary aim was to replicate a clash of heavy cavalry
column3: with each participant trying hard to strike the opponent while riding towards him at high speed
column4: if possible breaking the lance on the opponent's shield or jousting armour
column5: or unhorsing him. The joust became an iconic characteristic of the knight in Romantic medievalism. The participants experience close to three and a quarter times their body weight in G-forces when the lances collide with their armor.

column1: The term is derived from Old French joster
column2: ultimately from Latin iuxtare ""to approach
column3: to meet"". The word was loaned into Middle English around 1300
column4: when jousting was a very popular sport among the Anglo-Norman knighthood. The synonym tilt dates ca. 1510.

column1: Jousting is based on the military use of the lance by heavy cavalry. It transformed into a specialised sport during the Late Middle Ages
column2: and remained popular with the nobility in England and Wales and Germany throughout the whole of the 16th century (while in France
column3: it was discontinued after the death of King Henry II in an accident in 1559). In England
column4: jousting was the highlight of the Accession Day tilts of Elizabeth I and James I
column5: and also was part of the festivities at the marriage of Charles I.

column1: Jousting was discontinued in favour of other equestrian sports in the 17th century
column2: although non-contact forms of ""equestrian skill-at-arms"" disciplines survived. There has been a limited revival of theatrical jousting re-enactment since the 1970s."~0.31423547351519293

column1: 229~4~Lansdowne Road~19165~19179~"The Lansdowne Road Stadium (Irish: Bóthar Lansdúin
column2: IPA: [ˈbˠoːhəɾˠ ˈl̪ˠan̪ˠsˠd̪ˠuːn̪ˠ]) was a stadium in Dublin owned by the Irish Rugby Football Union (IRFU) that was primarily for used rugby union and association football matches. The stadium was demolished in 2007 to make way for the construction of the Aviva Stadium

column1: The stadium took its name from the adjacent street called Landsdowne Road."~0.25807968610543675
230~4~Leisure~2977~2984~"Leisure has often been defined as a quality of experience or as free time. Free time is time spent away from business
column2: work
column3: job hunting
column4: domestic chores
column5: and education
column6: as well as necessary activities such as eating and sleeping. From a research perspective
column7: this approach has the advantages of being quantifiable and comparable over time and place.

column1: Leisure as experience usually emphasizes dimensions of perceived freedom and choice. It is done for ""its own sake""
column2: for the quality of experience and involvement. Other classic definitions include Thorsten Veblen's (1899) of ""nonproductive consumption of time."" Different disciplines have definitions reflecting their common issues: for example
column3: sociology on social forces and contexts and psychology as mental and emotional states and conditions.

column1: Leisure studies and sociology of leisure are the academic disciplines concerned with the study and analysis of leisure. Recreation differs from leisure in that it is a purposeful activity that includes the experience of leisure in activity contexts.
The distinction between leisure and unavoidable activities is not a rigidly defined one
column2: e.g. people sometimes do work-oriented tasks for pleasure as well as for long-term utility. A distinction may also be drawn between free time and leisure. For example
column3: Situationist International maintains that free time is illusory and rarely fully ""free""; economic and social forces appropriate free time from the individual and sell it back to them as the commodity known as ""leisure"". Certainly most people's leisure activities are not a completely free choice and may be constrained by social pressures
column4: e.g. people may be coerced into spending time gardening by the need to keep up with the standard of neighbouring gardens or go to a party because of social pressures.

column1: A related concept is that of social leisure
column2: which involves leisurely activities in social settings
column3: such as extracurricular activities
column4: e.g. sports
column5: clubs. Another related concept is that of family leisure. Relationships with others is usually a major factor in both satisfaction and choice."~0.2787891887399323

column1: 231~4~Match fixing~10002~10014~"In organized sports
column2: match fixing occurs as a match is played to a completely or partially pre-determined result
column3: violating the rules of the game and often the law. The most common reason is to obtain a payoff from gamblers
column4: but players may also intentionally perform poorly to gain a future advantage
column5: such as a better draft pick or an easier opponent in a play-off. A player might also play poorly to rig a handicap system.

column1: Match fixing
column2: when motivated by gambling
column3: requires contacts (and normally money transfers) between gamblers
column4: players
column5: team officials
column6: and/or referees. These contacts and transfers can sometimes be found
column7: and lead to prosecution by the law or the sports league(s). In contrast
column8: losing for future advantage is internal to the team and very hard to prove. Often
column9: substitutions made by the coach designed to deliberately increase the team's chances of losing (such as having key players sit out
column10: using minimal or phantom injuries as an excuse)
column11: rather than ordering the players actually on the field to intentionally underperform
column12: are cited as the main factor in cases where this has been alleged.

column1: Match fixing generally refers to fixing the final result of the game. Another form of match fixing
column2: known as spot fixing
column3: involves fixing small events within a match which can be gambled upon
column4: but which are unlikely to prove decisive in determining the final result of the game.

column1: Other names for match fixing include game fixing
column2: race fixing
column3: sports fixing
column4: or hippodroming. Games that are deliberately lost are sometimes called thrown games. When a team intentionally loses a game
column5: or does not score as high as it can
column6: to obtain a perceived future competitive advantage
column7: the team is often said to have tanked the game instead of having thrown it. In pool hustling
column8: tanking is known as dumping. In sports where a handicap system exists and is capable of being abused
column9: tanking is known as sandbagging."~0.3141862920567222

column1: 232~4~NFL~7860~7863~"The National Football League (NFL) is a professional American football league consisting of 32 teams
column2: divided equally between the National Football Conference (NFC) and the American Football Conference (AFC). The NFL is one of the four major professional sports leagues in North America
column3: and the highest professional level of American football in the world. The NFL's 17-week regular season runs from early September to late December
column4: with each team playing 16 games and having one bye week. Following the conclusion of the regular season
column5: six teams from each conference (four division winners and two wild card teams) advance to the playoffs
column6: a single-elimination tournament culminating in the Super Bowl
column7: which is usually held in the first Sunday in February
column8: and is played between the champions of the NFC and AFC.

column1: The NFL was formed in 1920 as the American Professional Football Association (APFA) before renaming itself the National Football League for the 1922 season. The NFL agreed to merge with the American Football League (AFL) in 1966
column2: and the first Super Bowl was held at the end of that season; the merger was completed in 1970. Today
column3: the NFL has the highest average attendance (67
column4: 591) of any professional sports league in the world and is the most popular sports league in the United States. The Super Bowl is among the biggest club sporting events in the world and individual Super Bowl games account for many of the most watched television programs in American history
column5: all occupying the Nielsen's Top 5 tally of the all-time most watched U.S. television broadcasts by 2015. The NFL's executive officer is the commissioner
column6: who has broad authority in governing the league.

column1: The team with the most NFL championships is the Green Bay Packers with thirteen (nine NFL titles before the Super Bowl era
column2: and four Super Bowl championships afterwards); the team with the most Super Bowl championships is the Pittsburgh Steelers with six. The current NFL champions are the Philadelphia Eagles
column3: who defeated the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII
column4: their first Super Bowl championship after winning three NFL titles before the Super Bowl era."~0.32124532876242134

column1: 233~4~Nationalism~18671~18682~"Nationalism is a political
column2: social
column3: and economic system characterized by promoting the interests of a particular nation particularly with the aim of gaining and maintaining self-governance
column4: or full sovereignty
column5: over the group's homeland. The political ideology therefore holds that a nation should govern itself
column6: free from unwanted outside interference
column7: and is linked to the concept of self-determination. Nationalism is further oriented towards developing and maintaining a national identity based on shared characteristics such as culture
column8: language
column9: race
column10: religion
column11: political goals or a belief in a common ancestry. Nationalism therefore seeks to preserve the nation's culture. It often also involves a sense of pride in the nation's achievements
column12: and is closely linked to the concept of patriotism. In some cases
column13: nationalism referred to the belief that a nation should be able to control the government and all means of production.

column1: From a political or sociological outlook
column2: there are three main paradigms for understanding the origins and basis of nationalism. The first
column3: known as primordialism or perennialism
column4: sees nationalism as a natural phenomenon. It holds that
column5: although the concept of nationhood may be recent
column6: nations have always existed. The second paradigm is ethnosymbolism
column7: which is a complex perspective seeking to explain nationalism by contextualizing it throughout history as a dynamic
column8: evolutionary phenomenon and by further examining the strength of nationalism as a result of the nation's subjective ties to national symbols imbued with historical meaning. The third and most dominant paradigm is modernism
column9: which sees nationalism as a recent phenomenon that needs the structural conditions of modern society to exist.

column1: There are various definitions for what constitutes a nation
column2: however
column3: which leads to several different strands of nationalism. It can be a belief that citizenship in a state should be limited to one ethnic
column4: cultural
column5: religious
column6: or identity group
column7: or that multinationality in a single state should necessarily comprise the right to express and exercise national identity even by minorities. The adoption of national identity in terms of historical development has commonly been the result of a response by influential groups unsatisfied with traditional identities due to inconsistency between their defined social order and the experience of that social order by its members
column8: resulting in a situation of anomie that nationalists seek to resolve. This anomie results in a society or societies reinterpreting identity
column9: retaining elements that are deemed acceptable and removing elements deemed unacceptable
column10: to create a unified community. This development may be the result of internal structural issues or the result of resentment by an existing group or groups towards other communities
column11: especially foreign powers that are or are deemed to be controlling them. Nationalism means devotion for the nation. It is a sentiment that binds the people together. National symbols and flags
column12: national anthems
column13: national languages
column14: national myths and other symbols of national identity are highly important in nationalism."~0.15896339156342482

column1: 234~4~Olympic Games~1165~1178~"The modern Olympic Games or Olympics (French: Jeux olympiques) are leading international sporting events featuring summer and winter sports competitions in which thousands of athletes from around the world participate in a variety of competitions. The Olympic Games are considered the world's foremost sports competition with more than 200 nations participating. The Olympic Games are held every four years
column2: with the Summer and Winter Games alternating by occurring every four years but two years apart.

column1: Their creation was inspired by the ancient Olympic Games
column2: which were held in Olympia
column3: Greece
column4: from the 8th century BC to the 4th century AD. Baron Pierre de Coubertin founded the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in 1894
column5: leading to the first modern Games in Athens in 1896. The IOC is the governing body of the Olympic Movement
column6: with the Olympic Charter defining its structure and authority.

column1: The evolution of the Olympic Movement during the 20th and 21st centuries has resulted in several changes to the Olympic Games. Some of these adjustments include the creation of the Winter Olympic Games for ice and winter sports
column2: the Paralympic Games for athletes with a disability
column3: and the Youth Olympic Games for teenage athletes. The Deaflympics and Special Olympics are also endorsed by the IOC. The IOC has had to adapt to a variety of economic
column4: political
column5: and technological advancements.

column1: The advent of the state-sponsored ""full-time amateur athlete"" of the Eastern Bloc countries further eroded the ideology of the pure amateur
column2: as it put the self-financed amateurs of the Western countries at a disadvantage. The Soviet Union entered teams of athletes who were all nominally students
column3: soldiers
column4: or working in a profession
column5: but many of whom were in reality paid by the state to train on a full-time basis. As a result
column6: the Olympics has shifted away from pure amateurism
column7: as envisioned by Coubertin
column8: to allowing participation of professional athletes. The growing importance of mass media created the issue of corporate sponsorship and commercialisation of the Games. World wars led to the cancellation of the 1916
column10: and 1944 Games. Large boycotts during the Cold War limited participation in the 1980 and 1984 Games. The latter
column11: however
column12: attracted 140 National Olympic Committees
column13: which was a record at the time.

column1: The Olympic Movement consists of international sports federations (IFs)
column2: National Olympic Committees (NOCs)
column3: and organising committees for each specific Olympic Games. As the decision-making body
column4: the IOC is responsible for choosing the host city for each Games
column5: and organises and funds the Games according to the Olympic Charter. The IOC also determines the Olympic programme
column6: consisting of the sports to be contested at the Games. There are several Olympic rituals and symbols
column7: such as the Olympic flag and torch
column8: as well as the opening and closing ceremonies. Over 13
column9: 000 athletes compete at the Summer and Winter Olympic Games in 33 different sports and nearly 400 events. The first
column10: second
column11: and third-place finishers in each event receive Olympic medals: gold
column12: silver
column13: and bronze
column14: respectively.

column1: The Games have grown so much that nearly every nation is now represented. This growth has created numerous challenges and controversies
column2: including boycotts
column3: doping
column4: bribery
column5: and a terrorist attack in 1972. Every two years the Olympics and its media exposure provide unknown athletes with the chance to attain national and sometimes international fame. The Games also constitute an opportunity for the host city and country to showcase themselves to the world."~0.37767067117916475

column1: 235~4~Peloponnese~8068~8080~"The Peloponnese () or Peloponnesus (; Greek: Πελοπόννησος
column2: Pelopónnēsos) is a peninsula and geographic region in southern Greece. It is separated from the central part of the country by the Isthmus and Gulf of Corinth. During the late Middle Ages and the Ottoman era

Lonely Planet voted the Peloponnese the top spot of their Best in Europe list."~0.10054201596987242

column1: 236~4~Pharaoh~7284~7292~"Pharaoh (
column2: or ; Coptic: ⲡⲣ̅ⲣⲟ Prro) is the common title of the monarchs of ancient Egypt from the First Dynasty (c. 3150 BCE) until the annexation of Egypt by the Roman Empire in 30 BCE

column1: In Egyptian society
column2: religion was central to everyday life. One of the roles of the pharaoh was as an intermediary between the gods and the people. The pharaoh thus deputised for the gods; his role was both as civil and religious administrator. He owned all of the land in Egypt
column3: enacted laws
column4: collected taxes
column5: and defended Egypt from invaders as the commander-in-chief of the army. Religiously
column6: the pharaoh officiated over religious ceremonies and chose the sites of new temples. He was responsible for maintaining Maat

column1: During the early days prior to the unity of the lower and upper kingdoms of ancient Egypt
column2: a Deshret
column3: the red crown

column5: a white crown

column1: 237~4~Physical activity~87~104~"Physical exercise is any bodily activity that enhances or maintains physical fitness and overall health and wellness. It is performed for various reasons
column2: including increasing growth and development
column3: preventing aging
column4: strengthening muscles and the cardiovascular system
column5: honing athletic skills
column6: weight loss or maintenance
column7: and also enjoyment. Frequent and regular physical exercise boosts the immune system and helps prevent certain ""diseases of affluence"" such as coronary heart disease
column8: type 2 diabetes
column9: and obesity. It may also help prevent stress and depression
column10: increase quality of sleep and act as a non-pharmaceutical sleep aid to treat diseases such as insomnia
column11: help promote or maintain positive self-esteem
column12: improve mental health
column13: maintain steady digestion and treat constipation and gas
column14: regulate fertility health
column15: and augment an individual's sex appeal or body image. Childhood obesity is a growing global concern
column16: and physical exercise may help decrease some of the effects of childhood and adult obesity. Some care-providers call exercise the ""miracle"" or ""wonder"" drug—alluding to the wide variety of benefits that it can provide for many individuals. Aside from the health advantages
column17: these benefits may include different social rewards for staying active while enjoying the environment of one's culture. Many individuals choose to exercise publicly outdoors where they can congregate in groups
column19: and appreciate life.

column3: such as walking
column4: swimming
column5: and household tasks

column2: mobility

column4: such as respiratory disorders
column5: blindness

column2: more specifically

column1: 240~4~Pierre de Coubertin~9386~9405~"Pierre de Frédy

241~4~Playoffs~713~721~"The playoffs
column2: play-offs
column3: postseason and/or finals of a sports league are a competition played after the regular season by the top competitors to determine the league champion or a similar accolade. Depending on the league
column4: the playoffs may be either a single game

column6: or a tournament

column1: In team sports in the U.S. and Canada

column1: 242~4~Polo~7696~7700~"Polo is a team sport played on horseback. The objective is to score goals against an opposing team. Arena polo has three players per team and the game usually involves more maneuvering and shorter plays at lower speeds due to space limitations of arenas. Arena polo is played with a small air-filled ball

243~4~Powerboating~4649~4661~"Power boating describes activities performed in a motorized boat. Generally

column1: 245~4~Racing~920~926~"In sport

column1: 246~4~Rioting~10874~10881~"A riot () is a form of civil disorder commonly characterized by a group lashing out in a violent public disturbance against authority

column1: 250~4~Running~2798~2805~"Running is a method of terrestrial locomotion allowing humans and other animals to move rapidly on foot. Running is a type of gait characterized by an aerial phase in which all feet are above the ground (though there are exceptions). This is in contrast to walking

256~4~Sportsmanship~8923~8936~"Sportsmanship is an aspiration or ethos that a sport or activity will be enjoyed for its own sake

column1: 258~4~Team~859~864~"A team is a group of individuals working together to achieve a goal.

260~4~Tennis~4048~4054~Tennis is a racket sport that can be played individually against a single opponent (singles) or between two teams of two players each (doubles). 287~5~Shoulder pads~4528~4541~"Shoulder pads are a piece of protective equipment used in many contact sports such as American football

column1: The first football shoulder pads were created by Princeton student L.P. Smock in 1877. These were made of leather and wool and were thin

column1: Most modern shoulder pads consist of a shock absorbing foam material with a hard plastic outer covering. The pieces are usually secured by rivets or strings that the user can tie to adjust the size.

Properly fitting pads are critical. Shoulder pads are fitted to an adult football player by measuring across the player's back from shoulder blade to shoulder blade with a soft cloth tape measure and then adding ​1⁄2 inch. All points of the pads should be checked to assure proper fit. Maintenance during football season includes monthly checks and replacing worn parts.
In terms of American Football
column2: various styles of shoulder pads exist for different positions played. Pads for a quarterback are lightweight and offer freedom of movement. Pads for linemen are designed with few flaps and epaulets
column3: thus reducing the opportunity of being grabbed by the opposition. A player may have a preference for vinyl buckles or elastic straps.

column1: Tag rugby comes in several forms with OzTag and Mini Tag being some of the better known variations. Tag rugby has the highest participation levels in Australia
column2: Ireland
column3: New Zealand and the United Kingdom."~0.35096433212674516

column1: 291~5~Waterproofing~11200~11215~"Waterproofing is the process of making an object or structure waterproof or water-resistant so that it remains relatively unaffected by water or resisting the ingress of water under specified conditions. Such items may be used in wet environments or underwater to specified depths.
Water resistant and waterproof often refer to penetration of water in its liquid state and possibly under pressure
column2: whereas damp proof refers to resistance to humidity or dampness. Permeation of water vapor through a material or structure is reported as a moisture vapor transmission rate.

column1: The hulls of boats and ships were once waterproofed by applying tar or pitch. Modern items may be waterproofed by applying water-repellent coatings or by sealing seams with gaskets or o-rings.
Waterproofing is used in reference to building structures (such as basements
column2: decks
column3: or wet areas)
column4: watercraft
column5: canvas
column6: clothing (raincoats or waders)
column7: electronic devices and paper packaging (such as cartons for liquids)."~0.07926928236860425

column1: 292~6~Aberdeen~11116~11124~"Aberdeen ( ( listen); Scots: Aiberdeen
column2: listen ; Scottish Gaelic: Obar Dheathain [ˈopər ˈʝɛ.ɛɲ]; Latin: Aberdonia) is Scotland's third most populous city
column3: one of Scotland's 32 local government council areas and the United Kingdom's 37th most populous built-up area
column4: with an official population estimate of 196
column5: 670 for the city of Aberdeen and 229
column6: 800 for the local authority area.

column1: Nicknames include the Granite City
column2: the Grey City and the Silver City with the Golden Sands. During the mid-18th to mid-20th centuries
column3: Aberdeen's buildings incorporated locally quarried grey granite
column4: which can sparkle like silver because of its high mica content. Since the discovery of North Sea oil in the 1970s
column5: Aberdeen has been known as the off-shore oil capital of Europe. The area around Aberdeen has been settled since at least 8
column6: 000 years ago
column7: when prehistoric villages lay around the mouths of the rivers Dee and Don. The city has a long
column8: sandy coastline and a marine climate
column9: the latter resulting in chilly summers and mild winters.

column1: Aberdeen received Royal burgh status from David I of Scotland (1124–53)
column2: transforming the city economically. The city's two universities
column3: the University of Aberdeen
column4: founded in 1495
column5: and Robert Gordon University
column6: which was awarded university status in 1992
column7: make Aberdeen the educational centre of the north-east of Scotland. The traditional industries of fishing
column8: paper-making
column9: shipbuilding
column10: and textiles have been overtaken by the oil industry and Aberdeen's seaport. Aberdeen Heliport is one of the busiest commercial heliports in the world and the seaport is the largest in the north-east of Scotland.

column1: Aberdeen has won the Britain in Bloom competition a record-breaking ten times
column2: and hosts the Aberdeen International Youth Festival
column3: a major international event which attracts up to 1000 of the most talented young performing arts companies. In 2015
column4: Mercer named Aberdeen the 57th most liveable city in the world
column5: as well as the fourth most liveable city in Britain. In 2012
column6: HSBC named Aberdeen as a leading business hub and one of eight 'super cities' spearheading the UK's economy
column7: marking it as the only city in Scotland to receive this accolade. In 2018
column8: Aberdeen was found to be the best city in the UK to start a business in a study released by card payment firm Paymentsense."~0.15110429124344985

column1: 293~6~Aldenham~19817~19825~"Aldenham is a village and civil parish in Hertfordshire
column2: 3.5 miles (5.6 km) north-east of Watford and 2 miles (3.2 km) southwest of Radlett. It was mentioned in the Domesday Book and is one of Hertsmere's 14 conservation areas. This secluded little village has eight pre-19th century buildings that are listed buildings and the parish itself is largely unchanged

column4: since Saxon times when the majority of the land was owned by the abbots of Westminster Abbey.

column3: while Aldenham West also featured among the least deprived three per cent in the country. Radlett forms the eastern part of the civil parish."~0.27313443793281156

column1: 294~6~Alnwick~56760~56767~"Alnwick ( ( listen) AN-ik) is a market town in north Northumberland
column2: England
column3: of which it is the traditional county town. The population at the 2011 Census was 8

column1: The town is on the south bank of the River Aln
column2: 32 miles (51 km) south of Berwick-upon-Tweed and the Scottish border
column3: 5 miles (8 km) inland from the North Sea at Alnmouth and 34 miles (55 km) north of Newcastle upon Tyne.

column1: The town dates to about AD 600
column2: and thrived as an agricultural centre. Alnwick Castle was the home of the most powerful medieval northern baronial family
column3: the Earls of Northumberland. It was a staging post on the Great North Road between Edinburgh and London
column4: and latterly has become a dormitory town for nearby Newcastle-upon-Tyne. The town centre has changed relatively little
column5: but the town has seen some growth
column6: with several housing estates covering what had been pasture
