column1: 295~6~Amputation~52152~52163~"Amputation is the removal of a limb by trauma
column2: medical illness
column3: or surgery. As a surgical measure
column4: it is used to control pain or a disease process in the affected limb
column5: such as malignancy or gangrene. In some cases
column6: it is carried out on individuals as a preventative surgery for such problems. A special case is that of congenital amputation
column7: a congenital disorder
column8: where fetal limbs have been cut off by constrictive bands. In some countries
column9: amputation of the hands
column10: feet or other body parts is or was used as a form of punishment for people who committed crimes. Amputation has also been used as a tactic in war and acts of terrorism; it may also occur as a war injury. In some cultures and religions
column11: minor amputations or mutilations are considered a ritual accomplishment.

column1: In the US
column2: the majority of new amputations occur due to complications of the vascular system (the blood vessels)
column3: especially from diabetes. Between 1988 and 1996
column4: there were an average of 133
column5: 735 hospital discharges for amputation per year in the US."~0.09869885634525431

column1: 296~6~Amputee football~52115~52122~Amputee football is an disabled sport played with seven players on each team (six outfield players and one goalkeeper). Outfield players have lower extremity amputations
column2: and goalkeepers have an upper extremity amputation. Outfield players use loftstrand (forearm) crutches
column3: and play without their prosthesis.~0.20025812524843967

column1: 297~6~Ancient~3555~3562~"Ancient history is the aggregate of past events from the beginning of recorded human history and extending as far as the Early Middle Ages or the Post-classical Era. The span of recorded history is roughly 5
column2: 000 years
column3: beginning with Sumerian Cuneiform script
column4: the oldest discovered form of coherent writing from the protoliterate period around the 30th century BC.

column1: The term classical antiquity is often used to refer to history in the Old World from the beginning of recorded Greek history in 776 BC (First Olympiad). This roughly coincides with the traditional date of the founding of Rome in 753 BC
column2: the beginning of the history of ancient Rome
column3: and the beginning of the Archaic period in Ancient Greece. Although the ending date of ancient history is disputed
column4: some Western scholars use the fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 AD (the most used)
column5: the closure of the Platonic Academy in 529 AD
column6: the death of the emperor Justinian I in 565 AD
column7: the coming of Islam or the rise of Charlemagne as the end of ancient and Classical European history.

column1: In India
column2: ancient history includes the early period of the Middle Kingdoms
column3: and
column4: in China
column5: the time up to the Qin dynasty."~0.11255091781650672

column1: 298~6~Ancient Rome~3597~3603~"In historiography
column2: ancient Rome is Roman civilization from the founding of the city of Rome in the 8th century BC to the collapse of the Western Roman Empire in the 5th century AD
column3: encompassing the Roman Kingdom
column4: Roman Republic and Roman Empire until the fall of the western empire. The term is sometimes used to just refer to the kingdom and republic periods
column5: excluding the subsequent empire.

column1: The civilization began as an Italic settlement in the Italian peninsula
column2: dating from the 8th century BC
column3: that grew into the city of Rome and which subsequently gave its name to the empire over which it ruled and to the widespread civilisation the empire developed. The Roman empire expanded to become one of the largest empires in the ancient world
column4: though still ruled from the city
column5: with an estimated 50 to 90 million inhabitants (roughly 20% of the world's population) and covering 5.0 million square kilometres at its height in AD 117.

column1: In its many centuries of existence
column2: the Roman state evolved from a monarchy to a Classical Republic and then to an increasingly autocratic empire. Through conquest and assimilation
column3: it eventually dominated the Mediterranean region
column4: Western Europe
column5: Asia Minor
column6: North Africa
column7: and parts of Northern and Eastern Europe. It is often grouped into classical antiquity together with ancient Greece
column8: and their similar cultures and societies are known as the Greco-Roman world.

column1: Ancient Roman civilisation has contributed to modern government
column2: law
column3: politics
column4: engineering
column5: art
column6: literature
column7: architecture
column8: technology
column9: warfare
column10: religion
column11: language
column12: and society. Rome professionalised and expanded its military and created a system of government called res publica
column13: the inspiration for modern republics such as the United States and France. It achieved impressive technological and architectural feats
column14: such as the construction of an extensive system of aqueducts and roads
column15: as well as the construction of large monuments
column17: and public facilities.

column1: By the end of the Republic (27 BC)
column2: Rome had conquered the lands around the Mediterranean and beyond: its domain extended from the Atlantic to Arabia and from the mouth of the Rhine to North Africa. The Roman Empire emerged with the end of the Republic and the dictatorship of Augustus Caesar. 721 years of Roman-Persian Wars started in 92 BC with their first war against Parthia. It would become the longest conflict in human history
column3: and have major lasting effects and consequences for both empires. Under Trajan
column4: the Empire reached its territorial peak. Republican mores and traditions started to decline during the imperial period
column5: with civil wars becoming a prelude common to the rise of a new emperor. Splinter states
column6: such as the Palmyrene Empire
column7: would temporarily divide the Empire during the crisis of the 3rd century.

column1: Plagued by internal instability and attacked by various migrating peoples
column2: the western part of the empire broke up into independent ""barbarian"" kingdoms in the 5th century. This splintering is a landmark historians use to divide the ancient period of universal history from the pre-medieval ""Dark Ages"" of Europe. The eastern part of the empire endured through the 5th century and remained a power throughout the ""Dark Ages"" and medieval times until its fall in 1453 AD. Though the citizens of the empire made no distinction
column3: the empire is most commonly referred to as the ""Byzantine Empire"" by modern historians during the Middle Ages to differentiate between the state of antiquity and the nation it grew into."~0.1283445453782216

column1: 299~6~Anecdote~5914~5922~"An anecdote is a brief
column2: revealing account of an individual person or an incident. Occasionally humorous
column3: anecdotes differ from jokes because their primary purpose is not simply to provoke laughter but to reveal a truth more general than the brief tale itself
column4: such as to characterize a person by delineating a specific quirk or trait
column5: to communicate an abstract idea about a person
column6: place
column7: or thing through the concrete details of a short narrative. An anecdote is ""a story with a point.""

column1: Anecdotes may be real or fictional; the anecdotal digression is a common feature of literary works
column2: and even oral anecdotes typically involve subtle exaggeration and dramatic shape designed to entertain the listener. However
column3: an anecdote is always presented as the recounting of a real incident
column4: involving actual persons and usually in an identifiable place. In the words of Jurgen Heine
column5: they exhibit ""a special realism"" and ""a claimed historical dimension.""

column1: The word anecdote (in Greek: ἀνέκδοτον ""unpublished""
column2: literally ""not given out"") comes from Procopius of Caesarea
column3: the biographer of Justinian I
column4: who produced a work entitled Ἀνέκδοτα (Anekdota
column5: variously translated as Unpublished Memoirs or Secret History)
column6: which is primarily a collection of short incidents from the private life of the Byzantine court. Gradually
column7: the term ""anecdote"" came to be applied to any short tale utilized to emphasize or illustrate whatever point the author wished to make. In the context of Estonian
column8: Lithuanian
column9: Bulgarian and Russian humor
column10: an anecdote refers to any short humorous story without the need of factual or biographical origins."~0

column1: 300~6~Arena football~54655~54669~"Arena football is a variety of indoor gridiron football played by the Arena Football League (AFL) and China Arena Football League (CAFL). The game is played indoors on a smaller field than American or Canadian outdoor football
column2: resulting in a faster and higher-scoring game. The sport was invented in 1981
column3: and patented in 1987
column4: by James F. Foster
column5: Jr.
column6: a former executive of the National Football League and the United States Football League. It was a proprietary game (the rights to which were owned by Gridiron Enterprises) until 2007
column7: when the patent expired. Though not the only variant of indoor American football
column8: it is the most widely known
column9: and the one on which most other forms of modern indoor football are at least partially based.

column1: Three leagues have played under arena football rules: the AFL
column2: which played 22 seasons from 1987 to 2008 and resumed play under new ownership in 2010; arenafootball2
column3: the AFL's erstwhile developmental league
column4: which played 10 seasons from 2000 through 2009
column5: and the CAFL
column6: which began play in 2016 but is not directly affiliated with the AFL."~0.3755142381572073

column1: 301~6~Atherstone~56863~56873~Atherstone  is a town and civil parish in the English county of Warwickshire. Located in the far north of the county

column1: 303~6~Baseball~58662~58670~"Baseball is a bat-and-ball game played between two opposing teams who take turns batting and fielding. The game proceeds when a player on the fielding team
column2: called the pitcher
column3: throws a ball which a player on the batting team tries to hit with a bat. The objectives of the offensive team (batting team) are to hit the ball into the field of play
column4: and to run the bases - having its runners advance counter-clockwise around four bases to score what are called ""runs"". The objective of the defensive team (fielding team) is to prevent batters from becoming runners
column5: and to prevent runners' advance around the bases. A run is scored when a runner legally advances around the bases in order and touches home plate (the place where the player started as a batter). The team who scores the most runs by the end of the game is the winner.

column1: The first objective of the batting team is to have a player reach base safely. A player on the batting team who reaches a base safely
column2: without being called ""out""
column3: can later attempt to advance to subsequent bases (i.e. 2nd base
column4: 3rd base
column5: home plate) as a runner
column6: during teammates' turns batting.The fielding team tries to prevent runs by getting batters or runners ""out""
column7: which forces them out of the field of play and back to their team (usually temporarily). Both the pitcher and fielders have methods of getting the batting team's players out.

column1: The opposing teams switch back and forth between batting and fielding; the batting team's turn to bat is over whenever the fielding team records three outs. One turn batting for each teams constitutes an inning. A game is usually composed of nine innings
column2: and the team with the greater number of runs at the end of the game wins. If scores are tied at the end of nine innings
column3: extra innings are usually played. Baseball has no game clock
column4: although most games end in the ninth inning.

column1: Baseball evolved from older bat-and-ball games already being played in England by the mid-18th century. This game was brought by immigrants to North America
column2: where the modern version developed. By the late 19th century
column3: baseball was widely recognized as the national sport of the United States. Baseball is currently popular in North America and parts of Central and South America
column4: the Caribbean
column5: and East Asia
column6: particularly in Japan
column7: South Korea
column8: and Taiwan.

column1: In the United States and Canada
column2: 30 professional Major League Baseball (MLB) teams are divided into the National League (NL) and American League (AL)
column3: each with three divisions: East
column4: West
column5: and Central. The major league champion is determined by playoffs that culminate in the World Series. The top level of play is similarly split in Japan between the Central and Pacific Leagues and in Cuba between the West League and East League. The World Baseball Classic
column6: organized by World Baseball Softball Confederation
column7: is the major international competition of the sport and attracts the top national teams from around the world."~0.43059585567073355

column1: 304~6~Basketball~6809~6819~"Basketball is a limited-contact sport played on a rectangular court. While most often played as a team sport with five players on each side
column2: three-on-three
column3: two-on-two
column4: and one-on-one competitions are also common. The objective is to shoot a basketball (approximately 9.4 inches (24 cm) in diameter) through a hoop 18 inches (46 cm) in diameter and 10 feet (3.048 m) high that is mounted to a backboard at each end of the court. The game was invented in 1891 by Dr. James Naismith.

column1: A team can score a field goal by shooting the ball through the basket being defended by the opposition team during regular play. A field goal scores three points for the shooting team if the player shoots from behind the three-point line
column2: and two points if shot from in front of the line. A team can also score via free throws
column3: which are worth one point
column4: after the other team is assessed with certain fouls. The team with the most points at the end of the game wins
column5: but additional time (overtime) is mandated when the score is tied at the end of regulation. The ball can be advanced on the court by passing it to a teammate
column6: or by bouncing it while walking or running (dribbling). It is a violation to lift
column7: or drag
column8: one's pivot foot without dribbling the ball
column9: to carry it
column10: or to hold the ball with both hands then resume dribbling.

column1: The game has many individual techniques for displaying skill—ball-handling
column2: shooting
column3: passing
column4: dribbling
column5: dunking
column6: shot-blocking
column7: and rebounding. Basketball teams generally have player positions
column8: the tallest and strongest members of a team are called a center or power forward
column9: while slightly shorter and more agile players are called small forward
column10: and the shortest players or those who possess the best ball handling skills are called a point guard or shooting guard. The point guard directs the on court action of the team
column11: implementing the coach's game plan
column12: and managing the execution of offensive and defensive plays (player positioning).

column1: Basketball is one of the world's most popular and widely viewed sports. The National Basketball Association (NBA) is the most significant professional basketball league in the world in terms of popularity
column2: salaries
column3: talent
column4: and level of competition. Outside North America
column5: the top clubs from national leagues qualify to continental championships such as the Euroleague and FIBA Americas League. The FIBA Basketball World Cup and Men's Olympic Basketball Tournament are the major international events of the sport and attract top national teams from around the world. Each continent hosts regional competitions for national teams
column6: like EuroBasket and FIBA AmeriCup.

column1: The FIBA Women's Basketball World Cup and Women's Olympic Basketball Tournament feature top national teams from continental championships. The main North American league is the WNBA (NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Championship is also popular)
column2: whereas strongest European clubs participate in the EuroLeague Women."~0.4501993244918118

column1: 305~6~Beach~52278~52283~"A beach is a landform alongside a body of water which consists of loose particles. The particles composing a beach are typically made from rock
column2: such as sand
column3: gravel
column4: shingle
column5: pebbles
column6: or cobblestones. The particles can also be biological in origin
column7: such as mollusc shells or coralline algae.

column1: Some beaches have man-made infrastructure
column2: such as lifeguard posts
column3: changing rooms
column4: and showers. They may also have hospitality venues (such as resorts
column5: camps
column6: hotels
column7: and restaurants) nearby. Wild beaches
column8: also known as undeveloped or undiscovered beaches
column9: are not developed in this manner. Wild beaches can be valued for their untouched beauty and preserved nature.

column1: Beaches typically occur in areas along the coast where wave or current action deposits and reworks sediments."~0.0908629000247989
306~6~Beach volleyball~52278~52283~"Beach volleyball is a team sport played by two teams of two players on a sand court divided by a net. As in indoor volleyball
column2: the objective of the game is to send the ball over the net and to ground it on the opponent's court
column3: and to prevent the same effort by the opponent. A team is allowed up to three touches to return the ball across the net. The ball is put in play with a serve—a hit by the server from behind the rear court boundary over the net to the opponents. The rally continues until the ball is grounded on the playing court
column4: goes ""out""
column5: or is not returned properly. The team winning a rally scores a point and serves to start the following rally. The four players serve in the same sequence throughout the match
column6: changing server each time a rally is won by the receiving team.

column1: Beach volleyball most likely originated in 1915 on Waikiki Beach in Hawaii
column2: while the modern two-man game originated in Santa Monica
column3: California. It has been an Olympic discipline since the 1996 Games. The Fédération Internationale de Volleyball (FIVB) is the international governing body for the sport
column4: and organizes the FIVB Beach Volleyball World Championships and the international professional beach volleyball circuit known as the FIVB Beach Volleyball World Tour."~0.2901901610358407

column1: 307~6~Blindness~52035~52052~"Visual impairment
column2: also known as vision impairment or vision loss
column3: is a decreased ability to see to a degree that causes problems not fixable by usual means
column4: such as glasses. Some also include those who have a decreased ability to see because they do not have access to glasses or contact lenses. Visual impairment is often defined as a best corrected visual acuity of worse than either 20/40 or 20/60. The term blindness is used for complete or nearly complete vision loss. Visual impairment may cause people difficulties with normal daily activities such as driving
column5: reading
column6: socializing
column7: and walking.

column1: The most common causes of visual impairment globally are uncorrected refractive errors (43%)
column2: cataracts (33%)
column3: and glaucoma (2%). Refractive errors include near sighted
column4: far sighted
column5: presbyopia
column6: and astigmatism. Cataracts are the most common cause of blindness. Other disorders that may cause visual problems include age related macular degeneration
column7: diabetic retinopathy
column8: corneal clouding
column9: childhood blindness
column10: and a number of infections. Visual impairment can also be caused by problems in the brain due to stroke
column11: premature birth
column12: or trauma among others. These cases are known as cortical visual impairment. Screening for vision problems in children may improve future vision and educational achievement. Screening adults without symptoms is of uncertain benefit. Diagnosis is by an eye exam.

column1: The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 80% of visual impairment is either preventable or curable with treatment. This includes cataracts
column2: the infections river blindness and trachoma
column3: glaucoma
column4: diabetic retinopathy
column5: uncorrected refractive errors
column6: and some cases of childhood blindness. Many people with significant visual impairment benefit from vision rehabilitation
column7: changes in their environment
column8: and assistive devices.

column1: As of 2015 there were 940 million people with some degree of vision loss. 246 million had low vision and 39 million were blind. The majority of people with poor vision are in the developing world and are over the age of 50 years. Rates of visual impairment have decreased since the 1990s. Visual impairments have considerable economic costs both directly due to the cost of treatment and indirectly due to decreased ability to work."~0.08796486637828746
308~6~Bog~52763~52766~"A bog is a wetland that accumulates peat
column2: a deposit of dead plant material—often mosses
column3: and in a majority of cases
column4: sphagnum moss. It is one of the four main types of wetlands. Other names for bogs include mire
column5: quagmire
column6: and muskeg; alkaline mires are called fens. They are frequently covered in ericaceous shrubs rooted in the sphagnum moss and peat. The gradual accumulation of decayed plant material in a bog functions as a carbon sink.

column1: Bogs occur where the water at the ground surface is acidic and low in nutrients. In some cases
column2: the water is derived entirely from precipitation
column3: in which case they are termed ombrotrophic (rain-fed). Water flowing out of bogs has a characteristic brown colour
column4: which comes from dissolved peat tannins. In general
column5: the low fertility and cool climate results in relatively slow plant growth
column6: but decay is even slower owing to the saturated soil. Hence peat accumulates. Large areas of landscape can be covered many metres deep in peat.

column1: Bogs have distinctive assemblages of animal
column2: fungal and plant species
column3: and are of high importance for biodiversity
column4: particularly in landscapes that are otherwise settled and farmed."~0.1120702687480824

column1: 309~6~Bordeaux~46672~46680~"Bordeaux (French pronunciation: ​[bɔʁdo]; Gascon Occitan: Bordèu) is a port city on the Garonne River in the Gironde department in southwestern France.
The municipality (commune) of Bordeaux proper has a population of 246
column2: 586 (2014). Together with its suburbs and satellite towns
column3: Bordeaux is the centre of the Bordeaux Métropole. With 760
column4: 933 inhabitants (as of 2014) and 1
column6: 335 in the metropolitan area
column7: it is the sixth largest in France
column8: after Paris
column9: Marseille
column10: Lyon
column11: Toulouse and Lille. It is the capital of the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region
column12: as well as the prefecture of the Gironde department. Its inhabitants are called ""Bordelais"" (for men) or ""Bordelaises"" (women). The term ""Bordelais"" may also refer to the city and its surrounding region.

column1: Bordeaux is the world's major wine industry capital. It is home to the world's main wine fair
column2: Vinexpo
column3: and the wine economy in the metro area takes in 14.5 billion euros each year. Bordeaux wine has been produced in the region since the 8th century. The historic part of the city is on the UNESCO World Heritage List as ""an outstanding urban and architectural ensemble"" of the 18th century. After Paris
column4: Bordeaux has the highest number of preserved historical buildings of any city in France."~0.12306000992655709

column1: 310~6~Bowls~22708~22713~"Bowls or lawn bowls is a sport in which the objective is to roll biased balls so that they stop close to a smaller ball called a ""jack"" or ""kitty"". It is played on a bowling green which may be flat (for ""flat-green bowls"") or convex or uneven (for ""crown green bowls""). It is normally played outdoors (although there are many indoor venues) and the outdoor surface is either natural grass
column2: artificial turf
column3: or cotula (in New Zealand)."~0.31254880574025834

column1: 311~6~Caledonians~24817~24827~"The Caledonians (Latin: Caledones or Caledonii; Greek: Καληδώνες
column2: Kalēdōnes) or the Caledonian Confederacy were a group of indigenous peoples of what is now Scotland during the Iron Age and Roman eras. The name is an exonym: the Ancient Greeks and Romans knew their territory as Caledonia and used the term vaguely in reference to its inhabitants. The Caledonians were initially considered to be a group of Britons
column3: but were later distinguished as the Picts
column4: a related people who nonetheless spoke a Brittonic language. The Caledonian Britons were enemies of the Roman Empire
column5: which was the occupying force then administering most of Great Britain as the Roman province of Britannia.

column1: The Caledonians

column1: 312~6~Cerebral palsy~52100~52114~"Cerebral palsy (CP) is a group of permanent movement disorders that appear in early childhood. Signs and symptoms vary among people. Often
column2: symptoms include poor coordination
column3: stiff muscles
column4: weak muscles
column5: and tremors. There may be problems with sensation
column6: vision
column7: hearing
column8: swallowing
column9: and speaking. Often babies with cerebral palsy do not roll over
column10: sit
column11: crawl
column12: or walk as early as other children of their age. Other symptoms may include seizures and problems with thinking or reasoning
column13: either of which occurs in about one third of people with CP. While the symptoms may get more noticeable over the first few years of life
column14: the underlying problems do not worsen over time.

column1: Cerebral palsy is caused by abnormal development or damage to the parts of the brain that control movement
column2: balance and posture. Most often the problems occur during pregnancy; however
column3: they may also occur during childbirth
column4: or shortly after birth. Often the cause is unknown. Risk factors include preterm birth
column5: being a twin
column6: certain infections during pregnancy such as toxoplasmosis or rubella
column7: exposure to methylmercury during pregnancy
column8: a difficult delivery
column9: and head trauma during the first few years of life
column10: among others. About 2% of cases are believed to be due to an inherited genetic cause. A number of sub-types are classified based on the specific problems present. For example
column11: those with stiff muscles have spastic cerebral palsy
column12: those with poor coordination have ataxic cerebral palsy
column13: and those with writhing movements have athetoid cerebral palsy. Diagnosis is based on the child's development over time. Blood tests and medical imaging may be used to rule out other possible causes.

column1: CP is partly preventable through immunization of the mother and efforts to prevent head injuries in children such as through improved safety. There is no cure for CP; however
column2: supportive treatments
column3: medications
column4: and surgery may help many individuals. This may include physical therapy
column5: occupational therapy
column6: and speech therapy. Medications such as diazepam
column7: baclofen
column8: and botulinum toxin may help relax stiff muscles. Surgery may include lengthening muscles and cutting overly active nerves. Often external braces and other assistive technology are helpful. Some affected children can achieve near normal adult lives with appropriate treatment. While alternative medicines are frequently used there is no evidence to support their use.

column1: CP is the most common movement disorder in children. It occurs in about 2.1 per 1
column2: 000 live births. Cerebral palsy has been documented throughout history with the first known descriptions occurring in the work of Hippocrates in the 5th century BCE. Extensive study of the condition began in the 19th century by William John Little
column3: after whom spastic diplegia was called ""Little disease"". William Osler first named it ""cerebral palsy"" from the German ""zerebrale Kinderlähmung"" (cerebral child-paralysis). A number of potential treatments are being examined
column4: including stem cell therapy. However
column5: more research is required to determine if it is effective and safe."~0.19807880156751237

column1: 313~6~Cicero~4065~4071~"Marcus Tullius Cicero (; Classical Latin: [ˈmaːr.kʊs ˈtʊl.lɪ.ʊs ˈkɪ.kɛ.roː]; 3 January 106 BC – 7 December 43 BC) was a Roman politician and lawyer

Cicero introduced the Romans to the chief schools of Greek philosophy and created a Latin philosophical vocabulary (with neologisms such as evidentia

column7: as a final revenge of Mark Antony

column3: and classical Roman culture. According to Polish historian Tadeusz Zieliński
column4: ""the Renaissance was above all things a revival of Cicero

column1: 315~6~Cricket~30759~30766~"Cricket is a bat-and-ball game played between two teams of eleven players each on a cricket field

column1: Before a match begins

column8: delivering (i.e.
column9: bowling) the ball from one end of the pitch towards the wicket at the other end

column12: if possible

column1: Runs are scored by two main methods: either by hitting the ball hard enough for it to cross the boundary

column5: 000 B.P. Luminescence dating has suggested habitation in Arnhem Land as far back as 60
column6: 000 years BP. Genetic research has inferred a date of habitation as early as 80
column7: 000 years BP. Other estimates have ranged up to 100
column8: 000 years and 125
column9: 000 years ago.

column1: Although there are a number of commonalities between indigenous Aboriginal Australians
column2: there is also a great diversity among different Indigenous communities and societies in Australia
column3: each with its own mixture of cultures
column4: customs and languages. In present-day Australia these groups are further divided into local communities. At the time of initial European settlement
column5: over 250 languages were spoken; it is currently estimated that 120 to 145 of these remain in use
column6: but only 13 of these are not considered endangered. Aboriginal people today mostly speak English
column7: with Aboriginal phrases and words being added to create Australian Aboriginal English (which also has a tangible influence of Indigenous languages in the phonology and grammatical structure). The population of Indigenous Australians at the time of permanent European settlement is contentious and has been estimated at between 318
column8: 000 and 1
column10: 000 with the distribution being similar to that of the current Australian population
column11: the majority living in the south-east
column12: centred along the Murray River. A population collapse following European invasion and a smallpox epidemic spreading three years after the arrival of Europeans may have caused a massive and early depopulation. Systematic massacre and genocide of Indigenous Australians by British colonisers has also contributed greatly to depopulation.

column1: Since 1995
column2: the Australian Aboriginal Flag and the Torres Strait Islander Flag have been among the official flags of Australia."~0.20558690714515615

column1: 342~6~Indigenous peoples~5092~5110~"Indigenous peoples
column2: also known as first peoples
column3: aboriginal peoples or native peoples
column4: are ethnic groups who are the original inhabitants of a given region
column5: in contrast to groups that have settled
column6: occupied or colonized the area more recently. Groups are usually described as indigenous when they maintain traditions or other aspects of an early culture that is associated with a given region. Not all indigenous peoples share this characteristic
column7: usually having adopted substantial elements of a colonising culture
column8: such as dress
column9: religion or language. Indigenous peoples may be settled in a given region (sedentary) or exhibit a nomadic lifestyle across a large territory
column10: but they are generally historically associated with a specific territory on which they depend. Indigenous societies are found in every inhabited climate zone and continent of the world.

column1: Since indigenous peoples are often faced with threats to their sovereignty
column2: economic well-being and their access to the resources on which their cultures depend
column3: political rights have been set forth in international law by international organizations such as the United Nations
column4: the International Labour Organization and the World Bank. The United Nations has issued a Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP) to guide member-state national policies to the collective rights of indigenous people
column5: such as culture
column6: identity
column7: language and access to employment
column8: health
column9: education and natural resources. Estimates put the total population of indigenous peoples from 220 million to 350 million.

column1: International Day of the World's Indigenous Peoples is celebrated on 9 August each year."~0.07705692707878203
344~6~Indoor soccer~51304~51310~"Indoor soccer
column2: or arena soccer (known internationally as indoor football
column3: minifootball
column4: fast football
column5: floorball or showball)
column6: is a game derived from association football adapted for play in a walled indoor arena. Indoor soccer
column7: as it is most often known in the United States and Canada
column8: was originally developed in these two countries as a way to play soccer during the winter months
column9: when snow would make outdoor play difficult. In those countries
column10: areas such as hockey rinks or basketball courts are adapted for indoor soccer play. In other countries the game is played in either indoor or outdoor arenas surrounded by walls
column11: and is referred to by different names (such as fast football (futbol rapido) in Mexico
column12: showbol in South America
column13: and indoor football (futbol indoor) in Spain).

column1: Indoor soccer has different regulations from other versions of association football designed for indoor play
column2: such as futsal and five-a-side football. Unlike futsal
column3: which is played on wooden or ceramic surfaces
column4: indoor soccer is played on synthetic turf (or
column5: in the case of the British Masters Football variety

column7: and there are no player throw-ins.

column1: FIFA
column2: the international body that oversees international association football competitions
column3: does not sanction the synthetic turf version of indoor soccer
column4: having developed its own code of indoor football (which they refer to as futsal).

column2: Canada
column3: and Mexico

column5: collegiate and professional leagues functioning. While internationally less popular than futsal

column3: has been adopted by the WMF as a standard international name for the sport."~0.3286199342852326

column1: 345~6~Inuit~5282~5287~"The Inuit (pronounced ; Inuktitut: ᐃᓄᐃᑦ
column2: ""the people"") are a group of culturally similar indigenous peoples inhabiting the Arctic regions of Greenland
column3: Canada and Alaska. Inuit is a plural noun; the singular is Inuk. The Inuit languages are part of the Eskimo-Aleut family. Inuit Sign Language is a critically endangered language isolate used in Nunavut.

column2: the term ""Eskimo"" was commonly used by ethnic Europeans to describe the Inuit and Alaska's Yupik and Iñupiat peoples. However
column3: ""Inuit"" is not accepted as a term for the Yupik
column4: and ""Eskimo"" is the only term that applies to Yupik

column7: and they more frequently identify as ""Inuit"" for an autonym. In Canada
column8: sections 25 and 35 of the Constitution Act of 1982 classified the Inuit as a distinctive group of Aboriginal Canadians who are not included under either the First Nations or the Métis.

column4: and in various parts of the Northwest Territories

column1: In the United States

column4: although not of the European Union."~0.13713923872006445

column1: 346~6~Iroquois~6957~6965~"The Iroquois ( or ) or Haudenosaunee () are a historically powerful northeast Native American confederacy. They were known during the colonial years to the French as the ""Iroquois League""

column9: Seneca

column3: and by offering shelter to displaced peoples.

348~6~Kickball~14510~14518~"Kickball (also known as soccer baseball in most of Canada) is a game and league game
column2: similar to baseball
column3: invented in the United States by Nicholas C Seuss. As in baseball
column4: one team tries to score by having its players return a ball from home base to the field and then circle the bases; while the other team tries to stop them by tagging them ""out"" with the ball before they can return to the home base. Instead of hitting a small
column5: hard ball with a bat
column6: players kick an inflated rubber ball; this makes it more accessible to young children. As in baseball
column7: teams alternate half-innings. The team with the most runs after a predefined number of innings wins.

column1: Kickball is a popular playground game and is typically played among young
column2: school-age children. The lack of both specialized equipment and highly skill-based positions (like pitcher) makes the game an accessible introduction to other sports. It is just as popular among adults
column3: who are more commonly known to play similar games like softball and baseball.

column1: The game seems to afford equal enjoyment to the children and it gives a better understanding of the national game (Baseball)
column2: and at the same time affords them an exercise that is not too violent and is full of fun."""~0.2571318149405116

column1: 349~6~Kirkwall~57198~57206~"Kirkwall (Scottish Gaelic: Bàgh na h-Eaglaise) is the largest settlement and capital of Orkney

351~6~Lacrosse~7106~7114~Lacrosse is a team sport played with a lacrosse stick and a lacrosse ball. Players use the head of the lacrosse stick to carry

column3: catch

column1: The sport has four versions that have different sticks

column1: 352~6~Lancashire~27269~27279~"Lancashire ( LANG-kə-shər
column2: -sheer or
column3: locally
column4: [ˈɫaŋkɪʃə(ɻ)]; abbreviated Lancs.) is a county in north west England. The county town is Lancaster although the administrative centre is Preston. The county has a population of 1
column6: 300 and an area of 1
column7: 189 square miles (3
column8: 080 km2). People from Lancashire are known as Lancastrians.

column1: The history of Lancashire begins with its founding in the 12th century. In the Domesday Book of 1086
column2: some of its lands were treated as part of Yorkshire. The land that lay between the Ribble and Mersey
column3: Inter Ripam et Mersam

column6: Westmorland
column7: Yorkshire
column8: and Cheshire.

column1: Lancashire emerged as a major commercial and industrial region during the Industrial Revolution. Liverpool and Manchester grew into its largest cities
column2: dominating global trade and the birth of modern industrial capitalism. The county contained several mill towns and the collieries of the Lancashire Coalfield. By the 1830s

column4: Blackburn
column5: Bolton
column6: Burnley
column7: Bury
column8: Chorley
column9: Colne
column10: Darwen
column11: Manchester
column12: Nelson
column13: Oldham
column14: Preston

column1: The county was subject to a significant boundary reform in 1974 that removed Liverpool and Manchester and most of their surrounding conurbations to form the metropolitan counties of Merseyside and Greater Manchester. The detached northern part of Lancashire in the Lake District

column1: 353~6~Latin~11414~11419~"Latin (Latin: lingua latīna
column2: IPA: [ˈlɪŋɡʷa laˈtiːna]) is a classical language belonging to the Italic branch of the Indo-European languages. The Latin alphabet is derived from the Etruscan and Greek alphabets
column3: and ultimately from the Phoenician alphabet.

column1: Latin was originally spoken in Latium
column2: in the Italian Peninsula. Through the power of the Roman Republic
column3: it became the dominant language
column4: initially in Italy and subsequently throughout the Roman Empire. Vulgar Latin developed into the Romance languages
column5: such as Italian
column6: Portuguese
column7: Spanish
column8: French
column9: and Romanian. Latin
column10: Greek and French have contributed many words to the English language. Latin and Ancient Greek roots are used in theology
column11: biology
column12: and medicine.

column1: By the late Roman Republic (75 BC)
column2: Old Latin had been standardised into Classical Latin. Vulgar Latin was the colloquial form spoken during the same time and attested in inscriptions and the works of comic playwrights like Plautus and Terence. Late Latin is the written language from the 3rd century
column3: and Medieval Latin the language used from the 9th century to the Renaissance which used Renaissance Latin. Later
column4: Early Modern Latin and Modern Latin evolved. Latin was used as the language of international communication
column5: scholarship
column6: and science until well into the 18th century
column7: when it began to be supplanted by vernaculars. Ecclesiastical Latin remains the official language of the Holy See and the Roman Rite of the Catholic Church.

column1: Latin is taught in primary
column2: secondary and postsecondary educational institutions around the world.

column1: Latin is a highly inflected language
column2: with three distinct genders
column3: seven noun cases
column4: four verb conjugations
column5: four verb principal parts
column6: six tenses
column7: three persons
column8: three moods
column9: two voices
column10: two aspects and two numbers."~0.12370045930452415

column1: 354~6~Lawnmower~22799~22808~"A lawn mower (mower) is a machine utilizing one or more revolving blades to cut a grass surface to an even height. The height of the cut grass may be fixed by the design of the mower
column2: but generally is adjustable by the operator
column3: typically by a single master lever
column4: or by a lever or nut and bolt on each of the machine's wheels. The blades may be powered by muscle
column5: with wheels mechanically connected to the cutting blades so that when the mower is pushed forward
column6: the blades spin
column7: or the machine may have a battery-powered or plug-in electric motor. The most common power source for lawn mowers is a small (typically one cylinder) internal combustion engine. Smaller mowers often lack any form of propulsion
column8: requiring human power to move over a surface; ""walk-behind"" mowers are self-propelled
column9: requiring a human only to walk behind and guide them. Larger lawn mowers are usually either self-propelled ""walk-behind"" types
column10: or more often
column11: are ""ride-on"" mowers
column12: equipped so the operator can ride on the mower and control it. A robotic lawn mower (""lawn-mowing bot""
column13: ""mowbot""
column14: etc.) is designed to operate either entirely on its own
column15: or less commonly by an operator by remote control.

column1: Two main styles of blades are used in lawn mowers. Lawn mowers employing a single blade that rotates about a single vertical axis are known as rotary mowers
column2: while those employing a cutting bar and multiple blade assembly that rotates about a single horizontal axis are known as cylinder or reel mowers (although in some versions
column3: the cutting bar is the only blade
column4: and the rotating assembly consists of flat metal pieces which force the blades of grass against the sharp cutting bar).

column1: There are several types of mowers
column2: each suited to a particular scale and purpose. The smallest types
column3: unpowered push mowers
column4: are suitable for small residential lawns and gardens. Electrical or piston engine-powered push-mowers are used for larger residential lawns (although there is some overlap). Riding mowers
column5: which sometimes resemble small tractors
column6: are larger than push mowers and are suitable for large lawns
column7: although commercial riding lawn mowers (such as zero-turn mowers) can be ""stand-on"" types
column8: and often bear little resemblance to residential lawn tractors
column9: being designed to mow large areas at high speed in the shortest time possible. The largest multi-gang (multi-blade) mowers are mounted on tractors and are designed for large expanses of grass such as golf courses and municipal parks
column10: although they are ill-suited for complex terrain."~0.18232036304119528

column1: 355~6~Lent~14124~14128~"Lent (Latin: Quadragesima: Fortieth) is a solemn religious observance in the Christian liturgical calendar that begins on Ash Wednesday and ends approximately six weeks later
column2: 3 days before Easter Sunday. The purpose of Lent is the preparation of the believer for Easter through prayer
column3: doing penance
column4: mortifying the flesh
column5: repentance of sins
column6: almsgiving
column7: and self-denial. This event is observed in the Anglican
column8: Eastern Orthodox
column9: Oriental Orthodox
column10: Lutheran
column11: Methodist
column12: and Catholic Churches. Some Anabaptist and evangelical churches also observe the Lenten season. Its institutional purpose is heightened in the annual commemoration of Holy Week
column13: marking the death
column14: burial
column15: and resurrection of Jesus
column16: which recalls the tradition and events of the New Testament beginning on Palm Sunday
column17: further climaxing on Jesus' crucifixion on Good Friday
column18: which ultimately culminates in the joyful celebration on Easter Sunday of the Resurrection of Jesus Christ.

column1: In Lent
column2: many Christians commit to fasting
column3: as well as giving up certain luxuries in order to replicate the sacrifice of Jesus Christ's journey into the desert for 40 days. Many Christians also add a Lenten spiritual discipline
column4: such as reading a daily devotional or praying through a Lenten calendar
column5: to draw themselves near to God. The Stations of the Cross
column6: a devotional commemoration of Christ's carrying the Cross and of his execution
column7: are often observed. Many Roman Catholic and some Protestant churches remove flowers from their altars
column8: while crucifixes
column9: religious statues
column10: and other elaborate religious symbols are often veiled in violet fabrics in solemn observance of the event. Throughout Christendom
column11: some adherents mark the season with the traditional abstention from the consumption of meat
column12: most notably among Lutherans
column13: Roman Catholics and Anglicans.

column1: Lent is traditionally described as lasting for 40 days
column2: in commemoration of the 40 days Jesus spent fasting in the desert
column3: according to the Gospels of Matthew
column4: Mark and Luke
column5: before beginning his public ministry
column6: during which he endured temptation by Satan.

column1: Holy Week and the season of Lent
column2: depending on the Christian denomination and local custom
column3: end with Easter Vigil at sundown on Holy Saturday
column4: on the morning of Easter Sunday
column5: or at the midnight between them."~0.10876454259620476

column1: 356~6~Melbourne~24547~24556~"Melbourne ( locally [ˈmɛɫbn̩] ( listen)) is the state capital and most populous city of the Australian state of Victoria

column13: it was the host city of the 1956 Summer Olympics and the 2006 Commonwealth Games.

column1: Melbourne rates highly in education
column2: entertainment
column3: health care
column4: research and development
column5: tourism and sport
column6: making it the world's most liveable city—for the seventh year in a row in 2017

column8: and ranks among the top 15 cities in the world in the Global Financial Centres Index. Referred to as Australia's ""cultural capital""

column12: and Australian contemporary dance. It is recognised as a UNESCO City of Literature and a major centre for street art

column1: The main passenger airport serving the metropolis and the state is Melbourne Airport (also called Tullamarine Airport)

column3: and the main regional train and coach terminus is Southern Cross station. Melbourne is also home to Australia's most extensive freeway network and has the world's largest urban tram network."~0.2323717274529163

column1: 357~6~Middle Ages~7421~7432~"In the history of Europe
column2: the Middle Ages (or Medieval Period) lasted from the 5th to the 15th century. It began with the fall of the Western Roman Empire and merged into the Renaissance and the Age of Discovery. The Middle Ages is the middle period of the three traditional divisions of Western history: classical antiquity
column3: the medieval period
column4: and the modern period. The medieval period is itself subdivided into the Early
column5: High
column6: and Late Middle Ages.

column1: Population decline
column2: counterurbanisation
column3: invasion
column4: and movement of peoples
column5: which had begun in Late Antiquity
column6: continued in the Early Middle Ages. The large-scale movements of the Migration Period
column7: including various Germanic peoples
column8: formed new kingdoms in what remained of the Western Roman Empire. In the seventh century
column9: North Africa and the Middle East—once part of the Byzantine Empire—came under the rule of the Umayyad Caliphate
column10: an Islamic empire
column11: after conquest by Muhammad's successors. Although there were substantial changes in society and political structures
column12: the break with classical antiquity was not complete. The still-sizeable Byzantine Empire survived in the east and remained a major power. The empire's law code
column13: the Corpus Juris Civilis or ""Code of Justinian""
column14: was rediscovered in Northern Italy in 1070 and became widely admired later in the Middle Ages. In the West
column15: most kingdoms incorporated the few extant Roman institutions. Monasteries were founded as campaigns to Christianise pagan Europe continued. The Franks
column17: briefly established the Carolingian Empire during the later 8th and early 9th century. It covered much of Western Europe but later succumbed to the pressures of internal civil wars combined with external invasions: Vikings from the north
column19: and Saracens from the south.

column1: During the High Middle Ages
column2: which began after 1000
column3: the population of Europe increased greatly as technological and agricultural innovations allowed trade to flourish and the Medieval Warm Period climate change allowed crop yields to increase. Manorialism
column4: the organisation of peasants into villages that owed rent and labour services to the nobles
column5: and feudalism
column6: the political structure whereby knights and lower-status nobles owed military service to their overlords in return for the right to rent from lands and manors
column7: were two of the ways society was organised in the High Middle Ages. The Crusades
column8: first preached in 1095
column9: were military attempts by Western European Christians to regain control of the Holy Land from Muslims. Kings became the heads of centralised nation states
column10: reducing crime and violence but making the ideal of a unified Christendom more distant. Intellectual life was marked by scholasticism
column11: a philosophy that emphasised joining faith to reason
column12: and by the founding of universities. The theology of Thomas Aquinas
column13: the paintings of Giotto
column14: the poetry of Dante and Chaucer
column15: the travels of Marco Polo
column16: and the Gothic architecture of cathedrals such as Chartres are among the outstanding achievements toward the end of this period and into the Late Middle Ages.

column1: The Late Middle Ages was marked by difficulties and calamities including famine
column2: plague
column3: and war
column4: which significantly diminished the population of Europe; between 1347 and 1350
column5: the Black Death killed about a third of Europeans. Controversy
column6: heresy
column7: and the Western Schism within the Catholic Church paralleled the interstate conflict
column8: civil strife
column9: and peasant revolts that occurred in the kingdoms. Cultural and technological developments transformed European society
column10: concluding the Late Middle Ages and beginning the early modern period."~0.13161598477744596

column1: 377~6~Specky~32863~32887~"Speech is the vocalized form of communication used by humans and some animals
column2: which is based upon the syntactic combination of items drawn from the lexicon. Each spoken word is created out of the phonetic combination of a limited set of vowel and consonant speech sound units (phonemes). These vocabularies
column3: the syntax that structures them
column4: and their sets of speech sound units differ
column5: creating many thousands of different
column6: and mutually unintelligible
column7: human languages. The vocal abilities that enable humans to produce speech also enable them to sing.

column1: A gestural form of human communication exists for the deaf in the form of sign language. Speech in some cultures has become the basis of written language
column2: often one that differs in its vocabulary
column3: syntax and phonetics from its associated spoken one
column4: a situation called diglossia. In addition to its use in communication
column5: it is suggested by some psychologists such as Lev Vygotsky that speech is internally used in mental processes to enhance and organize cognition in the form of an interior monologue.

column1: Speech is researched in terms of the speech production and speech perception of the sounds used in vocal language. Other research topics concern speech repetition
column2: the ability to map heard spoken words into the vocalizations needed to recreate them
column3: which plays a key role in vocabulary expansion in children and speech errors. Several academic disciplines study these; including acoustics
column4: psychology
column5: speech pathology
column6: linguistics
column7: cognitive science
column8: communication studies
column9: otolaryngology and computer science. Another area of research is how the human brain in its different areas such as the Broca's area and Wernicke's area underlies speech.

column1: It is controversial how far human speech is unique; in that animals also communicate with vocalizations. While none in the wild have comparably large vocabularies
column2: research upon the nonverbal abilities of language trained apes such as Washoe and Kanzi raises the possibility that they might have these capabilities. The evolutionary origins of speech are unknown and subject to much debate and speculation."~0.15954919372313708

column1: 378~6~Sport~29~34~"Sport (British English) or sports (American English) includes all forms of competitive physical activity or games which
column2: through casual or organised participation

column8: to ensure one winner and one loser. A number of such two-sided contests may be arranged in a tournament producing a champion. Many sports leagues make an annual champion by arranging games in a regular sports season

column4: including objective or subjective measures such as technical performance or artistic impression.

column1: 382~6~Super Bowl~50515~50525~"The Super Bowl is the annual championship game of the National Football League (NFL). The game is the culmination of a regular season that begins in the late summer of the previous calendar year. Normally
column2: Roman numerals are used to identify each game
column3: rather than the year in which it is held. For example
column4: Super Bowl I was played on January 15
column6: following the 1966 regular season. The sole exception to this naming convention tradition occurred with Super Bowl 50

column9: following the 2015 regular season
column10: and the following year
column11: the nomenclature returned to Roman numerals for Super Bowl LI
column12: following the 2016 regular season. The most recent Super Bowl was Super Bowl LII
column13: on February 4
column15: following the 2017 regular season.

column1: The game was created as part of a merger agreement between the NFL and its then-rival league
column2: the American Football League (AFL). It was agreed that the two leagues' champion teams would play in the AFL–NFL World Championship Game until the merger was to officially begin in 1970. After the merger
column3: each league was redesignated as a ""conference""
column4: and the game has since been played between the conference champions to determine the NFL's league champion. Currently
column5: the National Football Conference (NFC) leads the league with 27 wins to 25 wins for the American Football Conference (AFC). The Pittsburgh Steelers have the most Super Bowl championship titles
column6: with six. The New England Patriots have the most Super Bowl appearances
column7: with ten. Charles Haley and Tom Brady both have five Super Bowl rings
column8: which is the record for the most rings won by a single player.

column5: the Super Bowl has frequently been the most-watched American television broadcast of the year; the seven most-watched broadcasts in U.S. television history are Super Bowls. In 2015
column6: Super Bowl XLIX became the most-watched American television program in history with an average audience of 114.4 million viewers
column7: the fifth time in six years the game had set a record
column8: starting with the 2010 Super Bowl
column9: which itself had taken over the number-one spot held for 27 years by the final episode of M*A*S*H. The Super Bowl is also among the most-watched sporting events in the world
column10: almost all audiences being North American
column11: and is second to soccer's UEFA Champions League final as the most watched annual sporting event worldwide.

column1: 387~6~Team handball~58975~58992~"Handball (also known as team handball
column2: European handball or Olympic handball) is a team sport in which two teams of seven players each (six outfield players and a goalkeeper) pass a ball using their hands with the aim of throwing it into the goal of the other team. A standard match consists of two periods of 30 minutes

column2: with a goal in the middle of each end. The goals are surrounded by a 6-meter (20 ft) zone where only the defending goalkeeper is allowed; goals must be scored by throwing the ball from outside the zone or while ""diving"" into it. The sport is usually played indoors

column4: though lower scores were not uncommon until a few decades ago. Body contact is permitted by the defenders trying to stop the attackers from approaching the goal.

column1: The game was codified at the end of the 19th century in northern Europe. The modern set of rules was published in 1917 in Germany
column2: and had several revisions since. The first international games were played under these rules for men in 1925 and for women in 1930. Men's handball was first played at the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin as outdoors
column3: and the next time at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich as indoors
column4: and has been an Olympic sport since. Women's team handball was added at the 1976 Summer Olympics.

column1: The International Handball Federation was formed in 1946 and
column2: as of 2016

column5: only two non-European countries have won the title: South Korea and Brazil. The game also enjoys popularity in the Far East
column6: North Africa and parts of South America."~0.421142593417369

column1: 388~6~Theodore Roosevelt~40512~40530~"Theodore Roosevelt Jr. ( ROH-zə-velt; October 27
column2: 1858 – January 6
column3: 1919) was an American statesman and writer who served as the 26th President of the United States from 1901 to 1909. He also served as the 25th Vice President of the United States from March to September 1901 and as the 33rd Governor of New York from 1899 to 1900. As a leader of the Republican Party during this time
column4: he became a driving force for the Progressive Era in the United States in the early 20th century. His face is depicted on Mount Rushmore
column5: alongside those of George Washington
column6: Thomas Jefferson
column7: and Abraham Lincoln.

column1: Roosevelt was born a sickly child with debilitating asthma
column2: but he overcame his physical health problems by embracing a strenuous lifestyle. He integrated his exuberant personality
column3: vast range of interests
column4: and world-famous achievements into a ""cowboy"" persona defined by robust masculinity. Home-schooled
column5: he began a lifelong naturalist avocation before attending Harvard College. His book
column6: The Naval War of 1812 (1882)
column7: established his reputation as both a learned historian and as a popular writer. Upon entering politics
column8: he became the leader of the reform faction of Republicans in New York's state legislature. Following the near-simultaneous deaths of his wife and mother
column9: he escaped to a cattle ranch in the Dakotas. Roosevelt served as Assistant Secretary of the Navy under President William McKinley
column10: but resigned from that post to lead the Rough Riders during the Spanish–American War. Returning a war hero
column11: he was elected Governor of New York in 1898. After the death of Vice President Garret Hobart
column12: the New York state party leadership convinced McKinley to accept Roosevelt as his running mate in the 1900 election. Roosevelt campaigned vigorously
column13: and the McKinley-Roosevelt ticket won a landslide victory based on a platform of peace
column14: prosperity
column15: and conservatism.

column1: After taking office as Vice President in March 1901
column2: he became President at age 42 following McKinley's assassination that September
column3: and remains the youngest person to become president. As a leader of the Progressive movement
column4: he championed his ""Square Deal"" domestic policies
column5: promising the average citizen fairness
column6: breaking of trusts
column7: regulation of railroads
column8: and pure food and drugs. Making conservation a top priority
column9: he established many new national parks
column10: forests
column11: and monuments intended to preserve the nation's natural resources. In foreign policy
column12: he focused on Central America
column13: where he began construction of the Panama Canal. He expanded the Navy and sent the Great White Fleet on a world tour to project the United States' naval power around the globe. His successful efforts to broker the end of the Russo-Japanese War won him the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize. He avoided the controversial tariff and money issues. Elected in 1904 to a full term
column14: Roosevelt continued to promote progressive policies
column15: many of which were passed in Congress. Roosevelt successfully groomed his close friend
column17: and Taft won the 1908 presidential election to succeed him. In polls of historians and political scientists
column18: Roosevelt is generally ranked as one of the five best presidents.

column1: Frustrated with Taft's conservatism
column2: Roosevelt belatedly tried to win the 1912 Republican nomination. He failed
column3: walked out
column4: and founded a third party
column5: the Progressive
column6: so-called ""Bull Moose"" Party
column7: which called for wide-ranging progressive reforms. The split allowed the Democrats to win the White House. Following his election defeat
column8: Roosevelt led a two-year expedition to the Amazon basin
column9: where he nearly died of tropical disease. During World War I
column10: he criticized President Woodrow Wilson for keeping the country out of the war with Germany
column11: and his offer to lead volunteers to France was rejected. Though he had considered running for president again in 1920
column12: Roosevelt's health continued to deteriorate

column1: 389~6~Trampoline~58396~58407~"A trampoline is a device consisting of a piece of taut

column1: 390~6~Try~4786~4789~"A try is a way of scoring points in rugby union and rugby league football. A try is scored by grounding the ball (the ball must be touching the player when coming into contact with the ground) in the opposition's in-goal area (on or behind the goal line). Rugby union and league differ slightly in defining 'grounding the ball' and the 'in-goal' area.
The term try comes from try at goal

column3: grounding the ball only gave the opportunity to try to score with a kick at goal.

column1: A try is analogous to a touchdown in American and Canadian football
column2: with the major difference being that a try requires the ball be simultaneously touching the ground in the in-goal area and an attacking player who is in the field of play or in-goal. In the laws of both codes of rugby

column1: 392~6~Volleyball~6823~6833~"Volleyball is a team sport in which two teams of six players are separated by a net. Each team tries to score points by grounding a ball on the other team's court under organized rules. It has been a part of the official program of the Summer Olympic Games since 1964.
The complete rules are extensive
column2: but simply
column3: play proceeds as follows: a player on one of the teams begins a 'rally' by serving the ball (tossing or releasing it and then hitting it with a hand or arm)
column4: from behind the back boundary line of the court
column5: over the net
column6: and into the receiving team's court. The receiving team must not let the ball be grounded within their court. The team may touch the ball up to 3 times but individual players may not touch the ball twice consecutively. Typically
column7: the first two touches are used to set up for an attack
column8: an attempt to direct the ball back over the net in such a way that the serving team is unable to prevent it from being grounded in their court.

column1: The rally continues
column2: with each team allowed as many as three consecutive touches
column3: until either (1): a team makes a kill
column4: grounding the ball on the opponent's court and winning the rally; or (2): a team commits a fault and loses the rally. The team that wins the rally is awarded a point
column5: and serves the ball to start the next rally. A few of the most common faults include:

column1: causing the ball to touch the ground or floor outside the opponents' court or without first passing over the net;
catching and throwing the ball;
double hit: two consecutive contacts with the ball made by the same player;
four consecutive contacts with the ball made by the same team;
net foul: touching the net during play;
foot fault: the foot crosses over the boundary line when serving.
The ball is usually played with the hands or arms
column2: but players can legally strike or push (short contact) the ball with any part of the body.

column1: A number of consistent techniques have evolved in volleyball
column2: including spiking and blocking (because these plays are made above the top of the net
column3: the vertical jump is an athletic skill emphasized in the sport) as well as passing
column4: setting
column5: and specialized player positions and offensive and defensive structures."~0.4289356707967082
